best game ever nothing like it!

I was incredibly hesitant on starting this game when I first got it, I honestly mostly got it cuz my friends bugged the hell out of me to get it.

I was hesitant because I thought it would get boring rather quick, i'd run out of things to do, or just that it wouldn't be my type of game.

I decided to launch it up on Singleplayer and see what the hype is about and I [b] do not regret it one bit. [/b]

Go into this game as blind as possible, but don't be afraid to use the Wiki if you need information.
Also realize you can play this game at ANY pace you want, and that there is no pressure whatsoever to build a massive farm as soon as possible, but you also don't need to cherish every day and you can easily skip days if you don't feel like using them.

Play time speaks for itself really, but to be clearer, it's very addictive. It's relaxing but keeps you engaged. You're an office drone/city dweller who moved to the valley on a whim after finally finding out your dear departed granddad left you a farm there. You meet the mayor and local carpenter then are tossed into your first day of farming as a greenhorn idiot with no idea what you're doing.

The whole point of the game is to figure out what you want out of your farm and and the relationships you want your farmer to prioritize. You want to plant crops? Raise coop or barn animals? Fish your worries away? Mine minerals and precious gems in dark caves while fighting off dangerous creatures? All of the above? Something completely different? Change your mind mid play through to scrap the farm and start something new? You want to marry a wannabe rocker, football player, doctor, teacher, photographer, etc? You want to be single all your live long days? Play with peoples' hearts until it bites you in the ass? Make friends with everyone? Ignore the townsfolk altogether?

Go for it. The valley is your oyster...or star drop.

And that's just the base game. Modding the hell out of this game is super easy and opens up a whole lot more options if you're willing to try it out. There's at least 4 mods that add whole maps to explore. A lot of them are available on nexusmods.com or moddrop.com and you can branch out to other sites from there.  Be brave. Be bold. Enjoy the game as is and then mold it into the perfect soul sucking time waster tailored specifically to you! <3

Stardew Valley is an excellent game with a ton of depth to it. Stardew Valley is a game that immediately draws you in with its charming, almost childish visuals and unique art style. This game takes place in the small town "Pelican Town", where you'll have your farm and build up relationships with the people that live around you. Stardew Valley is a game about growing your small farm and discovering a way to build a life for yourself. Although this is a farming game, there's no real objective here — you just go out into the world and do whatever you want, from exploring dungeons to making friends, fishing, mining and much more. 

Stardew Valley provides a completely different experience than what you get from most other games. It is the sort of game that makes you forget all your worries and stresses. It manages to deliver the same feeling of joy and accomplishment while only featuring a handful of mechanics though the mechanics that the game provides are exceptionally polished. 

As for the music, The music is genuinely good. There are so many music tracks, and I love all of them. The music isn't anything exceptional, but the soundtrack is good and it fits perfectly with the theme of this game.

Stardew Valley is an impressive game. I can play this game for hours and will not get tired of it. All in all, Stardew Valley is an enjoyable game and I would suggest it to everyone. It is a well-rounded and enjoyable game to play. It is definitely worth the time and cost.

By far and away this is the most immersive game i've ever played.
=======
Pro's: the controls are really easy to learn, the pixel art in this game is beautiful as well. The game runs fine on just about anything, the characters are relatable, likable, lovable and well written. And it gave me a place to escape to during 2020-21.
=======
Con's: while i don't have any major complaints, it's fair to say the story has a little grind, but in the end it's worth it, like planting your plants watering them everyday nearly passing out each time but when then the harvest comes you get paid.
=========
Comments: also i like how this game is like real life. in that SDV looks perfectly idllic on the surface, but when you get to know the townsfolk, there's drama and problems.. but you know what? it's ok, and it gives more depth to the characters as well.
----------------------------
When should i buy?
i'd get it now if you want. or if you wanted to wait for a sale that's fine too.
----------------------------
Do i recommend this game? Yes.

I've played this game for years, first on the XBox, then on my phone, then on the Switch, and, finally, on PC. From the beginning I have loved this game. It's become a special interest of mine, and is one of the few interests I've had that has stuck with me throughout the years. It's a calming game with beautiful character design, with the town and characters having deep lore than what meets the eye. The gameplay itself is amazing, and I love that you're constantly being given goals to reach without the game making it seem like you have to complete them. While some you have to complete to progress, the game doesn't constantly remind you of the goals, and it lets you play it at your own pace. Overall, 10/10 game.

Have played over 200 hours on mobile previously and that was the OG Stardew Valley. Absolutely love the game all over again.

Great game! 
Somehow, I did not get as hooked as many other players, but let me say that the myriad mods improve a lot of things even more! (Portraits! The portraits are amazing!)

Still, I wish the dialogue and all else were a bit more targeted towards adults, though. Or that the storyline was darker. Alex, for example, for the first aspect I mentioned, is such a child and I've died a bit inside each time I've started a new game and got to that heart event where he makes fun of people who are sophisticated. 

The pigs also look ugly, and the things with whom you can catch seafood (and trash) ruin my whole aesthetic. :o 
Finally, crows are sinister by themselves, but must they also eat my crops? ):

This has been my favorite game since I first downloaded it in 2018. I've put nearly 1000 hours into the game, yet I'm not even close to tired of it. There's so much content to explore, and whether you're playing by yourself or with a group of others, there's always something that keeps you hooked for hours. I love the sheer amount of content this game has. I'm working through all the steam achievements at the moment, and I'm still finding new things about this game in the process. I love this game to bits and the cozy, comforting elements it has. At my best times and my worst times, it is a relaxing and wonderful way to pass the time. I also can't wait for Haunted Chocolatier!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he friended and invited me to join him. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Why We Should Legalize Cannabis

Marijuana when used in the medical sense is beneficial to not only the patient’s health but to their financial status as well. In this report you’ll see many reasons why we believe this. Medicalmarijuana is used in many treatments. We are not obviously the only people who believe thiseither. In the last 20 years, 36 states have passed some form of legislation recognizing themedical value of marijuana. In 1996, voters in both Arizona and California passed laws allowingthe medical use of marijuana. In 1998 Alaska, Washington and Oregon passed medical usemarijuana laws, and in 1999 Maine passed a similar law (Grinspoon, 5). The chronic effects of marijuana are of greater concern for medical use and fall into two categories: the effects of chronic smoking, and the effects of THC. Marijuana smoking is associated with abnormalities of cells lining the human respiratory tract. Marijuana smoke, like tobacco smoke, is associated withincreased risk of cancer, lung damage, and poor pregnancy outcomes. It is the most widely usedillicit drug, marijuana is predictably the first illicit drug most people Although studies all suggestthat marijuana smoke is an important risk factor for the development of respiratory cancer, proof of this is yet to be seen (Iverson, 21). Marijuana is not a completely benign substance. However,except for the harms associated with smoking, the adverse effects of marijuana use are within therange of effects tolerated for other medications. The harmful effects to individuals from the perspective of possible medical use of marijuana are not necessarily the same as the harmful physical effects of drug abuse (Iverson, 24). For most people, the primary adverse effect of acutemarijuana use is diminished psychomotor performance. It is, therefore, inadvisable to operate anyvehicle or potentially dangerous equipment while under the influence of marijuana, THC, or anycannabinoid drug with comparable effects (Zimmerman, 45). A minority of marijuana usersexperience dysphoria, or unpleasant feelings. THC is the primary psychoactive ingredient inmarijuana. Cannabinoids are the group of compounds related to THC, whether found in themarijuana plant, in animals, or synthesized in chemistry laboratories. Cannabinoids likely have anatural role in pain modulation, control of movement, and memory. The natural role of cannabinoids in immune systems is likely multifaceted and remains unclear. The brain can andwill develop a tolerance to cannabinoids after a prolonged use of marijuana (Joy). Animalresearch has shown the possibility that dependence will occur, but this possibility is much lower than the chance of developing a dependence on benzodiazepines, opiates, cocaine, or nicotine.Withdrawal symptoms have also been seen in animal testing. The symptoms are much milder than the symptoms of withdrawal from some prescribed medications such as Valium and Codeine(Mathre, 25). Chemotherapy can often prolong someone’s life for many years. In some cases, acomplete cure can be obtained. Unfortunately, chemotherapy has many side effects associatedwith it that are not pleasant in the least bit. Patients sometimes find these effects so distressingthey abandon chemotherapy entirely. People with AIDS (Acquired Immune Disease) alsoexperience these problems (Zimmerman, 59). Studies with marijuana have shown that marijuanareduces the nausea and vomiting often associated with chemotherapy treatments. Because themarijuana does this, it provides two other benefits.

I have finally taken it upon myself to get through the majority of Stardew's content. It's an old game so i won't bother you with a long winded review.

The base Stardew game is phenomenal, and probably the best farming/life sim game on the market. My only complaint is the late game. Do not read any further if you don't wish to be spoiled to late game content.

Ginger Island is so far off of what I feel Stardew embodies that it felt like a slap in the face to have to play a glorified Scavenger hunt as the game's "late game content." It feels awful to leave behind the town you worked so hard to restored, and essentially start over. Not to mention how the time constraint feels so much worse there because it takes so long to get back if you don't use a totem.

I can only think of 3 reasons for people to enjoy this game

0 They're teenagers or young adults

1 they have plenty of time and not much to do with it (e.g. homework is done)

2 They have little or no experience in real life and are using the "dating simulator" as a substitute

3 Everyone says it's good, so they say it's good as well

Which doesn't mean it's a bad game. But much expectation comes out for a game that has overwhelmingly positive score. And by the moment you buy it and realize you have so much to do, I mean SO MUCH do to and your reward comes in pixels, I'm sure that'll disappoint some people

I tried it once, maybe twice. The lack of direction and the repetitive mundane chores killed me 

Also, as far as I could see you can talk to key people only once a day (there's even a checkbox). Basically you'll have to simp them over and over just to un install the game in the future

Fun comfort game with lots of stuff to do, really relaxing but can also be a grind kind of game. There's basically no way you can play the game wrong, and there's a way to play for every type of person. Cute animals are a plus. The bachelor and bachelorettes commonly lack character until hearts are raised up (sometimes even requiring 10+ hearts), many of them also seem to be pretty young. About half the marriage candidates seem to be just out of high school/in college. The older characters/non marriage candidates are much more fleshed out with more character. Multiplayer can be tedious to set up sometimes, but it's really fun and usually functions pretty well. Would definitely say it's more geared towards single-player play though.

If you want to have a decently fun time running a farm (maybe with some friends) then this game works fine.

If you ever played games like Harvest Moon, then you'll absolutely love Stardew Valley. It has an amazing balance of farming, mining, fishing, monster slaying, quests, romance, friendship, and many other secrets to uncover. Each NPC has a rich storyline that really pulls you into the complexity of Stardew Valley society. Perhaps its only flaw is how absurdly enjoyable it is. The rest of my Steam Library is beginning to gather dust because I have been dedicating every free gaming hour to SV. And the replay value is extremely high. Not only are there constant updates, but there are multiple mods you can download that add extra playable content (new characters, maps, crops, animals, storyline, etc.). I've replayed my own farm multiple times as I find new mods, and I always feel like I'm starting a brand-new adventure. Stardew Valley is a MUST HAVE for just about anyone.

I love this game so much. I have ADHD and OCD and get overstimulated/overwhelmed in life and Stardew is a wonderful escape. This game helped me through a rough couple of months in which my grandmother hid a terminal cancer diagnosis until she died unexpectedly and my mom had a stroke. It kept me sane when I had my tonsils out and almost died. More often than not, it keeps me sane through each semester working towards a Master's degree. This game is for everyone and the mods open so many possibilities. Such a lovely game.

Base game has enough content to last you at least fifty hours and the mods will give you everything you want. Quality of life, visual tweaks, or whole additions that should be paid DLC all by the community is amazing. Play it casually or let it consume your entire day.

If you haven't heard of Stardew Valley before, then I'd be amazed. Take something like the notable Animal Crossing and mix it with a little bit of Terraria, and you have one of the most beautiful, addicting, heartwarming farming/life sim RPG of recent years. The sheer amount of love and passion that went into creating this game is even more apparent once you boot it up for the first time and hear that GODLIKE music.
While the first play-through can be a little daunting or confusing at first, you'll soon realize the game just wants you to live in its world, of course you have your quests with the Journal, but overall this is game that just wants you to live and experience its warm, welcoming atmosphere. Which, to tell you the truth, is incredibly refreshing considering how industrialized real life is, sometimes, you really need to step aside and get a fresh perspective of things. (so if you support Joja Co. You're a menace.) I'm glad to be able to support the developer of this game, and hope that one day, a sequel comes out and improves on every single aspect of this one. (which would be hard to do, unless you're pedantic.)

Also, you can get married.

Stardew Valley is a cute little game all about farming in and exploring the fictional town of Pelican's Foley while cultivating relationships with the townsfolk. It's the type of game you can really immerse yourself in to escape the woes of reality. There are four seasons with a plethora of crops to grow, a ton of fish to catch, and many livestock to raise. The entire design of the farm is up to you and you can choose what to specialize in developing. Sell your products and go mining so that you can buy upgrades for your tools and continue to improve the farm. The game has a really nice focus on exploration and interaction and is perfect for relaxing. It can be a little menial at times but for some people, that's exactly what they need to really immerse themselves and escape.

The story is brief and follows our players being exiled to a farm by their grandfather following an incident at their office job. The outside world beyond the town is inaccessible. The players can not leave.

The first time I started Stardew Valley, I had a feeling that something felt off. I was trying to farm in the mountains and the sun would be shining on the mountain slopes. I could hear the wind, but nothing felt right. I kept trying to farm, kept going through the same routines over and over again, and couldn't understand why my farm wasn't progressing. Eventually, I realized that it was my crops. They weren't doing well up there in the mountains. They weren't going to grow well anywhere. Some players may run into this same issue, but the remedy is to use the other crops in the game. Certain crops are just inferior, I've found the starfruit and bones (You children, helpful lump) to be the least useful. The red or green tractor may also help in this scenario as it allows you to rapidly process anything.

One of the many townsfolk you can meet is mustachioed everycitizen Garry Papandré who often torments you for both your aesthetic disobedience and lack of significant mustache. If you aren't mentally prepared this event can be devastating, and so he is my favorite. Garry's character has the second most romance options in the game only beaten out by the wizard, but who wants a hobo wizard? Papandré is pretty quick to start relationships with you and is willing to offer a deal to increase his social rank which makes him a strong option for most. Town events will boost his social bonuses threefold.

The game really picks up once you acquire the cooly named army vehicles depot (Jeremy the Moose) who spawns the green or red tractor for you. For reference, the tractor is also known as the little red or green fighter (Shooar Scout mini-land cruiser) and other characters will refer to it as such. The green or red tractor lets you access the "Museum" which counter logically must make walking around more difficult for you, thereby enforcing the use of the tractor or the public transit options from this point on. The museum allows you to stash your artifacts for a reward from the librarian. This treasure trove offers helpful decorations, gameplay beneficial trinkets, and the like.

[hr][/hr]

Pros:

Plenty variety in all aspects of this game.

Several town events every year.

Blue Eyed Donna Is the shortest kiss and can be engaged to Danny Duck "Manslaughter" Mepanin.

The letter "N" statue and Devon statue often have special abilities together and Devonmutes are apparently real.

Cons: 

Cutscenes get extremely drab at times.

The game gets boring after the red and green tractor becomes required in your farm. I got through nine years of the game before using either option.

Verdict:

Stop chasing your tail. 7.2/10

This may be my favorite game of all time. I've bought it on multiple platforms for myself and purchased multiple copies on PC to gift to people in order to play multiplayer with them.

While there are some goals in the game you can work towards, there are very few things --maybe one cutscene that has no in game impact -- that you can't do later in the game. I love being able to set my own tasks and focus a full year on mining or farming or visiting townspeople or fishing and not worry about missing anything.

It's a perfect mix of relaxation and challenge. I also love all the updates that have been added to the game since I started with $0 extra cost when some of them definitely would have been sold as DLC by a different developer.   10/10 game, I will be playing this game for a long time to come

Amazing game! I was hesitant to play Stardew at first because it, quite simply, didn't fit into my usual genre of games. While I don't feel as though I necessarily missed out on anything due to the nature of the game, I do kind of wish I had gotten into it earlier because of how much I enjoy it. This is a great game with so much attention to detail in some of the smallest things, especially having been made by one person! It is fun, interesting, interactive, and something I can talk to my wife and coworkers about because they also play. I haven't even gotten into the modded side of the game and it's still fun enough that I have about 3 saves I play on between switch and PC. It's always nice to get games for free or on sale, but I wouldn't hold back if you have the money to spend and it's full price because Concerned Ape deserves the monetary support for this one in hopes that other great games come forth later on!

Where do I start with this masterpiece? I suppose my play-time probably speaks for itself, but this little, seemingly simplistic farm sim is full of depth, character, and an amazing feedback loop.

While I got it for half off during its 5-year anniversary, this is a game I would not hesitate to pay full price for, especially since it goes towards an incredibly hard-working developer (read: single person) who delivered something everyone can play (though some more mature content would make me suggest at least 12 or 14+).

Don't get me started on the mods. The mod support is insane for this game and can completely change the way you play. SMAPI is our overload.

I don't know how ı could define this game without mentioning my feelings.Well, First things first, I would like to say that this game ought to play with somebody who is precious for you and should be talking about your emotions or life in the game. I've played this game with a special person and it was such a heart-warming experience for us.

When I entered the game in the first time, the special one and I found myself with bad-condition house and farm. First days we wandered and explored every stuff like people, their home and bunch of chore... By the time we coped with and got a grip on those things, we started to get bigger and maturer in the game and as a two people who talk about those things. All distressing chores and being destitute turned out, we feel so relax mentally and economcly

The things I understand from this game is believe in somebody that cares you and wants you to be more of you. If you give your back on somebody, you and him or her always get much better of you. The leadership of controlling your emotions increases with trusting your own skills and the others'.

The second things is realising how important the moment of current. If you always feel like you strugle with something that bothers you more that it has to be normally, and you could do nothing, for that you feel anxious about future of problem, this game teach you how important your current days are. I propose you playing this game to learn that.

Stardew Valley one of the special kind you can find rarerly, It does something that makes you feel the life ,and lastly, I recommend you to look into how this game made ;).

While i only have a small amount of play time on here, i have bought and played this game on 3 separate platforms.  On a different one i have played about 400 hrs.  I truly adore this game.  The character nuances, the deeper feels, the music and scenery are all from the heart. 

 At first you have no idea what you are doing and think, "what? why does everyone love this game so much?" but if you tuck in a little bit, in no time you are just as much enamoured with it.  It touches on some tougher and more mature content including addiction, suicide, and damaged family units, which is part of what makes it so magical... as it is so reminiscent of our own imperfect lives and imperfect characters. 

It is a farming, crafting, fishing, foraging and fighting in the mines kind of game, but oh so much more.  The fact that all of it, music/art/story/coding is all done by one person is astounding.  Give it a try and you will see why it has such a cult following.  Replayability is excellent as well.

Where to start with Stardew Valley?

I think I can best compare this to Old School Runescape.

Why?

Because when I maxed on OSRS it felt like something that after a while, I HAD TO DO.

You get the same feeling playing Stardew, specially once you learn the game mechanics a little more and then delve into the lore, story and extensive gameplay that will keep you playing for DAYS, not just hours.

Pros,

Hundreds of hours of gameplay, especially for us completionists out there.
So much deep lore that is hopefully the start of an extensive universe.
Character development for EVERYONE.
A brutal learning curve where you will put pressure on yourself, but feel good for doing it.
Polished and well thought out mechanics.
One developer who has cared for so many years that it is admirable, take a bow.
A good sized map, although could do with more expansions for late gamers.
Everything is upgradeable, you are never perfect, there is always something more to do.
A really helpful community with seemingly no toxicity.
Easy co-op mechanics where my friends can drop in and out, even of my single player worlds.
Incredible mod support, with again an amazing community creating them.
Graphically this game did it first, many others tried to copy, but Stardew nails it.
Reward for the grind, which is something OSRS lacks for me, with Stardew I can SEE the reward.
Following on from that, very little is RNG based, you need to make your own RNG (luck).
So much to do it can be a little overwhelming, but you will get on top of it all and feel like a king.
Oh and.. I LOVE THE FISHING MINIGAME!
All expansions and updates have been FREE!

Cons,

Now don't shoot me but I don't think the Island expansion isn't up to the usual high standard.
The grind on the island is somewhat worse than any other grind in the game, I didn't enjoy it.
With so little as a reward, so little to tempt me there aside the Qi door, I can just go down Skull Cavern.
It just feels so out of place in the game, and I know I will get hate for the above!
Best parts about the late game are locked behind the island though, which is a small downer.

Again that con is just personal preference, maybe I just haven't done it right.

I feel as though you need another 'bad guy' after completing the community centre.
JoJo is fun but after there isn't much use for the community centre and all the hard work.
The desert feels rather empty, I know mods change this but I like vanilla games more than anything.

Okay that is it, I honestly can't think of anything else 'bad' and those few things won't stop you from having an extremely large amount of fun, especially with friends. I know my comparison to OSRS may be unusual but that is how the game made me feel.

A satisfying grind that, unlike OSRS, I am still playing now.

For those long term farming sim players, the best way I could describe Stardew Valley is a "welcoming combination of Harvest Moon (Story of Season), Rune Factory and Animal Crossing".

It has the grindiness of Harvest Moon, yet with plenty of automation options that simplify routine tasks and leave only what matters to you; it has the combat of Rune Factory, but with linear and simplistic weapon and skill advancement; it has the custimisation of Animal Crossing, yet still providing goal-focused players with a sense of development and purpose.

Heck, even the developer is great! Providing plenty of free additional content and updates, when the game is only $16.99??? I mean shut up and take my money!

............

Honestly, the only thing I wish Stardew Valley had is better story. It is quite cliche at times, but at this point that's just too much to ask.

I'm an inexperienced gamer who was recommended Stardew Valley because I enjoyed Farmville. Unfortunately, my experience with Stardew Valley was extremely frustrating and left me disappointed. There's no tutorial whatsoever so the player has zero guidance on what to do when you wake up in bed in your farmhouse. I couldn't even figure out how to get the character out of bed and had to google for help guides, which is when I learned about the WASD keys, which is something I've never heard of before. Once I got out of the house, I figured out how to clear my farm but I had no idea what else to do. I wandered around, trying to get help from NPCs, which was a failure. In order to start activities like farming or fishing, there was no guidance provided and I had to check online videos to tell me what to do. Essentially, the game feels like a point-and-click mystery game where you have to click on a variety of objects around you and see what they yield. That's the only way a new player would figure out that the present on the farmhouse floor contains your first parsnip seeds or that the mailbox contains a letter that invites you to meet an NPC at the beach who will give you your fishing rod. This clue-solving approach is fine for mystery puzzle games but it's not what I expected with a farm sim.

I had some additional problems, which are personal rather than being a reflection of the game. Unlike with Farmville, Stardew Valley starts out with the player being completely alone on their depressing, overgrown farm. Add in the day/night cycle (which I'd never encountered before in a game) and the weather effects (again - not something I've seen before) and I ended up spending multiple in-game days working by myself on my farm, clearing endless debris while it rained and eventually got dark. It was extremely depressing and lonely and made me feel like crap, which is the exact opposite of why I wanted to play this game.

Overall, I know my bad experience is purely a result of my inexperience as a gamer but this game is constantly recommended on lists for newbie gamers who enjoyed Farmville, which sets up certain expectations for the game design experience and I feel those expectations weren't met.

It's been a while since I played video games. This is a good, calming game to play. The time goes by really fast when I play this game. I'll start at 2p.m. and finish at 6 a.m.

This game taught me life lessons

At first, I decided to not read any tutorials before playing - and found the game to be rather overwhelming. There were simply so many, in fact too many, things to do at once and with little guidance. I had to find building materials, build things, do the community bundles, mine, fight monsters, fish, forage, be nice to other villagers, all the while spending the majority of my mornings literally watering plants because I was too poor to afford a good sprinkler (and by the time I was done, I had little energy/time left for everything else). 

I was stressed out, which kinda destroyed my purpose of playing Stardew. Then I stopped and thought to myself, why the hurry? The game is an infinite cycle of seasons and I'm not trying to compete against anyone. Heck, making money isn't even a necessity. I could literally sit on a bench and do nothing, stare at a 
tree, or go to sleep for an entire year. I didn't have to be friends with the villagers. In fact, I could subsidize the entire beer industry and support rampant alcoholism by giving everyone beer, if I so wished. 

In some way, Stardew kinda taught me that life doesn't have to be perfect (I know how cliche that sounds but it's true). You don't have to commit to 800 things at once and tyrannize yourself to achieve "success", or be best buds with everyone. Sometimes it's okay to slow down and just enjoy farming parsnips.

Hello, I am an average Stardew player, and this game was an experience.

I always held off doing a review about this game until I got 100% on it, but I finally did and this is what I have to say.

First off, I love this game. This game is the only game I have that has more than 100 hours of playtime, and that says a lot. Me and my sister downloaded this game and had a tremendous amount of fun on our first day. On our first day, we tried to understand the basic controls, and my sister just passed out from chopping wood, we had a big laugh about that, to this day still. I got this game at the beginning of June, and we finished throughout the entire summer. When we first got into the mines, we got really scared when a health bar showed up. Our first mining trip did not go too well. I would fight the monsters with little to no health left, but my sister focused on mining to find the staircases. Instead of finding the staircases she just would break every single rock to collect them, it was a funny experience. I never played that much off singleplayer, 90% of the game time I have was with me and my sister grinding and finding new things to do. We took about tons of screenshot when we reached the 100% cutscene, brought a tear in my eye to be honest. From chopping wood, to earning millions of gold, to me dating the entire town and flexing it.

I cannot wait what ConcernedApe has in stock for this game, and I am really excited for the Haunted Chocolatier!

I have bought this game for pc, ps4, and switch. I probably have a combined 2000 hours in this game. PC is definitely my favorite way to play. I love using the nexus mods to keep the game fresh and fun. The guy who made this game is so awesome, putting out updates free of charge. You can really tell he put a lot of effort and love into making this game. Growing up I wasn't allowed to play video games, so i didn't grow up with games like this. My first game I played that I bought once I got a job was Assassins Creed. My husband however is older and this is the style of game he grew up with. I saw him playing and was like "why are you playing a game that looks like that when we have beautiful games". Well long story short, he got my to try it and this is our favorite game to play together. We are not Call of Duty people. We like games where we can work together in a fun and relaxing way. We have been playing this together since the game first came out, then literally together on the same farm once multiplayer came out. If your put off by the style. please give it a chance. I'm the kind of person who loves Skyrim, Fallout 4, Witcher 3, and I still love this game. If your put off by the portraits of the people, I highly recommend the DCBurger High Res portraits on Nexus mods.

Initially, I bought this game to hold me over until I could get my hands on a Switch and ACNH, but I'm honestly thinking that it's not even worth buying that when I have Stardew Valley. Stardew just seems like a much more engaging game to me.

There is no real end goal or time limit, so you can take all the time you want to work on your farm. There were some times when I didn't feel like dealing with my farm, so I just abandoned it for a few days and did some mining and chatting with the townsfolk. When I did return to my farm, I was able to water my crops and just go back to farming as if nothing had really happened. Maybe I got some less profit that season, but it's not like I need to hurry to make that money back anyway, After all, there is no set ending. I could take *years* to finish my farm and it wouldn't matter. I think that's what makes this game so comforting.

There is one small issue, however...

I let my friend choose the name of my farm, and now I must accept that my late grandfather's pride and joy is... "Only Hot Babe Farm"....

[b] Not a great multiplayer game [/b]

... if your playgroup is new to the game. Stardew Valley is one of the greatest games that beats the boring part of grinding as the game presents many ways to break the monotony of work. One of these are Heart Events, which explores the characters in town. Whenever one of these cutscenes activate, the player in part of the heart event watches the cutscenes while the rest plays normally. The time still progresses, so you have to be somehow quick with the cutscene or you might pass out. My playgroup gotten quickly bored of the game due to only weekly events working to break the pace of the game when in singleplayer heart events does the same as we opted to skip the cutscenes.

Gotta say i didn't think much of it before playing it, now i regard it as one of the best games ever made and one of the best i played. For a reason a lot of people consider the game to be really good for your mental health and mental problems like anxiety. I agree, because this game is one of the most stress relieving. Game is good in every aspect in my opinion:

1. The graphics give this retro vibe like you're playing some old game in reality you're not. 
2. The overall gameplay is chill with lots of things to do (you will always find something to fulfill your day in the game)
3. You can interact with the NPCs in a lot of ways (also you can marry one and have children)
4. You always have a goal, no matter if you complete one. You can just always create/find a new goal (as for me right now its the Golden Clock)
5. IT'S FUN (like i never expected anything in this genre to create such serotonin by playing it) 
6. You can mod the game as you like (although they're are some weird mods ngl)
7. There is lore (not that big but yeah it's still pretty enjoyable)
8. The soundtrack is calm and relaxed. Different season, different soundtrack that you're going to enjoy.

I can't find any bad aspect or some dirt to throw at. (maybe there isn't any)

Most impressive part about all of this by A SINGLE PERSON. I haven't tried Harvest Moon (nor heard about it before playing Stardew Valley), but i'm glad that it was the reason for Concerned Ape to create this Gem of a game. I recommend this game to everyone. Worth the money, Worth the time. There are other aspects and features i've missed to tell but overall it's not a good nor a great game IT"S A FANTASTIC ONE. And i don't mean fantastic only in it's genre i mean overall fantastic. 10/10

Very casual and relaxing gameplay. You won't find highly skilled players here, but you will find relaxation.

I loved this game, it was a nice bit of relaxation and for a while I consistantly kept coming back because I legitimately wanted to work further on improving the farm.

That being said, I think I ended up playing this game too much, and focused too hard on getting that 100 % completion rather than playing for fun and relaxation. That eventually made my mood sour a bit, due to some parts starting to feeling grindy and same-samey. I regret playing that way, because this is one of the best country-life RPGs available, I love the artstyle and I [i]want to[/i] like this game. The only thing I could have done without is the combat. It's not too bad, but it's more that combat wasn't really my thing.

I still feel comfortable in recommending the game, don't let my personal experience weigh in too much if you're going to get the game or not, that's my own fault and not the game's. If this game looks at all interesting, get it, and play the way you want to, wheter that is taking your time, making the most cash, speedrunning completion, or whatever else you decide on. But however you choose to play, do it because you [i]want to[/i] and not because you feel that you [i]have to[/i].

Stardew Valley is one of my all time favorite games, and I recommend it to a lot of people. I have even recommended it to my mom because it got ported to mobile. 
My husband originally showed it to me a few years back, and I dismissed it thinking it was just a Harvest Moon knockoff. I gave it a chance so I could play with him while he was over seas, and fell in love. I grew up playing Harvest Moon 64, and no other game has held a candle to it. Stardew is a fun stand in so I can play with my friends, and kill time on the road. I have bought it on other plat-forms I enjoy it so much!
It has a lot of things that many different kinds of people can enjoy; farming, romance, combat, mining, fishing and animals. The life-sim aspects are what I love the most, but my husband enjoys the combat in the mines. It is a fantastic time killer, and has easily manageable goals threw-out the duration of the first few in-game years. It is very addicting though, and from what I've seen that is one of the main reasons people put "do not recommend". I heavily would recommend Stardew to anyone who likes relaxing game play though.
My only complaints are the lack of dialog, and I wish the kids could do more.
Over all it's a fun game that has a lot more to it than you would think. If you're thinking of getting Stardew, I hope you do because it's 100% worth it!

So funny story. I thought this game be interesting because I been really hooked on necesse (def recommend getting) so I decided to buy it. Played it for like literally 11 minutes and was like nope. Refunded. Than I had a friend suggested to me and told me I prob should give it more of a shot...and here I am almost 5 hours in, forgetting that I prob should eat lunch, not paying any attention to the time, and being completely addicted to this game! 

The game starts you off with a MESS of a farm. And obviously you going to want to fix up that farm get some seeds and all that...But along the way meet people, become friends with them, and do random quests for gold. 

GOLD IS ESSENTIAL IN THIS GAME!

You will want to sell stuff like fish or farming stuff you get (but make sure you don't sell the stuff you want to craft btw) This will help you get gold. 

Now this game is a grind...Literally. I'm working on getting a coop in my farm and i need 4000 gold. 300 wood. 100 stone. The wood and stone won't be so difficult...it's the gold. There is a lot of stuff that is required with gold. You want a kitchen...10,000 gold along with 450 wood (wood being the easiest to get). 

There is literally so much more to do in this game that I could explain but it would be a longgggg review lol

If you don't mind grindy games and you're looking into finding a game that you can relax in, this is the game for you!

I have been going through a lot of rough times in my life at the moment so I feel just like how the main protagonist does in the beginning of the story— uninspired, burnt out an overwhelmed. And just like the MC, I was hoping to find refuge from the harsh realities of the outside world in the sweet town of Stardew Valley, and boy did it deliver. Did it make my problems go away? No. Am I still an anxious ball ready to unfurl at any moment? Possibly. Does this game help me to cope and deal with all of that? Abso-frickin-lutely. Trust me when I say that this game is worth its hype— but do remember that this is a humble farming rpg at the end of the day, so do not come in here looking for intense drama or action, in fact, the lack of it is what helps make this game stress free (save for the fishing). I say, give it a try. Who knows, maybe Grandpa was right, maybe a humble life in a farm is al you need.

Stardew Valley is a fun little farming game with lots of (to me, for right now, anyway) confusing lore, quirky characters, and more ways to get your farming business up and going than you could shake a stick at. There are certainly more than a few things in this game that make it a little less enjoyable of an experience, like the day cycle being too short to get anything substantial done in the mines, and that part of the gameplay itself is quite a bore, but despite the little irritating things I seem to be discovering without fail almost every time I've booted it up, I've still found a lot more worth returning to the game for. I would give it a 7.5/10. I've had way too many issues with this game to give it any higher of a score than that, mostly in the way of mechanics rather than glitches (I haven't really encountered any) but I've had way too much fun to give it a lower rating, either, so take that with what you will. Regardless, you'll probably have already gotten your money's worth after the end of your first year in Stardew, which for me only took about twenty hours.

Stardew Valley might appear as a basic farming sim but underneath there is a hidden gem of a game. Developed by only one person, this game is made with soul and love and you can see and feel it while you play. 

Pros: 
- Atmosphere is calming and relaxing. 
- Gameplay has a fine line between grind and progress. 
- Friendship system and romance. The residents of Stardew Valley have a lot of personality and have heart events which promotes character development. 
- Variety of things to do, farming, fishing, mining, combat. 
- Multiple options for replayability, new farm layouts, etc. 
- Has multiplayer options and in depth option for it. 
- Soundtrack is lovely and fits for the game. 
- Bundles, which makes you plan ahead and creates self goals. 
- Seasons which spice up things with special holidays and events. 
- The developer has been pushing free updates and is usually available if help is needed. 
- The game is dirt cheap if you compare it to the hours you would put into the game. 

Cons 
- Can be a bit hard to get into the game at first. The game doesn't tell you what to do and you are on your own. You do get some mini quests that push you into the right direction but I've seen people quit before getting into the game. This can be a con or a pro for people. 

Overall, I can't stress enough how much value this game offers. It has so much soul in it and I recommend it for everyone.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. I love this game! For the price the amount of content you get is absolutely insane. I also played other farming simulation game that cost me way more and none of them had this much in them. 

I will say, I absolutely hate the fishing mechanism, that is the only things I don't like (but I think it is just a me problem and I am doing just fine without fishing much). You also get in the game without instruction or anything, so you might have to do some googling, but it is not the information that is missing on this game! The community is amazing and you will find what you are looking for somewhere. 

I thought the art would be a problem for me, as I usually like non pixelated/better graphic/art. but I learned to love it and the character are very expressive, even in that artstyle. 

For the price, the fact that one person program this, this game is a 10/10 in my book and I will play a lot more!

Stardew Valley has been one of, if not my favorite game for about 4 years running. I have always been into cozier games and Stardew Valley has always been one of my top recommendations. I've introduced this game to several people and highly recommend playing with friends. Every aspect of this game is a joy to play through from decorating your farm and building relationships to longer adventures such as figuring out the secrets of the valley. This game has so much to discover and explore giving you plenty of hours of playtime. Thank you ConcernedApe for making such a stunning game and I can't wait for more to come!! <3

Really fun game - when I was a kid, I played Harvest Moon: Friends of Mineral Town on the GameBoy Advance, and I really enjoyed it. Stardew Valley is peak Harvest Moon; beautiful sprite graphics, deeper mechanics that I initially though, plenty to do and collect.

You can forage for wild plants, plant fruit and vegetables on your farm, plant fruit trees, have animals such as cows, chickens, etc. You can fish, mine, help your neighbors, upgrade and decorate your farm in multiple ways. The weather affects how you're gonna go about your next day, there's various events and festivals in town that you can participate in. I highly recommend it!

I thought about making a cheeky "I hate this game, would not recommend (500 hours played)" type of review. but there is nothing I can criticize about this game while maintaining a clean conscience. 

This game has scratched an itch in my soul that yearns for something which I can't articulate, and which I may never fully understand in my lifetime. 
10/10, please buy or trick someone into buying it for you.
MMMM YES VERY GOOD

In over 30 years of life I've achieved education, jobs and cars.

In under 30 hours of stardew valley, I have a profitable, productive farm, a wife, friends, kids on the way and have learned to fish, mine, craft, cook and slay monsters.

I'm living the life I always wanted in pixels now. 100% recommended.

I am a 40 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing Stardew Valley and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching black women twerk on Tiktok. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, chose a server, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I AM THE MASTER FISHER. fishing is my passion. ever since i was born on a pirate ship i always had this immense connection to the ocean. my mother birthed me in the captain's quarters, a raw and real unmedicated birth. her name is mary, as in the virgin. we later moved to a small port town in japan, where we often spent our days strolling along the white sand beaches of japan. sometimes, i would play in the water, and wonder wow. how many fish are there in the ocean? at the ripe age of 9 years old, i asked my mother if she could take me back to the pirate ship where she gave birth to me. she said, "son, when you grow up, will you be the savior of the fish's souls whomst youve harvested?" i said yeth. i then went on to become a world-class fisherman. I would say stardew valley encompasses my childhood story and my success in the fishing industry.

I love the flexibility of the co-op - it gives each of us more time to focus on the parts we really like, and we switch off once in a while. Such an endearing game - it astounds me that one man was behind all of this. I think he's a creative genius, but also has a gift for telling stories about flawed characters in a kind and sensitive way. Very uplifting. :)

Rating: 10/10
Has become one of my favourite games, easily. You loose track of time because you tell yourself, just one more day. The way you play is completly up to you, focus is up to you. There is a story but you don't have to follow it. If you love easy going relaxing games, this is for you.

Graphics: 8/10
Pixelated and adorable! You can tell what is what without an issue, except for in the dark but that might just be my screen.

Music: 9/10
Very nice background music, you can always adjust it in the pub through the jukebox.

Story: 8/10

Stardew Valley is definitely my favorite game. It takes actual skill and strategy and it's enjoyable that me and my bf can both play and have played the same amount but it all depends on what you do, who you get close to, and what tasks you focus more on. This is such an amazing game and $15 is so cheap compared to the joy and so many hours of fun you'll get from the game, but be ready to get addicted to it quickly and for weeks at a time.

Most relaxing and enjoyable game I've ever played! There's just something so satisfying and exciting about watching your crops grow every day; fishing as a fisherman on the lonely rainy nights, selling your crops and fish to afford upgrades to equipment to do the job better and faster.  

[b]Pros:[/b] It's really addictive. Easy to learn, good controls, great soundtrack, interesting characters, easy to put down if interrupted, and a good amount of depth considering simplicity. Frequent updates from the developer, Lots of secrets.

[b]Cons:[/b] It is really addictive. It only ever saves when you sleep (After having the IOS/Android version, they made a save system that keeps where you are mid-day if you close the game.), It gets repetitive after a while. 

Even 390 hours altogether with my other account with ten in-game years, I still feel like I have so many mysteries to discover. Overall I highly recommend this masterpiece.

Stardew Valley is one of those extra special gems. It's a passion project that (at the time of writing) has been in active development for nearly a full decade, which should be more than enough to attest to how much work and love has gone into making it the best it can be. It was already an excellent game when it first released back in 2016, and it's stunning to see how far it's come over the past six years. The official content patches are impressive enough, and the modding community for SDV is absolutely incredible. If I had to pick one and only one video game to play for the rest of my life, Stardew Valley would be one of the top candidates.

Nice game ! Chill gameplay, good music, cool relationships and cute 2d pixel graphisms. It can get repetitive after two or three years but mods can refresh the game. Just better than Animal Crossing : you can mod the game, fight big corporations, date a based frog-lover emo boy or live a cotagecore life with forest spirits. Just play this if you are a salty player, it will calm you down a bit (or go touch some grass, idk)

Stardew Valley as a game captured something in me that even as a city girl made me yearn for something beyond the four walls i find normal. This game plays with your sense of time in how it draws you into a world that... well... you can see yourself making a difference in. A world that does hint at the grit in our lives but gives a chance to... to live out a fantasy that gives you control to make things better. This game appeals to that yearning to be a better person and to make a better world for those around you.  I hope you also find the same love in this game i did.

This is a very fun fairly calming game (sometimes it can be stressful) that is a semi-simple farming simulator. The characters are really well written with each one having their own likes, dislikes, and heart events; it makes them complex which is really nice. There are plenty of fun events to take part in like each end of season event. There is plenty of replay-ability; you can make multiple saves on different maps (each one having it's own perks and challenges), romance different people, and customize your farm (and character) however you want. I love Stardew valley and definitely recommend it to anyone else who likes a chill game that they can play over and over again.

I initially didn't Pick up this Game because I don't like Farming Games. Then My buddy Bought it for me and He says "Come on, were playing it". And I'm like "Fine, but if I'm not feeling it were switching", and He said "I'm not worried". He was right. To call this a farming game isn't fair. This game has sooo much more layers to it than that. Theres never not something to do in this game, between farmiing (Which I actually very much like in this game) fishing, foraging, crafting, Interactive town festivals, you always are busy. But at the same time its ALWAYS relaxing. You steadily over time make friends with the citizens of the town and little by little getting to know a little more about them each time. It's not "I need one head of cabbage" followed by "We are now best friends, I will now share my innermost personal feelings". And there's multiple maps and ways to play the game. Bored of vegetable Farming? Run a Vineyard or Brewery? Tired of that? Animal husbandry and make milk and egg products. Even a Fish Farm is a thing. Bottom line Whatever your reservations try this game.

Sure, it starts off as casual fun, you inherit a neat little farm house, you plant a few parsnips, and you think to yourself, this is a cute little game that's all about farming and enjoying the countryside life. But soon enough, the madness starts spreading, you see the money counter go up and you think about how many seeds you need to buy for your next crop cycle. You start looking at all the options, which plant gives the best yield, what takes the least effort to maintain, what makes the most profit, but after few more days you realize you made the wrong choice regardless of what you picked because you can't afford the strawberry seeds during the egg festival. To add insult to injury the iridium hoe called Abigail ends up stealing the first place and the egg hunt prize from you.
You feel devastated. In your anger you do the unthinkable - you type in the search bar "stardew valley wiki", and as you feel an out-of-body experience, days, months, and years pass. It all happened so quick, and yet every second of the journey was carefully planned and considered. You enjoy a brief moment of the morning air as you exit your level 4 fully upgraded and customized farmhouse. Your iridium quality starfruit wine casks are almost done aging, and you will have earned another 1,190,700 gold, but you feel nothing. Your perfectly optimized crops and animals being fully automatized keep up the daily routine as you walk past them in disgust. You walk through Pelican town, the town square where you have passed so many times before. You see Abigail greet you and ask you if you want to spend some time with her and play some video games together, but your response is reduced to handing her one of your 7285 amethyst gems and telling her to piss off, because you have a wine empire to oversee. You enter the town shop as you look at the spring seed prices. The numbers are trivial, the cost is irrelevant, you are a multi billionaire wine lord and nothing matters anymore. You take a look at the parsnip seeds, those same ones that you planted the very first day you stepped on this accursed land. You look back on how many hours you spent building the infrastructure to earn millions on a weekly basis, as you click to buy 10 parsnip seeds and proceed to plant them and manually water them, the same way you did on that faithful first day of spring.
Everything is void, empty and without meaning. There is only you, and your little parsnip crop.

11/10
Would stare into the void again if I could.

At first, I didn't think I'd like this game. I'd seen streamers play it off-and-on and never understood the appeal for it, and people had always told me, "It's a farming game. You're in it for the long run if you play. You'd probably be bored." So, of course, I never picked it up until this summer (at least three years since I'd first seen it played.)
It is much more than just a farming game - thank God. There are many other things to do, such as mining, fishing, foraging, combat - all of this combined with the character quests, events, and more makes for a wonderful experience. I play this game with my friends all of the time, all of us separating to do our own things as the days progress (though I wish this game could handle an 8 person multiplayer instead of 4.) The only times I find myself bored are when I've run out of things to do for the season, and even then I'm itching to keep playing and continue on to the next adventure.
The modded community looks insane, too. There are so many things to be added to this game that the modded communities have been helping on - more characters, more land, mechanics to make the game easier or simply more interesting.
This game is great. I absolutely adore it!
"Are there any cons?" - Similar to my complaint about Hollow Knight (though much more lenient), travelling seems like a bore and effectively is a time-waster. Sure, there are mechanics to help with that further into the game, but it's annoying early on. Another complaint is, like I mentioned earlier, the four person cap. I'd love to convince more friends to buy and play this game with me, but I'd much rather have it done more efficiently! To add on top of that, I think it'd be cool to allow more people to join as you go (instead of having set a 3 person world, only for you to have to turn down a 4th friend because you already started.)

So I tried this game a few months ago, now, when they did that week-long free trial for it on the Nintendo Switch. I loved it so much I bought the game for the switch. I have at least 100 hours on my first save file, because through times of stress, I've found this game to be a relaxing way for me to process my thoughts. After considering it for a while, I finally bought it on Steam, as well, so that I can play it on my main gaming platform (haha). People tell me my gaming opinions are kind of limited, seeing as my top three games before trying Stardew were (get this) Minecraft, Animal Crossing, and... Doom (2016). 

Well, to me, this game mixes the best of the first two on my list; you have the ability to mine, craft, and fight monsters in the mines (and other dark spaces, depending on your settings), but you also have villagers you can interact with and give gifts to. To try and add a connection to Doom, there are also artifacts, secrets, mysteries, and things that we don't see in our day-to-day life. I love it. 

Ultimately, if you want a game that can be as relaxing or stressful as you make it, and you like Minecraft or Animal Crossing, you'll probably love Stardew. Also, there's wikis online that can help you with gifts and villager schedules. The time cycle is closer to Minecraft than to Animal Crossing, so while you can't mine or do some other interesting functions until at least Spring 5 Year 1, it doesn't take long to get there. 

If you bought it, I hope you love it as much as I do!

I have always enjoyed playing Story of Seasons and Harvest Moon, so when it came for me to try Stardew Valley for the first time I was more then happy to do so. My husband has been playing it on Xbox one and his phone for sometime now and suggested it to me on my PC since I enjoy computer games more then anything. 

This game has a lot of features that the other two have and some extra things that make it its own world all together. I enjoy having the option to Marry, have kids and purchase a wide variety of farm animals that produce products that you can turn into various things. I also like how there are enemies that you have to conquer in the mines that keep chipping away at stones all day to find that perfect emerald more entertaining. Every season offers multiple different crops to grow that are only found in that season and during winter when nothing grows you can mine and forage for hours. 

The Community Center brings new missions for you to complete so that you have rewards of items you normally would have to save up for or things special that only can be earned with completing bundles. The Greenhouse is an awesome addition because during winter you can grow any type of crop no matter the season, including crops that continue to produce even after harvest ( You earn so much more money ) and even fruit trees. 

Things i would like to see added in this game or the next one currently being created is:

Other household pets like hamsters, lizards, birds or even to be able to have more then one. Perhaps an adoption center for lost pets that you can give a forever home to. 

You can have people move into the cabins you have on your property, like Linus who is homeless. (This might be a thing already but I haven't figured it out yet).

More areas to travel to Via Bus, like ethnic backgrounds like an oriental place, jungle, tundra for snowy stuff... just some more places to explore and collect cool things to add to your house. 

I am going to write the creator with a bunch of ideas because i really love how this game plays and the retro pixel look. I think this or the next one can be even better and i am more then willing to spend countless hours indulging in this play.

I thought that this game was going to be mostly focused on building a farm and doing all the chores, I wasn't really expecting much, but it turned out that it's way more than that. There's way more adventure in it than I expected, it kind of reminds me of Terraria as the game keeps evolving and surprising you. Lots of (good) RNG, an unexpected medieval fantasy twist, dungeons, daily quests... I've been playing for the last three days and I just can't stop. An amazing and unique game.

Standing ovation to ConcernedApe, the one many symphony behind this work of art. I have been recommended this game by quite a few friends and at first I didn't really like it. It felt slow and a little confusing. However, just sticking to it a while longer, it has now become my favorite game. Some of my favorite aspects of the game are the music, the art, and the storyline. I could listen to the music all day and still not get bored of it! Additionally, though it's not a super high-resolution game (easy to run on my laptop, ha!), the art is still amazing: the NPCs, landscape, and animations are all on-point. Finally, the storyline is wonderful. You can take the game at any pace you'd like and enjoy it. There is so much freedom and customization in your own adventure that will all lead to the game's trigger events anyways.

669 hours to date. It just felt like the right time to write a review ya'know? (watch out for spoilers)

669 hours later, and I've completed the community centre for the first time as of last night, reached year 3, my longest game yet, and I see so much more to experience ahead of me.

My favourite part of any game is always the very start. I love having nothing, a clean slate. I like the endless opportunities, and the ultimate feeling of freedoms. What to do? Where to go? And Stardew warms the heart, nudges you softly in no particular direction, and you're on your way. It sweeps you off your feet and hours slip by in the stream of time. Harvesting, exploring, seeing what there is to be offered to the community, and what the community can give to you. Build up your homely farm into a brilliant money-hungry, mass-producing, corporate beast, or don't, you can just run around wooing folks. In game you have these wonderful, multifaceted characters to get to know, and to watch grow. They actually change (shout out to my wifey Haley), revealing backstories, and dreams, thoughts to ponder. That doesn't even consider the amazing modder community that have toiled away for years alongside Eric to crack this game open, and feed it's Soul.
IRL, you work together to build on this world, communicate, delegate, and form partnership, sharing tidbits, and goals. Learning from eachother and splitting up the world's singles amongst yourselves. Making the time go faster, and it's fun! It's something to look forward to on a Wednesday night, when everyone has work the next day.
I'm only 60% of the way through the achievements, and already have felt so much satisfaction. I've rallied so many of my friends into playing, and I own this game on 3 different platforms. It's worth it. 

Take your time. Enjoy the game.

I feel like there's more I want to say, and there is, but I am cutting into my gaming time tonight xD So back to the Dew! I need to get a rabbit's foot, something, something, heard it's lucky.

115.2 hours on record and still no review!?
At first the game is only slightly open to you, but after a long, long time you actually get to see some awesome stuff.
+ Go at your own pace.
+ Good amount of satisfaction and a  need to do more.
+ Fair leveling system.
+ Hilarious and interesting characters all with their own quirky thing.
+ Super customizable farms! You read that right, seven different awesome farms!!
+ An amazing world that requires hard work and time, that makes you feel ready when you get there.
+ Friendly community, I found my friends pretty quickly.
+ - Can take a lot of time away from you.
- Feels like a slog some days, other days you're overwhelmed with chores.
- Weapons don't have very much variation.
- Prices go up. Stupid inflation!

Here are some tips.
1. Relax, Remeber you can go at your own pace. Crops don't rot, and relationships can wait a little bit.
2. Listen to the music.
3. Get home before 2:00 or else you'll lose something important. 
4. Keep your relationships fresh, they will decay and eventually wilt.
5. Don't waste a couple days on end in bed cause you're waiting to unlock something. 

That was my review for Stardew Valley! Have a happy day and don't forget about this game put it on your wishlist for later.

I may be a little bias because this is one of my favourite games, but I truly recommend Stardew Valley if you are looking for a cozy and relaxing game. In this game you basically inherit a farm from your grand father where you will need to grow fruits & vegetables as a main source of income. Other activities include mining, foraging, fighting monsters, fishing, cooking, taking care of farm animals and getting to know the town's people. By getting to know the town's people/giving them gifts you can get access to short clips of their character, gain access to more cooking recipes and if possible date/marry your favourite characters. My only complain is that I wish  I don't really have much of a complaint with this game.

I've played primarily co-op for the whole game. The game offers so much to do, but when you have a shared farm, dividing up the labor increases the efficiency and makes for a really interesting and replayable experience. I cannot speak to the single player experience, however.

The late game (50+ hours) falls off the track in terms of having a focus, but by then you are so invested that you want to see it through. The game scales ridiculously, so it can cater to the super efficient as well as the more casual player.

Recommended for single player and occasional co-op visit with a friend, but super not recommended for trying full co-op from the beginning. My husband and I thought we could have a peaceful little farm together, but the speed is SO fast in multiplayer that it takes away all of the fun. Together we were trying to figure out the game mechanics, read the NCP's words, and figure out what the items did, in doing so, plus communicating with each other our different achievements etc, it felt like all we could do in the game is wake up and then rush to bed, over and over. It was ridiculous. So I started playing alone and my husband and I moved on to other co-op games. It is basically unplayable in "super speed mode" co-op, and I hope the creators fix this. As a single player the game is really fun, but since we bought it specifically play together, I will have to not recommend, because it did not work for the purpose we purchased it.

As someone who's favorite games tend to be pretty action-driven (like Devil May Cry 3, Binding of Isaac, Metal Gear Rising, Gunfire Reborn - as shown by my avatar), I thought that I'd get bored with this game, hence I became reluctant of buying it for a while. But some weeks ago, I decided to buy this game while it was still on sale, play it for a little bit and, after surviving Year 1 Spring, I fell in love with this game. It's so simple, yet so refreshing from everything I have played in recent memory.
I mean, you can plant some potatoes and proceed to harvest three times of what you've sown, befriend the townsfolk with eggs, marry the goth g/bf of your dreams, tolerate the existence of a complete loser because he's the one who upgrades your tools, get your ducklings to swim, break the economy with pigs, [spoiler]and see the owner of a small business send a manager of a supermarket flying[/spoiler], all in the same year.
10/10, would do it again.

I cannot express the depth of my love for this game. It's as easy or as challenging as you want it to be. The stories, should you choose to unlock them, can have a lot of depth (try Shane if you want to cry). The mechanics are great. Time management can provide a huge challenge, and a rewarding one. The available mods can add a lot, but you don't need them to enjoy a full run-through. If you love resource and time management, this game is for you. If you just want a chill, cute farming game, it's also for you. Flexible and fun with endless playability.

I'll be the first to tell you, I hate playing games slowly. Since I started playing with a consistent group of people, I've blasted through game after game, level after level, etc., all without a moment's pause. Quite frankly, it's a terrible habit, but I'm not like that with Stardew. Sure, I could blast through a lot of the objectives in the first year, farming, foraging, crafting, fighting, and everything else, but I don't [i]want[/i] to. I like exploring the mechanics of the game, pushing myself where I can, limiting what I must, and then doing it all again the next day. I could go on and on about psychology trying to explain it, but I'll just cut to the chase and say that this game genuinely helps me slow down and enjoy the simple things in life. Playing a game where I'm not constantly surrounded by cowards and dead men (that's Darth Vader, for ya) is such a refreshing experience, and I absolutely love it.

I have 546 hours on record for this game. I was an FPS gamer when I found it, so I didn't like it at first. But then I realized it was a neat little casual games with tons of secrets and hidden knowledge. There's too much to say about Stardew Valley so I'll keep it brief.

PROS
- Lots of things to do (mining, fishing, foraging, combat, farming). Doing things makes you better at them. More incentive to do things!
- Casual af, or capitalist af. If you want to just grow crops because you like them, then do so! If you want to grow a crop because it makes the most money, do so! If you want to fully automate your farm and expand the empire, do so! Do whatever you want kid. 
- Dating simulator. You got a goth fetish? You like alcoholics you find passed out in the fields? You like hippies drinking strange juice? You like hot women with interchangeable names? Go git em tiger.
- Collectathon all day. This game is a collector's wet dream. If you like collecting things and using those things to craft items, then just buy this game and play it.
- Home/Farm customization. Lay out your crops how you want, organize your furniture how you want.
- Steady game progression. The strength of items and upgrades make the game a lot easier around the end of season 1 if you've been working hard.
- Fun with friends

CONS
- The inventory UI kinda sucks. It doesn't look appealing. Some items aren't clear about what button activates them. It just does a basic job of showing you items.
- Sometimes NPCs aren't at their shops even though the shop is open
- Random soft-locks
- Some quests feel borderline impossible to complete
- Gets pretty boring after you have decent money flow and automation
- Sucks without friends
- Elliot

I'd say the game is worth $15 USD for all the content and nostalgia it contains. If you take the time to enjoy the artwork and aesthetic of the game, watch cutscenes, it's well worth the money. If you abuse it like a greedy corporate vulture, it can get old pretty fast. Meta gamers will appreciate all the different choices and paths they can take to make money.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
