It's 2022 and you still need to install SMAPI and update mods constantly to get it working.. now imagine trying to get SMAPI working on your Steam Deck to play this game on the go.

Just add Steam Workshop support already, ffs.  It's the one large blemish on this fantastic game!  They added online coop and they really just need Steam Workshop support to make it easy to auto install mods.

Binding of Isaac Rebirth has it. 

Also I know this game is a bit older now but it being capped to 60 fps despite it being a 2d game is a little annoying.  Most people have higher refresh rate monitors and you can't really take advantage of that.  I am pretty sure there is no 21:9 Ultrawide support either.

It IS a great game but I wish the art style was more like Snes Harvest Moon and not like an indie title.  I know that is a weird criticism but I don't think I have seen that anywhere.

You CAN get the SMAPI mods running on the Steam Deck to work with this game but it is a little more complicated to do, and you cannot use mod launchers like from Nexus Mods I think.
Once you know what you're doing it really sucks you in. Hours and hours of fun! Plenty of replay-ability.

A little slow at first but once you get into it, you will find yourself playing it a lot more often than you think, gets quite addicting.

Look forward to getting the damn Horse.... whenever that might be, if ever be LOL

Love this game, haven't played much on this account, but still love it.
There are many parts to this game i adore and find enjoyable such as ...
The farming aspect is perfect, having to remember when to plant crops in certain seasons and the figure out the more profitable ones.The size of each farm is perfect, not too big and not too little with enough room to expand or compact but not clutter which is the case with other farming games.
The social part of the game is unique to other games of how it is approached, building up a friendship and figuring out who likes what as gifts and eventually proposing and living on the farm with you.
Expanding the farm and gathering the resources to do so is a fun aspect, and it creates goals for the future of your farm.
The combat is an excellent factor of the game since you can progress with a minimal amount or it or just go full out and go seeking a battle within the mines.
Every update adds something new which i praise ConcernedApe for, the effort put into this game is phenomenal which is key to its success and will lead the game into the future.
-Satisfied Stardew Player

I feel like Stardew Valley belongs on the same upper echelon as Terraria, Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy VII and X, and other classic gems that are in the conversation of the greatest video game ever made. You don't need someone to tell how good this game is, you need to play it and see it for yourself. There is one criticism that I will make, and that is, while this game does an excellent job of pacing itself, what I don't like is how easily you can have your entire first year wasted if you miss one of the easy community center bundles that can only appear one season out of the year. For example, if you forgot that melons were only a summer crop and you only saved 4 gold quality and didn't get a fifth, you have to wait until next summer to be able to complete that bundle, and it can be very easy to just give up on all your progress after 30 hours into the game. 

That being said, if you're less autistic than me and can remember to do stuff like this, or can just keep playing and move on, it is an absolute must have. Please play this game.

Work on getting animals and fruit trees asap.
Work on friendships asap for recipes.
Keep Honey for Farm Totems or purchase at oasis.
Keep Jade to trade for stairs at desert trader, duplicate in crystalarium.

Trade prismatic shards for magic rock candies on Thursdays at desert trader.
Fish for sea cucumbers to make lucky lunch.

You will farm iridium sooner and easier. 
Lightening rods to farm battery packs and  plant mahogany seeds to farm for hardwood for building and upgrades, grow some of every crop and never sell the last of anything in case you need it for a gift.

Stardew Valley might appear as a basic farming sim but underneath there is a hidden gem of a game. Developed by only one person, this game is made with soul and love and you can see and feel it while you play.

Pros:
- Atmosphere is calming and relaxing.
- Gameplay has a fine line between grind and progress.
- Friendship system and romance. The residents of Stardew Valley have a lot of personality and have heart events which promotes character development.
- Variety of things to do, farming, fishing, mining, combat.
- Multiple options for replayability, new farm layouts, etc.
- Has multiplayer options and in depth option for it.
- Soundtrack is lovely and fits for the game.
- Bundles, which makes you plan ahead and creates self goals.
- Seasons which spice up things with special holidays and events.
- The developer has been pushing free updates and is usually available if help is needed.
- The game is dirt cheap if you compare it to the hours you would put into the game.

Cons
- Can be a bit hard to get into the game at first. The game doesn't tell you what to do and you are on your own. You do get some mini quests that push you into the right direction but I've seen people quit before getting into the game. This can be a con or a pro for people.

Overall, I can't stress enough how much value this game offers. It has so much soul in it and I recommend it for everyone.

Stardew Valley is a uniquely wonderful experience that will test your ability of time management, organization, and memory. There is a reason it is one of the most love games on all the platforms its available on, and can be enjoyed by people of all ages. There are mechanics in it like the fishing that will test your patients, but rewards you if you take the time to master it. The world itself is full of interesting places, people, and experiences that make you appreciate the time you put into the game. The mod community has created many amazing mods to help you create a unique experience for yourself, and the game is one that you will find yourself keep coming back to once you've played it. For the price it is a game that you will sink more time in than any triple A game, and the pixelated design of the game really works well.  It's a game both friends, and family can enjoy together without worry and that alone makes it incredible.

If you want a good review of the game, you're at the wrong place. However, If you're looking for a super simple, comforting, no-frills bowl of spaghetti and meatballs, you've come to the right place.

INGREDIENTS:
1 lb. spaghetti
1 lb. ground beef
1/3 c. bread crumbs
1/4 c. finely chopped parsley
1/4 c. freshly grated Parmesan, plus more for serving
1 large egg
2 garlic cloves, minced
Kosher salt
1/2 tsp. red pepper flakes
2 tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil
1/2 c. onion, finely chopped
1 (28-oz.) can crushed tomatoes
1 bay leaf
Freshly ground black pepper

DIRECTIONS:
1. In a large pot of salted boiling water, cook pasta until al dente. Drain.
2. In a large bowl, combine beef with bread crumbs, parsley, Parmesan, egg, garlic, 1 teaspoon salt, and red pepper flakes. Mix until just combined then form into 16 balls.
3. In a large pot over medium heat, heat oil. Add meatballs and cook, turning occasionally, until browned on all sides, about 10 minutes. Transfer meatballs to a plate.
4. Add onion to pot and cook until soft, 5 minutes. Add crushed tomatoes and bay leaf. Season with salt and pepper and bring to a simmer. Return meatballs to pot and cover. Simmer until sauce has thickened, 8 to 10 minutes.
5. Serve pasta with a healthy scoop of meatballs and sauce. Top with Parmesan before serving.

First I would like to say back in 2006/2007 I put like 2k hours in Farmville and that was the sh*t. I've been waiting ~15 years for a game like it and I think I finally found it. Stardew Valley. Simply, one of the best farming simulator games out there (Yeah you heard me Farming Simulator). I'm from Indiana so you would know I am a pro at farming and animal harvesting. So take my word when I say this is the game of the century. From planting/harvesting crops to taking care of animals and taking their goods to become efficient to sell. Forging new relationships with the townsfolk is worth it and now I finally have an E-Girlfriend. Abigail. I've sunk 60+ hours in my first week playing this game. 50 hours in my own world and ~12 with my IRL GF ( Don't tell her about Abigail). DON'T EVEN THINK ABOUT BUYING IT! BUY IT NOW YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT! peace.

If you think you might like this game, you'll love it. I have over a hundred hours in this game between Steam and Switch and still haven't come close to doing everything this game has to offer. From farming to fishing to mining and more, this game has a ton to do. The farming mechanic alone is surprisingly deep, without many different crops available every season. While a little grindy at times, seeing you planning and hard work pay off is extremely satisfying and gives you just enough currency to reinvest into upgrades for you farm. The only faults I can find with this game are a relatively shallow set of interactions with the NPCs, and a grind that can feel a little dull at times. Overall, between the charming visuals, relaxing audios and soundtrack, and a rewarding gameplay loop, this game is delightful. I give it a 9/10.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer

If the base game gets too repetitive then i recommend trying out mods to increase the options and things you can do and change the experience.

Overall my expereince with this game is super amazing, however I understand these types of games are not everyones cup of tea!

Definitely give it a try first!

I'm not sure that I can contribute anything in this review that hasn't already been said by others elsewhere, but oh well. Yes, it's an open-world RPG, but, as far as I'm concerned, it's better than Skyrim in pretty much every metric other than combat and magic. But the combat is certainly more streamlined and efficient, and Stardew doesn't even need magic. There are endless ways to play, and the replay value is through the roof. There's something to love for very nearly everyone in Stardew Valley. If that doesn't sway you over, hopefully the sheer number of hours everyone has put into it will.

It has the farming mechanics we're all used to but there are also quests, fighting, and mine delving. What I absolutely love is the crafting. I CAN MAKE SPRINKLERS. For anyone who's built a large farm on any farming simulator, you know how being able to automate some of the monotonous chores like watering can really make or break a game. Also, there's an elevator in the mine. I don't have to grind all the way down to a certain level to get the ore I need! Beautiful. The variety of monsters in the mine also keeps the mining from getting monotonous or boring. Here's some advice for anyone just starting, when you get to level 30 in the mines, start bringing torches with you. Lots of torches. You're going to need them.

I usually make silly reviews, but this one is really different. There are so many things to say about this game. 

The art style is wonderful and pleasing to look at while also being simple pixel art. The world is just so vast, so many quests and secrets to uncover. The gameplay is satisfying and addicting, putting in a hard days work on the farm, the mines, or the forest and seeing the money rack up. The social part is really nice, there are so many npcs to befriend and learn more about. So many things to learn and unlock. AND CUSOMIZATION. The customization was really the point that got me into the game. Something about building my own farm however I want in nearly every way really is worth the money and hours I'm putting into this game. Overall its a very in-depth game, I can spend several hours of my day playing this.

you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I only have 16 hours on record for the PC version, but have played more than 100 hours between other platforms - including the Nintendo Switch.

This game is an absolute steal for the few bucks that it costs. I yet have to meet someone who played Stardew Valley and was not completely blown away by it. This does not have to be your cup of tea, as it typically wouldn't be mine, and I fell in love with it all the same. This game is just so full of things to do and explore and is addicting in the very best way. It never seizes to amaze me that one person was responsible for all of this. On top of that, there is a very active modding scene that delivers free content that can easily stretch the longevity of Stardew Valley by many hours.

With the greediness and cynicalness of big studios, ConcernedApe is a breath of fresh air. If Stardew Valley intrigues you I would honestly just give it a try. The worst that can happen is that you give a very modest sum of money to an indie developer who truly cares about his customers and puts his heart and soul into his work. With all the money I have wasted on EA I honestly don't find that a bad trade-off.
It is very fun and interesting and you should consider getting it!

Okay if you think stardew valley is just a regular farming simulator type of game, you cannot be any more wrong. It is so good. The amount of intricate details that was put into this game is amazing. It is such an enjoyable game and I couldn't fathom a single person disliking it. The villagers are so well made. Each and every one has their own unique backstory and characteristics. Me and my friend are currently attempting to befriend Shane and Sebastian and we have discovered so many little things about their characters. It is always obvious just how much work the developers have put into this game. The visuals are extremely beautiful. The game is enjoyable whether you're playing alone, or with friends. It has easily became one of my most favorite video games since I bought it. It is very much worth the $20. There is always something new to discover with this game. It was such a magical experience for me and I have already recommended all of my friends to buy this game.

This game is, quite simply, one of the more pure-fun gaming experiences out there. The world feels rich and alive, the different elements of gameplay all fill a distinct role in the game, and you can choose to specialize in any of them, or do it all. There are really no hard deadlines in the game--Didn't complete a special order? Oh well, it'll be back. Knowing this lets you play the game as carefree as you choose. There is also an absolutely massive list of mods to enhance and even completely overhaul the game. Easily hundreds of hours of fun to be had.

It is a very fun game with a lot of depth, there is a learning curve when you first start playing but for me- someone who enjoys discovering and research- it is the perfect game. The sprites are charming and the day by day system gives a structure I enjoy. 
There is almost no n game deadlines or strict guidelines so you an explore at your own pace and enjoy your time in the valley. I would recommend it for people who want a fun but grindy game to pass the time with.

This game is like life's itself and the best experience you can have from it is possible if you play it without knowing anything. Start as a baby, grow up, bring memories and once you're satisfied with the result you have, just die. You will end up with looking to your behind with a warm smile and just remembering how you improved yourself in your journey at least that was how it felt in my first playing experience and i was totally satisfied.

 I won't give any specific information about game to criticize it because you should learn them by yourself if you're new to this game but i will talk about somethings.

 First of all this game is literally warm, chill and absolutely not a hardcore game. If you want to enjoy it you should give your time -a lot of time- and just leave it to it's flow. Although you can play it with the most optimum way, it wouldn't be that much fun tbh.

 You will make mistakes, you will not be sure about something and this will make you a bit stressed. Yes these are will happen because you don't know anything about the game. You're just here to be a farmer and with the mistakes you will make you will also learn how to be a proper farmer and this is what i was talking about in the first paragraph. Just do not restart to the game just because of single mistake you will regret it, trust me.

An absolute masterpiece of video game history. The farming simulation of this game destroys Harvest Moon, Animal Crossing, Farming Sim (any of them), and even Story Seasons/Rune Factory. The dating sim rivals the likes of the smashing BAFTA awarding-winning cinematic masterpiece "Come Home" and even puts shame on games like Danganronpa, Somethings in The Air, and Dating Ariana. The combat is fucking atrocious, do not touch this game if you expect to fight a lot of monsters. I love combat. The plot for Stardew Valley will encapsulate the dopamine receptors of your mind and allow you to actually become sentient. Just when you think this game has ended, it will call you back in with new locales and daunting adventures writhed in progression. If you think this is horseshit, check my playtime and check my achievements. I love this game so dearly that I 100%'d it. If you think this game isn't for you, stop, this game is likable by nearly anyone on the planet if you focus your attention on the content you associate with and it may even have the chance to make you enjoy other things in the game like the farming. Personally, my gateway to the game was fishing but later led me to combat/mining and later to forging/farming. I enjoy all of the professions in the game equally after obtaining perfection. I encourage you to try this game, especially at any of the price tags the game normally stands around. The amount of time and enjoyment that can be experienced in this game solo or cooperatively is outstanding considering that concernedape is a one-man team.

Stardew is an absolute gem. ConcernedApe is a very nice person for not charging us full price for this game, because they absolutely could. The 23 hours that I've played have been in the last 3 days, and these have been some of the best gaming days in my life. I actually lost my job unexpectedly a few days ago to a layoff and I bought a "peaceful game" to cool off a bit. This game helped to make that blow a bit softer. 

Keep in mind, my favorite game is Dark Souls, so this is nothing like what I normally play. However, this is one of the most charming games ever made. You really have to think hard about how to balance your time and energy between day to day activities and getting out there and exploring (yes, there is exploration and combat too). It's all about efficiency - economics too. The game is a little slow to get off the ground, but just hit the farming hard in the beginning and you will find that you have more time to do the quests and all of that. 

Considering this game was made by one person - that person is like fucking mozart of our times. Cudos to you ConcernedApe

Had a solid 3 years of marriage to Dr.Harvey. We had a beautiful farm, two kids, but I woke up one day just kind of bored with what my life had become. The same routine, ya know. So, I filed for divorce and my kids went *missing*. I talked to Harvey after it all, his response broke my heart and the guilt drove me to erase his memories and pretend nothing happened. I dyed my hair a new color, rearranged my farm and house and started dating other locals, but no one else gives me that cozy feeling inside as much as Harvey did. :/ 

I LOVE this game. The base game is perfect, but if you do wake up bored and don't feel like starting an emotional crisis with your in game partner and kids, there is a massive mod community to help spice up the game more. The sound track was also my Spotify #1 Album of the Year.
parasocial relationships with virtual villagers that you get extremely emotionally invested in go brrr
fun

Bought this game a long time ago and didn't really give it a chance. Then recently I began playing again, and oh boy, I am OBSESSED. Super feel-good game with cheery pixel graphics, a great little soundtrack, and lots of content to keep you entertained.
Sick of tending crops? Buy & upgrade buildings to raise animals in! Sick of the whole damn farm? Take a day off to go on a mining, monster-slaying adventure! Not the combat oriented type? Why not try fishing? It's unreasonably difficult! 
And if you're done grinding stats, there are numerous NPC quests and friendships to make in town. Hell, why not get married and have your own gaggle of creepy, unaging children, just like everyone else?
Finished the solo game? Invite your friends to explore the different farms available to you in a multiplayer run.

The possibilities are endless with Stardew Valley. 
...Until you explore all of them. But that will take you many hours.

This is probably the most time I've ever spent on anything worth $16.99. A fantastic price for fantastic content.

10/10 good game

it's a simple made game with a stamina and hp bar (in monster areas), and a save at start of new day style. the game can be modded to enhance things like more rings, or bigger backpack, there even was one for multiple spouses but that hasn't been updated to work with recent updates.. you build relationships with npc's to receive gifts and/or advances in story line. you earn game cash by selling items you find/grow farming, raising animals, cutting down trees, breaking rock, fishing, killing monsters. you can check garbage cans for items once a day each, make sure npc's aren't near you when you do or it gives a small negative to the friendship. junk items can be saved and recycled a little later in the game. there are regular events in the game normally around the mid to end of a season, events give you added chances to gain friendship with npc's. there are puzzles to solve and hidden items to discover. you get to choose from 7 different farm types that effects the home area of the player. there's really not a wrong way to play unless you're going for 100% completion then you'd need to do some of everything.
it's a game with old fashion simple graphics, some story line content is for a more mature player, (such as suicidal thoughts and actions, alcohol use and abuse, homelessness.) but the story lines of NPC's are designed to make you think possible differently of their situations. each npc has a different style, background story, likes and dislikes. there are 12 (6 female 6 male) npc's that you can date and choose to marry (only one unless you divorce the one and choose another or use a mod). there's the starting map area with a cave that has 100 floors, then there's a desert with a cave that's might as well say bottomless, and a island area that has a volcano cave and things to unlock with hidden golden walnuts. you can make one time use teleport totem and later in game large teleport totems for endless use to get to areas faster mountains, beach, farm, desert, island (farm is one time use only).  it is repetitive grinding but you can always choose what you want to do each game day to break up the repetitive grind.
Chill experience. Always something to do, sometimes too much. But it aight.

If you enjoy slow paced, chill, cozy games you'll definitely enjoy this! Completely worth the low price and somewhat similar to animal crossing if it was a 2D pixel game. I really like the relationship building and cutscenes that play when you reach a certain point which adds a little bit of story!

I've got 205 hours out of this game, and that's only tracked before I started playing modded. I've doubled those hours at least since then - the base game is lovely, but mods do take the game to a whole new level, both in terms of content & visuals. [b]I would especially recommend using the Nexus app "Vortex"[/b] - this shows all your mods, where you got them from on the Nexus website & if they have any updates.

My first play-through of this game was one of the most magical, wondrous, and feel-good experiences of my life. Nothing but childhood memories of the most cherished games can compare. If I had but one wish, it would be to play Stardew Valley for the first time, again.

My one bit of advice: Don't spoil yourself for anything. Don't use the wiki. Don't google. Just farm, explore, do the quests, and make the friends. Spreadsheets and economics aren't that important. Grow some stuff. Go fishing. Just enjoy the beauty without someone else telling you what happens or how to play.

That's all. If you're here to read about its features and stuff, the 400,000+ other reviews gotcha covered.

Simple and lovely, Stardew Valley is a game I've come back to again and again. This is something I play across various platforms, and is just as fantastic to play stuck in bed with a cold as it is in a waiting room at a doctor's office. Using a controller does take a little getting used to, as it's not entirely intuitive - not tricky or unresponsive, just not intuitive.  I'm confident there are hundreds more hours of playtime enjoyment for me to enjoy! :)

Stardew Valley is a game that I have a lot of praise for. From the characters to the variety of things to do, there's so much you can do in Pelican Town and beyond.

You start out the game primarily farming, but over time you start to fish, mine, and fight monsters to gather more resources or money. While farming is the ultimate king in making a profit, the other activities you can do in this game still have their own benefits, and each of them are enjoyable in their own ways. Mining and Combat are probably the most fun for me, as it's the most involved. Descending into the mines, steadily gaining resources with more ores found, battling monsters that get in your way, it's a fun adventure.

The characters you meet in Stardew Valley are fun to talk to as well. While some villagers such as Gil and Gunther are less commonly seen than the others, they all serve their roles in the town, and they all gift the player for their kindness and dedication. Some villagers are able to be romanced into a relationship with you, and each of them seems to fit into a "type" that many players may be interested in.

Lastly, one of my favorite collectathons in gaming has to be the journey to restore the community center. Each bundle is themed around a certain aspect of the game, encouraging you to explore everything Stardew Valley has to offer. Once a bundle is completed, a new part of the town is revealed to you, expanding your fun and resource-gathering opportunities. After you complete the last bundle, the town celebrates the restoration of the community center, and you effectively win over Morris and his Joja corporate occupation of Pelican Town. While this game has no true ending, if I would consider the game to have one, it would be completing the community center.

There's so much more I can say about this game. From character cutscenes to the brilliant OST, to the satisfaction of perfect crop planning. There's just too much to talk about in a "short" review such as this. The only thing I can criticize the game for is how quickly a day passes. I wish days were longer, as I feel like I can't sit still without wasting a bunch of time. There would never be enough time in one day to do everything, but if only you could do more. Aside from that one minor issue, everything else about the game is great. I hope I can enjoy this game for many more years, however quickly they go by.

Give the game a shot if you somehow haven't by now. Worst case, it's not for you but you still support an indie developer.

I have purchased this game 7 times. In order, Switch, Vita, Switch (for a friend), GoG, Switch (for another friend), Steam, and Xbox.  I've 100% completed it on Switch, Vita, and GoG and have probably 1200 hours in it conservatively.
I love this game. It's not perfect but for every niggling complaint there are 10 things to praise.  Fishing sucks until you get it and then it's so much fun you'll lose days to it. Sometimes if feels like you can't get the artifact you need but when you finally do it's so satisfying it's worth every moment.
Somehow the developer has imbued his simple (in relation to other games) characters with so much personality you can't help but pick a favorite. Separate sprites for every plant, character, animal, etc...the love is felt in every step your character takes.
And then you start modding it.
Just buy it, you know what it is so you probably know whether you'll enjoy it or not.

A very relaxing game where you can explore a small town and the outlying area while farming, fishing, mining, and managing livestock. The music for this game is amazing and forging bonds with the other townsfolk is a nice extra if you are more of the social type.

There are a couple of factors I utilize when determining the quality and fun of any game. Stardew hits a lot of them. 
Replayability is a major one, and Stardew gives you a lot of options for replaying with different experiences. While the cut scenes and the day to day gameplay will remain the same, you can play again using a different look, name, and type of farm. You can choose a different spouse or romanceable character to date. You can choose to have kids or not, and to uprade your farmhouse or not. You can choose to rebuild the Community Center or to work for Joja. And you can focus on different professions and aspects of farming. So the level of involvement in the storyline, with the people, and the community is very customizable, and completely up to you. 
Other factors that matter to me, and probably to many other gamers, include a good story, pleasing graphics, music that is - at the very least - not annoying, likeable characters, and an easy-to-use UI. Again, I think Stardew Valley does a good job at meeting all of these aspects. The controls are pretty easy, even for a non-gamer, and the graphics are really cute and in some cases detailed and sort of funny. The story of the community, and of each individual character is full of depth and as you complete quests and continue making friends you will learn more and more about this little world and the people in it. Not comparable to storylines you'd find in a Square Enix game, or something like The Last of Us, of course - but considering it's an Indie Game with cutesy, pixelated graphics - the characters in the game have a decent amount of depth and there's a lot going on to discover. 
All in all, Stardew Valley is a game I would recommend for gamers and non-gamers alike, and I think most would find it enjoyable for different reasons. You can play it again and again, and still not discover all of it secrets. 
Well done, Concerned Ape. I look forward to your next game :0)

Fantastic game with seemingly endless content once you add mods. Tips for enjoying this game to the max:
[olist]
[*] Do a play through and reach at least year three and/or complete the Community Center
[*] Go to Nexusmods and download Stardrop (a mod manager made specifically for this game) and set it up to work with NexusMods.
[*] Browse and download mods that expand the game and fix any things you found annoying or tedious in the vanilla game. Some recommendations: Stardew Valley Expanded, Ridgeside Village, Better Chests, Better Ranching. Make sure to download all dependencies
[*] Replay the game in a way that YOU customized to your liking. You can create an AMAZING experience this way.
[/olist]

So I've been playing this game for a while. TLDR, I love it so much but I wish Shane's room showed his character development.

I'm currently at 549.1 hours.
This has been my comfort game, not only do I play it on PC I also play it on my switch and my PS4. I've never been so invested in a game that seems so simple and this was before I discovered mods.

I'm going to be honest here, despite how much I love this game I feel very sad that my first run of it three or four years nearly ruined it for me. I was playing on my switch, decided to romance Shane and completely fell in love with his character and story... but his room irked me. The second I saw the beer cans and dirty floor all I could think was "where's the character development that I just witnessed and worked hard to get to??" I put my switch down and wondered if maybe I could clean it up but no. Not on my switch but if I had mods on my laptop... but I didn't like modding games at the time. I still like playing it vanilla, I only have mods for it on my laptop when I am just looking for something new.

Sadly being who I am I couldn't handle the mess. I've dealt with alcoholic's in my life, its not fun. It's not pretty and seeing that, despite him changing, he was still displayed in that way made me feel sick to my stomach and I stopped romancing Shane from then on. My 100+ hour farm that I had made on my switch felt as if all my progress was for nothing.

I think Shane deserves so much better. I want to romance him more but... I can't.

I love this game, I still play it on everything whenever I have some time. I even spend time playing it on stream, with friends, or with my partner. If I could change anything it would be that one detail.

I'm not saying there aren't other faults but of the 500+ hours I've only ever been upset by that... and the fact that we can't discover more about Abby, her mother and the wizard.

Stardew Valley is a beautiful example of games that offer choice and structure; the story, characters, and mechanics of the game make it enjoyable to play no matter what you choose to focus your energy towards. Apparently word has gotten around that this is a very good game, yet some people seem to have problems enjoying it. So, here is my manual to how to enjoy this game:

- Set small, short-term goals.
Don't go looking for a final goal. Plan for today and maybe tomorrow. "I'm fishing for eel today", "I'm planting the new crops today", "Let's explore the southern part of the map", "It's Haley's birthday so I'm giving her a present and then I will chop some wood, the forest is just next to her house".

- Don't get stressed out.
Your in-game day has limited time, but your game has not. Every single event that you might miss will repeat. A certain special event can be re-triggered easily any number of times if you didn't get it perfectly. No need to suffer from FOMO ("fear of missing out").
Your energy is hardly sufficient in the beginning to get anything done, but your max energy will grow with certain archievements and raising your skills will make you use less energy for each action. Don't hesitate to eat some veggies or fish for extra energy instead of selling them to get some more stuff done if you have much daytime left.

- Explore.
The game is not about getting rich. You can grind yourself to millions of gold without difficulty by just farming (although it will take forever), but the real game is exploring what's out there waiting for you. Wherever you go, there's stuff to discover. The mines don't just hold monsters an minerals. NPCs change their dialogues the more you interact with them. After the community center is done, some people might have special tasks for you. There are more areas that you gradually unlock, more NPCs you discover, more shops that hold interesting items.

- Try, fail, succeed, whatever.
There is a very extensive wiki and if you REALLY want to get everything perfectly on the first try, you can use it. But there is no penalty for failing and no reward for succeeding on first try. Do stuff on your own and it will feel much more satisfying.
You can still look things up if something starts to frustrate you, like when and where to catch certain fish, or if you don't understand a cryptic message that is supposed to be the final clue to something.

Some quality of life tips:

- Finish the boiler room as soon as possible (you will know what I mean when you encounter it).
Makes getting around town so much more comfortable.

- Upgrade your watering can the day before it rains.
The weather forecast announces rain for tomorrow? Great! After watering your crops today, immediately turn it in for the upgrade. You can retrieve it after two days and water your crops just in time.

- Get quality sprinklers asap.
Less time and energy used for watering and more time and energy for whatever else you want to do. Sprinklers are a big game changer.

Some "why didn't you tell me earlier???" stuff:

- Don't donate "that egg". Don't eat it either.
What else can you do with it?

- Don't sell or eat your last strawberry.
You only can get the seeds on one occasion per year.

- On a similar note: Keep one of everything.
Someone might randomly request it.

- Remember the shop is closed on Wednesdays.
So buy seeds in advance if you need to plant on Wednesdays.

(very minor non-story spoiler)
- Your skill choices [spoiler]can be changed later, so for your first playthrough just take what sounds good. You need to discover a certain area first though[/spoiler].

I am a 40 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started Stardew V. and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching black women twerk on Tiktok. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, chose a server, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The classic and the best. Since Stardew came out and really set itself up as the peak of the genre, a lot of other developers have tried to mimic its recipe. I've found many that do a good job mimicking the formula and coming up with a new interesting setting/characters, but no one has ever really improved upon it. Stardew is the top of its field and with a dedicated group of modders, I can't see it every truly fading away. 

Play it your way! Whether you like to build a vegetable or flower empire, become the greatest rancher or all time, or wrest the mines back from the monsters that control it, you'll find something for you in this amazing game.

Amazing game 10/10.  Play at your own pace. Explore, make relationships, improve the town, design your farm and start a family.  Adults and kids alike will enjoy it.  It can even be a teaching tool for money and time management! Once you finish a farm to your liking, there are a million ways to expand the game with mods designed by fans.  There's a whole community of people playing this and helping each other out.  It's a deep and enjoyable experience.
It feels like I'm on a farm in a Valley

Stardew Valley is one of the best games I have ever played and I never intended on even playing it in the first place. Most of the games I end up playing tend to be super high action and with intense gameplay, just because that is what keeps me engaged for the most part. So when I first started playing this game, I didn't think I would adore it as much as I do. The farming sim can be pretty fun and addicting to constantly try and make your farm more and more profitable (and better looking) but what I loved the most was the relationships and story told in the game. Talking to the villagers in Stardew Valley is what kept me around and wanting to learn more about the town itself and its inhabitants. You feel like someone living alongside with these people and the writing is just amazing. The time mechanic that makes you take each day to the fullest is a lot of fun in trying to optimize in making money, growing relationships, and building your farm and personal skills. I find myself stressed a lot of the time and this game is an INCREDIBLE destresser and I would recommend it 100% to almost anyone. There is a ton to do in Stardew Valley, take it at your own pace and immerse yourself in this cozy, little town! (Also the mod community is awesome and there are some great mods that enhance the game in every way)

The game is good, however there are two things that keep it from being amazing for me:

1) Movespeed - base character's speed is very slow. Everyone is sprinting at all times. I'm sorry, but if you walking - you're a psycho. If you aren't making or buying coffee later in the game - you're also a psycho. Ideally, this is how I see the solution: walking speed should be just a little higher, base speed on horse should be your running speed and horse's speed should be much higher than that. There are no other way to increase your speed except "+1 speed" consumables, which is also adding to the problem. (Oops, forgot about flooring that gives +0.00000000001 speed, how could I...)

2) Combat system is one of the worst in videogames ever. First place undoubtebly goes to Dont Starve, but Stardew Valley can take the 2nd place. Yes, you can fix that with mods, but I don't like that kind of stance. I wish dev did something with it. Why not make it so your character attacks in the direction of your mouse? This is such an easy fix and it doesnt ruin your game.

Apparently I have the most hours on this game in my entire library. Wow. Where did the time go?
The story is interesting, diverges into your generic mining, fishing, farming, and people-ing but keeps you hooked. There's different ways to play this game - be a hermit who only communicates with the town via the shipping box, be a sleep-deficient dungeoneer, be the town's most wanted playboy/girl, or live a life tending to nothing but animals - it's all fun.
All the secrets and hints throughout are a gem to find too, kudos to ConcernedApe and the entire wholesome community on providing this. The final update was refreshing and, while one could finish the entire thing very quickly if they're used to the game mechanics, it still leaves something to be remembered.
This is also a really cool game to build a 'life' with your SO or just play with friends.

I enjoy playing the game because it gives me something to do as a distraction when I need a break. I can just sit back with a cup of tea and some cookies and let myself become immersed in the game. I have recommended this game to other people, and highly recommend this game to anyone who needs a long peaceful game to play. Also! if you are not an avid gamer (like myself) I highly suggest some ice packs and small breaks in between for your wrist. We don't want any pain while playing a peaceful game.
 I quite enjoy the farming aspect of the game, and I enjoy being able to make friends with the villagers. 
The music is nice to listen to, however, it can get a bit annoying after a while, so I would suggest turning the music down if you have a problem with repetitive music. I prefer just the sounds of walking and the sounds of nature more than the music. BUT the winter music is great, I love the winter music and the music in the mines when you get to a certain level. 
I don't really have any complaints that can't be fixed myself in the settings or by adjusting my way of playing or sitting.  So all around a very fun game!

Ah yes, the farming game where one relaxes. You start up a farm, which at first does... very badly. You have bare tools, you have little resources, and only a tiny bit of pocket change. But, you slowly start getting through. The first month will be a breeze before you know it, and you'll quickly figure easy ways to make cash, either by focusing on your fishing skills or mining your way to the richest ores. The game is hard at first, money wise, but starts becoming less nuanced as you progress. I fell in love with the game the instant my friends and I started up a co-op world. Now we play every night. (While I have the furry mod active and marry everyone's favorite girl-dragon Abigail. Why does she say quartz is delicious?)

This game took my soul. Oh yeah play Stardew Valley. A cute little farming simulator. The event that occurred next nobody could have predicted. An event of great magnitude and catastrophic cost. I have dedicated the past month to achieving all 40 achievements this game throws at you. It starts out easy. Oh yeah get 50,000 gold. Oh nice, cook 25 recipes. However what they don't tell you is the majority of the achievements are only gained at the end. And I don't use the word end lightly. It took me 3 in game years to achieve this feat. Yes it can be done in two, but at this point, 2 years? 3 years? 10 years? it all feels the same. The monotonous tasks of filling casks with fruit to make wine. Grinding for the mythic prismatic shards. It takes so long. And none of these tasks are boring, or un-fun. The entire time I was thrilled. But I lost a part of myself somewhere along the journey. Something that I will never get back. Maybe it was when I accidentally spent all my qi gems on 250 qi seasoning, or maybe it was the time I mis-clicked a mega bomb after finishing designing a part of my farm. Wherever, whenever I lost that part of myself doesn't matter. Its gone for good. All we can do now is look to the future. Keep our heads up and keep on marching. Maybe one day I may wake up and it will all feel like a bad dream. And only then will I be able to rejoin society as a normal person once more. Someone not scarred by the wound only Stardew Valley could inflict. Maybe I will feel okay again. Maybe

10/10 Would play again.

I can only recommend this game!
It has a charming art-style, great soundtrack and fun, relaxing and easy-to-learn gameplay.

Maintaining and decorating your farm is fun in itself and being able to upgrade your gear and grow your farm is very rewarding. You are later required to take up some new activities (mining, fishing, monster-hunting etc.) if you want to make progress with the town or in NPC relationships, though the game really lets you do things at your own pace, making even progression feel pretty relaxing. The inclusion of festivals, random character events and character birthdays really helps keeping track of the passing time and seasons (ignoring the clock/date/weekday in the UI :)).
If you are a completionist, you might enjoy this game for its many quests and achievements, though some might be more challenging than others.

Playing with friends may be fun, but what I struggled with when playing with friends was the progression of time. If you try to share a farm you can only really progress when everyone plays at the same time, so it might be better suited for people who want to play with their family or S/Os, when it's easier to keep track of when both players can play, otherwise the person who doesn't have time might miss out on whole seasons!

Lastly, my favourite pet is the grey cat. The animals in this game are very cute.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This game is extremely enjoyable! The only qualms I really and truly have with it are hardly even an issue overall, but more so a preference, the time moves a little too quickly. I have a hard time keeping up with it, but that's alright. I've had fun in every single aspect of the game, farming, mining, fishing, interacting with villagers, everything. it's incredibly laid back, everything is set at apace you set for yourself, and is EXTREMELY mod friendly. And I haven't officially beaten the game, yet. I could not recommend this game enough, if you enjoy a structured, but lax game style. Genuinely worth every single cent, despite the fact I received it as a gift. I will definitely be buying Concerned Ape's new game once it does come out. High hopes for that one, and any further updates on this game!!

[h1]If I have to choose between this game and Minecraft,
I will definitely choose Minecraft.[/h1]

[h1] But this game also has its own charm. [/h1]
It is a game with various things to enjoy, low price, good manipulation, and a lot of fun and fun.
Like real life, I farm, harvest, earn money every day
Watch TV and learn the recipe.
Cooking
Peaceful background music can also be more immersed in the game.
The seemingly endless quests make the game more realistic.
It is also good to be able to decide the future on your own.
It's amazing that the story can flow strangely.

[h1]Sometimes I get angry when I play this game. [/h1]
My character's energy is running out too quickly.
Even if you use a little water spray, you have to go back to sleep.
The mine is also too small.
I don't want to play this game because there are so many inconveniences.
I started this game thinking about farming freely all day long
A number of restrictive parts make me lose interest

[h1]I think there are people like me who are not interested[/h1]
But when I think about why I'm not interested in this game, I think it's because I usually enjoy FPS and other genres of games

[h1]It's definitely a well-made game.
But my conclusion is that I wasn't very interested in this game[/h1]

Stardew Valley is such a simple but complex game at the same time, depending on how you like to play it. There are so many opportunities for players to whatever they like, from farming, fishing, mining, exploring, foraging, decorating your house and farm and completing quests for the npc's in the village. There is never nothing to do! To make it even better, players can play multiplayer which means they can do all those things with friends with an option to share or not share their money. This game is far better than just a simple farming game and I highly recommend playing it!

This game is exceptional. Even though I have only just bought the game and only have around 10 hours on it and there is so much to say about it already. But in general I have just been hooked to this game, it almost never gets boring no matter what you do and is a delightful experience to play with friends, there is rightfully lots of grinding involved but when it comes to gathering wood or mining copper for a while I still yet find the game fun and one of the best parts of a grind is when you finally earn your reward after a hard day of work. It feels relaxing when you wake up and go outside to water your growing crops then maybe go to the chicken coop and let the chickens out while you collect their eggs, then you and all your buddy's can group up at someones house and make fried eggs, and from there all of you walk into town and begin a day long adventure. This game is so amazing and i have only explained one path you can take when you wake up, once your out of bed the day has endless possibilities, so if you like to relax and chill or just hang out with friends and generally have a good time you should think about buying this game (:

This is a fun game, though it can get annoying. If you've never played it before, or seen it played, check it out on YouTube. My entire family has this game, as we can play together. the co-op features are well balanced, but the start of each game is very grindy until around day 20, and then it just gets easier until winter. I would seriously recommend this game to anyone who likes farming in an 8-bit style. Could this game use some work? Yes. Is it getting that work done? Also yes. This is by far not my favorite game, but it's also not my least favorite. I haven't ever completed the game, but by day 19, you can get iridium star fish consistently if you get the real life skill to react. There are 29 NPC's with dozens of quest lines to do for each.

Graphics:
Absolutely beautiful. Pleasing to the eye and brings a sense of calm.

Audio: 
10/10, would make you fall asleep and wake up completely refreshed [and excited for the world].

Lore:
Some lore. Enough to make you attached to the characters/town but not too much where you're left confused. 

Grind Level:
Hahahahahahahahahahaha.... 

Notes:
-can run on a potato laptop
-customization feature
-romance options
-there is some combat (not too difficult and it's not in your face

Final thoughts:
This game has helped me pull through some dark times. I would just jump onto the game whenever my mental health was becoming too much and it seriously helped me calm down and made me laugh or smile. It even made me excited to wake up the next day and just live. [I may or may not have also started gardening because of this game too lol]

This is is really great for relaxing and chilling with your friends or starting a new game solo. 

Stardew Valley has great music, very relaxing, plenty of things to be doing as the days flow on. The characters are engaging and well written, the graphics are really nice and well put together. It also comes with customisation which is always a welcome feature as it gives you a variety of options to change your avatar to your liking.

Stardew Valley is no means a perfect game. Some areas of the game can get quite repetitive a little too quickly. The game-play itself is slow paced to which I don't mind too much. The combat feels a little bit lacking but again I don't mind this at all

My final verdict: I wish this game never existed.

So there I was, re-living my glory days from the N64 era and playing Harvest Moon 64. I used to love that game. After replaying it again a decade later, I looked into what other farm-sim type games are out there. I stumbled across Stardew Valley. This game is everything harvest moon could have been but so much better. I still can't believe it was created by just one person.

Let's start with the art - who the hell needs to buy an NFT? Just pop into SDV! The artwork in this game is beautiful, interesting, and very well balanced. Everything from the map to the character portraits. I used to be one of those pixel-art haters (don't judge, I've come around) and this game totally changed my mind.

The music is also perfect. It fits with the art style, the game themes and the season vibes. Not making this up, I sometimes put it on in my car when I drive to work because it puts me in the mood for earning money.

The character dialog is also well written and the characters themselves breathe life into the little mountain village.

Finally the gameplay. There's a lot to say about this but I'll try to keep it concise. First, my favorite thing is that there isn't anything that's missable and you aren't punished for not completing things right away. This is in stark contrast to HM64 where you're under constant time pressure to get the collectables before a certain date. SDV is deep but not overwhelming in terms of complexity. The gradual progression is easy enough to follow but still challenging enough if you're a maximalist. I'd call it a low-stress strategy game. Relaxing enough to end your IRL day with but interesting enough to still be engaging. The goals are more-or-less easy to understand so you always have something to aim at.

To summarize, this is one hell of a game and if you're looking for something relaxing I'd strongly recommend SDV. I can't believe that it only took one person to make one of the best games I've ever played. Bravo.

The most low-stress farming simulator with amazing world-building I have ever encountered. Must play at least once. TL;DR at end. 

There is pathing in the game for who you want to be with skills that reflect it, even with farm types. The community center is great for the first timers, but Joja Mart also works for those who despite Pierre for being closed on Wednesdays (the audacity I know).

All characters have a personality and life and dreams, despite being in a small town, they're happy for the community, but also wonder if city life is better. That doesn't matter as much to people like the Wizard who shows that the outside world has a rich history of wars, environments, and race (shadow people, dwarves) disputes. These hints are sprinkled throughout the game and really mentioned after completing the community center (either path), but it shows how much CARE was put into the smaller details. 

The marriage system is cute and amazing, especially because all characters have vastly different personalities and styles. Each person has their own hopes and dreams (and problems) so you can see they're not always perfect and happy (despite how they initially seem). Characters have depth and fleshed-out stories the more you increase your bond so you get to see them in happy and vulnerable moments. Of course, this only matters for people like me who read and enjoy the story. 

If you want to be silly, you can do so much with the game including your own challenges or picking up trash out of residents' trash cans (just try not to do it in front of them). Rather than the traditional route, you can do the game starting wherever you want (with some small restrictions for areas). There is freedom and more to the game the more you do and more you interact with NPCs. 

There is no pressure to be the best because exploring is at your own pace. I did use the wiki to remember things because I had seen so much content on YT beforehand, but that didn't diminish the experience but enhanced it because I wasn't running around giving people things that would make them hate me. 

TL;DR: Play the game already and marry emo, nerd Sebastian.

you should buy this because it's worth every penny. i was never the type to like "resource management" or "non-intense pvp" games until i played stardew. it's easy to write off as a minecraft, terraria-type game, but once you play it you realize the genius behind stardew. it has elements of roleplay, it allows you to be creative in a challenging way, and you have different events to look forward to year after year. yes, after awhile, it can get repetitive -- but that's where the mods come in. stardew is incredibly easy to use mods on. even if you get bored of playing vanilla stardew (you can explore other aspects of vanilla like the other farms, some challenges, adjust the money margin, etc. there's so much to do in this game and always not enough time, and i think that even if you stop playing this for years, it's not difficult to imagine you'd play it again.

This is a really fun, relaxing game where you grow a farm, catch fish, mine ore, and make friends in a comfy town full of memorable characters and packed full of secrets and things to discover. Fans of other chill games like Harvest Moon or Animal Crossing will likely feel right at home.

Despite it's fairly innocent appearance, there is tons to discover and do in this game. Besides the obvious task of restoring the farm and planting crops, there's animals to raise, items can be foraged from the wilderness around the town, fish to be caught, there's mines to explore and loot, and people to talk to and complete quests for. This game is also chocked full of new things to explore and secrets to discover as well, and it takes a very long time to discover and do everything this game has to offer. My only complaints are that fishing is a bit frustrating and tedious at times and the game becames a bit tedious at the end once almost everything is completed, as there isn't much to do other than collect money, but these were pretty minor parts of the entire experience.

The game has a delightful, charming, pixelated art style and great music. It also ran very well, and I only encountered a few minor bugs during my playthough.

This game also has a healthy modding community, with many quality-of-life, graphical, and gameplay mods available online. Modding this game is also extremely easy compared to many other games. I'd highly recommend checking out some mods if you decide to get this game! A useful guide on modding this game can be found [url=stardewvalleywiki.com/Modding:Player_Guide/Getting_Started]here[/url].

The game also supports local and online multiplayer. However, the experience in multiplayer isn't quite the same as it is in singleplayer, as some things clearly weren't designed for multiple people, so things like cutscenes don't always play for everyone, and there are numerous things that only the host of the world can actually do. However, it's still quite a bit of fun and worth trying. I'd just recommend playing it alone first to get the full experience.

[b]TL;DR[/b] This is a relaxing farming sim with tons of things to do and people to meet. Although there are a few things in the game that can be tedious (such as fishing or the late game), there's a ton of content and things to explore, the game looks great and runs well, it has a healthy modding community, and it has multiplayer. I'd highly recommend getting this game for anyone who's interesting in giving a casual farming sim a try.

Tis a great game, I have nothing but nice things to say about it. Except that they fixed the late night glitch so now you can't stay up forever but that is what mods are for. Even without modding or using glitches to summon items and just playing it all normal is fun and challenging. You grow crops, raise animals, make friends, get married, have kids, amass obscene wealth, become the hero of your town, eat maki rolls, and fight monsters lurking down in the caverns for loot. Such a well-rounded game reminding us what life could be like doing your own thing rather than giving your life away to a mega-corporation. Both options are available in this one, very unbiased. Similar in many ways to Graveyard Keeper which I also regard with high esteem.

This game is relevant to the Troubles, also known internationally as the Northern Ireland conflict, from 1968-1998. I won't comment much more in-depth on that because I live in relative comfort in Australia, but what I can grasp is that the world as a whole is moving closer to nationalism. With that being said, I give this game a perfect rating because it caused me to think. It had a strong impression on me, causing me to think about the meaning of the current state of what's happening in the world. Sure, I still have to get up & live my life but the truth is that we ALL have hurt someone or done worse but at the end of the day, it's realizing our mistakes & thinking about the effect it has on other people. I'm very aware that things arent that cut & dry but at the same time they really are. I enjoy a AU$56.95 of entertainment once in awhile to take my mind off things but this kind of game is getting harder to come across & deserves recognition. I've seen others comments about this game starting out slow & then ending with a bang or picking up....that's life. It welcomes you in & then spanks you. Last but not least, the graphics in this game are pretty damn good so in a nutshell, if your into games that provoke emotion layered with a historically based script & great graphics then this one is worth it. Enjoy.

I love this game. 

It has plenty to do and the multiplayer makes it even better. There's always something different for everyone to do.

Single player you can zone out and work on your farm without any rush. There are time sensitive missions (complete by the end of the day/end of the week) but you don't have to do them. I'm pretty sure even if you fail you can try again later.

But I really do recommend this game Multiplayer. It makes everything a lot easier and makes things go a lot more smoothly. While you can't get immersed like you can in single player, it means if you really hate doing something your friend loves - you're off the hook! Just make sure you have friends who pull their own weight.

Stardew Valley is an amazing game and I absolutely love it. It can be very relaxing but also very stressful depending on how you play it or think while going from day to day in game.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
1. You get to make your own character(obviously).

2. [spoiler]YOU GET TO CHOOSE WHAT PET YOU CAN HAVE!![/spoiler]

3. You get to choose what kind of farm you live on.

4. You get to choose which skills you build upon(i.e. foraging, fishing, fighting).

5. You get to decorate your farm by building and placing fences and paths as well as other things. Unfortunately, [spoiler]fences tend to rot and break, so you always have to make sure you have a high supply of them.[/spoiler]

6. You get to befriend the townsfolk, and even choose from a selection of men and women to romance...WHICH ALL OF THEM HAVE BACKSTORIES TO MAKE THEM SO MUCH MORE INTERESTING AND LOVABLE!!

7. You get to explore and earn rewards for helping the townsfolk and restoring the community.

8. You get to restore your farm and get resources at the same time.

9. You get the thrill - sometimes nuisance - of having to restore energy and health, and you can't stay up too late which can be a problem [spoiler]if you don't have one of the community upgrades or a totem that can teleport you anywhere based on the statue that you wish to travel to and you're in the mine or Skull Cavern. With restoring energy or health, it can be a hassle if you don't have much on you when you go to the mines. If you pass out in the mines, you lose everything you find there on that trip and sometimes more and you're taken to Harvey who charges you for a doctor visit or you will be found by Marlin, Demetrius, or Clint while they're in the mines for their own reasons, meanwhile if you pass out on your way home due to it being late, Linus or another townsperson will find you and tell you that they saw someone pick-pocketing you, so you lose money and some resources.[/spoiler]

10. In multiplayer mode, you can divide up tasks which could lessen the stress that one could possibly feel while playing Stardew Valley depending on their planning and time management.

Now I bet you're wondering why it can be stressful besides some of the very inconvenient scenarios that I've already stated, which happen to be due to poor planning or poor time management on the player's part. Well, trying to restore/build your farm while helping others, building the community, exploring to acquire resources, and romancing one of the bachelors/bachelorettes can be a lot, especially since [spoiler]even though it isn't stated directly in the beginning, you have 3 years before your grandpa's ghost appears and basically judges you on your work with the farm, community, and your personal life, which you do have a chance even after that to better yourself and finally lay his spirit to rest,[/spoiler] but some people can get very antsy at the idea after playing it once or [spoiler]seeing the note that grandpa leaves on his little altar the first time they play.[/spoiler] So nothing really is a "con," at least by description, since it's mostly based on how the players play, but it still bothers some people, myself included. Only because I'm terrible at time management and I don't always plan properly when I go exploring. XD

Otherwise it is an absolutely wonderful game that I absolutely adore!! <3

I am a 55 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 12 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I thought I'd escaped the pull of Stardew Valley. I'd downloaded it ages ago, played for 10 minutes, then shut it down for a couple years.

But then, I gave it another shot, as I was generally bored of the other games I had, it was too hot to enjoy the outdoors, and nothing good was on TV. And then I realized I'd played for an entire day. I mean, sunrise to sunset in the real world passed AND I WANTED TO KEEP PLAYING.

For such a basic, throwback game, it hits all the "oh, just a little longer" buttons. Just one more day and maybe you'll level up that skill. Just one more day and you'll be able to upgrade that tool. Just one more day and you'll be able to afford that building. Just one more day and you can finally buy that animal. Just one more day and maybe you'll reach the bottom of the cave. Just one more day and you'll be able to fill out that bundle.

It's repetitive, that's for sure. I'm not going to pretend that I load up a game thinking I'll do something new. But I'll happily boot up to let my mind wander while I fish, mine, farm, fight, and forage for hours on end.

Oh, and the icing on the cake? This game is weird. What on the surface seems super Normal Norman Rockwell pretty quickly spirals into David Lynch territory.

This game scratches a few different itches at once.

From the farming-sim angle alone, there is a yummy sense of reward. Varying kinds of rotating fruits/veggies to grow and sell, "number go up" and all that, supplemented by mining resources and monster loot, etc., are the best in any game that I've ever played. In fact, both during an after late-game, it's both engaging and relaxing gameplay. 

I've never much liked dating sims, but the relationship system was a good way to incorporate substance in the NPCs a little more than just buying recepies and such. Good writing that allows for loots of choices, and I really dig good writing.

At least a quarter of my logged hours are AFK, and this is because the game does not allow for spontaneous saving without 1)cutting the rest of the day short, or 2) losing that whole day's progress, RNG and all. The only option is to leave the game paused if I know I'll be back soon. Not to say the game isn't REALLY GOOD otherwise, just the save-function is irritating.

In Stardew Valley, you play as Walter Hartwell White, a man who has moved to a farm in Stardew Valley away from his family in Albuquerque, New Mexico. The game sets you free and allows you to create the meth lab of your dreams and get caught in tense gang violence. You will develop or sour relationships with fellow residents, build your methamphetamine empire, and even commit multiple homicides all while trying to get the local police off your trail. Recommend this game if your into chill, relaxed, felony committing gameplay.

Stardew Valley, is a game which you choose the depth you want to dive. It's a great little chill farm sim, fishing sim. rural town sim or whatever, but beyond that it's a game that can evolve and change with you and your play style. Its my comfort game. It's a game I play in my most depressive states and a game I play at my happiest times. It invokes the feelings of late nights of my childhood watching TV and feeling like nothing could ever go wrong, a feeling I've chased for years. Its just that kind of vibe. Will everyone jive with this, no, but its just what some of use need in this trying time.

I have played Stardew Valley for years both on PC and Switch. Its the only game I can play even when I don't feel like playing a game. I find it so relaxing and easy to pick up for an hour and put back down. PC gaming makes modding limitless but even vanilla, it is a perfect game. You can play it as quickly or slowly as you want. Don't get lost in 100%ing it on your first run. Just enjoy it. Explore, make friends, build your farm. There are hours and hours of game play and coop makes it more fun. If you are unsure, just try it. It might be a bit confusing at first if you've never seen anyone play it but make those mistakes on your first farm and try again.

One of my favorite games. I have purchased this multiple times across platforms and not regretted it once. I do recommend buying it on PC solely because of the mods you can add. The base game is wonderful as is, though. I was originally dismissive of the game but I am glad I gave it a try because it is such an amazing game. The main gameplay loop is farming, but you can also mine (with combat), fish, and forage. When playing co-op, you can have people specialize. Each day has a time limit of about 10 mins IRL, which easily leads to the "just one more day" loop and before you know it, it's 3 AM. You have a town of people to talk with and grow closer with as well. The game itself can be pretty long and there is a lot of content to get through. The sole creator and developer of the game put in a lot of love into this game and it shows. I look forward to their next game.

I forgot to write a review for this game so I thought I would do an honest review for once. This game is (for me anyway) one of the best ways to release stress. You can start at your own pace, you can just go fishing if you enjoy that, and you can grow friendships with the characters. Although the game is a very good stress reliever, there are two things that throw it off from just chilling all day. The cave system especially is very stressful and expect to die (A LOT!). Another thing is the way that growing crops works. If you are growing crops and they don't grow by the time the next season comes, you waste the crops and they shrivel up. Aside from that, the game is very good and it is super fun to play with friends!

i want to spend my whole life playing this game. the beauty of this game not only lies in the visuals but the experience it brings to the player through the music, the npc and player interactions, the many possibilities of how someone enjoys the game, etc. this game is very refreshing and relaxing. if this game were a physical thing in my hand, i would hug and squeeze it out of love and excitement. my love for this game goes beyond anything in the world, beyond barriers of any kind. i thank concernedape for making this game.
