Stardew Valley is one of those games I will never get tired of. It was the first game I was gifted with my first console, and I sunk hours into it on Xbox. When I left for college, I got a PC and finally got this game as a gift and I have put so many hours into it. I will never be tired of the characters, secrets, the ever expanding world, and the freedom I get to customize my farm. The music is iconic, the animals are cute, and the mysteries are always coming. I hope to cone day finish it 100%, but until then I will continue to play and have fun doing my daily chores and adventures. Thank you, Concerned Ape, for making this amazing game!

I am a 41 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 11 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

You can never really go wrong with a farming/life sim. Throw in mining, combat, and lively townspeople, this game honestly is one of my favorite games of all time (i have more hours on my Switch as well). I don't think I can think of anything negative to say about this game, seriously, this game is like perfect! Music in the game is relaxing, art style of the game is pleasing, mining & combat system is engaging and exciting, and building friendships with the people of Pelican Town is fun! The game even has "missions" you can complete to get farther in the story of the game. AND there's requests from the towns people that you can do, complete those requests for materials, money and gain friendship points to the person you help with said request. ALWAYS something to do. Raising cute farm animals is very fulfilling also, just a great game. Highly recommend to anyone who likes cozy games.

This game is incredible. I have only played for such a short time, but the time I have put into this game truly makes it an incredible experience. Nearly every aspect in this game makes it a great experience, full of probably up to 200 hours of gameplay. Games like Stardew Valley are not games I frequent, but the incredible experience this game has to offer is unmatched with anything I have been able to find on the market to date. The graphics are beautiful, with loads of colour in each one, truly giving the town a beautiful vibrant atmosphere. The season system is also great, as it forces you to change up what you do for every season, which adds to the incredible immersion this game has on offer. I am ashamed in myself that I had not played this game sooner. However, the game does get somewhat repetitive after a while. But I say with great confidence that this is no reason the not get the game. I have and will continue to reccomend this to anyone I know. 9/10

It combines everything I like about Minecraft, Animal Crossing, and Terraria; while still maintaining its own unique feel. The main story revolves around inheriting a farm, but there is much more to this game than just farming crops and raising livestock. I thought I would be intimidated by how quickly time passes in this game, but I found that I was still able to do my daily "chores" and still have time to do other things (forraging, mining, fishing, etc).

10/10 Why didn't I buy this sooner?

I have been playing the game since it came out. 

My phases of playing it have come and gone over the years but I ALWAYS come back to it, normally for a few months at a time. 

Despite playing since it first released, I'm always finding new things. It is a delightful experience alone and I've had even more fun playing with my friends. It brings back all the joy and curiosity of playing Harvest Moon as a little kid. The community for this game is also amazing-- mods keep it fresh (even though the base game doesn't need much to keep me engaged even after all this time).

In all, it's one of the best games I have ever played and is extremely impressive for a one man dev team...really excited for their next game : )

If you don't like this game then you don't pass the vibe check.
If you like this game then you know it is addictive like meth. Seriously. 

I say just enjoy the game and go at your own pace, no one is forcing you to do anything but yourself. When and if you start a new game, it's always about being better than last time or it can just be a chill playthrough, you decide that. Plan your days accordingly, you can't do everything in one day or you will burn out in real life. 

Endgame is worth it in my opinion, you really feel a sense of progression throughout the game. At first the time limit, energy and exploration are overwhelming, but you get used to it, as I said go at your speed and don't compare yourself to others. 

The world record for the community center is like 2h30 or something, And a perfection speedrun was done in less than 24 hours, so yeah.. Don't push yourself if you don't have the knowledge or will yet, focus on learning, either on your own or by watching guides or etc. Learn new tricks and apply them. That's how you should play but honestly do whatever you wish, it's a sandbox. 
The really good stuff is kinda tedious to get, that is if you even get to the endgame. You thought it was easy? *laughs in Mr. Qi*

I must admit, I'm unsure why but I never really got into this game when I first bought it. Fast forward four years, a bunch of Wand of Sparking videos about it, and three of my buddies having a blast playing it, I decided I'd give it a faithful shot. Not because anything about it put me off or seemed uninteresting, but because I guess I never really got into it - What a mistake that was not to try it sooner!

This game is great! It's relaxing, the artstyle is wonderful (even though it's in my personal taste that I dislike how bright the colors are, a saturation option might exist but I'd have to check), and the gameplay is just perfect. As I describe it to anyone I'm telling about it: "It's Harvest Moon on steroids."

Another thing: I'm so used to saying "developers" when I'm talking about games. One of my buddies corrected me there, it's just ONE GUY who made this! Isn't that cool!? He had some help on some of the final stages (especially multiplayer support which is hell so that is totally understandable), but that's still amazing and this game is just a blast overall.

Progression, content, fun, likeable characters, it's all there. 9/10 I highly recommend! (No 10/10 because I try not to rate anything 10/10, no perfect game can exist but this one is the most defining of a genre so that's as close as you can get to being there!)

P.S. I know I have all five of the money achievements and that's because monkey me cheated in 2018 so I'm going to get perfection someday as an apology to ConcernedApe, this game is lovely!
P.S.S Everyone in my group who plays this (including myself) crushes on Leah lol

As of writing this review I've played this game for 121 hours across pc, xbox, and switch. I cannot recommend any game more highly than I can this. I picked this game up when I was at a point in my life where playing countless rpgs, action, adventure games had drained me of my will to play games at all. I felt addicted to my phone, mindlessly scrolling through various social media platforms consuming as much media in every form I could manage. 

I downloaded this game as a whim with some birthday money during the summer, and immediately felt excited to play a game again. I was drawn into an experience that felt hand crafted to enrapture me. Over the course of sixty hours on a single file I absorbed everything I could about Pelican Town and the Valley, and it left me craving for more. I purchased the game on on switch so I could play a multiplayer file with friends long distance, and I enjoyed every moment of this novel experience. I most recently purchased it here on steam so that I can begin to explore a whole new part of the Stardew Valley experience, the community of people playing it.

An even more handcrafted experience exists in community created mods, that alter the very essence of the game. No longer are you engaging in dialogue with ConcernedApe's characters, but those of countless others who experienced just what I have and who sought to create that again for someone else. I'd argue that this game all about community is heightened by the newfound community of players and modders I have discovered. To summarize my feelings about this game, please, if you want to engage in one of the friendliest communities around, and interact with and explore what it means to be part of a community, please purchase and play this game.

This is the kind of game that really makes you expect more from AAA studios. It's sometimes hard to believe that this was created in its entirety by a single man working all alone on his passion project, but here it is.

The game is engaging, polished, and an example of how something doesn't need to be super flashy in order to be immersive. This is why I fell in love with games to begin with. What a triumph from a once-in-a-generation, incredibly gifted developer. 

I can't wait to see what he does next. If you are waffling on buying this game, just get it. It's worth every penny and I'm sure you have spent more on less, if you have bought any AAA title in the last few years.

Farming sim (2D)

This a pretty neat game cause there's a lot of different ways to play it. Do you want it to be a simple relaxing game or do you want to get into the nitty-gritty of optimising your farm and maximising profits? Stardew caters to quite a wide range of play styles. There's also a lot you can do in making your farm yours with customisation and decorations, as well as the different farm layouts.

Also you can get a wife or husband. Really the selling point of the game in my opinion.

This game is literally how you find the partner of your life or how to find wholesome friends. I literally spend so much time trying to build flower gardens in all my saves every season no matter what, you get a cute 8 bit style game, so much to do, mods that expand gameplay or make it easier, villagers that you can interact with, multiplayer where you can joking fight your friends on who gets to married first. you name it its there. Honestly this game is so much more fun with someone else to play with so like if you have friends and bunch of free time get your friends in and play with them!
Very relaxing, amazing for just wanting a game to chill out.

HOW TO MAKE A CHOCOLATE LAYER CAKE
GATHER YOUR INGREDIENTS
Cake
12 tablespoons unsalted butter (1 1/2 sticks), very soft, plus extra for greasing pans
1 ¾ cups unbleached all-purpose flour (8 3/4 ounces), plus extra for dusting pans
4 ounces unsweetened chocolate, coarsely chopped
¼ cup Dutch-processed cocoa (3/4 ounce)
½ cup hot water
1 ¾ cups sugar (12 1/4 ounces)
1 ½ teaspoons baking soda
1 teaspoon table salt
1 cup buttermilk
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
4 large eggs
2 large egg yolks

Frosting
16 ounces semisweet chocolate, finely chopped
8 tablespoons unsalted butter (1 stick)
⅓ cup sugar
2 tablespoons corn syrup

INSTRUCTIONS
FOR THE CAKE: Adjust oven rack to middle position; heat oven to 350 degrees. Grease two 9-inch-round by 2-inch-high cake pans with softened butter; dust pans with flour and knock out excess. Combine chocolate, cocoa powder, and hot water in medium heatproof bowl; set bowl over saucepan containing 1 inch of simmering water and stir with rubber spatula until chocolate is melted, about 2 minutes. Add 1/2 cup sugar to chocolate mixture and stir until thick and glossy, 1 to 2 minutes. Remove bowl from heat and set aside to cool.

2
Whisk flour, baking soda, and salt in medium bowl. Combine buttermilk and vanilla in small bowl. In bowl of standing mixer fitted with whisk attachment, whisk eggs and yolks on medium-low speed until combined, about 10 seconds. Add remaining 1 1/4 cups sugar, increase speed to high, and whisk until fluffy and lightened in color, 2 to 3 minutes. Replace whisk with paddle attachment. Add cooled chocolate mixture to egg/sugar mixture and mix on medium speed until thoroughly incorporated, 30 to 45 seconds, pausing to scrape down sides of bowl with rubber spatula as needed. Add softened butter one tablespoon at a time, mixing about 10 seconds after each addition. Add about one-third of flour mixture followed by half of buttermilk mixture, mixing until incorporated after each addition (about 15 seconds). Repeat using half of remaining flour mixture and all of remaining buttermilk mixture (batter may appear separated). Scrape down sides of bowl and add remaining flour mixture; mix at medium-low speed until batter is thoroughly combined, about 15 seconds. Remove bowl from mixer and fold batter once or twice with rubber spatula to incorporate any remaining flour. Divide batter evenly between prepared cake pans; smooth batter to edges of pan with spatula.

3
Bake cakes until toothpick inserted into center comes out with a few crumbs attached, 25 to 30 minutes. Cool cakes in pans 15 minutes, then invert onto wire rack. Cool cakes to room temperature before frosting, 45 to 60 minutes.

4
TO MAKE FROSTING: Melt chocolate in heatproof bowl set over saucepan containing 1 inch of barely simmering water, stirring occasionally until smooth. Remove from heat and set aside. Meanwhile, heat butter in small saucepan over medium-low heat until melted. Increase heat to medium; add sugar, corn syrup, vanilla, and salt and stir with heatproof rubber spatula until sugar is dissolved, 4 to 5 minutes. Add melted chocolate, butter mixture, and cream to clean bowl of standing mixer and stir to thoroughly combine.

5
Place mixer bowl over ice bath and stir mixture constantly with rubber spatula until frosting is thick and just beginning to harden against sides of bowl, 1 to 2 minutes (frosting should be 70 degrees). Place bowl on standing mixer fitted with paddle attachment and beat on medium-high speed until frosting is light and fluffy, 1 to 2 minutes. Stir with rubber spatula until completely smooth.

6
TO FROST CAKE: Place one cake layer on serving platter or cardboard round. Spread 1 1/2 cups frosting evenly across top of cake with spatula. Place second cake layer on top, then spread remaining frosting evenly over top and sides of cake. Cut into slices and serve.

Stardew valley is one of the most calming games I have ever played. It is one of two games I consider a comfort game of mine, as it really helps ground me. The game graphics are cute and niche with a pixel style. Stardew also doesn't follow a certain time frame for how the game progresses. You are allowed to do many different things as your character and are not required to do certain activities on certain days (though some events and activities are highly recommended :)). Stardew valley gives the player a freedom to explore a new town while also meeting new people and trying new things.

I am totally new to Stardew Valley. This game is like they took pokemon, animal crossing and minecraft and mooshed it together into one game. I love all three of those games so this is perfect. I love all the different things you can find, farm, mine and craft. I instantly got addicted to this game and NEED to play it every day for at least a little bit. (Sometimes meaning SEVERAL hours) Although the in game days go by rather quickly, I suppose it helps keep the excitement high because you have to be decisive and focused. Especially if you plan to spend the day mining. Anyways this game is great fun, I love coming back and seeing my plants growing, also getting deeper in the mine, leveling up my character and collecting things for the community center. 

P.S. Fishing is WAY harder than Animal Crossing. Good Luck!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

This game is fun. This game has a vibe to it that many other games like it don't have. It's hard to explain what a vibe is but this game has it.  

The main issues I have with the game are quality of life issues. (Which most if not all can be fixed with mods) For example, because of how short days are sometimes you don't have enough time the first day of a new season(Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter) to re-hoe/till the land, plant seeds, and water. Which can be the difference of getting an extra harvest and ton of money. This is the case even with iridium upgrades. This is simplified! It goes deeper then this. Which I don't feel like detailing. Best to play without mods and discover what those quality of life issues are for you and mod from there which is very easy. 

FYI this applies to each harvest besides the re-hoeing and maybe watering if you have sprinklers 

More examples is poor map quality/clarity/accuracy and NPC locations on map, The lack of Harvesting tool like harvesting with the Scythe(it's manual unless you have a certain hut as far as I know)

Best farming simulator so far! There are so many aspects of the game which makes it unique. Not only can you tend your farm and grow crops, but you also have a variety of customizations for the layout of your farm, house, barn etc. The sandbox feature just makes this game stand out among others.
200+ hours into this game, and it could have been endless.  Love to play with my partner.  Will probably come back.

So, if you plant exactly 1 cauliflower, 1 potato and 1 green bean alongside as many parsnips as you can, then sell all but 1 parsnip and plant potatoes with the money made, you'll be able to easily buy 20 strawberry seeds by the 13th. Cauliflowers take 12 days to grow, you begin the game on the 1st so they'll be done by the 13th. You need 1 cauliflower, 1 green bean, 1 potato and 1 parsnip to complete the spring farming bundle, which rewards 20 speed-gro. Speed-gro allows 1 extra harvest of strawberries if they're planted on the 13th (aka when you purchase them). This raises your gold profits from 2944 gold to 5415. This is not counting farming levels or tiller profession, and assumes you're selling them raw. And if you can keep some strawberries to transform into seeds once for spring year 2, then each seed with a basic speed-gro will give you a profit of 756 gold (again, not counting farming levels, professions or transforming the strawberries into artisan goods).

I don't know how I managed to play this game well over 100 hours. A farming sim with pixel graphics is about the last game I ever thought I'd enjoy but for $5 I figured I might as well give it a try. 

The progression once you get your farm going and start working towards consistent income is pretty addicting. I can't tell you how many times during a play session I said 1 more day and then ended up playing 5 more because I always felt like I had a goal I needed to finish. The fishing mini game is also oddly satisfying and it's mechanics make it feel more rewarding than fishing in some other sim games (think animal crossing).

I also assumed that given there was no spoken dialogue, this would be a game to play with a podcast or video going on the 2nd monitor. I ended up almost never doing that because this game has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard. Each theme somehow perfectly fits the season or location and really does add to the experience.

I've played Stardew Valley for one-and-a-quarter in-game years and I've enjoyed every bit of the experience.

You've probably seen the trailer — Stardew Valley is a life and farming simulator game, similar to the Animal Crossing series etc.
You're starting a new life as a farmer in Stardew Valley and you grow crops, decorate your farm, go fishing, go mining, go foraging, craft items (similar to Minecraft), and interact with NPCs and become friends by carrying out favors, among other activities. [spoiler]Apparently you also get to marry someone and have kids![/spoiler]
Of note is that the game runs on its own daily/yearly cycle, independent of the actual date and time of your system clock, where the calendar is divided into four seasons instead of twelve months (28 days per season), each season offering seasonal events, varying crop availability, and other awesome stuff.

There's a lot to like about it. Fun gameplay, beautiful graphics, refreshing atmosphere, nice music. I don't think there's anything I've disliked about it so far... I just want to keep playing the game more and more.

Just buy it. I promise, you will love Stardew Valley.

Stardew Valley is probably the most addicting game I have ever played. The first 10 or so hours can be a little daunting, but once you get in the groove and realize what goals you want to accomplish first then those 10 hours quickly become 100 hours. 

There is a little bit of everything in this game from farming (mainly about plot organization and time management), fishing, dungeon exploring, and even a little dating. Game is very relaxing with short bursts energy, like when you all of a sudden find yourself on a dungeon floor with like 30 enemies.
Fun game. Great with friends or alone.
its good

Stardew Valley is relaxing, has lovely story telling, and lets you play how you'd like. I've played multiple save files and have enjoyed myself each time. 

The one thing I would caution is that it can be a little overwhelming in how much freedom you're given at the start, so if you're brand new to the game, I'd recommend watching some videos to get an idea of what you can do. 

Don't let that dissuade you, though, because once you get a rhythm going you're sure to have a good time.

One of my favorite games of all time. I have nothing but praise for this game. Gorgeous pixel graphics and a super catchy soundtrack that never gets old. Fun and unique gameplay mechanics. The ability to take things at your own pace whilst also feeling like there’s always something more for you to do. Amazing post game that adds hours to the game that was added in a FREE UPDATE. Super easy modding support that quadruples the lifespan of the game. Tons of ways to improve your experience even after your third or fourth time playing the game. Update added the ability to decorate outside of your house, so if youre like me and love decorating that’s an added bonus.  Well worth the money and then some. This game could be $60+ and I’d still recommend it. 
Main downsides would be that if you’re playing vanilla, once you reach the monumentous task of perfection, the gameplay gets a little stale. Also festivals really are an early game thing that has very little impact or variation later on. You can play the game as long as you want, but everything after perfection is a little aimless. Still, I’d highly recommend this game. An absolute classic that almost everyone, regardless of age or gaming experience, could enjoy.

Stardew Valley is incredibly engaging, I regularly forget what time it is irl when playing. There is much to discover and many different things to do, you can both follow the red thread by fulfilling the quests, but you can also completely ignore them and just free-play. Having the option to do both farmer and adventure style is very nice. The accompanying music fits well and is pleasant to listen to.
If I need to find something negative it would be that the NPCs are sometimes difficult to find when you want to end or hand in a (re)quest.

Stardew Valley
Developed by ConcernedApe
Published by ConcernedApe

In honour of my fiancé’s birthday, a review of something we enjoy play together.

Stardew Valley starts with the premise of a farming sim. Your character is burnt out on city life and moves to their grandfather’s old farm which they inherited. In theory, your job is to rebuild the farm and build your life in the community. In reality, there’s so much more than just watering and harvesting crops.

The first major sub-plot is the war between Joja Co and the small town. The corporation doesn’t give a shit about who they trample in their quest to make money (sound familiar?), and are perfectly happy to drive local general store owner Pierre out of business. They also care not one whit for the local environment. You have the choice between restoring the Community Centre and helping the town to thrive again, or buying a Joja Co membership and just focusing on making money.

Apart from making money with farming though, you have a lot of different options for how to spend your time in Stardew Valley. Want to go digging in the mines for rare ores and gems? Go for it. Want to combat monsters in the mines (or on your farm if you chose the right one)? Easy. Want to set up a winery on your farm and sell excellent booze? The locals will love it! How about going  fishing and catching all the available fish? Got you covered with a fishing mechanic which is far from the worst I’ve seen. And more: cooking, crafting, raising animals, befriending all of the villagers, getting married and having kids… so many options. There’s even a combined library and museum to fill up with artifacts found while digging, mining and fishing.

For a long time in farming sim type games with romance aspects, players could only be heterosexual. In this, pretty much everyone’s a bisexual disaster. Okay, not really, but it doesn’t matter what configuration of genitals is present in regards to relationships. The only thing that matters is whether a biological pregnancy can take place, or if you use an adoption agency. In addition, you select whether your character is male or female at the start of the game but can then make them look like whatever you please - whether that’s male, female, androgynous, or a duck-faced alien. Before the latest big update, there was even basic polyamory - you could date everyone and no one cared, but marrying meant that you had chosen that one partner. Unfortunately that has been changed and now it’s inadvisable to date everyone at once. Please ConcernedApe, let me have my bisexual polyamorous disasters back!

There is, of course, even more to the game than these basics.  I have over 750 hours spent in-game and I still haven’t explored everything. Even better, more is constantly being developed - and the game continues to update for free. This game is a true labour of love and is in turn loved by the community.

The graphics of Stardew Valley are very fitting. It’s a sweet style reminiscent of old-school Harvest Moon, but still unique. The music is also soft and beautiful, and lively when called for. I love everything about the aesthetic chosen for this game.


In all, I love Stardew Valley. It’s been a comfort game for years now, something that I will always return to. For single-player I prefer my PC version as there are some mods that I really love (is base-game vodka making too much to ask for?), but playing co-op via Switch is a bonding activity that I love. Our pets love it too - cuddle time with the whole family!

Top 5 Pros:
- Decent fishing mini-game
- Can be any sexual orientation (having no romance is a valid option)
- Many different viable playstyles
- High replayability
- Great split-screen co-op

Top 5 Cons:
- Combat is very basic
- Very little racial diversity
- Poly option was taken out
- Saving only once per day even in single-player (WHY do games do this???)
- Events happening every year can get very repetitive

Would I recommend?
Between my fiancé and I, we own at least 5 copies. Yes I recommend, on whatever platform you like best.

(More game reviews at www.quirkyandcute.com.au)

If you're feeling stressed and overwhelmed from the real world. Just dive into Pelican Town and you"ll forget all of your problems.

On the surface, Stardew Valley is a game about farming, but there are more adventures awaiting curious players beyond cultivating a rich and bountiful garden. From mining and fishing to making friends and falling in love, Stardew Valley's Pelican Town is stuffed with rewarding opportunities. As modern day woes give way to pressing matters on the farm and within your newfound community, Stardew Valley's meditative activities often lead to personal reflection in the real world. It’s a game that tugs at your curiousity as often as it does your heart.

Your journey begins in the field, cleaning up a neglected and rundown farm. Plotting and planning your garden requires care and attention to detail. What fruits and vegetables do you grow? How much room does each plant need? How do you protect your crops from nature's troublemakers? You learn through practice, and while the basics are easy to grasp, you quickly need to figure out the best way to outfit your budding farm with new tools and equipment.

Upgrades help speed up essential tasks like tilling the earth and watering your plants, but advanced equipment becomes a necessity when the time comes to break down large rocks and stumps that stick out in your garden. The crafting menu also entices you with optional time-saving tools; automated sprinklers that water the crops every morning, artisan equipment to make preserves or beer out of your harvest, and refineries, such as a furnace for turning ore into metal bars. If you want something, you can make it, you just have to scour your environment for the necessary components. As your farm improves, you gain the ability to raise livestock. Animals are expensive to buy and maintain, and the barn they live in isn’t cheap either. You start small, with a barn just big enough for a few chickens and ducks. But if you run an efficient and bountiful garden, you can eventually afford to upgrade to a bigger barn and keep hearty livestock like pigs, cows and sheep.

You have to feed your stock every day, which can get expensive, but they will eventually begin to produce eggs, milk and other rewards for all your hard work. Beyond their monetary value, animals are simply endearing to be around. Give them a name and work a little petting time into your routine; before you know it, your commodities have become your friends. Like your crops, the goodies livestock produce give you a sense of accomplishment, but their companionship is a different yet equally valuable reward.

When your farm is healthy and your equipment set, Stardew Valley opens up and your routine expands: after you water your plants, feed your animals and tidy up in the morning, you get to head out in search of adventure and friendship. There’s a mine north of Pelican Town with a seemingly endless bounty of buried treasure, but also danger. Combat is simple--a plain swipe of a sword will brush back most common monsters--but the dangers you face grow as you delve deeper into the mine, pushing your basic tactics to the limit.

There’s a risk/reward relationship to seeking out valuable treasure, as it becomes increasingly more difficult to defend yourself from procedurally generated creatures the deeper you go. You hit checkpoints--in the form of elevator stops--every few floors, which both encourages you to keep going and to return in the future in search of grander rewards as checkpoints allow you to skip past the mine's early levels. The precious gems you find can be sold for profit, donated to a museum that will conduct and share research, or simply hoarded in a chest to be fawned over down the road.

When you grow weary of toiling underground, you can also spend time fishing on lakes, streams and coastal beaches. Fishing in Stardew Valley is straightforward--you use one button to reel in a fish and let go when the line is tense--but it gives you a chance to soak in your surroundings and experience the joys of catching a wide array of fish unique to specific seasons and locations. It’s a calming experience at sunset after a long day that gives you a chance to reflect on your progress and daydream about adventures to come.

Stardew Valley constantly encourages you to explore, be it mining, foraging for fruit in the woods, or collecting seashells, and your curiosity is amply rewarded. Every hidden area you find, every train track you follow, leads to new sights and discoveries that add detail and color to the world around you. Yet as fulfilling as farming and exploring are, visiting Pelican Town's community center pulls you ever deeper into your new life. Like your farm at the beginning of the game, the community center needs a little attention at first: you’re sent out on fetch quests to gather the necessary materials to fuel its reconstruction.

Outside of the community center, the rest of Pelican Town's inhabitants also need your help. In working together to achieve small goals, you grow to understand your neighbors' personalities and identify what makes them tick. Some are pursuing their hopes and dreams, while others fight day to day to overcome personal obstacles; others are quirky creatures of habit that round out the community's overall identity.

Relationships are gauged by a heart meter, and getting to a certain number of hearts results in a cutscene that offer a closer look into your new friends' lives. Offering gifts and completing tasks from a board in the center of town are easy ways to increase your connections, and slowly but surely you’re allowed in the inner circle of people’s otherwise private lives. You may befriend a father named Kent who’s dealing trauma after years at war. He’s working on his temper and trying to bond with his child after being away from home. The child, whom you meet in hiding in his parent's basement, is quiet and introverted. But when you put the time in to get to know him, he reveals that he actually doesn't mind being alone, even though he believes that he's at odds with his parents. These personal moments are touching, and encourage you to spend more time getting to know the people around you.

And if you decide to enter Pelican Town's dating scene, don't be surprised if you end up with butterflies in your stomach. Giving your crush the right gift and seeing the joy on their face makes you genuinely happy, but you have to put yourself out there first. Sure, working with townsfolk in general is a good way to understand the ins and outs of potential suitors, but no amount of preparation diminishes the impact of anxiously delivering a heartfelt gesture. Because you've invested so much time and energy into forging relationships, you get nervous when you expose your feelings, regardless of the fact that you're courting a pixelated crush. Through strong writing and characterization, Stardew Valley stirs up surprising feelings: when your date shares his umbrella in the rain, you know he's the one.

My best friend described this game as 'cosy', and I couldn't agree more. It is so wholesome and lovely. The soundtrack is almost my favourite thing about it, as it matches the seasons and gets even better in the mines, which houses my equal favourite gaming music.

It somehow doesn't make you feel like you need to progress in game; you could try to mine as quickly as possible, own animals as quickly as possible or make the most amount of money as quickly as possible... but if you wanted to you could just take whatever time you have and have your own bubble of joy and beauty. You also don't feel as though you're missing out by choosing different dialogue options or career paths. It's one of the very few games I've played that I've somehow become really immersed and have just focussed on what I've wanted to focus on, without doing tedious daily tasks or risk missing out on rewards. 

The 1.5 Update added so much content and QOL changes, I feel like I've only started, but am living my best life whenever I turn the game on. It is an absolute delight. 10/10

After devoting 680 hours to Animal Crossing: New Horizons, I was a little anxious to pick up Stardew Valley and see how the two would compare. Once I purchased Stardew, I couldn't put it down for 2 weeks straight. I can confidently say that both games serve their own unique purpose and are both worthy of playing for different reasons.

Your life in Stardew will quickly develop as you plant more crops, build more farm buildings, upgrade your tools, and become more friendly with the townspeople. The game gives the player clear objectives and rewards in a somewhat predictable (like the time it takes to turn milk into cheese) but satisfying (end of the day sales numbers) way. There's only so much time in a day however, and as you unlock more of your game, you'll start to maximize the hours in your day to fill it with harvesting, gifting, and exploring outside the valley. The changing seasons and special events keep the player engaged and there are SO many secrets across the game to be uncovered. The soundtrack is absolutely perfect and pairs wonderfully with the charming pixel art design of the valley and its characters.

Every single part of this game was developed by ONE MAN which makes every detail even more impressive and he deserves every sale. Do not think of pirating this game because I will find you. Even if this game was $50, it would still be worth it. I play Animal Crossing when I want to chill in real time talking to cute animals and arranging furniture in a house. I play Stardew Valley when I want to grind, harvesting on the farm in the morning, foraging in the forest, desert or island during the day, and decompressing with the townspeople at the local pub at night. For anyone who enjoys sim/ farming games-- no, even if you DON'T like them, this one is 100% worth a buy and deserves a spot in your library stat!

Had a couple hundred hours on the Switch version, and decided to get the Steam version to play with a couple friends of mine, a decision I would not regret. 
It was fun as hell to just boot up Stardew Valley every now and then and just fuck around with friends, planning out specific things, like having one person tend to crops and dealing with debris on the farm, while the other is off fishing, in order to maximize profit, while also trying to gather everything for the Community Center as quick as possible. 
Even without friends to play Stardew Valley with, the game has a lot to do when playing solo. For one, the plot is thicker than Boston's North end on Jan. 15th 1919. Every Character has a plethora of interactions that take place after bonding a large amount with said Character, which is done by gifting specific items to specific NPCs, said information can be uncovered by interacting with specific things, like digging through dirt and finding a missing book, speaking to other NPCs, or through literally just playing the game. (No seriously, your bound to run into TONS of stuff, no matter what you're doing, or where.)
And if you're not too into becoming deeply immersed in the story, the game-play is great too. There's a ton of stuff to do like mining, smelting, fishing, tending to crops, taking care of animals, crafting items to make specific tasks easier, or if you're like me, spending absurd amounts of time making ludicrous amounts of crab traps to get unreasonable amounts of snails.
I would ABSOLUTELY recommend Stardew Valley, it's an overall incredible experience, with large amounts of things to do, it's stupid fun to play when I have spare time.

TL;DR When bored, I boot up funny farming game, because it's fun.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Stardew Valley is a game that will live in my heart for eternity. Even years after I stop playing it. 
In this game there is truly something for everyone. There's aspects of romance, farming, grinding, puzzle, adventure, combat, and some of the most immaculate storytelling I've ever seen in a game. The character development in this game is better than many movies I've seen. It's simple and relaxing for those who want a calm and peaceful experience but challenging and angering for those who haven't touched grass in ages. On the topic of non-grass touchers, you can experience talking to a woman for the first time. 
When I bought this game I expected a simple farming experience. I usually love fast paced challenges, but I began playing this as a break, or a getaway. It began as just that. However, especially in the newest (1.5) update, there's more frustrating and mind-wrinkling minigames. Despite this, if you want a simpler time, you could spend time with your spouse or your children. Maybe go around and talk to people. Give gifts, forage for fruits, dive into the mines, etc. 
There's different styles of playing. Decorate your farm, befriend the town, produce artisan goods such as wine, cheese, and jelly, etc. The game gives you two different options for early-middle game progression. Bring the town together by giving mysterious creatures various items that they request, with the end goal of repairing various necessities such as a bridge to a quarry, a bus to a desert, or the big prize, a community center for the town. Or you could side with the mighty corporations, and turn the wrecked community center into a warehouse, and pay money in order to repair the earlier mentioned bus and bridge.
Various events, many of which play off on real world holidays, bring the town together and introduce exclusive shops and minigames for the character.
Maybe you could bring the real family together in a co-op farm.
If I haven't convinced you, you can download mods that heavily expand the game. Maybe you can increase the quality of living with automation or tractors.
All of this resulting in what will likely remain for a long time as my favorite game. All made by one man. So, please, I usually don't just blatantly ask this, but buy this game. Support the creator and all of his current and future endeavors. Believe me, you will not regret it.

A simple, chilling farming game with a good story plot that is full of character development. There are also other activities besides farming, such as foraging, fishing, mining, crafting, cooking. The weather system is lively. It's a fun process trying to get to know the people of the village.

I honestly thought this was a childish game until I got playing with some online friends. I was thinking Nintendo farm game, which I am not into, I am more of a racing/off-road gamer, but this game is SOOOO relaxing, I mean, if you got nothing to do you just go fish. Could you want more? Well, there is a bar, you can get buzzed on coffee or booze, your choice.

In the end, I think that this game actually blended enough content to keep adults entertained, like dating, trying to get married, having a family and just wanting to make as much cash as possible. 

The single player game is a grind, I mean a grind! With three ppl we've made it to yr 2 have so much stuff on the farm, and its growing each time we log on. 

Issues: random disconnection when in multiplayer, weird transition lines when walking around, v-sync, graphics all where they should be, nothing I have found fixes the issue.

There are multiple different goals provided by the game, or you can set goals for yourself. There's no set ending, or "true ending," which makes Stardew Valley excellent for long term play. There is a plethora of variables that will change the game experience, so you can play over and over again to explore different options.

I have never heard of Stardew Valley before but it had suddenly gotten really big when it had an update after not having one for several years, and it was cheap so of course I had to check it out. I didn’t think I was going to like it because it was very pixilated and I was used to more 2D games, but it was a farming RPG so I wanted to give it a shot and I have to say that I loved it. It’s so simple in design and you can’t really see the details in your character, but it didn’t bother me after a while. I spent most of my first year just figuring things out because there are no instructions. It really immerses you in what is actually happening because when you get to a farm, do you automatically know what to do? No. And that is what the whole experience is for. To put you in the shoes of your character. So I really had to find things out as I went and it got easier the further along I got.

If you're looking for single-player game that you can play at your own pace, this is the one. I'm a big fan of sim games and this scratches that itch while being so much more than just a city or village builder. You get to design your home and surrounding area however you please, while forming relationships with the people in town and uncovering secrets and much more all around. There's a lot to discover and the developer clearly cares about his fans and works tirelessly to keep the game updated and put some new things in every once in a while. Can't recommend this game highly enough.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

While Animal Crossing New Horizons and Stardew Valley are both amazing games for rest and relaxation, what sets these two games apart is the freedom of pacing yourself. In Animal Crossing, many things are time gated in real time such as building a bridge or gaining new residents. This directly limits how much a player is able to play in a given day. This cycle eventually causes said game to feel forced and repetitive to the point which causes the game to feel more like a chore to play. In comparison Stardew Valley's time system can be controlled via in game sleeping. This means that time based objectives such as upgrading a tool or growing crops are much more in control of the player. On top of everything, Stardew valley has a much better way of creating goals for the player to reach, from conquering the Mines and Skull cavern, to completing the Community Center, exploring Ginger Island, to finally True Perfection. The Music, Art style, Characters and large variety of content all created by one man alone (Eric Barone) ultimately fascinates me as to how a masterpiece can be created from the ground up.

I have over 100 hours in this game combining both the Xbox and Steam version. Over those 100+ hours I have gone through many characters, friendships, and story choices in this game.

There are so many pros to this game, stellar 2D graphics, an amazing sound design and soundtrack, a brilliant story with so many different directions, both in the positive and negative based on your actions, not just for the main story, but also the side stories, character development, and even your own character's character arc if you decide to do one. The game-play is easy to understand and is never gets stale since there's so many different things you can do in just a single day. The amount of content and easter eggs is truly astounding and just adds to the overall enjoyment of Stardew Valley, after playing for so long on both PC and Xbox there is still so many things I haven't seen or done, which gives it such a great replay value. Character progression in terms of in-game skills is also varied, allowing you to go for whatever you want, or maxing them all out, truly becoming the best farmer the valley has ever seen.

I don't really have many cons for Stardew Valley. My two main ones (even then they are still minor with in game ways to make it less annoying) are as followed. My biggest issue is that fishing is extremely busted in terms of making money, many times there isn't a reason to really do anything else like farming, foraging, or mining other than doing the missions given out and to upgrade your farm. Although a counterpoint is that any profession can make you ludicrous amounts of money, but fishing is by far the easiest, and quickest way to make a lot of cash in the game, especially in the first year of the game. My other main issue is clothing, excluding hats, the only way to get new clothing once you pick your set of clothes for your character (as far as I am aware) is by using a sewing machine either in one of the NPC's houses or after completing said NPC's special request in which case you are rewarded your own sewing machine. I would love it if there was a clothing store or a clothing catalogue you could buy some of the default shirts and pants from, or allowing the player to pick a few sets of clothes they could switch through via a dresser to make it more realistic/to make the game feel less stale with allowing some variety in wha your character can pick to wear each day, which would also allow for new items and things to do like washing and drying your clothes. I haven't encountered any bugs, glitches, or exploits as of writing this. 

Overall, Stardew Valley is absolutely stellar. There are so many positives from this game that I couldn't list em all, and every con that exists is minor in scale and not that big of a deal all things considered. I absolutely recommend this game to everyone, it is genuinely a 10/10 experience you'll never wanna stop playing.

This game is very relaxing, and I love it. After a long day, when I'm sore, and tired, I open this game and take care of my farm and my animals. Everybody in the town is very unique and it's fun to just go around talking to people and making friends with everybody except one person you dislike. In addition, the style is very charming, whether it's the town's design or the adorable chickens, I can't really find one thing in this game that it fails at accomplishing. Overall, I'd recommend this game, as it's varying playstyles can help accommodate just about anyone. Want to just relax and take care of animals and crops? Pick the basic farm. You want more combat and action? Go for the farm that has more space, but enemies. Need a break and want to play an arcade game? Go to the bar and play the mountain king game.

Disclaimer: I have way more hours played in this game as shown, but changed accounts since. I wrote this review relatively at the beginning of playing, and since played through the main story. My two only criticisms are the time passing: its fun in the beginning of the game, when you are grinding and it really matters what you do every day. However, once you have pretty much completed the game and just want to check in at your farm and hang out, it becomes somewhat annoying. The other issue I had, before the most recent update, is the few options you have for decorating your farm. However, I LOVE. Lo-ve the new additions. So overall, 10/10 would recommend this game to anyone.

Stardew Valley
An RPG farming simulator that incorporates the best of Pokemon, Animal Crossing, Harvest Moon, Minecraft and Don’t starve together. You can grow crops, raise animals, process farmed goods to artisan products, explore and fight in mines, forage, fish and socialize with townsfolk.
Graphics:	7/10
The pixel art and fixed perspective follows the example of the old gen 3 Pokemon games. This can be a huge plus for some players who enjoy the retro vibes of the game but can throw off players seeking breathtaking high definition environments found in newer games.
Despite the minimalism in graphics, the overall game design does not lack customization of your own character and plot, allowing players to build unique farms. The map is compact but allows the player to unlock new areas to explore over time.
Music:		10/10
The beautiful soundtrack plays a huge factor in the charme of this game. I found myself not enjoying the game as much significantly, and even feeling less urge to play when the sound was off. The sound effects are extremely satisfying, from chopping wood to watering plants, and the ambient music is beautiful and varied that you never get fed up with it. Unlike the Pokemon soundtrack which can get obnoxious to the point where rumours claim it drives people to suicide, Stardew Valley’s relaxing tunes will always be a source of comfort and happiness.
Controls: 	5/10
On the PC, controls can be confusing as both right and left click perform certain tasks. This can lead to some accidental destruction of crops with your axe or the unwanted question of whether you want to eat an item you are currently carrying. Nonetheless. The controls are simple and do not require much practise.
Gameplay:	8/10
As it is a farming simulator, most tasks are concerned with the daily watering of crops, collecting produce and taking care of your animals. This can get repetitive, but as the game progresses, mechanisms that automize the process can be acquired. However, to some these activities are part of the joy in playing Stardew Valley, imitating popular mobile games like Farmville which are entirely built around these mechanisms. Once the duties on the farm are completed, players can engage in more challenging activities like fishing, foraging or fighting in the mines. Additionally, designing and decorating the farm, organizing crops and buildings is a big part of gameplay that many enjoy. Overall, there is a variety of activities which players can indulge in, allowing for different playstyles and preferences.
To top it off, there is also a multiplayer mode available, which allows for friends to help each other out or build separate farms. Edit since the new update: there has been so much new content added, including new missions for players who have completed the “main story” of the game. Absolutely love this.
Story:		10/10
While most of Stardew Valley’s experience is an open-world gameplay that allows you to follow any activity you want without a storyline to follow, there are cutscenes and progressions that unlock when certain conditions are met. Some of the interactions with villagers are very emotional and go beyond simple video game storylines. Throughout the first years, certain events and storylines change, keeping the game intriguing.
Characters:	9/10
The characters are original and interesting, the complete opposite of cookie-cutter Animal Crossing villagers with mostly irrelevant interactions. Some may completely ignore the individual storylines of the townsfolk as it mostly does not impact gameplay, but if players pay close attention to dialogues and investigate houses thoroughly, they will come to appreciate the little story details hidden around town. Each villager has their own personality and schedule, allowing different people to find their favourite character and befriend them.
Originality:	6/10
Many aspects of Stardew Valley are found in other games, the difference is that Stardew Valley implements them so well. Fishing and foraging in Animal Crossing was one major source of income, Stardew Valley has it too – but it is only one activity of many. The multiplicity of activities makes the game more complex than many of its comparable rivals. A bonus is that the game is constantly being updated and receives even more details and additions that keep it interesting even to long-time players. Upon much demand from the community certain villagers were made eligible for marriage which were previously not, and most recently the developer allowed players to vote on the next type of tree that will be introduced in the game (Mangos!!).
Difficulty:	5/10
The game is rather relaxing and does not make it difficult for players that want to take it slow. Of course, competitive players who want to maximize profits and efficiency will find that getting the most out of each day can be challenging. There are certain punishments, for example when staying out too late at night or running out of health or stamina, however these are not too drastic (like in Don’t starve for example, where constantly dying in winter for example can be extremely frustrating) 
There are two aspects which require closer inspection: the fighting and fishing mechanisms. Fighting in the mines becomes more difficult with each level, but overall does not exceed a level of difficulty that would make it hard to progress or frustrating to play. It provides a welcome alternative to the relatively risk-free farming and resource gathering, but can be done easily if players come prepared.
One point of much criticism is the fishing minigame, which can be extremely difficult and indeed frustrating. It becomes easier as the fishing skill increases, but makes it hard for new players to get into catching fish.

Everyone I have spoken to that has played or still plays Stardew Valley absolutely loves the game. If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

If I had to think of what brings back to Stardew Valley as opposed to other farming type Sand Box styled games, if would have to be for its gameplay. Other games like this tend to be tedious or the beginning of those games tend to be unforgiving, but with Stardew it's much more easier to pick up and there's something pointing you in the right direction. You are also rewarded for exploring the world where you are able to find resources that will help you at any point in the game. Even that stupid fishing mini-game I struggled with when first playing I absolutely love now!

And unlike other farming type games Stardew Valley gives you other options on how you can run things in the game instead of relying solely on planting stuff. There have been many playthroughs where I either didn't touch crops or barely utilized them finding a completely new and fun way to play the game.

This is also a game where I can just set up a system and am able to do that over and over and over, you get that point. And that works well for me because it actually gets me focused as well as calms me down to a point where I find myself not only completely relaxed, but if I play this game before bed time I have tired my mind to where I can sleep just fine! This game is very therapeutic for me and it helps my unfocused brain just shut down and calm itself. That is just wonderful.

There is nothing quite like Stardew Valley, similar yes, but not to the degree of this game, and I feel like other games in the genre have been trying to replicate that. This may have been initially a love letter to the Harvest Moon/Story of Seasons franchise, but it has come a long way to diversify itself from it and I love that we have such a wonderful game.

Okay fam listen up. This is my favorite game *ever*. I adore Stardew Valley so much. It's been my safe space for quite a long time now! I started by watching playthroughs of it on YouTube back in 2016, and eventually got it on my old phone and quickly put in over 80 hours. Now here I am today, with this many hours on my laptop and working my way into over 50 hours now on my Switch. Don't miss out on this game, you'll regret not giving this one a chance. Five stars all around!

I got so tired of all of these low-quality-graphics-styled games that have been coming out more recently, and that's why I really hesitated to get this game for so long. It just seemed like a boring, low-effort game, kind of like Animal Crossing but 8-bit. It's not though. In reality, Animal Crossing is incredibly boring compared to this game. This game is amazing.

One of the first things you notice is how complex the stories are, and how there's so much to discover. You could probably play this game for 6 months and still not have discovered half of the game's content. I feel like I've not even scratched the surface of what this game has for me. There are a million places for you to explore and a million more people to meet. 

On top of that, every villager in this game is so unique which is why it's so much fun to form relationships with them. While this game is very story-driven, there's a great mix of quests, exploration, and mindless wandering so you aren't stuck grinding one specific thing.

I don't want to spoil anything, so I'd recommend just buying the game and trying it out. It's adorable and just plain fun.

I know this is gonna be disliked, so treat this as a "Mixed" review, but I'll get to that.

First, the good:

Stardew Valley is a cute little farming sim set in the small hamlet of Pelican Town. It is atmospheric and immersive, with well written characters that certainly feel real.
The music is great and fits perfectly with the current theme of the game, cheery and bright music for Spring and Summer, and calm and tranquil music for Autumn and Winter. Each romanceable character also has their own theme that plays during their relationship events, which can certainly aid you in falling in love with the character.
The pixelated art style makes the game feel cozy and relaxing, provided you can tell what you're looking at.

But that's about where my praises end, now the bad:

The beginning of the game is a slog, confusing, and directionless. I have countless saves that didn't make it past the first in game week from losing motivation to continue playing within a couple hours, then never playing again for months before coming back and starting again.
There is no sense of purpose and the game doesn't show you what is supposed to be your goal until you are hours in, the Community Centre, but that itself provides little to actually do at the start, once you add everything you can from this season you can't do much beyond wait until the next season.
The mechanics of the game are poorly explained with the in game tutorial ending at two boxes at the side of the screen telling you how to walk. You are never even told how to buy crops, and how each crop differs from each other, for example.
The game requires you to have the community made wiki open on a second monitor almost at all times, destroying any immersion it had, as the game never tells you where different fish are located, or what gifts a character likes, unless you are willing to spend many hours trying to do trial and error, and writing down the outcome of it for future reference, which is obviously a lot more difficult than just opening the wiki.
The in game day is hardcoded to end at 2 am, causing you to pass out, and if you're anywhere but your farm, you'll have items and money stolen from you, but again this isn't told to the player until they've experienced it once, which can lead to you feeling cheated as some valuable items are deleted without warning. The closest the game comes to telling you is a "It's getting late." popup which to a new player wouldn't mean much.
This time limit can also lead to you wanting to maximise the most out of every day, so you don't miss something important that won't come back until next year, which can quickly lead to burn out as the game becomes more work than game. I have seen people say "just don't play that way and just relax." which is ok advice but I know some people, such as myself, that won't be able to rest if they're not constantly doing everything needed, which leads me to my final point.

This game is not for everyone, most games aren't, but on the question of "Do you recommend this game?"; to a player new to gaming or just the average player in general? No, this game is very niche despite the very vocal playerbase. I could only recommend this game to someone with experience with the Harvest Moon style, who already knows what to expect, or someone with a strong resilience to the poor new player experience and motivation to get through to the second year, where, despite my hatred for this saying, I'd say the game truly begins.

This game has a very relaxing, charming vibe to it.  After having played it for about 11 hours, the gameplay potential still seems pretty big.  There's a lot I haven't done... haven't even tried to do.  The game doesn't force other avenues on you, either.  They are just there.  As a casual game that you can just jump into and out of as limited time demands, its pretty great.  It doesn't demand a lot, and it really helps me to zone out and unwind.  It sounds like faint praise, and in a way it is because I'm not invested in this game in the same way I am other, more intense games, but I still very much recommend it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 21 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Stardew Valley is one of the best games out there right now in the farm siming community in my opinion since the early harvest moon games. It has everything from Farming, Fishing, Mining, Fighting, and intriguing characters with backstory and lore. That the community can talk about. 

It has some of the nicest community memebers too; from the developers of mods for it to the first timer farmers. I have made some new friends and had fun with old ones on Stardew co-op. I have had the enjoyment of watching the game grow from buying it back in 2016 to regetting obessed with it now in 2022.

I would recommend this game to anyone who loves cozy casual farming games along with my fellow fans of the harvest moon series as this one is one of the best farming games out there!

beautiful game

first off, the music is amazing. every single track is perfect for the themes.

secondly, the prices for things is balanced and grinding overall is good and even enjoyable most times, though i imagine it will end up getting boring at some point, however my point still stands.

thirdly theres way more features than just farming. I mean, you can mine, do quests, forage for stuff, cut down trees, cook food, go fishing, gift the other villagers, and eventually even get married and have children. So even if its winter, you haven't got any crops planted or much, you've always got alternatives so you dont just immediately go back to bed and sleep for the next day.

thirdly it has modding support so you can create and download mods from other people. this has allowed me to add mods for the game so I can progress much faster and stuff

another great thing is that bugs on this game are practically non-existent, which means you can play the game worry-free.

the only downside i can think of is that the game only saves after you sleep, which means you will lose some progress if you forget to sleep before quitting the game. At the same time, this isn't really much of an issue anyway because anything you lose is still re-obtainable.

overall, I rate this game 11/10.

This game is for those who likes achieving, collecting,  and  profiting as you turn a rundown farm and community center into  order. Your farm can really make some profit with what you choose to farm including animals and fruit trees. As for the community center, you have some choices that will either turn it into a movie theater later or a place that the villagers will use for their crafts. There is mining in some locations that prove challenging for some faint at heart but you can work them a few floors at a time and they are fun. there's relationships and stories to uncover and friendships to make as you adventure your way through this game. Also there's added content now and a whole new places to explore and new villagers to meet too. In these new places comes new trees and things to craft and collect. In this game, you get to choose, craft, and enjoy. The new places makes this game new again so if you've played this game before, try it again and see the new developments to experiment. Enjoy and adventure on.

After years and years of having this indie darling sit on my library shelf, I finally pulled it out and decided to play it.
I wanted a game that had a really satisfying grind and progression system, and I got just that. Stardew Valley really scratches that work-reward itch, if slightly too generously. Since tons of heap has already been praised onto this game, I will instead try and put into words what I thought might've made the game more enjoyable.
1. More challenge. Maybe there's a mod for this, but I would've liked something more abrasive, more difficult. Most of the challenge I get from this game is remembering what I should be doing next! And sometimes it makes me wonder whether I might not be losing my memory in my old age. 
2. Varying costs of items like in a free market. I'd have liked it if the prices of materials and produce were variable over time, like in an actual market place dictated by scarcity. It would have added another dimension to the game that would've made it a lot more interesting. 
3. More story content. I enjoyed the little bit of story content provided so far, but there really could be a lot more.
4. More mature. Not necessarily meaning to push it into R-rated territory, just to have more interesting and serious themes explored throughout. I think the quick time events could have been used to do this. 
Those are the areas where I would have made changes to the game myself. 
But that said, stellar experience, hard to put down, I'm going to probably see this save game through to the end of year 2 hopefully having gotten married by then and earned 2 mill.

If you're curious enough about this game to read reviews, you should buy it, whether it's on sale or not. Stardew Valley is one of the few games out there that's actually [i]underpriced[/i]. It's the best $15 I have ever spent in gaming, and I have gotten my money's worth a hundred times over.

The great thing about Stardew Valley is that it has an activity for every mood. Need some stress-free time to unwind? Spend the day farming, fishing, or saying hi to the folks in town. Want some high-stakes action? Go treasure-hunting in the monster-infested mines. Want a real challenge? The arcade games in the town saloon are challenging enough to be Steam games in their own right. What you do each day is up to you. No activity is required to beat the game, but they are all so engaging and rewarding that you will find yourself planning your actions days in advance so that you can do them all!

A gamer who goes through their life without having played Stardew Valley has missed out on something truly special. In terms of quality, customizability, replayability, progression, and heart, it stands toe-to-toe with any AAA title out there. It's one of the best video games I've ever played.

If you haven't already, get this game. You are missing out on so much. Stardew Valley is a cute little game where you own a farm, in a little farm called Stardew Valley. You can grow crops or harvest animal products from your animals to earn money. There are some mines that you can slay monsters like slimes, skeletons, and much more. There is also a community center with little cute apple guys called junimos and it is abandoned so you have to find items to put in bundles for the junimos and they will give you presents like seeds for your farm or food and stuff like that. Once you complete a certain amount of bundles in a thing you can get a star and you will get a special reward that unlocks a new part of the map. You can also go fishing and catch a different variety of different fish. You can also marry somebody and have up to 2 kids and tghey are so adorable and fun to take care of! You can also give them little hats that you can get from a hat mouse guy. Overall, Stardew Valley is a cute little farm simulator for all kinds of people. GeT iT nOw!!!

I've played countless hours of Stardew Valley across many platforms. Not just PC. It's hard to believe anyone could dislike this game, unless you simply are not interested in farming sims. 

Like many Harvest Moon inspired games, you inherit a farm and leave the big city behind. What makes Stardew so special is the characters. Stardew Valley gives us a variety of characters and a deep look into their problems as you develop your relationship with them. No one is perfect and that is what makes it so special. 

The game also takes all the best aspects of your typical farming sims to create a new expansive experience for the player to enjoy. Even after countless new games I still learn something new, whether it be something I can do with an item, or about another NPC that I didn't know about previously.

I'm a huge farming sim gamer and have been playing the classic Harvest Moon/Story of Seasons games since the early 2000s. I can say with confidence that Stardew Valley by far tops them all.

This game has refined the genre so much I truly believe it is now the gold standard for not just farming sims but crafting, survival and lifestyle games. There is so much to play with - just when you think you've hit the end of what you can do, even more unlocks to the point where you could theoretically play this game forever. I just might!

When I first bought this game in 2017, a lot of the features Stardew Valley now boasts had not yet been released and even THEN it was remarkable. With the addition of online multiplayer and other secret goodies I won't spoil, this game is a delight to share with friends and loved ones.

Farming is extensive and excellent. Ranching is optimised for all kinds of play styles, be it selling the animals and their products outright or refining them into more complex artisan goods. The lifestyle simulator is extensive and emotive. It is clear so much thought and love has been put into crafting characters with thoughts and feelings analogous to people everyone will know in the real world.

One developer made this, the gameplay, the art, the music, everything. I cannot fully express in words just how amazing that is or how deeply this game changed my experience with gaming. A hobby I once engaged in alone I now share with friends because Stardew Valley is just so easy and so appealing for beginners to pick up and play. My mum LOVES this game.

If you have any doubt in your mind, please buy this game. And then push it on your friends and loved ones like the addictive, delightful time sink it is.

Or, it can be so stressful as you try to do the math to decide what you need to make the highest profit.  It is a game for everyone and anyone.  Plus, it's cheap- skip lunch some day and check out Stardew Valley.  It's worth it.
