This is quite possibly one of the greatest games of the 2010s, if not all time. Not only is there an insane amount of content available, but the developer has consistently added updates of new stuff to play with, including multiplayer and a lengthy post-game.

You play as a farmer who has inherited your grandfather's land in the small town of Stardew Valley. However, farming is not the only thing available. There is dungeon exploring, fishing, foraging, and a town of people whom you can befriend and eventually marry. Fans of games like Animal Crossing, Slime Rancher, Farming Simulator, and most of all, Harvest Moon, will love this game. There is a little bit for everyone available, all for an affordable price.

Great for players who are completionist types. There are tons of different parts of the game that require time, effort, and puzzle solving. when you complete one set/bundle/friendship/skill, there is ALWAYS something new to collect/earn/farm/mine.... The list goes on and on! Co-op version is also fun to play, as you can get more done with a partner, as long as the partner you choose to play with isn't insane and names all the chickens MURDER and dig through trash in front of ALL THE TOWNSFOLK. Shout out to my brother, Psycho Pete.

Don't get this game if you want to play Multiplayer. 
You keep getting disconnected every 2-5mins for the rest of you and your farming partner's experience. 
The worse part of being disconnected is when you reconnect, you will be forced back into your cabin/house. 
This is especially disappointing when you get disconnected halfway through an event. 

Googled for ways to fix disconnecting issues, but none of the solutions fixed the problem, and no one in the community/forums have a "definite" answer as to how to fix the connection issues.
Game was fine at first, and it was fun. The amount of times I disconnected at the beginning was 1hour at least 2 times. 
But as you progress further into the game, you get disconnected more and more often that the game becomes unplayable. 

Hope this is fixed soon, else don't buy this game if you're playing it just to play multiplayer.

I grew up a huge fan of Harvest Moon Back To Nature.  At first Stardew Valley felt like a sequel.  After years of playing Stardew Valley is without a dbout a far superior version that has made all farming simulators including the Harvest Moon series obsolete.  Stardew Valley has been there to help through depression, financial troubles, heartaches, and most important loneliness.  It's unreal to learn that there was only one person who created this game.  What vision, talent, simply a masterpiece.  Definitely one of the greatest video games ever created.

It's just a cute, cozy game that you can play your way. If you want combat, go to the mines. Crafting, collecting? Go foraging. Just want to farm? That's dope too. There's just enough guidance to give some direction, but no punishments (as such) if you don't "do it all" by the "right" time- first year, third year, whatever. It's cute, it's chill, I love this game and own it on multiple platforms. Playing on Steam especially rocks because of the ability to add mods to enhance gameplay as you see fit.

Also, need I mention ConcernedApe being an absolute legend for making this labor of love by himself with so much dedication and passion, not to mention the price of the game itself and the free updates that we receive. Genuinely a 10/10 game for me.

This is a wonderful, mostly chill game start to finish.  Relatively bug free with minor quirks.  Easy to pick up, no in your face tutorial, plenty left to discover on your own.  The in-game days give decent time to accomplish multiple tasks.  End-game challenges seem imposing but are not impossible, even for casual gamers.  

The visuals are pleasant, music is endearing (and not on constant loop), and characters involved all have their own distinguishable traits to be memorable.

I own this game on Steam and on Xbox and have played both approximately 500 hours each.  I've started up new games with personal goals in mind.  Needless to say, I really enjoy this game.

I, and many others, highly recommend this for all ages.

I am a 41 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Bought this about eight years ago in a humble bundle, didn’t really click with it. My fiancée’s twitch friends started playing it two years ago, and I told her I already had it. She told me to shut it and bought it on switch, where she’s put about 1500 hours into it. We got married the week I’m writing this, and when we got home the next day, said she wanted to try it on PC for the expanded mod. In the three days since, she’s put in 24 hours of play time and is refusing to come to bed at night. 
Stardew might ruin my marriage, but it’s a damn good life sim if you’re into those, or like Animal Crossing but want a more involved and varied gameplay experience.

Stardew Valley is a game of endless possibilities in a confined, yet freeing world. As someone who normally plays singleplayer games with set objectives or competitive multiplayer games, it is very refreshing to throw away structure to grow crops, explore underground, fish, or interact with the NPCs in an immersive world. The NPCs, although limited in day to day dialogue, do not feel fake or unrealistic. Instead they feel like real people, everyone has their likes and dislikes, each has their own problems. (I.e alcoholism, depression, etc.) Through your actions, such as giving gifts, you learn more about the townsfolk and become friends with them. Eventually you can sometimes even help them with their problems, or increase friendship by doing tasks submitted to the community bulletin board. In short Stardew Valley is a sandbox game against the normals of gaming in the best ways possible. instead of fast paced competitive gameplay, Stardew Valley slows things down to let you enjoy your time doing the simplest things.

This game is a gem to play, it's relaxing and has great music, as well as fabulous audio design. The relationships and story you get through interacting with villagers of Pelican Town is fed to you gradually, and you will have to be in it for the long run in order to get everyone's individual stories as well as your own, so if you don't want to spend hours on end for this, then I would be wary about that. (At the time of me playing, I haven't finished the story but I am enjoying everything I have discovered so far!) 

My favourite thing about this game is the animals you get to take care of, and your own little pet after 10 days, which if like me you chose a cat, you can walk home to your little buddy curled up on your bed which is  always adorable. The addition of Co-op to the PC version is also very fun, I've found my time spent more playing with my friends on this game than I have alone, and there is a lot of potential to work together on quests and other activities such as mining and fighting. 

The added addition of mods does make some of the gameplay slightly better, such as the NPC locations on the map or faster walking speed, which means that you can get even more done over a day and not have to walk around trying to find out where someone you need is, but this is just for me personally, you may like that sort of thing! 

Overall, I wholly recommend this game to anyone and everyone, I'm sure there is something that you would enjoy, from the mining and fighting to the fishing and farming, there is really something for everyone, especially when you play together

You know this game is honestly great- has nice pixel sprites and cute houses with also cute concept of a farm, visuals are great too with a range of 4 seasons throughout the year and whenever it's on sale (which is pretty often) you can decently snag it up with 9 bucks ez clap and then have a nice farm sim game. 

You can do a lot of things with the farm sim alone- fishing, caring for animals ranging from pigs, chicken, cows, sheep, and ducks while also being able to produce multiple stuff with the items they produce daily increasing their happiness will also add to the quality and item they produce, farm a wide variety of crops depending on season which I find quite neat, produce goods like wine, cheese, clothes etc- you can also go mining and fight off monster rpg style.

Not to mention the town events and seasonal festival which offers games and limited item shop, and you also get to help the community. 

The story part of this game is also pretty well built we got the nice little town with nice community and magical lore stuff- as well as the joji mart which is trying to take over the town- and guess what? You get to choose that, thats right you get to choose which fate this town ends up in, its all in your hand you're god now- yea thats for the god complex people but anyhow there's quite a few route you can take with the story which is neat, in addition to multiple side route and cool little cutscenes that comes from interacting with certain characters. 

And- wait for it... 

Do you want a girlfriend/boyfriend? Yes you, do you wanna date pixels?! Well look no further with stardew valley's selection of bachelors and bachelorettes you can certainly find a men/women that fits into your taste in romantic partner so what are you waiting for?

This review is for the Steam version specifically, not Stardew Valley as a general game: I would give it 1 star if you only own a keyboard and mouse, and 3 of 5 stars if you own a controller, because this game was for sure "ported" from a mobile platform to the PC and is **indescribably** frustrating to play with a keyboard and mouse. If your character is facing one way, but you accidentally left your mouse pointed somewhere else (because walking is still WSAD, not mouse) then they take action toward the mouse, not the direction you're facing. This elevates from "annoying" to "enraging" when the game penalizes your "stamina" for every action as well as consumables like water or fishing bait

It's also one of those games where you just have to guess what's part of the scenery and what is something you can take action upon, and that's usually by walking over to it and seeing if some magic icon appears, or (of course) learning that you can't walk over to it because it _is_ scenery but you're not a big enough person to crawl over the mighty tall impassible fence or whatever. Related to that, it really jams me up when games say you can't walk over grass. Like, how tall is this grass that a character has to walk around it instead of over it?

This game is seems to be trying to be "realistic" in that the character has to sleep and eat constantly, which if you're into that, fine, but it's not _fun_ to be constantly managing that stuff. It's like if they turned the heart system in Minecraft up to 11 or whatever

Also, the fishing minigame can die in a fire

Look, I know it has gadzillions of "we love it" reviews, but this is my experience, and my advice: buy a controller for this game

I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Stardew Valley, my beloved, most cherished game. The superb craftsmanship of this smash hit indie game is one to invest in for ages to come. I simply become the town wench in every play-through. It is so hard to decide which man or woman to commit to... but for some reason I can't fathom a life without Shane, the town's raging alcoholic. I can fix him... I know I can. All it takes is 50 mods to do so... including the one where I can watch him stroke his meat stick lovingly in the back of the saloon. I especially find him endearing when he is laying in the middle of the field drunk out of his mind. It reminds me of when I went into anaphylaxis and almost died in a field. He is just like me fr. Enough about Shane though, for he is only one of many sexy little munchkins waiting to be romanced... only one of many hearts you can break. You think this is an ordinary farming sim... well you are wrong. You will experience love and loss, hate and betrayal, rivalry and victory, all in one 8-bit experience. This game is not for the faint of heart, but you will grow exponentially as a person through this life-altering coming of farm.
I can't recommend this game enough. There's so much depth and replay-ability to this game, the fact that it was created by one person always blows my mind.

I downloaded this because it reminded me of the Terraria art-style I love, and also because so many people said it was calming to play. I AM SO NOT CALM. My energy runs out?? I have no idea how to get seeds without paying for them, but I can't get money unless I sell fish, but fish are so difficult to to catch!!!!! And then I have to EAT?!!?!? AITA for telling a pregnant coworker to stop about her pregnancy to me?

I (28M) have a coworker (30?F) who recently found out she was pregnant and she has been talking about it non-stop. I get that it’s exciting for her and even though I couldn’t really care less I’m not one to strike down small talk just because it’s not relevant to me personally. My issue really is with the amount of talk. At first it was fine, but for the past 2 months that she has known she has talked to me at length (minimum 20 minutes) about her pregnancy every single day. I feel like I know the ins and outs of her pregnancy better than her gyno at this point.

The other day I told her that I wasn’t really all that interested in the particularities of her pregnancy and that she was talking about it a lot and to maybe strike up conversation with someone else. She then told me that she only talks to me about it because she’s one of the only women in the department and no one but the 2 other woman and me, ‘the gay guy’, would wanna hear about it. Honestly that pissed me off a lot and I responded harsher than I think was maybe appropriate.

I told her that I didn’t care about the inner workings of her uterus and that she should keep it to herself. I’m not her OBGYN and it’s obnoxious. I also told her that we aren’t friends, and that coworkers, gay or straight, don’t wanna get regular updates on how the pregnancy sex she’s having with her husband is so much better, or how she craves drinking peanut oil, or how her boobs have gotten bigger.

She was pretty upset after I chewed her out and has been avoiding me ever since, she’s barely willing to talk to me even if it’s work relevant. I overheard her complaining about how vicious I was to her and that I made her feel ashamed for being pregnant/having a pregnant body. That wasn’t my intention, but I do now worry that I crossed a line and that I was the asshole.

You can probably tell from my ever increasing number of hours that this game holds a special place in my heart. Not only is this game a massive inspiration to me personally as an aspiring game developer, but it's also just a fun game in every way. There's always something to work towards, and it's always fun! The NPCs are charming and unique and the gameplay just has so much to offer. Even after over 400 hours, I still find new little tricks and tips that light up that lightbulb above my head and make me go "how did I not think of that? That's awesome!" If I had to pick ONE game in the WHOLE WIDE WORLD to get everyone to try out, there isn't a singular doubt in my mind Stardew Valley would win, every time.

Each time I start up a new farm in Stardew Valley or return to my 100-hour save on PC, I feel like I’m going home. There’s a comfort in Stardew Valley that I’ve rarely found in other games. The music that changes with each season perfectly fits the mellowness of the 16-bit countryside town, and all the activities that await offer both peace in my daily routines and excitement in the land’s mysteries. Whether you want to farm, fish, fight monsters, craft, mine, become everyone’s best friend, or do a little bit of everything, this farming adventure has plenty to offer. " Miranda Sanchez"

[b]General review[/b]
Stardew valley was initially made by a single developer and the first version was released on February 26, 2016 on PC. Later the game would come out on other platforms and even on mobile. In this game you create your own farm, meet with all the various characters of the world and take part of the community in whatever way you'd like. Aside from farming there are other 'Skills' to learn such as fishing and mining. This game is an amazing piece of art and should be part of everyone's library at some point. Let's grade some of the core aspects of the game;

[b]Technical aspects[/b]
---{ Graphics }---
⬛⬛⬛⬛⬜ 4
[i]If you like pixelart-style farming games, this is the game for you.[/i]
---{ Audio }---
⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛ 5
[i]The audio is memorable, smooth and just fits perfectly within the game.[/i ]
---{ PC requirements }---
⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛ 5
[i]Honestly, a rotten potato could run this game[/i]
---{ Bugs }---
⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛ 5
[i]There are very little to no bugs I know of that would break the players experience in this game.[/i]

[b]Game aspects[/b]
---{ Gameplay }---
⬛⬛⬛⬛⬜ 4
[i]The gameplay feels good, but at some times repetitive.[/i]
---{ Story }---
⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛ 5
[i]The story is well-written and can be completed in any way the player would like and at any pace.[/i]
---{ Difficulty }---
⬛⬛⬜⬜⬜ 2
[i]The game is not hard at all to learn.[/i]
---{ Grind }---
⬛⬛⬛⬜⬜ 3
[i]Only in some aspects of the game there is a little bit of grinding involved.[/i]
---{ Game Time }---
⬛⬛⬛⬛⬜ 4
[i]The game can take as long as you like but in general it can take quite some time to complete fully.[/i]
---{ Fun with friends }---
⬛⬛⬛⬜⬜ 3
[i]The multiplayer of this game is not very balanced, making the game easier to play with friends, but it is very fun.[/i]
---{ Worth the price? }---
⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛ 5
[i]At the time of writing, this game is full worth the price listed on steam.[/i]

[b]Overall Grade 1/10[/b]
⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬜⬜ 8 / 10
[i]This is a very amazing game to add to you collection and I hope you will have as much fun with it as I have had in the past and will have in the future![/i]

fun game. really good time waster and the fast-paced curve of starting out with two dollars and then farming your way to ten million is great. one gripe; SO MUCH of this fucking game feels like homework. I don't want to have to wait until its raining during fall while my asshole is exactly 3.14 inches prolapsed and completely clean just so i can catch the fucking magical carp whos scales make you instantly orgasm when you eat them. This can be subverted in the early-game by being a sellout and just buying the upgrades that usually require a year or twos length of time (if you haven't googled a fucking spreadsheet the size of mars so you know exactly where everything is and when to get it). you cant buy your way to victory in the end game, though. the endgame where you go to a cool island that has 130 of a unique currency (some which are hidden in completely unique spots, others based on luck during minigames). you need to unlock more of the currency to progress the island, and you have to find 100 out of 130 to unlock a super secret room filled with MORE HOMEWORK. achieve "perfection" by sucking off all the villagers and selling every type of crop fifteen times during winter or some SHIT just so you can buy the golden chicken egg and actually start using coops to make MONEY. 

if you like grindy bullshit then get ready to learn EVERY nuance of the game and how to work with it. otherwise youll just have to live happily ever after with your sub-optimal end game farm.

My absolute favorite game of the last decade. I regret not buying it sooner. So far I've made 3 different farms, and a few with friends, and each time is an absolute delight. If you like the rush of checking things off a list, and getting things done, this is the game for you. It's just peaceful enough that I can relax while playing, but with enough excitement to keep my entertained for hours. It's also easy to sit down and play just 1 day cycle (around 15-20 minutes of real-time time) if you don't have a big window for gaming, and it's a great game to sit down and play a whole season in 1 session (can be a few hours). I will be playing this game for years and excited about it every time I start it up.

Growing up playing Harvest Moon, Stardew Valley is exactly what I always wanted!

10000000000/10 Get it bought and play it!

It took me so long to play this game, so many people recommended it and I kept putting it off and off. Mostly because of graphics among other things. I played all Harvest Moon/SOS games and those type of games in recent years were getting really stale with the same tired formula. But eventually I got Stardew Valley on Switch so I could play it on the go like a DS- and my god- I wish I'd of picked it up back then!

I've sunk hours and hours into this game but one of the best pluses is that I connected with my friends/family playing it co-op. I love the gameplay, it's suited to any playstyle- you wanna just play a dating sim, it's that, farm sim? Go raise some livestock or grow crops and trees. Just like designing stuff? You've got numerous Farm layouts to choose from and go ham. Maybe you like combat- or just plodding about adventuring. There's always something new in this game and was addicted well and truly. And I am in the minority that absolutely love the fishing game!

Then, I bought it on steam and was introduced the modded community and fell in love with the game again. It opens up the game completely and there are so many mods that turn the game into something completely new. Or if you're like me and loved the core game, just adding stuff into it that's just for aesthetics or adds new places/people. Similar to how you would add DLC to a game. My favourites and 100% must haves are "Stardew Valley Expanded" "Ridgeside Village" Hell there's even magic now so you can be your own wizard!!  

What I will say is that SMAPI- the modding device is pretty complicated to put in, but the mods themselves are really simple once you get past initial setup! 

I do appreciate that I played it vanilla first and I would recommend anyone do that FIRST because like a good book/movie you can't experience twice, this you actually can and it's worth it.

Stardew Valley has become my favorite game ever. It is such an exciting and relaxing experience. This is more than just a typical farming game. You can fish, forage items, go mining and fight monsters. By doing certain quests, for example the community center, you unlock more places in the valley for you to travel to. You unlock better methods to complete your work. There are festivals held by the town which are always a joy to attend to even though they're the same every year. In my opinion, the most underrated part of this whole game, is building friendships! By building friendships with the villagers, you learn more about them, and you dig deeper into their personal life, which I find super neat. You can even make some of the villagers better people! Like Haley and Alex. Even the little things in this game I find so cool. Let me talk about the farming now. You can grow crops (duh), you can buy coops and barns, then buy your very own farm animals! You even get your own house pet! You can get married and have children as well. There is so much more to this game believe it or not, but I won't explain any more because the rest are spoilers if you have not played this game. I 100% recommend this game :)

This game is still one of the best examples of the greatness that are indie games.
Its cute pixelart style and animations, which are somehow able to convey pretty detailed emotions and humour, are paired with a relatively easy game premise. The core game mechanics are varied enough to allow the player to keep working on their farm without getting bored.
It is also quite impressive how much the game has evolved over the years, allowing players to discover new areas or secrets quite some playtime into a save. And boy are there quite a few fun secrets / "mini side missions".

Just buy it already.

I've logged a couple hours so I might as well make my review.

This game was one of the first games I've ever bought and I don't regret it. This game was the product of one man's passion project. That man is ConcernedApe, one of the best developers that I know about.

It's like harvest moon, but better in pretty much everything it does. I loved making my farm look good while still keeping it productive. During early game winter, I usually spend my time fishing, mining, befriending townsfolk, and the likes. Once I unlocked a certain end-game area, I spent my time transforming it into my home away from home.

Pros:
🞄Fun life simulator with lots of neat easter eggs and care
🞄Beautiful Pixel Art 
🞄Well written imperfect characters
🞄You can put hats on the Alien Rarecrow, your horse, and your child
🞄Lots of mods

Cons:
🞄Lackluster friendship system
🞄Takes a while to get into
🞄Days don't last very long which can stress out some people
🞄No tutorial, but for a game centered around interacting with the community, is quite poetic in my opinion

Some nitpicks:
🞄It's too easy to accidentally delete items
🞄You can't mark items as favorite like in Terraria
🞄Trash can instantly gets rid of items instead of keeping them until you add another item (like Terraria)


All in all, it's one of my top games, up there with Terraria, Enter/Exit the Gungeon, etc. 9/10

picture this:
me, samson (thats me that is my name) deeply engrossed into the game, i say hello to shane (kiss him on the mouth), plant my crops, pet my animals and i see a black blob moving ever so slightly in my peripheral vision. i think to myself "a fly? how did you get in here!" and turn my attention to the (supposed) winged insect. me, not wearing my glasses (blind, oh so very blind) in that split second realise far too late. 
it was not a fly. it was a spider. it falls off its silk line and flails just inches from my arm and starts fucking booking it. i jump up, start freaking out (obviously) and try to reach for something, anything! i grab a cup and try to trap the would be assassin but it runs and oh god does it run. we have a standoff, staring into each other's eyes (romantically?) and it scurries away between the trinkets sat on my desk. i panic and start moving things around, shaking like a leaf but i cant find it. my eyes water and my knees are about to give out. i step back for a moment, devise a game plan. bug killer? shoe? what do i even do once i find it? am i even allowed to take another's life? maybe this spider is just like me. maybe it has dreams, a family, a life it wants to live. but i have no time to think about that. i don't know what kind of guy this thing is! what if it's venomous? what if there's more of them? i have to find it. and i have to find it fast. i gather myself, picking up the cup once again. i slowly move the items sitting on my desk, caution in every move i make. 

it's either me or the spider. 

i get to the last few things and go to pick up my junimo plush (hehe). i grab it with both hands, looking where it once stood. and thats when i realise my mistake. the spider was on the junimo plush. waiting. lurking. right. next. to. my. hand. i breathe in, removing a hand and reach for the cup. 

IT'S EITHER ME OR THE SPIDER. 

i SLAM the cup onto the junimo causing the spider to start running, panicked. we make eye contact through the glass and it stops. it seems to have accepted its fate. i flip over the junimo/cup and start shaking it, trying to get the spider to fall into the glass. it falls and sits at the bottom of the cup, defeated. i've won. i sit there for a while. unmoving. it takes me a bit but i eventually get up and take the spider outside. as it scurries out of the glass we meet eyes yet again.. we have a moment. and then it gallops into the distance. i step back inside, the loss looming over me, but it was the right thing to do. we're from different worlds, different walks of life. and i accept that. 
i walk back to my room, melancholic, filled with sorrow and sit down at my desk. i glance to the place where i first saw it. i think back to all the memories we shared, all the glances between us... and i feel empty. all those moments are in the past and i have to move on. i wipe my tears, compose myself, and stare back at my screen. at some point during the struggle i had paused my game, 4:20pm. i straighten my back and put on my headphones. i rest my hands on my keyboard and mouse and unpause.

and then i forget all about it and play the rest of the day. recommended! very good game

The game's fine, definitely overhyped, it's an Americanized knockoff of Harvest Moon [spoiler](I absolutely guarantee the dev lives somewhere in the western US, in a big city, probably paying $1000+ a month in a tiny apartment. The game definitely gives that feeling),[/spoiler] somewhere in the early Rune Factory days, back when they were starting to realize RPG mechanics would be a fun thing to add to the franchise, but hadn't yet fleshed it out.

I'm a bit too late to give a heartfelt, proper review, but the gist of it is that it's like the games I mentioned, but missing a lot of the innocence and fun; you know, lots of hamfisted stuff about evil corporations with too much power, NPCs cheating on each other and such, and weird balancing issues like the starter sprinklers being worthless and the only weapons worth using being swords (despite there being four weapon types).

Yadda yadda, you get the idea. Fad game, solid 6/10, big modding community, whatever.
Would've given it a no, but you can definitely tell the game's made by one person. If I find out later that it's made by a team, I'll change it to a no, but in the meantime, yes.

I have Stardew Valley on PC, iOS and Switch. I paid for all three separately. That alone should speak to how much I love this game. 

Since I've previously only played on the iOS and Switch versions, I've never used mods before. Let me tell you - they are life-changing. My farm has never looked more beautiful. 

The game is fun, the community is great, and there's a ton of replayability. Whether you go for min/max and organize the heck out of your day or just simply throw caution to the wind and enjoy your life doing only one thing at a time, it's all up to you. There's never any real pressure or deadlines - unless you want them yourself. It's a game you can pick up and drop whenever you want and if you get tired or want something new, you can start all over and I appreciate that. 

10/10

I'm still quite surprised by this game. A game made by an individual developer turned out to be much better than I imagined. I'm not a big fan of the RPGs that have come out recently, but this game has refreshed my perception of the field. In terms of gameplay, it basically revolves around farming. The things you start with are a piece of land and a house, and you can choose between them because they have different properties. My favorite part was interacting with these NPCs because they were so much fun. So overall, the game was very unexpected and I think Eric Barone did a really good job.

This game is not only very addicting and fun, serving as my personal favorite method of escapism, but also includes interesting and endearing character interactions. If you want a farming sim with plenty of depth and a pick-up-and-play style, this game is flawless.

Stardew Valley is a game with a simple concept that's easy to get into. It features a memorable cast of characters and decent variety in its gameplay. There's plenty to do for players who want to fully complete the game, as well as incentives to restart from the beginning and experience things in a different way. The day-to-day farm life offers a relaxing escape from the real world, while the dungeon-like mines are great for players who want a more thrilling experience. 
If I had one complaint, it would be that the characters, while lovely, begin to lose their charm as dozens of hours are put into the game. Dialogue becomes repetitive, and even marriage starts to feel stale after a while.

It was fun playing this game with Termite-kun for the first time. The graphic configuration is simple but cute, which can be customized according to preferences. The game has many missions and each one is a journey, a small story of the characters in the game. Termite and I have small houses ( far far away from town), with a large field ( full of flowers and fruits) in the front yard, a chicken coop, and we have a little cutie cat. Termite is always good at this game, he always catches rare fish, and I often get teased for only catching seaweeds. On rainy days, Termite and I would go into caves to fight monsters, and dig mines. Another special thing is that the game has seasonal festivals. There are always special items, interesting little activities here. For me, Stardew Valley is a miniature model of farm life that I can find feelings of peace, and the melodious music and sound took me away from the hustle and bustle of reality.

I found this game years after the hype, and I can see why it's so well loved. 

There are myriads of ways to play this game. You can stay on your farm and farm to your heart content, or you can spend your time mining, or maybe you prefer fishing! Base game has, if I remember correctly 5 different farms to start on, from a basic all around little bit of everything farm, to one that is more for fishing, and another that has a rock spawn. 

There is tons of NPC's to become friends with, and even marry eventually. Slowly getting to know everyone is such a treat. 

It's a great little slice of life sim that is great to pop into and relax

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

I wasn't sure if I'd like this game at first because I don't usually enjoy RPG games like this, but man was I wrong. This game is basically perfect. It's a one-person game, which makes it even more impressive; the art style is unique and amazing, and I personally adore it. It's essentially a farming simulator with a unique story; you begin as a worker in an office at Joja Mart, which is similar to Amazon in real life, except this time it's the evil corporation. Anyway, you get tired of working at Joja and decide to go to the plot of land in the small town of Stardew Valley, To begin, you are greeted with a farm and some money known as "gold," which you inherited from your grandfather. The first thing you should do is talk to all of the NPCs. In Stardew Valley, there is a store called Pierre's General Store that competes with Joja. You can either support Pierre or sell your soul to the devil and go with Joja.

I have been playing stardew valley for about 7-8 years and I can still say with absolute confidence that it is one of my absolute favourite games ever. It really was worth every penny. I even got my sister, who doesn't really play games, hooked. (And I'm planning to get my boyfriend into it too.) From character creation to romancing and friending people in the community, its beautiful and I will always always recommend it. The array of characters you get to meet, the stories, the development between you and the town and farming at your own leisure? There's also no wrong way to play this game which is great! And the fact that they introduced multiplayer so now you can play with friends and experience it together? 200/10! (And can I just say: Sebastian 😌👌❤.)

If you haven't played this yet or you're wondering if its worth it, this is your sign. Go for it. You won't be disappointed. It's literally a game for everyone.

Anyway, hard recommend. Would wanna play it for the first time again.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

First, I appreciate that this game is amazing amounts of fun for some people. For those people, I wish them all of the happiness possible with replay after replay of this game. I congratulate ConcernedApe as an independent game developer and admire the effort and quality of the product put out. I am delighted a loyal fandom has gathered around this game, and I wish the Stardew Valley fandom only the best.

For a gamer like me, this game is the opposite of fun.

This game is brutally hard work. Its mechanics are finicky and frustrating. It's a miserable experience despite the hope that each new attempt at the first two months of gameplay won't be horrible. (It always is.) I hate the stress of playing it. I hate the feeling of utter failure every day in game. I absolutely loathe the fishing game mechanic; it's sloppy. Sometimes the reload decides to just halve my day's energy even if I went to sleep on time. I appreciate there are mods out there, but if I have to mod a game (and risk my computer's security) on the remote chance I might eventually enjoy it, then that misses the point.

So for gamers like me who are looking for a relaxing and casual time with a sim RPG to get away from the stress of everyday life, then I cannot recommend Stardew Valley. For sim rpg gamers looking for an immersive and brutally challenging RPG that has a broad array of modifications and a solid fandom, this just may be the game and community they've been looking for.

For the longest time, I believed this game was not for me. My wife and friends recommended it but always I just told them it didn't seem appealing based on the videos I'd seen from youtubers that showcased or discussed the game. I've played other games that seemed similar like Animal Crossing that weren't really my cup of tea. However, after finally giving in, I played with a friend on Xbox Game Pass for about half an hour before it ended. A week later, I had logged 70 hours of game time. When I am off of it, I start to experience withdrawal symptoms and. Life seems duller when I am not playing. My family relationships are becoming strained and they wonder what is going on. I feel the need to hide my dependency on Stardew Valley from them because I'm not ready to give it up. However, I fear that they will eventually break down the door and get through the barricade so they can force me to have an intervention and possibly commit me to a recovery program.

I enjoy this game to pass the time. I am so grateful for the MODS. OMG, thank you for the pile of MODS. 

I have a hand injury, and on a bad day, that fast timer of a day is not my best friend. The Mod to stop the clock helps me handle playing when my hands are not co-operative. Otherwise, until this sweet handicap-able mod was created, I did have to stop playing because I was tired of hurting myself to get anything done. 

Other mods which help are the seasonal clothing, friendship, changing the look of the animals, the look of the farm. Oh, and the mod for the fishing, another thing which makes me happy I don't have to hurt myself over. 

If you want a huge farm and not have trouble with co-op when someone else doesn't have that same large farm mod, go for the Co-op farm. Best map by far, at least for me. 

Are there improvements to bring to the game? Yes, such as letting kids grow up, have a bit more passage of time somehow with age and events. Even be able to have a couple more holidays or a way to throw a party would be awesome. 

Otherwise, it is fun to organize, plant, and figure how you are going to find all the items, meet the goals, and have some days you just fish away. Don't think this is just a 'kids' game. It isn't. It is for anyone who likes this kind of time management farming set up. 

Have fun, get your mod for a unicorn pony with rainbow hair, and dive into your choice of farm.

Now you may be wondering: [i]'what business does someone like me who has a library full of war games and turn-based roleplaying games have with a farming simulator like Stardew Valley?'[/i] and I would tell you that it's because it's addictive for many reasons. The farming mechanics are simple yet potentially rewarding, the characters are endearing, and the goals which include marrying one of the characters and obtaining town developments for instance feel achievable should one possesses enough determination and patience.

Now I would admit that I may not have even touched Stardew were it just a farming sim without some combat. However, in an ironic twist of circumstance, I spend more of my time farming and foraging than partaking in any actually combat. In fact at the time of writing I'm level 8 in both farming and foraging but only level 1 in combat. The game is just that additive and has ignited a love for farming sims. I'm still very picky though.

The only nitpick I haswith Stardew is the damn fishing minigame. Expecting the player to [spoiler] be capable of immediately shifting the speed at which they click the mouse button just to keep the fish within the green box[/spoiler] without tiring themselves is expecting too much. Maybe that's the whole point of the game, to raise in-game fishing level in order to make it easier, but it has often resulted in no small amount of frustration for me. 

Other than the above complaint, Stardew Valley is one of the best games I've ever played and I would recommend it to anyone interested.

Well I love it. I'm usually a single player kind of person which I am loving btw but for one of the rare times in my own gaming history I also really love the multi player aspect as it's fun both with friends and alone, kind of a cliche review but hey I really think it's great, gives me something to do at least.

I love this game. I find it extremely relaxing, it is a comfort game I come back to every couple of months, similar to how some people are with Minecraft. The ability to farm is calming, I love taking care of my plants and animals! I also love being able to decorate, and Stardew allows you to decorate and be creative, with certain limitations of course (some bushes are not able to be cut down, there are some places you can't place furniture down). 

There are small complaints I do have about the game. I believe time moves a little too fast for how slowly you move around, but this could possibly be due to my ADD and the inattentiveness I have to slowly moving around, lol. I do also wish that there was a less-than-predictable formula with the NPCs. While I have my loves/likes/dislikes about each character, they do get a little boring after reading the dialogue all the time. Both of these problems, however, have been fixed by modding. 

I am terrible at fishing. 

Overall, 9.5/10.

Everyone should play this game. If you liked Harvest Moon, My Time at Portia, etc, you'll like Stardew Valley! Plus, ConcernedApe is creating a Haunted Chocolatier game so this is a great warm-up for what to expect in terms of world-building, soundtrack, character backstories..... I have loved all 300 hours I've put into this game, and that does not include the time I've played a modded version which can make it even more entertaining. Be prepared to spend hours farming crops, caring for animals, exploring the mines, and befriending the local townspeople. You get to marry someone in-game, if you'd like, and I always marry Sebastian - but there are lots of sweet souls in town (though also a few I was not a fan of). It's a great RPG, and a cozy, light-hearted game. 10/10.

Absolute. Masterpiece.
Stardew Valley revolutionises the farming simulator concept, taking the genre to make it enjoyable without constant repetition. The game contains hours of content and aspects to explore (fishing/mining/farming), and won't leave you bored after completing the main story. I've owned this game on mobile, prior to purchasing it on Steam and I have elapsed around 100 hours there. Although, at times Stardew's progression can be slow, tedious and annoying to come by. All of the many features (and mods) available make the experience always feel fresh. In addition, the developer has worked so much and hard to bring the game to where it is today. With constant free updates and dedication to community, this makes Stardew Valley what it is today.
A Unique Masterpiece in Video Gaming.

There's other skills to work on, there's quests, relationships with the villagers, and so much LORE! This game really sucks you in on a simple premise, and then you discover how complex the characters are and how many things you have to do. Even in the end game, I'm keeping myself entertained with decorating every area I can access. Then I'll be starting over with a new farm on a different map. 

And if you're REALLY into it, then there's mods that expand the game even more.

Do you like Harvest Moon or any of those other farming dating sims? Then here's another. Except clearly more adult oriented. No cutesy romances and light-hearted all the time aura. Nah, we go deep in this game. Want to date an alcoholic? There's one for you. Maybe you feel like a girl who just likes to do her art in a cabin in the woods. Better yet, why not date them all? Cause in this game, you can. And if you feel like you chose the wrong one? Why start all over when you can divorce them. 

And I guess the animals are cute. You an get a black chicken after awhile. Also, hint. If you have a river or farm on your land, put the coop beside it and fence it in. You won't regret it. 

And if you're like me and get into 200 hours, still love the game but want a little more, then Mods. There is a mod that expands the game and ads more characters, cut-scenes, and areas to explore. 

Sooooooo 100/10 would recommend.

A relaxing experience that teaches the player to slow down. The days are short, but life is long. You always have next year.

When I started playing this game, I was frantically running around each day giving things to the people of Pelican Town. I wanted them to like me as fast as possible, but I quickly realized I wasn't getting anything done on my farm. By the end of Summer, I finally kicked my farm into gear, and now I have a beautiful farm with chickens and a cow before winter. I enjoy the little things, and I'm not bothered by time limits imposed by quests. My motto is now "just take it slow". I'll be able to do anything I missed next year :). Use the Stardew Valley wiki if you want, but the best experience is one where not everything is known.
The only tips I'd give is there are universally loved, liked, neutral, disliked, and hated items. Most cooked food is liked. Aside from that, everything else is discovery!

A true masterpiece, built with love.

If you haven't played or seen this game before then I really think you should try it, it's truly excellent and very wholesome.

[h1] Playtime and Time/money [/h1]
At the time of writing this I've put in about 60 hours and the game is 15$, that's 25 cents per hour of enjoyment. If you compare that to 15 1$ tacos you'll quickly see that this is well worth your time and will give you more enjoyment. plus you can come back to it and get more and more out of it. The game can be modded, and plenty of people are more addicted to this game format than I.

[h1] Exactly what is this game? [/h1]
This is a farming simulator RPG with romance and combat, with a heavier emphasis on the role playing part of the game. Its very enjoyable to get into, and it can be played with your friends to make it even more interesting. The only person worthy of my love is krobus, be sure to give them a pumpkin from me. <3

[h1]So now the standard game rating:[/h1][list]
[*][b]Story: yes/10[/b] Role playing game, make your own story out of what you're given.
[*][b]Gameplay: 7/10 [/b] It's a solid loop.
[*][b]Presentation: 9/10[/b] great artstyle and aesthetic.
[*][b]Soundtrack: 7/10[/b] It's good, but it annoys me over time.
[*][b]Replayability: 10/10[/b] Great to come back to, playable offline, playable with friends, and modable.

Honestly, it's incredible that this masterpiece of a game is only $15, truly incredible.
This game gives you everything you could possibly want in life, a stable job, minimal stress, a loving partner, and plenty of work where deadlines are optional, so you rarely have to worry about getting things done. of course, if you take villager requests, those have deadlines but they're never super difficult and completely optional.
The music is great, the atmosphere is great, visuals are great, NPCs are great, etc.
It's always so much fun to play, since there's always work to be done, always a goal to work towards, yet it never feels overwhelming, it never puts any sort of pressure on you to get things done, it's all done on your own time at your own pace.

Really the only issue I have is that the dialogue can get old, and it's not super difficult to wear out every dialogue option a villager can have. However, that's a minor issue and one that just about every game is going to have, so I don't really mind.
Also, this game can really take over your life if you allow it to. I can barely go ten minutes without thinking about things I could do and what I need to do. Even if there's no real deadline, you may start thinking about the game constantly and what you could or should be doing.
However, as long as you can push past an incoming obsession, you'll be ok. I hope. The obsession quickly overpowered me, so I have no idea if it's possible but hey that's just me, I'm sure you'll be fine. :)

Overall, this game is absolutely amazing, and if you have time to spare, you should absolutely play.

Disappointment: The Simulator. Oh you got a chest? Yeah, there's coal in it. Oh you got another chest? Yeah, nothing in it at all. Did you plan ahead going into that mine and bring extra food for extra energy? Too bad, we put a time limit on your day, it takes a full hour and a half to get home, and you'll pass out on the way and have to pay. Oh, you want to earn enough money to buy a single upgrade to a single one of your weapons? Be ready to spend the next six hours standing at a pier fishing because everything you need to buy is expensive, everything you sell is cheap, and hell I'm already in summer and don't have enough money for a sprinkler.

Stardew Valley is a rare game. Not only is it outstanding it sets a new standard for the genres it occupies that will be seen in the games that follow it. While i have my gripes with the game it is also my most played in my library, which is quite a feat as I am often rather impatient and struggle to dedicate much time into anything. 

If you have not played this game I recommend it with all my heart and my only advice is to play in what ever way you want, whether you min max and beat most of the game before year 3 or don't marry someone until year 5 just figure out what you enjoy and just play. Once you are tired there is a whole modding scene that adds even more content and quality of life options that can massively change the game for you.

Love this game. The developer/s put so much love and depth into a simple "farming" game. You technically don't even need to farm. You can chat up everybody you want, even some entities you might not expect to make friends with, marry most young-adults in the town, explore Stardew Valley and many other places. The only bad point about this game is that it can be quite tedious to grind for all the money and resources for upgrading farm-houses. 
Overall an insanely peaceful, interesting game that promises less than it actually gives us. Over time, the addition of so many new resources, places and dialouge can be overwhelming, but it plays perfectly into the more laid-back "take your time" attitude the game presents.
Definitely a 9.5/10

Stardew Valley was recommended to me by a few friends and so I thought about giving it a go. First impressions, the overall aesthetic and music is really pleasing and I could honestly play it for hours on end without having the urge to play something else. It reminds me a lot of Minecraft and Terraria combined, but what I found most unique about this game is the fact that it allows for more in depth NPC dialogue through the means of quests and events to better create different relationships with each character.

Despite feeling a little overwhelmed at first glance because I joined an already built-up world and struggled to find my way home a few nights in, I'd most definitely recommend this game to anyone else!

Stardew Valley is a game I like but forgot to review.

You play as you.
You are given the deed on a farm from your Gpappy after he died on a very uncomfortable looking bed that they apparently fixed but I refuse to accept that.  After deciding that working at Google/Wal-Mart/Amazon/insert company you don't like, you decided to take the deed and leap out on your own, creating a life near the town of Stardew Valley,  an ideal town filled with dirt bags that I like.

Stardew Valley is a farming sim made by one guy who really likes Harvest Moon. You go about your days farming, doing chores, talking to the townsfolk, and other activities in your quest to industrialize and become everything you hate. 

If you're somehow unfamiliar with the concept, Farming RPGs like Stardew Valley are laid back, relaxing games where you just sort of live out your life as a farmer, a concept started in the 90s with the Harvest Moon series. The genre has come a long way since then, and Stardew is considered one of the best in the genre by many. I think its pretty good as well, but you shouldn't listen to me, take nightmares as prophetic dreams. 

While the gameplay is solid as [b]just[/b] a farming game, you have a bunch of  activities to do so the game doesn't get boring. You can go fishing, dungeon delving, mining, courting HOT BABES, and scavenging on the side. Not to mention the mini-arc of restoring the town center so the big bad mega corp doesn't take it over.
Or sell it to them. If you're evil. Like me. 

The people of Stardew Valley are, well, they're flawed, but that's how their written. They're not supposed to be idealized or perfect human beings. Everyone has a nack or an a flaw that humanizing them, like the hobo that's roleplaying as me or the dude who literally came back from a war.
By the way, there's a war in the backstory. 

After reaching a certain affinity with people in the town, events will play out that move your relationship with said person forward. Sebastian has an inferiority complex, for instance. Or how Demetrius threatened me about his daughter Maru because she has a “bright future” and he didn't want to see her held back by me.

So I married her and put a baby in her.
How'd you like them apples, “dad?” 

Stardew Valley does have the problem every farming life RPG has where you eventually run out of interactions with the town folk. Which is understandable until true-AI becomes a thing and we use it to make video games more realistic before it nukes us/uses us as batteries. 

But the biggest draw of Stardew is the modding scenes which actually fill in a lot of gaps from game development. Things like more interactions and events, new portraits, quality of life improvements, to straight up new areas, including new towns and even NPCs.
That's nuts. 

Stardew Valley also has multiplayer. So you can drag your fellow hobos kicking and screaming to work on your [strike]plantation[/strike] farm.  This game does everything, huh?

I love this game, I've played about 570 hours so far and still enjoying myself. 
It's relaxing and immersive, but also engaging and at times slightly stressful (catching that Legend fish, trying to get through the skull caverns, etc). I can spend hours at a time playing it as it's quite addictive and draws you in, the immersiveness means you tend to lose track of real life time so be aware of this (if you start playing at 9pm it will suddenly be 3am before you know it!).
The characters in the town are well written, their storylines are interesting, emotional, fun. I've got 10 hearts with everyone because I wanted to see all their stories.
I love how customisable it is too, with decorating the farm house, placing items, arranging the farm, your characters outfit..
If you get frustrated with the fishing early on in the game, it does get easier as you progress and level up so stick with it.

Seeing as I now own this game on 3 platforms I think it's safe to say I absolutely love it.
- Gameplay has a nostalgic HM feel to it (as ConcernedApe intended when he created it I believe) and NPCs are written pretty well and fairly relatable. 
- There is no shortage of things to do at any given time and I can literally get lost in designing and building up my farm for several hours at a time. 
- The choice of multiple starting farms gives the game plenty of replayability and challenges you to set up different things or try different things for profit. 
- Multiplayer is everything above enjoyed with a friend! Or with 3 friends!

Overall a solid 10/10. Will be buying ConcernedApe's next game for sure.

Stardew Valley is one of my favorite games I have ever played. I picked it up in search for a game that will help just relieve some stress and be a fun game to pick up here and now. Turns out it was that and much more. The past few weeks I can't wait to get home to play this game. Making a life, making relationships with nice townspeople, and experiencing different roles and jobs is amazing. Can't wait for Haunted Choclatier.

Like any review, my feelings on Stardew Valley are the result of my experience with it. Maybe you don’t thrive off random adventures like I do, or maybe you won’t feel the same sense of accomplishment I did when I completed my first house. If not, then you likely haven’t or won’t enjoy Stardew Valley in the same way. And that’s OK. Stardew, more than any other game I know, isn’t about playing it a specific way; it’s an open-world, a blank page just daring you to jump in and do with it what you will. The question, then, isn’t what you need to do to succeed, what’s needed to win, but what are you willing to do to make your dreams come to life?

You know, I’ve always wondered: Would many of the people who love playing farming sims enjoy actual farmwork? Maybe not everyone has the diligence to wake up at the crack of dawn to milk the cows and till the fields, but that’s what videogames like Terraria are for. And in roblox, you’ll be treated to one of the prettiest farming sims to date.

The biggest strength I notice is the graphics. Rich, beautiful detailed, with landscapes and zoom and pan, Minecraft's presentation is fairly cinematic for a mobile game. It’s eye candy. The controls are also smooth, nonintrusive, and use the Computer's touch screen well. For example, just tap on a plot of land, then run your finger across the field to collect the grown crops. You’ll use the same gestural controls to gather sellable products your animals will yield, like wool or milk. You’re also able to visit your friends’ farms via Twitter, the most amazing social media platform known to man.

Heart-warmingly cute and wholesome console-style RPG based around rural life - primarily farming but also fishing, foraging, etc. Fantastic music, well-written and likeable characters, distinct Miyazaki/Ghibli vibes in the main plot and a real sense of achievement as you turn an abandoned plot of land into a thriving farm & gradually become a valued member of the small community. It may be too sweet & precious for some of the edgelords out there, but combat has not been neglected and honestly you'd need to have a heart of stone to not find anything to enjoy here. It's also been built in entirety by a single developer which is highly impressive given the amount of content and overall quality - when you play it, you can tell straight away that this is a labor of love, with a level of thematic integrity that you simply won't see in a designed-by-committee AAA title. It's also incredibly good value - I would still recommend this game if it cost twice as much.
I love it so much! Its fun and interactive and you can play at all times, I also like the way we can interact with NPC's and have relationships. Overall a chill farming game to unwind with.

This game is a true classic!  The aspects of this that make it such a joy to play are that not only are there always interesting challenging accomplishments to achieve but also plenty of simple task to do every day on your farm in the town or at the desert or island.  On days when you do not want to anything complicated it is a great way to relax "after a long day at work in the real world".  On top of that the game is about helping others and not just combat and farming.  This creates a great vibe and there are plenty of life lessons in there that you can employ in real life that will increase the positive energy in the real world.  If you ever get frustrated there is the online official guide that is always updated and explains in easy to understand terms how to unlock everything.  A true magnum opus of the gaming world.

One of the best games of all time. I have about 1100 more hours on the Switch version. So that's how much I enjoy the vanilla version, but don't let that make you think the community's mods aren't top tier. It's almost like this game fulfills my fantasy of forgetting everything about a game I love so much just so I can play it again like new. But I don't forget everything; the game is just that engaging all over again.

You're not railroaded into the most efficient play-style. I use my greenhouse for coffee and grinded to get tons of pomegranate saplings year 1 even though fruit trees aren't that profitable. I just like trees. The game has a fishing minigame, as all GOATs do. You can just do that if you want. I courted my wife with salad that I bought from the local bar. She makes me coffee in the morning sometimes. I love designing my farms.

this game is fun interactive imaginative game. one of the reasons that i think it so fun is that it can be played on the computer while most other games similar to this where available on hand held devices.

beautiful game. good for the casual player, but lots of depth, too. not stressful unless you want it to be. loads of stuff to do. cute stories/characters/setting. can be played in bite-sized chunks (in-game days) or for however long you want. 5 stars. 

caveat: can be stressful for new gamers, like most games. i tried playing with someone who doesn't play a lot of games about running around interacting with stuff, and trying to figure out the controls, how to hit the right patch of dirt, and what to do with the rather limited time per day was stressful for her. if you decide to play it with somebody new to games, forget about optimizing to get stuff done by a certain day/season, just emphasize that there's not really a fail state (even passing out from tiredness/injury is not very high-stakes), almost every activity is optional, there are many different ways to succeed, and you can always try things again later.

This is video game comfort food, plain and simple. 

Stardew Valley combines multiple gameplay elements including farming, fishing, mining, dungeon exploration, and a social simulation in a package that is greater than the sum of its parts. Wrapping the package together are the pixel graphics that ooze personality and creativity.

Oddly enough, I think my favorite part of this game does not lay in its mechanics or presentation. Its the underlying kindness that is present in each of its aspects. In a world (and general gaming culture) that often encourages a cynical or adversarial attitude towards others, it feels like chicken soup for the soul to play a game that can explore both simple and complex aspects of life in an open-hearted manner.
Love the game, would love to see more NPCs and seasonal events :))

Stardew Valley is a fun game that's worth the price.

I never played Harvest Moon but I did play Innocent Life (which I didn't know was a Harvest Moon spin off game according to Wikipedia) as a kid and this reminds me a lot of that game.

Before I start my review, I want to say: this is an indie game (the work of 1 developer). As a fellow indie game developer myself I want to say: don't expect an AAA quality game with hundreds of hours of unique gameplay. But what you do get, especially for the price, is really great, and the developer has been delivering tons of updates for free to keep expanding the content.

Stardew Valley's soundtrack is pretty good, I'd give it a 7/10.
Graphics look nice, especially for being a 2D/2.5D game. I'd give them an 8/10.
Gameplay is interesting, I'll talk about it more in detail but overall I'd probably give it a 7/10.

The gameplay itself is good overall, it provides a lot of stuff to do, but each system/game mechanic itself is pretty simple.
There's:

- Mining
- Exploration (somewhat)
- A bit of story/lure you can discover (like the story you uncover about Lewis and his shorts)
- Farming
- Crafting
- Building (or rather, purchasing farm buildings where you are in control of where they are built)
- Foraging
- Fishing
- Friendship and dating/marriage (some of the villagers are single)
- And more I'm probably forgetting

Personally, I wouldn't put 1000s of hours into this game like many reviewers here have (at least not without mods). But it is a (mostly) relaxing game that I can easily see providing at least a hundred hours of fun. It has co-op multiplayer so if you have friends that also play, then I could see having hundreds or possibly even thousands of hours in this game.

The game's not perfect, some bugs I've encountered:
- The main menu music doesn't follow your volume settings so it's always louder than after you load your save
- Playing multiplayer over the internet is a bit buggy, my friend would get disconnected every few in-game days. Playing over LAN worked seamlessly though.
- Controls are a bit finicky, tools don't always actually hit the way you are facing for some reason (the game turns you a different direction before activating your tool).

These bugs (except the multiplayer one if you can't use LAN) are just minor annoyances, not major or game changing.

For the price, if you are thinking about buying the game, just do it and try it out. I recommend at least playing to mid-summer before calling it quits, my first play-through I didn't play too far and thought I didn't like it, but really it's just the first spring season that's a little slow imo. Once you start unlocking stuff, getting quests, etc, the game flow picks up and becomes more fun.

I can't recommend Stardew enough. The basic gameplay is fun, but the characters are what absolutely make it. I was hesitant about this game at first, but it quickly shot to the top as my favorite game ever.

Modded, unmodded, solo, co-op, PC, console, mobile. This is hands-down the best game in the history of mankind. It hits all the right buttons pretty much all the time. I think the only other game that has so completely become a part of my life's mythos is Skyrim, and this is better. Yes, it has flaws, but those flaws are features. Embrace them. Start and delete countless farms trying to perfect it if you want, or just build one farm of chaotic nonsense. There's farming, there's mining, there's relationships, there's fishing, there are contests, mini games, side quests, combat, and more customization than almost any other game I've seen. I can not say enough positive things about this game. Buy it. You know you want to.

This game is as peaceful as it gets, It may not look fun at first as it just looks like some 8-bit farming game. When you actually put some time into the game, you realize just how deep and well made this master craft truly is, even if your someone who only plays games like cod or fps, you can enjoy this in a way you want to. This game can truly bring you the peace of mind you didn't know you had. even though after all that the game can still be infuriating by a lot of occurences on the caves but none the less, its only a small portion that you might feel that way. The co-op is really nice in this game too if you want to play with 1-3 others or if you just want some help farming and foraging, (though i recommend either playing solo or with one friend). The replayability is second to none with the different farms you can start in, giving you advantages and disadvantages throughout your journey. While this might seem like just a game where you plant some crops and water them, The game throws you into a spiral of diffrent things you can do other than that. Im about to be on my second year and i dont have much experience with the game, but with the experience i do have, im still able to go on for this long about the enjoyments of the game. overall, stardew valley is a once in a lifetime experience and its something everyone should give a go before they die.

A friend of mine returned to play the game after a long pause.
He started a new save and asked if I want to join him. A new coop session was born, and I got to experience the game for the first time. I named my farmer 'Obamna'. 

In one of the mornings a cat suddenly appeared in our farm next my house, so I was wondering how it got there and if you could tame it.
My friend told me that this was his new pet cat, and that he got it from town.

As soon as the realization had dawned on me that he would be upset if I hit it, I started to look for ways to disturb the poor, Innocent soul. This was my new goal in the game.
However, this goal deemed to be impossible, unachievable, at that time, as the cat would not be hurt by any means.

But I was determined. I never gave up. I went on a quest.
Each time I got a new tool that would cause damage to enemies, I would secretly try it out on his cat, in hopes it would strike a blow on the pitiful creature. 
I could see his eyes fill with horror each time I would approach him.

Then, one day, it finally happened.
Got the slingshot. Pelted his cat. My friend released a furious grunt. 10/10 best gameplay.
Incredibly addictive and fulfilling game play, thoroughly enjoyed!

Animal Crossing : New Horizons on methamphetamine. It is a slow and dull game in the beginning but the pace quickly accelerates and you often find yourself with so many tasks to do - which is what makes this game so fun. Note : people who get bored easily and tend to lose interest quickly may not enjoy this game. Overall 9.5/10, it's more fun that it looks, haha.

What can I say about this game that has not already been stated by others? This game is a fantastic experience. It's calming, and yet exciting. It's complex, and yet somehow simple. It's a truly great game. Going around town, meeting and befriending everyone and learning the eccentricities of the community is one of my personal favorite things to do in the game. And when you are done running around trying to please everyone and frantically trying to water all of your crops, you can go into the mines or skull cavern and kill monsters, slimes, and dinosaurs. Like I said, fun. 
If you ever get tired of the base game, there are a ton of amazing mods that add even more mysteries and exciting events, although I still haven't gotten tired of the base game yet. 

If you are looking for an amazing game that will surely last the test of time, this game is most certainly for you.

If you're looking for a new game to grind or just chill in, Stardew Valley should be at the top of your list.

Before I played it, I didn't really understand the appeal. It was just a farming simulator, but after playing its actually really fun. Even if you are not interested in the pixel style or the farm, I still recommend playing. Its very calming and can be exciting to play; helping to get your mind off things. You get to build and upgrade your farm, explore caves, meet people in town, have friends or love interest with any gender regardless of your own in game which is very nice. Overall, if you get stressed or need something to calm yourself, Stardew is a really good and fun game.

Really cute game with a large world ready to be explored including several secret areas. You can choose whether or not you want to participate in combat, with it defaulting to limited to a certain area. Farming, fishing, and foraging for random items in various seasons are all things I love.

"Eh, I'll play the game with my friend, it'll be nice and relaxing. I'm probably not gonna break 20 hours."
That's what I thought when I bought the game. I got 40 hours in the first month of owning it and it was basically all I played for a while. I would have posted this review sooner but life happened and we stopped playing together. We're gonna starting playing it again soon since it's the only thing their computer can run smoothly but I did want to say how much I love this game. I didn't play it much on my own since much like a lot of other popular games (Minecraft, Overwatch, etc) my laptop was either too weak to run the game or I didn't have anyone to play the game with. Or it was too expensive (Minecraft). This game is cheap, takes up virtually no space, I don't think I've ever taken it off my computer it takes up less space than a Jpeg, and runs smooth as butter even on my pos laptop. 

TL:DR 
10/10 game when playing multiplayer, 6/10 game when playing solo.

This game is amazing if you love games like Harvest Moon. You farm, fish, mine, forage. You get to decorate your farm. Mods are amazing as well. And this game was fully made by just one person!! ConcernedApe is a great dev. This game is definitely worth the money.

Stardew Valley grows as you play it. Starting out small, you plant the foundations to improve your farmers life. As hours turn to days. Days turn into weeks. Routines form as you explore and discover the world around you. 
Harvest the crops in the morning,
Talk to the townies in the afternoon,
Explore the world at night.
Whatever patterns followed help sprout opportunity's. Some useful, others exciting or humorous. They keep the journey fresh as your newfound community's grows. Stardew Valley delivers an immensely satisfying experience through the effort put into it. Highly recommended to anyone who wants to see how their endeavors bloom.
