Very enjoyable farming game loaded with enough content to keep someone occupied for at least a hundred hours.
The game is more enjoyable if you avoid looking anything up until the second year in order to capitalize on the sense of discovery.
The game is also more enjoyable if you take task completion rather casually instead of competitively. It is okay to miss some goals in the first year. It is fine to not maximize profits every single month. I ended up playing through 7 years of the game and the only thing that ruined it for me was a single item that most people won't try to obtain.

On the other hand, the creator of the game felt constrained by the focus of the game (farming and interacting with the nearby environment) and, in my opinion, progressively added content that was pushing the boundary as to what should be in the game.
There are some areas further into the game that are single-use or extremely rushed/unrefined (ironically the last scene in the game lol)

The rest of this review will be a rant from a player that had about 50 hours of their life wasted on subjectively dumb choices.
I have mixed feelings about this game after completing it to 100%. I loved most of my time in the Valley, but I absolutely hated some of the decisions that the creator made.
The game was originally designed and marketed towards farming, socialization (residents of the game), and exploration. 
Why would you add items/achievements that are only obtainable through absolutely infuriating means that are completely unrelated to the rest of the game? (Fector's Challenge)
Why would you make the most expensive item in the game (10 million gold) required for 100% completion after you've already had to raise at least 3.5 million for the rest of the items in the game going towards 100% completion?
(For those that would mock my last question) Why would you make that useless of an item 10 million gold in the first place. By the time someone raises the funds required for the item, they don't need it. At least make it stop time or something.
Why would you add an entire remote area completely removed from the rest of the game instead of expanding on the existing town and its restoration efforts? There are only two options to help the town after the main contribution of the game (keeping this spoiler free).
Why would you make the endgame challenges require 100 [item] and then leave 3-6 of those [item]s be completely locked behind a bug that is only fixed once you have access to the endgame challenges (LMAO)
Why would you add a tool that late in the game as an afterthought and have it be almost completely useless?
Why would you add basically two areas for 1 quest and then leave them completely useless for the rest of the game?
Why would you add a new area for a single item and leave it useless for the rest of the game?

ah, stardew valley my love.
it took me a realllyyyyy long time to figure out the playstyle and not want to do everything in one day, making it not enjoyable and just stressful. once i finally got the hang of it, i honestly adored it. (also half started playing because of sebastian.)
i didn't think i'd love the characters as much as i do, or the artstyle, or the ost, or any of it, really. it's a pretty unique game and it got me hooked the second i figured out how to actually play it. within the first couple days it had already gotten me drawing. i've already drawn around 6 of the characters and i haven't even been playing for that long. :sobs:

anyways, amazing game, i adore it. i can see how a lot of people think it nostalgic, so i'm just excited to come back to it in a couple of years and get all the memories of losing the egg festival to abigail and being rejected by everyone at the flower dance (and obviously many more) suddenly flying back at me.

Great game, art is very pretty, and it has an incredibly active modding scene. If you get tired of the base game, so many people have made their own offshoots of the story, or just revamped the entire game. Since there's also multiplayer, it's a wonderful game for families to bond over.

[h1] It's a great and lovely Game [/h1]

I like the aesthetics of the game the pixel art, the animation and the sound is lovely. It's very nice to play after a stressful day to turn of, and relax. At the beginning there are a lot of things to do, you can fish, fight in the dungeons, mining in the dungeons, planting seeds, feeding animals, foraging talking to people and managing your time and energy to do so.

It has also a nice Co-op multiplayer mode were you can build your farm with a friend. 

If you like farm games where you have to take care of your farm, like planting seeds feeding your animals but also like to go into dungeons, then it's the right game for you.

This game is one of those few indie gems where the game is worth far more than the price of admission. I think that the best way for you to experience it is to not stress about what to do. There aren't any real things in the game that "expire". Aside from a handful of quests, everything can mostly be done at whatever pace you prefer. Just play and do what seems fun to you. If you want to look at the wiki, you can, but try to go in as blind as possible.

If you're on the fence, just get it. You won't regret!
Good for ones who enjoy laid-back and peaceful gameplay
this is the 4th time ive purchased this game, and if i could id buy it 10 more times

I have CPTSD. If you're not familiar with it, it is Complex Post Traumatic Stress Disorder, even though I hate the negative connotation of "disorder".  It is literal brain damage due to multiple traumatic events. My brain was rewired against my will to respond a certain way to certain triggers and I can't control my triggers. Anyway, under the CPTSD umbrella is Anxiety Disorder, MDD, insomnia, trauma responses, and so much more that I don't have time to go into. One of my best friends suggested this game to help me focus on something other than the triggers around me in my daily life. Not only has it helped me cope in times of stress and high anxiety but it has also aided me in my social dysfunction as well. Here recently, things have gotten pretty bad. Like, call the hotline bad. Anyway, this game has been in my daily routine now for a few months and I have been able to visualize success in social interactions because of this game. My friends and I have a co-op farm now because I got to role play being a friend first. I've grown a lot just playing this game. With therapy, my friends, and this game, I've healed enough to be able to go to FanExpo this month. Wish me luck! And download this game. :D Happy Stardewing!

Here is my strategy guide. Set up a coal mining camp, send all of the children of the town to the farm and pay them 10 gold/hour. Pocket all of the profits. Passive income. Don't marry any of the town women. Waste of time. Send them to an ancient fruit plantation. Pay them nothing, pocket the profits. Serious profit. Kill the homeless guy. He is a freeloader bum. Send the men to the mine and force them to kill the slimes and mine from 6am to 10pm, do not allow them to slack off or take "breaks". That ruins profits. Pay them 100 gold/day, split among all of them. Provide no healthcare or benefits. Survival of the fittest. Invest all of the profits from the mine into weapons to steal cauliflower seeds from Pierre. Sigmas don't "pay" for what they want. They get it by any means necessary. Turn the entire town into your slave labor town, where everyone works until they die, lining your pockets, and barely being able to eat. Move on to the next town. Passive income. Invest into the rare fish market, hunt them all until they are extinct, leading to a rise in their price. If you have all the supply, and everyone else has a demand, you can control the prices. Get into insider trading. No laws forbid it. My town, my rules. This is what seperates the sigmas from betas, the winners from losers, and the rich from you bums.

If you find yourself preferring to manage tasks in sim style games rather than manage tasks in your RL - then you many not want to start this game because nothing in your RL will get done. Your children will starve, your house will be messy, you'll fail your classes, you'll get fired from work, etc ; )  Stardew Valley is about as addictive as it gets.

This game has the usual goal oriented farm tasks that you would expect like gardening, animal husbandry, crafting, house and land upgrading opportunities - but what sets SDV apart from some others of this ilk is the extended world beyond your farm.  There's extensive mining,  fishing, and monster hunting opportunities that will reap rewards that you can use to improve your SDV farm & life.  The SDV world is populated with towns folk for you to get to know and has many community activities for you to take part in.  Not only will towns folk send you on paid quests, but you have the opportunity to nurture relationships with them - even marry one of them and have a family of your own if you wish. 

The animation is charming and the interface is relatively simple and frustration free.  The tasks never become too repetitive as there is enough variety of things to do in this world, and this variety also allows the user to customize their approach to the game. Is the farm going to be your focus, or are you going to loose yourself in the depths of the mines, or are you going to become a bold monster hunting adventurer, or a master fisherman?  There are several different farm set ups to choose from and you'll have fun upgrading, improving and customizing your buildings and land.  Just don't forget to feed your kids - the RL ones, that is.

I look for Stardew Valley in every new game i want to play. 

*SLIGHT SPOILERS AHEAD*
Sandbox games get dull quite fast, even if there's a end goal you're working towards. In Minecraft, although the game technically ends when you defeat the dragon, the journey along the way is what most casual players enjoy the most, and that's where Stardew Valley shines. At the beginning, you are constantly frustrated at the fact that your energy and gold is too low to do anything productive, but somehow, every little bit of progress inches your further towards success. All of a sudden, you're in the midgame phase with around 10k profit every night, incubating void eggs to hatch cool chickens, and working to finish the community center. The game just feels very rewarding with every milestone you complete. It feels good that when you complete a difficult task, you're rewarded with a helpful item or sparkly sounds and a new star badge. I completed the 1000 slimes quest and was rewarded with the Slime Charmer ring, one of the most game changing rings for the Skull Cavern and combat in general. 

The small dev notes when you cheat are hilarious too. You want to glitch the game? Go ahead! Just know that CA is going to give you a snarky little message for abusing Clint's telephone line. Speaking of, ConcernedApe's story is amazing. Coming from someone who grew up on mobile and classic games such as Farmville, Penguin Diner, and Cooking Mama, this is the perfect implementation of nostalgia and modern gaming technology. There are videos up on his Youtube showcasing early previews of the game and it's just inspiring to see how he's reworked many of the games graphics and animations to what it is today. It's also just nice to see game devs interact with their community- CA hosted a Stardew Valley Cup not too long ago. I think the community surrounding the game is what caught me and kept me compelled. All the different metas creators have created and many people use in their games today and all the dedicated modders that work hard to build onto an already incredible base game.


At time of review, I only have 2 save files and one co-op save file that we abandoned in year one, but I truly just find a getaway in this game. There's just the right mix of RNG elements that makes the game alive. Waiting for lucky days to go out and do anything is another reason why I thiink I've lost so many hours to this game. The "oh, I'll just do my mundane tasks until my Skull Cavern run," makes you get a lot done, imo. All in all, if you're seeking a slow-paced getaway game, Stardew Valley is for you. There are so many surprises and easter eggs that just cannot be covered in a Steam review, you just have to play it out! Worth every penny.
fun relaxing game no matter the playstyle

Amazing game! I tend to get super interested in a new thing and then completely overplay it, resulting in me getting bored and then not playing it again. This game has been my favourite for 280 hours and I have yet to get tired of it. There is no end to the things you can do in this game, and no end to the kind of game you want it to be. You can be an achievement hunter, trying your best to get 100% perfection, or you can be a casual farmer, enjoying the relaxing atmosphere of Pelican town. You can try to earn as much money as possible, or you can take your time exploring the world. This game is truly well made and I look forward to spending an absolutely unholy amount of time playing it!

I have never played a game that was so obviously made as a labor of love as Stardew Valley is. Not only is the game engaging, fun, and immersive, but it is also clean, polished, and visually pleasing. The story and mechanics are great, the activities are diverse and each one has a very simple "skill tree". I have put the SDV soundtrack onto my regular playlist because it is just that good. There is not a single aspect of this game that disappoints. If I could only purchase one game on Steam this would definitely be it.

This is such an amazing game! I've enjoyed playing it alone and with friends and it's so relaxing! This is my happy place after a stressful day!

You do what you want and you can work at your own pace. I love varying between farming more seriously and regularly or skipping a farming season to focus on mines or quests or fishing. I now have 2 junimo huts, which makes this much easier and I can still have some income because the junimos will cultivate the crop for me. 
I've also enjoyed building friendships with villagers and seeing the cut scenes with silly or sad stories. But if stories aren't your style, you can always skip them. 

It's a game filled with quests, puzzles (especially on ginger island), and so many different activities including crafting, farming, cooking, fighting, fishing, mining, gathering resources, foraging, etc.  I'm very much enjoying trying to achieve complete perfection on the farm, which is the big, main goal of the game. (if you feel like doing it)

Stardew Valley is such a relaxing game, from chatting with the NPCs or planting your own parsnip garden. Even the mines, which can be somewhat stressful to conquer, are enjoyable and present a good time for anyone who plays. The seasons in-game give it a wonderful dynamic, and I can't help but get attached to all the characters, even the ones I don't like. The dialogue is often witty and the characters are all unique, with special traits that make them who they are. With hundreds of recipes, you'll never get bored making new meals, and finding secret missions and items, the game never loses your attention. There's always new challenges and items to find, or just new dialogue to see.

A great game with an amazing community. It's very easy to lose time while playing Stardew Valley between building up your farm, the community center, relationships with the npcs, and exploring the world. It's also a treat and a joy that there are so many mods that help to enhance to experience of the game or even make it feel like you're playing the game for the first time all over again. I can say with 100% certainty that this is not a game I will ever get sick of playing, and I will always recommend this game to anyone that enjoys games within the same genre. It's easy to pick up and play, enjoyable, and fun.

According to Steam, I've played this game for only nine hours so far, and already I'm in love! Stardew Valley combines some of the best elements from my favorite games, which I will not name here for the sake of the developers. (as a creator I know how hard having your work compared to other peoples can be) I love the melding of classic RPG mechanics like combat and spelunking with a calming farming aspect, as well as amazing character designs and dialogue between the characters. The energy and schedule mechanics are also a great way to keep the pace up, and it can be really stressful (in a good way) when you're 10 layers deep in the mines and realize you have 1 in-game hour until your character passes out then and there. I'm always kept on my toes in there!

At over 1800 hours in less than a year and a half of finding this game, I think we can clearly tell how much I love this game. This is my comfort game. My come home and decompress from a stressful job and the every day trudge of living every day with depression and anxiety. This makes all of that melt away for a while and you get to enjoy the simple things in life, even if it's just a simulated version of a simpler life. 

This video game is one for all ages too! My family and I live an ocean away from one another. I find it difficult to keep in contact and reaming consistent in people's lives. This game helped with that a lot! Now my mom (50's) and I (30's) make it a habit to spend a few hours most weekends playing Stardew Valley, sometimes my sister and her husband (20's) both play along as well! 

I know this is a long post, and it might seem like a really over dramatic thing to say, but I found this game when I was in a really dark place. I struggled to reach out and have a simple conversation with anyone, even people who I consider my inner circle. We were in the middle of a pandemic and everything looked so bleak. Now while Stardew Valley didn't fix the pandemic, or magically solve my mental health issues, it most certainly helped me cope, and it allowed me to forget about everything else, if only for a few hours. 

I cannot recommend this game enough. It will leave you with lots of fun gameplay that is equal parts challenging and relaxing.
This game has helped me manage through the hardest times in my life. This is one of my favorite games

I rate Stardew Valley a 50 out of 10. And I know that's not possible, but that's how much I enjoy it!
It's worth every penny and has so much to offer, 
Role play, Romance, Building wealth, Resource management, Comedy, 50/10 ;)

As a very big fan of simulation games- especially cute ones like this, I was absolutely taken aback by the amount of content this game has. When I first got it, I was on my iPhone and didn't really know much about the game. From that point on, I explored the game more and more. There are things for everyone to do- including fishing, mining, and working towards the community center. You can play with friends, or by yourself. The community center really helps with working as a team and working to reach a goal. 

This game gives a really relaxing and therapeutic vibe, leaving endless opportunities for play styles. You can go slow and enjoy the game for what it is- or you can try to speed run and add a certain area of challenge to the game. I have Stardew Valley on every console I have. Pc, Nintendo Switch, Xbox, and Ios. I have replayed it hundreds of times, and have never gotten bored. Not to mention that the developer is incredibly kind and we all admire him for doing what he did with this beautiful game. To have this all for 15 dollars is a steal- and I would have to highly recommend it.
It's very calming and I plan to get back into it this year.

I don't have many games that I am nostalgic about, but this is on the top of that list.
I remember loading it up for the first time and how it refused to load because it needed to be connected to speakers for it to work. I also remember the relief and excitement when I was able to get it to work.
The joy I experienced with every new discovery, and how angry I got at myself for using cheats before completing everything on my own. But even still, years later, I always end up coming back to Stardew Valley.

I enjoy this game immensely, in no small part due to the sheer variety of things to do.  There are multiple play styles available due to the skill tree. I'm also impressed that one person continues to make updates and additional content for this game. It's a beautiful thing to see.

I enjoy this game so much I play it on PC, PS4, and Switch, I don't do that with any other game, it's just got so much content, I can fall in love with the game just by choosing to follow different roads from previous play troughs.  I think I've played close to 300 hours on switch too, and a bit less on PS4. I still amen't bored.
Which is amazing after years of playing, probably the best value purchases I've made on steam.
Helped by the fact that the dev added in a hell of a lot of additional content long after the game had shipped, adding even more diversity to each play through. 
A nice game for co-op multiplayer too, it's enjoyable to guide a new player through, and once they're fluent in stardew, its great to watch the farm grow, to go to events together, and hey! you can even marry your co-op partner! how many games can say that? Or that it let's you have the sweetest monster roommate in the world? and I do have to give it points for having 8 romantic options, which include men or women and anyone can marry any of them.
It's as good as any harvest moon game I've played, and much better than any modern game in the series, yet it has its own heart and own identity to me.
If you're into the harvest moon farm sim genre, in my opinion, you cannot do better than Stardew Valley when it comes to bang for your buck.

Bought it in a bout of impulse hyperfixation; It has been more or less four days and I've made it to year two. I've been clinically diagnosed with a few things, but my OCD is probably the main contributor to why this game sits so well with me. This game is the perfect outlet for the stress my brain soup causes me. 

There's always a clear cut goal in sight, never a moment to forget what your doing or let your mind wander. the fact that you have so many specific goals, and are on a tight, but not murderous schedule is great.  

The characters are amazing and the art is adorable. Linus is a king, a Bestie, and deserves the world. I am also very homosexual for all of the bachelors. and Haley, shes kinda a toxic favorite and I'm living for it. 

I'm only just starting to get my footing with a couple mechanics so i don't have a ton to say against the game. I don't entirely love how fishing is done, but that's only a minor thing for me. 

I wish it made things like you NEED to have the silo before you can get animals or you cant feed them, or that you can also fish with the C key on PC more clear. but i figured it out. There's a huge community that's very dedicated to keeping information things extremely up to date, and I'm very thankful for that.

Overall 1000/ 10 would neurotically farm virtual peppers for the rest of forever. Thank you very much to the creators and community :)

Perfect balance of task-based and free-form gameplay. The combat is localized to allow players to know when they should be expecting a fight on their own terms, and the combat-creatures are appropriately not-scary to go with the overall feel of the game. Some character conversations can touch on heavier topics without warning, but most of it is surface level. Unfortunately, the game is excessively gendered when referring to the player, with dialog being specified to the male or female option chosen during character customization. There is an in-game way to change your character, including gender, but it costs in-game money and the dialog remains heavily, strictly "Sir" or "Ma'am". The NPCs do not make note of any changes made to the character and doing so only changes the dialog's gender-based phrases and looks of the character. It is also impossible to rename your pets, though you can change what they look like when far enough into the game (in the same screen as the character re-customization), so pick a name you know you'll like. Beyond that, and a few (accidentally, i assume) abelist interactions made regarding George (the elderly man in a wheelchair), the game is very inclusive and an overall wholesome experience. There are ample secrets to found, and the farming base of Stardew Valley makes it enjoyable to keep playing even after all the main tasks and secrets have been unlocked. ignoring the typically optional dialog with the NPCs, I highly recommend this game.

This game has single-handedly ruined my life and put it back together.
It's addictive -- that could be a pro or a con depending on who's looking at it.

Would I recommend this game? Absolutely! It's one of the few games I've bought multiple times to have on multiple platforms. The reason is simple; the game knows what it is and how to execute itself with wonderful ease and amazing fun. 

I never played games this could have been a spiritual successor to, like Harvest Moon, but it is one of the calmest and most satisfying titles of its like. You can swap out the quiet calm of your farm for exploring the mines, spicing up your game and letting you enjoy more. 

If you're looking for a game with a wonderful soundtrack, a fun little story, and simple and easy mechanics to it then this would be it. 

It easily makes my list of 'Must Play Games' should I ever get around to making one.

I've tried games often recommended by the crowd that likes stardew valley (think animal crossing) and before felt as though there wasn't enough there for me to play for an extended period of time. I do not feel that way with this game. This game is a good cross-over between minecraft, sims, and a classic dating sim. There are essentially unlimited avenues to play the game, i'm about 70 hours into just one save and plan on starting another one (without abandoning the old one) to try out different choices. If you like farming, mining, monster fighting, fishing, and dating simulators.. this is a good game.

When I first saw the game I thought it would be kind of boring, but I decided to buy it anyways and I do really not regret! Itś such a cozy game, it feels like a mix of Zelda and Minecraft. You can play the game in many different ways, you can focus on farming, fishing, mining or the animals. It doesn't really matter what you do as long as you do it at your own pace and your own way. Make friends in town, get a stable income. Try to calculate when itś the best time to plant your seeds, There is so much to do and I cannot imagine ever finishing this game because there is so much to do and so many different ways! I do really recommend especially to play with friends,.. The only reason I would see not to buy is if you dislike "old" graphics. It looks way older than 2016 but it somehow really fits the style of the game. If you prefer to play something with more action minecraft or some other survival game would be more your thing, but if not then really grab this game! Its totally worth it.

my one (and only) beef would be the lack of elevator on the skull mines; as a player with hand mobility problems, combat is not exactly a suit of mine. I enjoyed the elevator on the first mine, as it let me brave the depths at my own pace and take a break/bail after only 5 levels, giving me the ability to go on short sessions while my stamina lasted and still return to my checkpoint later. the lack of an elevator on the skull mines is very dissapointing, as to go deeper then max 10 floors would be straining myself, especially with the presence of so many difficult monsters.

Non-the-less, that is a bit of a niche complaint; the average player will have nothing to worry about.

I would say the game that you must play if you have spare time. The music, the storyline settings, the map, regular updates make this game always fresh and exciting. You will feel the time pass away instantly, there are always tons of stuffs to do no matter your in-game progress, even after completing the game. I have spent hundreds of hours in this game, and I would say am not regretting this. (I spent 120h to complete the game and all achievements, it is relatively fast tho.)

The multiplayer mode allows friends to join in the server and it was a great time playing with them. The game is not fast paced, and it is relaxing, peaceful which is a great place for both gaming and chatting. 

Although there are some multiplayer issues, that sometimes, players cannot invite others on steam and some minor bugs, otherwise, I will say it is a 10/10.

Averagely good game for playing with 3 other friends as long as all of you could be online together at the same time. Festivals are relaxing, no competition at all, though multiplayer still prone to grieving. Control is fine, easy to master. Need mods to make this game more fancy. Some useful mods include NPC appearance mod, stuff check for beginners (with the cost of reliance of this really helpful feature), and mods for easy automation.

The downsides are problems when you play with bad internet connection. For non-hosts, moving to desert may costs more, more time wasted to go to the mine or even any other places, and lost benefit if disconnected exactly before the day ends. The game does instantly teleport player to the bed when disconnected. A LAN party is better recommended, tho.

I bought two copies of this game, one for my switch and now one for my PC. 

I was never a fan of farming games because I get bored really easily due to repetitive content and no real special things to find. This game squashed all of my concerns. I started playing this and was immediately hooked. There is a ton of content, interesting things to find, cool ways to customize your farm, and the ability to build relationships with characters that have their own likes and dislikes. 

You can absolutely tell there is an inspiration from games like Harvest Moon- another great farming game. I love that the problems I had with that game were solved with this one. Basically looked like ConcernedApe wanted a new Harvest Moon, but wanted certain problems resolved and set out to do that. But eventually it became a game of its own and set the bar for all future farming games.

It is amazing that this was all developed by one person and I can't wait for the new game ConcernedApe is making. I will absolutely be buying it.
it was so fun and worth the money, i love how inclusive the game is.

Stardew Valley is an open-ended farming RPG with a lot of depth and a good balance of sundry activities (mining, fishing, foraging, etc.), humor, drama, etc. It can be addicting and is a great game for both single player and co-op if you have friends. Every playthrough is different and if you want to keep things fresh, there is an abundance of mods available. One of my all-time favorites. I received this free as a gift but would have bought it myself and have gifted it to friends and family members.

[h1] Stardew Valley Is A Universal One-In-A-Lifetime Experience [/h1]

[b]From the moment I started playing Stardew Valley, something clicked. The urge to go as slow as possible while trying to do so much in a day is a thrill some games just can't provide. [/b]

[i]Stardew Valley has a message.[/i][b] However, you don't have to be centralized around the idea of the message all game. Some games have a meaning that the entire gameplay and story revolves around, however, the meaning of the game is only a tiny fraction compared to the gameplay. It's crazy how much 1 developer, with enough time and effort, can create something that can strike peoples hearts emotionally.[/b]

[b]Stardew Valley can be emotional, sympathetic towards other characters within town, but the next second your harvesting 5000 blueberries and making 50 grand. So many possibilities in Stardew Valley, it's insane. Without spoiling this game, I just want to say, if you give it a try, you can't go back. I'll give you 20 minutes and you'll be sucked in.[/b]

[b]Buy the Game.[/b]

If you don't already own this game, buy it now and join the hundreds of thousands of people who have fallen in love with Pelican Town and it's residents. At face value, it's a farming sim but it's so much more than that. You'll build relationships with townsfolk and learn new secrets. Uncover the magic of the Junimos and delve into the lore of what's beneath this charming little world. Sail away to a remote island and bring hope to those abandoned. Uncover treasures throughout the land, in the mines, caves, and volcano! Upgrade your home, decorate, plot your land, redesign for optimal farm production, keep farm animals happy, fish, make honey and wine, forage, and so much more! You may not know what you're doing in the beginning but you will soon realise it's all coming together and you'll be ready to take on new challenges. 

This game has an amazing fan community. You'll quickly understand why. I recommend learning more about the game's creation from the ground up. It's truly inspiring!  I've purchased collectors edition sets and will support the developers ongoing projects. Stardew Valley will always be one of my favorites!

When I first thought of posting a review I glanced at the game page and thought it said I'd played 3.4 hours.  In fact, I'd already played for 34 hours.  Time truly seems to fly when playing this game.  I've enjoyed every facet of this game.  
Whether it is farming, fighting, fishing or foraging ( a true 4F game) I've had fun.  There is something for everyone in this game and I recommend it.

Best game I have ever purchased in my life! I have played this since the first versions came out and I have adored it ever since. It is such an adorable and relaxing little game, I love everything about it, from the pixel graphics to the amazing little villagers with all their personalities.

Super chill game. Even more fun with friends. Building your farm up and getting your loot makes this game the best farming game in my opinion. There are several challenging things to accomplish, and just when you think you've completed the main part of the game, it opens up and reveals even more. There is so much to do, and your possibilities are endless. One thing that I will say is that for your first playthrough, avoid watching too many guide videos; that'll take away the chill vibe you get from your first playthrough. On your second playthrough though, go nuts; min max every day and get basically infinite money. Worth a play alone or with your friends.

This game saved my life.

I am 50.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

love love love. the co-op mode can be a little fussy sometimes but it never takes long to figure out. im america based and ive even been able to play co-op with friends in western europe with little to no issues. i havent completed my first full playthrough yet which shows how much gameplay it has. there's so many aspects and for me it never gets boring. this is really great to play with friends and to play by yourself, and is really good (for me) for destressing. 

only thing i would change is being able to upgrade your friends' homes on co-op mode, and them being able to pick which house they get when they log in for the first time. if that was an option i feel like it would be way more feasible to do super long lets plays with them long term. another thing is that if you have a coop world and your friend plays when you're not online, you lose hearts with the villagers bc you're not interacting with them. im not sure if theres a way to fix or pause that. overall very great game and 100% worth your money (for both the game and the soundtrack)

Get all the best aspects of Harvest Moon/Story of Seasons, some rune factory, purge all the bad and frustrating parts, put some more quality of life, some good plot, characters and some new cool mechanics, why not? Also, charge like 1/5 of what a normal story of seasons/harvest moon/rune factory would cost, then you have stardew valley. It's by far the best game in the genre, since it's release, and it just got better and better over the years. A dozen or more farming, monster ranching games release since 2016 but none were able to reach this one. Aside from terraria, it's the best bang for your buck you gonna get on steam for a long time. That is for the single player

Also, great music and charming graphics. If there's one thing that maybe you gonna find better in other games is the graphics. But c'mon, this whole thing was made by one guy.

Also, did you read that this game is multiplayer too? And it's so seamsless i can't believe, you and your friends can tend to different tasks at the same time on totally different parts of the game. While one tend to the crops, other can tend to the animals, other can go buy some seeds, other can go hunt in the dungeon. If you want to farm a lot you can all work at the crops at the same time, do whatever you want, i dont care, the game lets you! It's a feature so well realized, i never saw a AAA game put so much effort in it's coop.

If you don't know if you like this kind of genre, this is where to start.

Stardew Valley is exactly what you need at the end of a stressful day. The game is full of calming music and weather sounds. The in-game characters are diverse and interesting. You may find yourself becoming attached to them, I know I did! The game is endlessly re-playable, there are different maps you can try out and endless ways to format your farm. You can replay the game and try to get closer to different characters, or you can even try speed-running to get hearts. If you are looking for a calming game full of content or a stress reliever that makes you feel warm inside, this is the game for you.

I wasn't sold on this game initially. Everyone was talking about it. I was watching Lilsimsie (a streamer) a lot at the time, and she would often have Stardew days on stream instead of sims4. One day I ended up watching some of her playing Stardew and I ended up buying it that same day. My husband and I were obsessed with it. 

What immediately got me hooked is the same thing that keeps me coming back to re-play it. The atmosphere of the game is so relaxing. The graphics are an acquired taste, initially off-putting, but now, extremely charming. The story is charming. The decorating/setting up the farm is a lot of fun. The holidays, the way time passes, the seasons, everything about it. 

I love how on second playthroughs (or more like 5-10 at this point) you can go about it completely differently. First time we focused on farming. Second we focused on fruit and fruit trees for wine/jams. Third we did animals and farming. Fourth we tried just doing a small farm with mostly mining/exploring. There are a ton of ways to play the game to make it feel fresh.

I mean, what can I say about Stardew Valley that hasn't been said before? I was initially turned off because I was stupidly biased against the pixelated art but I'm so glad I changed my mind and tried this game. For the price versus content, you're getting so much. It's a hodgepodge of things: farming sim, crafting, fighting, rpg-ish. It's simple yet complex, it can be tedious or chill depending on how you play. I've played about 600 hours and I think I only started during lockdown. On top of that, there's a large modding community and so many mods that can add hours of content. Thank you CA for making this wonderful game!

I've outlined some good and bad things about this game below:

The Good
-there is SO MUCH to do it's actually ridiculous
-the romanceable characters are very cute and diverse in personality
-most of the heart events are solid, and i like that you have dialogue choices for these and when you talk to the villagers sometimes. the heart events will affect the game, mostly through dialogue
-very high replayability, as there are lots of choices affecting your playthrough
-the game is essentially neverending so you can just keep going in a save you really like. this also means you can set your own goals for yourself in game
-the game is still being updated, meaning there could be improvements later on. the ginger island update, for instance, was huge and added so much more to the game
-theres a lot of excellent mods
-the music is really good

The Bad
-the dialogue is very repetitive
-once married, your spouse doesn't really do anything. it's kind of depressing, they just kind of wander around and stare at household objects 5 out of 7 days. it feels like you've trapped them rather than married them, and they tend to lose that spark that drew you to them in the first place
-many of the non-marriageable characters can be kind of flat. i'd like to learn more about Marnie, for instance, and develop more of a relationship with her than is currently possible
-some of the controls can be confusing or frustrating, like how sometimes if your mouse is too far away you'll end up hitting a spot you didn't mean to and destroying your crops. i'd suggest turning on the thing which shows you where you'll hit immediately, at least until you get used to the controls

overall, this game is very good and definitely worth your time. 9/10

Gotta say, I adore this game. I grew up playing animal crossing, something about the simplicity of a life sim where you build yourself up slowly always captivated me. Though, the most recent game really disappointed me, but then I found Stardew. And honestly, this game is everything the latest animal crossing game wish it was. Though, comparing this to AC is unfair, the overall quality of everything trumps any of the newer features the games have to offer. I like how regardless of how you take the game, you're never failing. You can rush through, get married, focus on profits, and it's all correct. Regardless of what some fans may tell you, there really is no wrong way to play Stardew Valley, and that's honestly a trait i love in a game. A game that is so rich with features and story, yet no one way to "win" it either. It really is just a happy, honest little farming game :)
(though, one gripe, i dislike the combat, but not everythings perfect!)

This game at first looks like a wholesome farming sim. It is far more than that and it will consume your life!

You play as a farmer in a definitely apocalyptic world of war and famine. Capitalism is everywhere and the dead are now undead. The villagers are so realistic that most of them (If not all) are horrifically depressed. You will unfold a story so deep you will try to remember a time you thought it was just a wholesome game. 
Your character runs a farm (one of the few establishments not paying a tax due to the overwhelming need for new farmers to fight the food crisis.). 

The music will draw you in! Awesome soundtracks to fit the themes!

Choose your favorite villagers and look on the Stardew wiki to make sure you get them only gifts they like. As you get hearts with them cut-scenes will play and show you just how much the world has affected the characters. As you grow attached to the characters you will want to help them but there is only so much you can do.
Eventually, marriage will be an option and you can start a cute little family! [spoiler] You can choose to make children go away and that choice will haunt you all the rest of your playthrough. [/spoiler]

At one point this game broke the Geneva Conventions. It is true! Look it up!

Excellent and wholesome game to play alone or with friends.

A simple chill game where you move to you can plant fruits, vegetables, etc. on a farm, can befriend the townsfolk of Stardew Valley, witness the Jojamart and Pierre conflict (complete the Community Centre to see the best of it), and even fall in love and start a family.
 
The villagers have lovely and interesting stories for those that are interested in the social aspect (I recommend Leah's for best experience), the museum and Community Centre collections are good for completionists, and the feeling of success through farming, artisan creations, and mining can satisfy money/business-orientated players.  The seasonal events are fun at first, but lose their spark after playing the game for a few in-game years. Artifact, mineral finding are a pain but anything for a full museum! 

The multiplayer is easy to set up and allows you to easily make farms to play with your friends or significant other.
The in-game emotes are adorable and are my favourite part about the game even though it's such a small detail.

I, like others, have been waiting for a Harvest Moon game to come to the PC for such a long time. The Harvest Moon series has been one of my all time favorite series I've played since I was a kid. I'm so glad this game came out and became as successful as it did as so many other farming sim games have been starting to come out as a result.

There's multiple farm layouts to choose from at the start of the game each giving you an advantage in a specific skill and changing the main way you earn money and how you play during your playthrough. The game has farming, fishing, foraging, mining, combat, exploration, and so much more.

Like the Harvest Moon series you can grow many crops depending on the season, care for your animals and farm materials from them such as milk, eggs, wool, etc. and craft it into other items which you can then sell. You can get married and have children in the game, you're able to upgrade your tools, buy furniture, expand your house, get a horse stable, build chicken coops, sheds, silos, barns, and choose where on your farm to put them, and so much more.

The game has a museum where you can collect books, gems, artifacts, fossils, etc. and complete the museums collection. You can restore the community centre unlocking locations, buildings, and more.

There's so much you can do in this game and you can easily get more than a hundred hours, even several hundred hours just from a single playthrough. Not to mention there's various mods you can also install to add more content to the game and get even more hours out of it.

The game has great music and chill gameplay if you just want to sit back, relax, and have some fun in a stress free game (unless you're like me and make a list of the best gifts to give to every npc, make a list of which fish to catch during which season, time, and weather and make sure you get everything within the first year, and use a farm planner to pre-plan the entire layout of your farm).

This is another good cost to hours game, where it's only $17 Canadian (less during sales of course) and you can easily get several hundred hours or even more than a thousand. It has great replayability with so much to do in the game, just don't go to the arcade in-game and play Junimo Kart. 

I would easily recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of farming sims such as Harvest Moon, Story of Seasons, Rune Factory, Innocent Life, etc.

(Seriously, don't play Junimo Kart unless you're a masochist).

TLDR; Best game I've ever played! Great for playing alone or with friends. Super cute and fun; I absolutely recommend this game!

Stardew Valley is my favorite game I have ever played. I have always loved videos games growing up, and I've played all types of games over the years and I honestly would recommend Stardew Valley over everything else. It is a great mix of relaxing and content filled game. There is so much to do in the early game and mid/end game (there is not "end" to the game, but there are late game items and things to unlock which is what I mean by end game). The game is super cute and soooo detailed. Like amazingly detailed. Every NPC has an explore-able backstory and they are extensive and intricate it is amazing. The game is so impressive in even just that one aspect alone. The soundtrack is beautiful and just so calming. The animals are so cute!!! I love watering the crops and saying hello to the animals every day and getting to know all the NPCs. I play the game with my partner and it allows us to play video games and still spend time together. We both enjoy games and it's always nice to have more games that we both enjoy that we can play together. We have also played with other friends who also really love the game and we always have such a good time (except when someone dies in the skull caverns of course). It is the perfect game to play with friends or alone and I tend to have trouble finding games that are just as enjoyable in a group as they are as a single-player. I just can't say enough good things about this game. I 100000% recommend anyone buy it if they are thinking about it.

Good, relaxing game. Stardew Valley is a lovely land that you will get lost in. Whether you are farming, mining, fishing, or building relationships; this game is great! I love all the little details.

I was initially hesitant to buy this game. I've never been one for "life simulators" and typically hate doing any farming even in games. But one day. On a whim. I saw that it was super cheap and said. Eh why not. I played it for a little bit and was quickly overwhelmed. And then didn't touch the game for almost 2-3 years! 

Finally again, on a whim I decided to give it another try one day. And I fell in love with this game. It's more than just a simple farming sim. It's a community sim. The interactions with the people and rebuilding the community center. Just feel ... nice. And having previously worked for real world walmart. The MC's dislike of Joja kinda resonated with me. Making it feel a lot more personal. Even, more immersive.

Look there's a frickin list a mile long that could be said about what's GOOD about this game. And more is STILL being developed. And almost every single con I can think of is either being slowly patched by the dev themselves or can be fixed with mods. Even if you don't like this type of game. Give it a shot. There's a LOT more here than farming and talking to people. And if you simply have to have combat in the game that's there to. There's caves you can go in for resources and monsters to fight but ... you don't HAVE to do anything. 

Stardew is the most chill game i've ever known. The game doesn't care how you play it even if you do literally nothing at all. As long as you're enjoying your time that's all that matters. The only real end goal is having a functional farm by the end of year 3 but even that is OPTIONAL. Just get it. Try it out. And don't stress about anything.

The game's meant to be taken at a relaxed one day at a time pace. Who cares if something is suboptimal. Who cares if you're not making a million gold a day. Who. Cares. If you don't even do any farming. ... Just enjoy it.

This is the game I play when I am frustrated, upset, or otherwise down. This game brings me great joy and peace. If you want a game that is full of peaceful enjoyment, this is a game for you. I have nothing but positive things to say about this game.

If pixel art isn't your style, PLEASE don't let it keep you from trying this game. It's absolutely worth a shot if you like games such as Minecraft or Animal Crossing. Though the main gameplay elements are centered around the farm simulation, there's a ton of strategy and room to learn/hyperfocus with combat and mining elements. In addition to that, who you befriend first really matters. There's a diverse cast of characters, and certain villagers can help your playthrough along in ways that others can't. My favorite part about the game is how much it teaches you to fully utilize each day. Time goes by quick, and the only way to stop it is to not be actively playing (menus and dialogue will pause the game, for instance), so you have to plan ahead to make sure you stay on top of everything. The time restraint is even more evident in co-op, where pausing isn't an option AT ALL (save for very specific circumstances), giving it a certain challenge to balance out the extra helping hands on the farm. Lastly, it has great mod support if you want to tailor the gameplay or art more to your taste. I won't spoil anything, but this game has more content than you think, with more on the way. Give it a try if you haven't already!

Stardew Valley is a remake of Harvest Moon from an alternate universe where the developer had deeper ambitions than to dump out essentially the same game year after year with a lazy theme change and scant graphical upgrade. There's more plants, more upgrades, more activities, more choices, more villagers, and more waifus/husbandos than ever before, and it was all made by one guy. The daily routine is soothing and the relationships with the townspeople are surprisingly involving --option to sell out to Wallmazon aside.

It also has regular (free) updates, like it's some kind of labor of love or something!

This game is amazing for anyone who enjoys slow-paced role-playing games with an emphasis on NPC relationships. Even though the story is still relatively the same every play-through, there is enough variability that it somehow stays fresh every time you play. There are so many areas to explore, things to unlock, and people to meet in this game!

PROS:
+ Realistic NPCs
+ Many customization options, for an easily replayable game
+ Multiplayer support
+ Something for everyone, be it fishing, farming, caring for animals, combat, and more.
+ Very aesthetically pleasing, with many options for home decoration.
+ Lots of lore and story elements to puzzle over.
+/- VERY long. The Community bundles take a LOT of resources, and unless you check the "completable in first year" box, it isn't guaranteed that you will complete the community bundles in the first year. On top of that, there is still so much to do, so you if you're the 100% completionist type be prepared to invest a lot of time into this game.

CONS:
- One big con in my opinion is the lack of a gender neutral option in the Character creation screen. The game does allow you to marry a character of the same gender however, so I have some hope that the developer will add that at some point.
- The game does get repetitive and does require some micromanaging.
- The world is not large and does not have much to explore, though I suppose that's intentional because of the "small town" aesthetic of the game.
- The player character can only be altered late-game, with the exception of clothes: befriending a certain NPC will give you access to creating new clothes, though that does (expectedly) take a while.
- Sometimes the screen will be zoomed really really far out, seemingly for no reason. Using the built-in "zoom" option is not preferable as the game becomes incredibly blurry. The solution is to change your resolution to something else and back again, though this does not work 100% of the time.

Overall, a very well-rounded and fun game! Great for passing some time alone or with friends and family, and is sure to keep you occupied for quite a while.

But,  if you want a game that you can decorate, can make friends, can farm, can fight, can travel, can grind, this is 100% your game. 
A plus? It is also multiplayer so you can drag your friends down a deep, dark pit of your new obsession: Stardew Valley.

 It is so well worth the 14.99 and sometimes it goes on sale for 9.99 or cheaper. As much as I love discounted games, I would pay full price over and over again for this game.

Love this game, very peaceful and takes you out of reality and there is a lot to do as well. Farming, Mining and fighting are just a few. You can follow the missions and stuff that the other people give but it is not necessary to progress through the game.

When I first saw this game I thought it might be kind of similar to the game 'Rune Factory: Frontier' which I had played on the Wii.  I've eagerly awaited a port for PC but as of yet it currently can only be played on PC using an emulator.  Stardew Valley gave off some very similar vibes though so I thought maybe it might be close enough to sort of fill that same gap.

The game starts out simple enough, your grandfather left you a farm and you need to work to repair it and get it up and running again.  You chop logs, break rocks, till soil, plant seeds and harvest your crops.  There's a  lot of room to play around with your farm and where you want to place things.  There's also a foraging aspect which helps encourage exploration of your surroundings too.  The game is more than just a farming sim though, it also has RPG elements and you can battle monsters in the mines that in turn drop loot you can use or sell.  In addition to that it has some adventure game aspects such quests and some fairly light puzzles.  You can date and marry certain people in the town and even have two kids.  Later in the game you can even forge your own weapons and equipment and add specific power-ups to them.

I grew up on pixel graphics so I found the graphics to be somewhat nostalgic feeling.  The animations are fairly simple and the character sprites very 2D but the characters themselves, not so much.  Each character has a bit of a backstory and unique character traits you get to know as you build friendship points.  At certain levels of friendship you're given the treat of special little cut scenes.  You get to make choices on how you respond to the cut-scenes too.  Sometimes it can help your relationship or hurt it.  This adds quite a bit of story elements to the game.

Part of the beauty of this game is that you can play it in so many ways.  If you just want to have a calm farming experience, growing crops, playing around with aesthetics or optimal functionality in your builds, then you can play it that way.  The music in the game somehow manages a great balance of calming and upbeat.  If you want a little more excitement you can delve deep in the different mines and battle a variety of monsters and collecting and crafting better gear.  If you like adventure then you'll probably want to work on completing quests and solving the puzzles.  If you're more into stories you'll probably enjoy making friends with everyone and exploring their personalities.  Really, there's a little something for everyone and enough content that if you get bored there's something else to try.

In the early game it really feels like completing the community tasks mounts to a climax.  It's easy little goals to attain and strive for but once you finish the community center that's really just the beginning of the game.  You can unlock other mines, a desert, and an Island.  The game is much more expansive than you will first anticipate and it's possible that the developer may release future expansions to bring even more content and explorable areas.  The game does have a sort of "ending" in which you'll see a special cut scene but you can keep playing on so the game doesn't ever truly end.  You can also create a new character to play again from the beginning.  There are different farm types that present different challenges and benefits which make for a little replay-ability.

In addition to different maps you can also play this game in co-op mode with friends.  I don't personally like multi-player experiences, I prefer solo adventures, but I do like that if you chose to play this way each character can have their own house and while you can work together, you can also go off and do your own thing.  You aren't limited to the host's farm or experiences and guests can upgrade their cabin, get married, and essentially experience everything the games has to offer.

There are really only two things I disliked about this game.  First, there's the save function, you can only save by going to sleep (or ending the day by falling asleep outside your home/bed or "dying" in the mines {you can't actually die you just get beat to within inches of your life apparently}).  Sleeping ends the day and your game progress is saved.  However, I often find that I have to leave my game in the middle of a day when I don't have time or the ability to finish my day or even run to my bed so I can save.  Instead, I had to open the menu, which pauses the game, and then either just leave it running in the foreground or if I had to do something on my computer, let it run in the background till I could get back to the game.  So, for example, at the time of writing this review, Steam has 1,062.9 hours logged playing this game.  However, between my two save files I only have about 509 hours logged in-game.  So, it spent about half the time sitting open in the background on my computer simply because I could hit a save button and continue later.

The second thing I didn't like was the fishing mini-game.  I've played plenty of games that have fishing mini-games in them and they are all similar but all have their own unique flair... this one is the worst fishing mini-game I've ever played.  Maybe other people found it easy but I couldn't get how to catch fish.  There's something to do with patterns and clicking at the right times but I completely failed at it every time.  The only thing that made fishing redeemable was actually a mod that let me skip the mini-game portion.  While I don't necessarily advocate mods, I found the game partially unplayable because of this mini-game and it was really ruining my personal experience with playing the game.  The mod made the game playable and fun again.

Mods are actually one of the things that for some players could be a real plus side to the game.  Stardew Valley has a fairly large modding community with mods for everything from changing the NPC's dialogue avatar to skipping fishing mini-games to adding elevators to creating new expanded areas to explore.  If you find yourself too frustrated with an aspect of the game, there's probably a mod for it.  If you love mods for games you'll love this game.

The last thing I'd like to touch on is the game's achievements.  There's 40 of them which is a fair amount and most will unlock naturally over time with normal gameplay, but there are several collection based achievements that you have to work for.  Many of those require a lot of hours of game play.  For example, if you want to catch all the fish you won't be able to do it unless you fish in every season, some require reaching maximum friendships which can take a lot of time to build, and of course others require you to get a huge sum of money.  Collectible items are gained through RNG drops so even if you do everything right you could be doing it a long time to get those drops you need.  For completionists, like me, that can be very frustrating and it's a big part of why I had to put in about 500 hours to get all the achievements.  It could be a lot less or even more depending on your luck with the RNG.

Overall, this game is a gem, I don't usually recommend games at full retail price, but I'd say this one is actually worth it.

I made a long review complaining about the lack of racial diversity, but I'll say this shortly; the dating options on this game are lackluster and deeply melancholic. The relationships you form are inherently materialistic; all you do is hand out gifts like a bank account. Creating personalities and unique interactions will greatly improve the experience. Creating racially diverse NPCs will improve the experience of dating. You date people you are ATTRACTED TO. The NPC interactions are boring and if someone says this doesn't have to depict "reality" or "make a game yourself" doesn't negate the blatant racism of this game. If I were to "date" and engage in the poor lackluster option on this game, I would have to date an NPC, I would not be attracted to if my criteria were anything except "white". I would also not gain any main benefits besides the disappointing dialogue and horrendous interactions. If I had to make a game for every sad racist game like this, I would be a multi-million dollar game developer. You did everything right except the bad NPC interactions and deeply disconcerting lack of racial diversity. Sorry for being a Karen, but I just find these aspects of the game laughable how people justify it. Just don't add a dating option if it isn't beneficial and if It directly offends the preferences of its players. I don't find white people romantically attractive, so do something about it, Eric so people would stop being offended by your game. Otherwise, incredible game, you also subconsciously attract racist people, just saw a mod that makes Demetrius white... https://www.nexusmods.com/stardewvalley/mods/817/ Good job, Eric. I don't identify with any political party, nor am I an SJW. I just believe in being nice to people. Still going to play the game though, so who really cares what I have to say.

It's a great game to sit down and play after a long and tiring day. You're able to do things at a pace you're comfortable with, unlike in Animal Crossing: New Horizons, where you're restricted by time. As someone who's played both, I genuinely prefer Stardew Valley more. Which is surprising, considering I spent around $45 more for the ladder. You don't feel forced to 100% the game immediately, so you can take all the time you need to get settled, get to know the places and appreciate the small details. Definitely consider playing co-op with friends or family. This game perfectly encompasses what a relaxing farming sim should be like: wholesome, unique, and abundant in content so that you never get bored. Everything in this game comes directly from the heart, I can tell. So if you're sitting on whether or not you want to buy it, there are just zero issues all-around. I really can't think of another Steam game more worthy of my $15.

10/10

I absolutely adore this game. It is the kind of game that you can always come back to. It's a good way to get away from the crazy of the world. There are many different aspects to this game, and just when you think you've discovered everything, you find something new.

Outside of Steam's record time, I probably have another 200+ hours on this game on other consoles. This game is now my standard I compare to other farming games like Rune Factory, Story of Seasons (Respectfully very wonderful games too) and Harvest Moon (Who have gone very down hill over the years). To marry any of the marriage candidates is the biggest plus compared to HM. It's very easy on the computer and the soundtrack/sound effects are amazing. It's incredibly fun to play multiplayer too, it makes farming and making gold a lot easier, especially since you don't have to split up your days into just farming and mining, instead you can divide the tasks.

The only real downside is when 2 am hits in game. The fear in your co-farmer's voices as they race for the house and fall asleep on the front porch to be robbed is still pretty funny, especially when you're the one early to bed.

[h1]THUMBS UP [/h1]

You looking for an addictive farming experience. Well stop looking because this game is [b]it[/b]!
[hr][/hr]
Reasons:

✧ [b] Customization [/b] (From your character, to your farm layout, and even adding hats on things, this game has a ton of options!)
✧ [b] Story [/b] (Short and simple. Lots of room for story building of your own.)
✧ [b] Crops [/b] (So many crops to choose from! And some that aren't as well known in games.)
✧ [b] Characters [/b] (So many bachelors/bachelorettes to choose from! With all of them having their own set of engaging stories.)
✧ [b] Gameplay [/b] (From farming, to fishing, to fighting, and to playing arcade games. This game has a ton of different ways to play!)
✧ [b]Mods[/b] (The modding community for this game is insane!)
[hr][/hr]

Highly recommend this for anyone that enjoys a nice farming game.

ive played through the game to perfection, and i reached that goal after 200+ hours and 7.5 in game years (reached 100% on summer 2 year 8). great friends and all fish were the hardest goals for me to achieve, but it was a great incentive for me to actually fulfill that aspect of the game, which i normally wouldn't have done. i consider myself a casual player, but i always have big goals, like perfection or completing remixed cc, etc. 

my favorite aspect of these big goals is that i get to make lists, which ive discovered is something i really like doing, and i wouldnt have known that without this game. im currently working on my second perfection save, and im filling a notebook with information that i'll need, such as crafting and cooking recipes. 

this game requires so much effort, but at the same time it's effortless. i love it, and i recommend it to anyone looking for a casual game that also has non-casual aspects

Such a fun Indie Game. Always nice to find something different when all the newer triple AAA games come out bland or unfinished. No, this game right here, full of content. At face, it may just look like a top down farming simulator but, it is much more than that. Not only will you be doing farming, you will also be mining, fishing, foraging and fighting. As you progress, you unlock new items and have a choice between professions. At the Beginning, you have a choice between 7 different farm layouts (with one being more specialised for multiplayer). Each farm has there strengths and weaknesses. 

Now, the core crux of gameplay relies on you having great Planning skills. The goal is to make lots of money to buy certain items, upgrades, more crops, buildings, etc. You also have a goal in mind as you progress: Rebuilding the old community centre in which you need to give certain items to complete its many bundles. Each bundle will provide a unique reward. Completing them will unlock certain benefits, new areas and mechanics. Alternatively, you can buy a Joja Membership, destroy the community centre and pay gold instead of providing certain items. 

Because time moves very fast in Stardew, along with a curfew in which you will get knocked out if you are not in bed by 2am, you need to properly plan your day out.  While I personally found the walking speed to feel a bit slow and the time a bit too fast, I played with it for around 2 seasons and then after that, I got a mod which made my walking speed 50% faster to improve MY personal experience and found it a bit more fair. I still appreciate how the game tells you that you aren't suppose to do every single thing and need to prioritize one or the other. 

Farming is the main method of making money, from planting and harvesting crops, to building coops and barns to house animals. Foraging is required for crafting certain items for the farm, such as wood, tappers and seasonal wild seeds which provide a lot of early game value. Mining is also essential for crafting, finding gems to sell or gift and ores to convert into bars to upgrade your tools. Fishing is recommended for early game and shouldn't be ignored, providing various ways to make fishing easier or your crab pots more valuable. Finally, combat while simple in design is also essential as it is paired with mining. Since monsters are within the mine, you need to defend yourself with either a sword, hammer or dagger. progressing allows for additional food items, rings to boost stats as well as a slime press and incubator to make eggs or raise slimes which sell for a immense value depending on the egg. 

Along with building up your skills, you also need to interact with the many characters with a range of personalities, backstories, events and rewards they will give you If you improve there friendship. Improving friendship mainly involves finding the right gifts to give them. The Game does its best to indicate through dialogue what character loves what, along with a bit of guessing. Fortunately, if your having trouble finding a gift they like or love, the wiki provides all the information you need. In addition, there are "help wanted" requests where a certain character will need a particular item and they will pay you and increase friendship. There are also 12 characters in which you have the choice to romance. After reaching 8 hearts on one, there will be an exclusive event and then you can buy a bouquet to make them your girl/boyfriend, As well as a Mermaid's Pendant you can buy on rainy days which will then allow marriage. Spouses can have a chance to cook, water crops, fill up pet bowls, etc. 

There is so many things I've not yet touched one that would make this review too long such as the events, ginger island and much more but for a value of 1$6 AUD, this is well worth the price. This is a game brimmed with content and made with effort in mind, Highly recommended for someone that wants to try something new.

This is absolutely one of my favorite games and I have sunk so many enjoyable hours into this game. It is full of heart and the multiplayer option makes it even better. Not to mention the replay value of the game is incredible; I have created many farms and loved each one. Highly recommended to anyone who likes zen, peaceful, and lighthearted games. Stardew Valley can't be beat!

Absolutely adore this game. There's so much to do and explore with a seemingly never-ending list of quests and personal goals. It looks great, sounds great, is beautifully written, and runs well. Recently, though, I've been having issues where it struggles to open and to connect. Takes anywhere from 2 to 20 minutes to open, then another 2 to 40 minutes to connect to my friend's game (he's been hosting our world). Not sure if this is a game issue, steam issue, or computer issue, but it's the only steam game I've ever had this problem with. All that said, I love this game so much that I wish I could play it every day, and I think it's a game almost everyone would enjoy. Relaxing because it's engaging with a no stress story line.

Adam McIlwee (born March 11, 1989), better known by his stage name Wicca Phase Springs Eternal, is a singer-songwriter and producer from Scranton, Pennsylvania. He is a member of emo-rap collective GOTHBOICLIQUE, super-group Misery Club, duo Coward and band Pay For Pain. He is also a former member of emo-band Tigers Jaw and rap collective Thraxxhouse.

McIlwee started playing guitar at 13 and around that time he founded his first band, Closed Mouth.
During his middle school years, he played in different punk and ska bands (Green Chair, Bad Seed, and Captain, We’re Sinking, among others) along his friend Ben Walsh, but they were always kicked out.

In 2005 Adam and Ben formed emo band Tigers Jaw, which he left in 2013 to pursue a solo project. Wicca Phase Springs Eternal originally started as an electronic project, but once he started getting beats from producers he switched to emo/cloud-rap music.

His stage name Wicca Phase Springs Eternal was suggested him by visual artist Caroline Bren he knew on Tumblr. He emailed her “what do I call this project?”, and she just said “Wicca Phase Springs Eternal.” According to a Reddit user, the name has roots in the phrase “Hope springs eternal [in the human beast,]” which essentially means that hope is forever-lasting. When we replace “Hope” with “Wicca phase”, it can be interpreted to mean that the wicca phase in one’s life is forever-lasting.
Wicca is a pre-christian religion that in simple terms is focused on the supernatural and black magic and stuff. Followers of this “religion” inhere in nature and that emphasizes ritual observance of seasonal and life cycles, hence “springs eternal”.

Some of his musical influences are Phil Elverum, Bright Eyes, Bob Dylan, Lil B, Clams Casino, and Bonnie “Prince” Billy.

This game is DEEP! For those of you that like Minecraft and Animal Crossing, there is a ton of content for you. The storyline is complicated and rewarding. The gameplay is relaxed if you so choose (taking care of animals, planting crops, etc.). It is also harrowing and challenging if you wish (mining the deep with a bunch of monsters to fight, stepping up to the various seasonal tasks and getting to bed on time!). Play for some farm-sim chill time and/or push yourself to reach Perfection. All in all, an absolute gem!

Stardew Valley is just as fun to watch as it is to play. I watched my friend play for years before I decided to buy it myself. I immediately was asking all sorts of questions on "how". The BEST advice I was given is TAKE YOUR TIME and DO NOT CHEAT! It truly does take away special moments and quirks in the game if you look too far into the game. Stardew Wiki was really helpful without giving too much away about the "achievements" of the game. It also notifies you of any SPOILER alerts, which I appreciated. I can't wait to see how far this game goes. Everytime I think I've unlocked everything, something else exciting happens and continues the game even further! It's such an amazing game.
Don't play it! You'll just end up sucked in into Stardew, you'll never want to leave ;-)

Stardew Valley is a wonderfully made game that you can immerse yourself in a calm and relaxed game session of farming, fishing, foraging and socializing. I love to play with friends on co-op. In one weekend, myself and two other friends were able to get through an entire year of fun.
Getting to know the villagers and see how they grow is an experience in yourself- without knowing this entire game was made by one man alone. Then it's just impressive how each character has development as they get to know the Farmer. Having that kind of impact on the community is rewarding. Even if it's just a game.
I recommend this game to anyone looking for a good time. And I'd be impressed myself if you've 100% this game with the amount of content it has.
