If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Such a calming and relaxing game but with seemingly endless things to do. I have played this game for countless hours across multiple platforms. This game has easily become my comfort game and my go to when I'm extra stressed or depressed. ConcernedApe is the man and I will absolutely be trying out any future games he develops.

Features
Turn your overgrown field into a lively farm! Raise animals, grow crops, start an orchard, craft useful machines, and more! You'll have plenty of space to create the farm of your dreams.

4 Player Farming! Invite 1-3 players to join you in the valley online! Players can work together to build a thriving farm, share resources, and improve the local community. As more hands are better than one, players have the option to scale profit margin on produce sold for a more challenging experience.

Improve your skills over time. As you make your way from a struggling greenhorn to a master farmer, you'll level up in 5 different areas: farming, mining, combat, fishing, and foraging. As you progress, you'll learn new cooking and crafting recipes, unlock new areas to explore, and customize your skills by choosing from a variety of professions.

Oliver Twist is a novel written by Charles Dickens (1812-1870), a man who had a difficult life. He had worked since he was a child and he had no money. He gave Oliver , the protagonist, those characteristics.

The story is about a child, whose mother had died, that was sent to a workhouse. Oliver was an innocent and pure boy. When he was eleven, he was tried to be sold from the workhouse as an apprentice, but he escaped from there. In his way to London, he met a boy called Artful Dodger and then ended up with Fagin, the leader of a gang of thieves, who taught children how to steal.

Luckily, Oliver also found people who took good care of him and helped him with some problems he had had.

In my opinion, the novel is very entertaining and it makes you want to read more.   I liked the fact that Fagin and Sikes tried to change Oliver, but he continued to be an innocent good boy.

My favourite character is Mr. Brownlow, who took care of Oliver and loved him despite the things he had done, and his past; and my favourite part is when he is accused of a robbery he hadn’t committed and Mr. Brownlow took him to his house because he was sick. I liked the end , and I wouldn’t change anything in the book.

I love this game for so many reasons.

I suffer from night panic attacks and just sitting around waiting for my medication to calm my racing heart is often agonizing.  Then I found Stardew Valley.  It distracts me without being overly stimulating like so many other games I play and has helped me beyond measure.

I admit at first glance I scoffed at the graphics and figured it was just another one of those 'farming sims'  - but when I really started playing I was instantly enchanted.  The story of Stardew Valley is so much richer and deeper than what's seen on the surface.  The townsfolk aren't just fixed NPCs that you interact with.  They have routines - lives if you will - and their dialogue reflect their likes, dislikes and dreams.  The fact that some have reflections of real-world problems and you can influence their lives makes them that much more relatable.  Growing and managing a farm is only part of the journey in Stardew Valley.

This game is beautifully crafted and you can tell the developer put his heart and soul into it.

The only downsides I find is the fishing mini game (mini games in games are the bane of my existence) and that my 'kids' never grow up and help on the farm. However, I don't mind because of all the positives the rest of the game provides.  

I highly recommend Stardew Valley to anyone seeing a unique and rich gaming experience in a calming and beautiful atmosphere.

Although my play time is 5 hours on steam (at the time of this review 5/1/22) I have played Stardew valley for hundreds of hours on other platforms. After playing this game for around a year (on other platforms) I can say, that yes Stardew valley is worth the money. Considering that the game is only 15 dollars it is a great bargain of a game. The main reason why I like Stardew valley is that the game appeals to multiple different playing styles. You want to only talk to the villagers and not focus on money? You can go ahead. You only want to focus on profits and making crazy money? You absolutely can. You want to do nothing for three years to piss off the reason why you went there? You can.

The reason why this game is not a 10/10 is because it can be challenging to new players. The grinding times, using a wiki constantly, feeling overwhelmed. But when you get learn the game and overcome the challenges the game gives you, it is REWARDING as hell. 

Summary : Whether you buy the game and do not play it again, it is still worth it because when you really get into the game it is one of the most rewarding addicting and rich games out right now. Hours of endless content, Freedom to play how you want, and just being fun all around makes Stardew valley worth it. I forgot to mention but there is an active and supportive community that make tons and tons of incredible mods that only help the game feel like a better game unlike some other games.

I bought this game before it came out and found that I had spent waaayyy too many hours playing it.  I like that it's cultured in western aspects as most games from this genre are normally Japanese.  I like Japanese a lot, but seeing a Western-influenced aspect like this is actually a breath of fresh air and even the developer of Harvest Moon said it best himself.  "This game is amazing."  Over the years, as the game has changed, they've added multiplayer coop, which I've yet to experience, which will probably add up another few hundred hours once I get people involved in the gameplay of this game.  This is a must-play farm simulator.  I'm looking at Sun Haven as my next go-to farm sim to try out at a later time, but it is an early access title.
A perfect spiritual successor to Harvest Moon.

Great game that settled its own genre over the farming simulators. 

What do you get to do in this wholesome game:

- Manage your farm  (yay!) in different ways (crops, harvest, animals, buildings) 
- Interact with the village NPCS (marriage options too).
- Go fight monsters into the cave (spooky).
- Progress into the village events and charming story.
- Enjoy the simple things of your virtual farming life.
- Mod friendly

Personally what would i like to see this game to be even more perfect than it already is

- Saving not tied to sleeping (maybe there are mods covering this).
- More farming crops and automation handling.

At the time it got released, it was a personal favorite indie of the year of mine.

An example of a labour of love, good job conernedApe!

I've only played a little so far but I'm already hooked! I've been looking for nice, vibey games to play when I'm bored to pass the time and this was one of those games & more! The story is meh, not really that big and doesn't control the game but that's ok since you can basically write your own narrative, do mini quests, explore and progress in a satisfying way. Co-op is integrated pretty seamlessly so you can play with friends whenever. The world is very peaceful and the music + ambience slaps. I heard that one person made this is...I'm shocked! Some friends recommended this to me, I hope to surpass their hours. Great game for all ages, shapes and sizes. 

Pros:
Music
Exploration
Visuals (big fan of the pixel art style)
Vibes
Game Length (definitely worth the money, you can sink in so many hours)
There's probably much more I haven't even discovered due to my little time played...

Cons:
The energy system annoys me so much (I want to do more and sometimes it can be very jarring!)
You can't save progress until you sleep
Combat is simple (good if you wanna just turn off but not very engaging for those who want more)
Fishing can be an absolute pain
Anchovys fetch quest, me and my homies hate the anchovy fetch quest.

EDIT: I am definitely not addicted, I just crave Stardew Valley every day, my empire of star fruit is growing and spreading globally and I'm accumulating millions of coins every second.

This game is an incredible experience in the start you think its just another farming game. But after the slow earlygame the game picks up and becomes incredible. The early game may be slow (You will probably like the earlygame if its your first playthrough) but when you get to know the list of countless colorful characters with many personalities that you get to know overtime. The mid game is the most stressful/eventful part of the game you are constantly getting closer and closer to completing to the community center. Which I would say is the big story mission before the game is close to completion if this game wasn't so well made but even after you finish the "main story boss" you still have a ton to do ex: the movie theater. Also don't worry there is still more ginger island has about just as much content as the main island and is so in depth you can spend hours apon hours just watching tutorials and getting lost in the content ginger island has. I would have to say that the best part of ginger island is the farm or mr qi's room. Lets start with the farm its a HUGE plot of land that you can grow any crop on YEAR ROUND also next to the farm there is a few tiles you can use to plant fairy roses for almost the best passive income in the game fairy rose honey. About mr qi's room after you reach enough golden walnuts you get access to about the coolest shop in the game with the most innovative items up for purchase some of my favorites include the horse flute the sprinkler attachments and the qi's seasoning. The horse flute is used to summon your horse anywhere. The sprinkler attachment lets your sprinkler reach one tile further and the qi's seasoning improves buffs. The rest of the game is out for you to explore, but stardew valley isn't without its flaws like how difficult it is to make a stardew valley server because no easily accessible website right now (the multiplayer is fine but we want a server up 24/7) also for veterans of the game I want the game to start with the community center and the mine already open (after you have got to ginger island in one of your play through's) and if you have got to perfection in one world just for you to start with more energy, those are all of the big flaws and thats all I have to say its an amazing game.

Love the game. 8/10. 

single player is awesome because you have enough time to do everything with the game pausing whenever you enter a menu. The game feels very well paced and if you enjoy playing alone its awesome.

However, my friends and I stopped playing the game halfway because the time limit for each day on multiplayer felt like it was too short and we all felt rushed. There was ( is? ) no way to stop the game for everyone, and even if there was that would be horrible if EVERYONE had to stop what they were doing for one person. 

It would be great is there was an option to adjust the days time length in multi-player. Otherwise, I feel like the games pacing in multiplayer is borderline anxious and near halfway in the game it becomes downright stressful.

Don't get me wrong, great game on all fronts BESIDES multi-players pacing.

Stardew Valley (SDV) is a diverse game.  I love that I can plant crops, chop wood, break stone, forage, fish (although I have difficulty with this part),  and interact with the villagers and give them gifts.  And, all this at your own pace.  I am nearing 50 yrs old and was introduced to this game by my oldest son about a year ago.  Who knew I would become a 'gamer', even if it's with one game only.  I also love that you can play on various systems.  Although, it would be nice if you could play your same farm from the PC on your mobile, instead of having to make a separate farm for each (also applies to anyone, like me, who started on the mobile and moved to the PC).  Beyond that, I LOVE this game!!!

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Stardew Valley is one of the most passively aggresive bad games.
Your energy bar is so low that you're spending more time recovering, than doing anything remotely considered fun. And if you don't make it to bed (an actual game mechanic) in time, well tough luck you're losing more money than you made grinding that whole day + you will start with even less energy, which is really shitty since walking distances are very long and at nighttime it's almost impossible to see where you're going. Grinding is extremely slow, and thats exactly what you'll be doing here exclusively. Selection of animals and plants is extremely restrictive. Overall not a pleseant experience.

You know what I really hate in this game?

You're CONSTANTLY running against time!

Today was raining... Cool no crops to water, let's get to the mine!
Oh there's a task in pierre's... ok going back home to gather what I need.
Then go through whole town to find the NPC I need, at the right time and the right place.

By the time I arrive to said mine it's past 12:00, my day is ruined.

Can't even do one damn task because the day runs so fast and if I dare taking a wrong turn it's instantly more hours lost, and I better get back home before 00:00 or it's going to be much much worse.

Can't believe this is so stressful to play. Running all around nonstop because I doesn't actually have the time to do anything. What a scam.

Stardew Valley puts you in charge of your deceased grandfathers old farm plot. 
Its located in Pelican Town. A town filled with exciting people to befriend or maybe even, belove. Furthermore, each season comes with special festivals that fit very well.

Your task here is to rebuild your grandfathers farm to its former glory, whilst making so much dough that you eventually can afford spending 10 mill. on a clock covered in gold. Yep you heard me, a clock! :-P

Your way to this grand prestige consists of [i] *deepdiving in the wiki*.. [/i] ehm.., I mean, mastering every single one of the following skills: [b] farming, mining, foraging, fishing and combat. [/b] You will eventually learn your way of planting the right crops, foraging for the right forageables and fishing for the right fish all while donating strange artifacts to the local museum and finding secret letters that guide you in the right direction.

[b] The 1.5 Update expands on the features we love while also adding new ones. Its a really well developed update that bring back old school players like myself! [/b] 

[h1] This game is a MASTERPIECE [/h1]
Therefore I had to scavenge my brain for these cons.

[b] CONS [/b]
- Trains are useless.
- Too few "Special Orders".
- Combat can be frustrating.
- Some festivals lack content.
- "Journey Of The Prairie King" is way too difficult.

Been playing this game on and off for years. There's a reason it's basically top-tier standard for any list of resource management games, sim games, cozy games, sweet games, etc. It can be as challenging and stressful as you'd like, or not. The charm, attention to detail, and discovery in this game never really stop. Mechanically pretty simple and lots of ways to navigate goals and accomplishments, so it's really great for people new to gaming. I swear the opening music instantly lowers my blood pressure. The ultimate comfort game.

with 120+ hours in (and counting), i can safely say that stardew valley is on of my favorite games of all time. it single handedly took what made harvest moon fun and just expanded it. Eric Borone, really refinded this game to a mirror shine. goes to show his passion for creation is limitless. only nit picks is that the marriage stuff and the way that you interact with villagers (outside of the cutscenes) is pretty limited, and an expansion to that would be very nice. but im aware that its alot to ask of a single developer. but it would be nice to see character interation expanded apone. other than that, this game is near flawless, and i can see my self clocking in, hundreds apone hundreds of hours into this great fun indie game. without a doubt in my mind, pic this game up, you will not regret it.

This is a review for Stardew Valley on the Steam Deck. (Stardew is a great game with a developer who loves their game and community)

Stardew is rated as Verified for the Steam Deck, this means that right from the start playing Stardew Valley should have no issues at all and require no tinkering. 

This biggest issue is the lag. The game suddenly drops to 0 FPS for a few seconds. Tried changing v-sycn, display mode, limiting FPS and nothing solves this issue. 

Other than that, I wish the game would be more zoomed out. I feel like I don't get to see far enough, currently as zoomed out as possible and it still feels small. 

I do not recommend Stardew Valley for the Steam Deck, the lag makes it unplayable.

Shane 10/10

Maybe it's cause I'm always stoned af when I play this game, but really, what's not to love? Farming, mining, foraging, fishing, cooking, creating friendships and improving relationships, completing the community bundles, building your farm from the ground up. People I've talked to who have never played the game always ask me what's so special about a farming game ... but you just need to play it, then you'll know the wholesome addiction that is Stardew. I, like many others here, have spent >400 hours in this game, so I promise, it's not just a boring sim. 

Biggest suggestions? 
- Play it vanilla your first run, then add the expansion mods from Nexus. 
- Also, don't look at the guides online. Don't let the grind get in the way of your enjoyment for your first time playing. Explore, take your time, don't worry about anything all too much. Explore the town and find what you enjoy doing the most. Figure things out for yourself - it's more rewarding. After Year 2 you can restart with mods and then follow the guides online that will maximize your profits and in-game time. Until then, do yourself a favor, and stay away from reddit lol.

By now you most likely know about Stardew Valley. There is a reason everyone knows this game. It is by far one of the best sim/farming/crafting games out there and has remained that way for many years now. I have Stardew Valley on console and Steam for macOS. It was great playing the vanilla version and now I'm having great fun with the mods (Nexus). 

This game allows you to create your dream farm (or a group farm you can play with others online) in your way. There are many paths, braziers, scarecrows, statues, furniture, machines, buildings, fences, crops, flowers, trees, animals, etc. to make your farm perfect for your vision. You can also decorate most of the town (indoors and outdoors) as well! Farm, raise animals, mine, fish, forage, and more for materials to sell, use in crafts, or give to the NPCs as gifts.

The NPCs and storyline are immersive and entertaining. You can even marry and divorce them. There are secrets everywhere in this game. You can earn your way to an island that can be your home away from home. All the little details are what makes Stardew Valley so interesting.

I do suggest getting the Steam version for the modding ability. There are a few mods that honestly should be in the vanilla that help with quality of life issues. There are many great mods ranging from cheat menus to clothing or furniture options. I know some people either don't have the time or patience to play long term games like these so things like the cheat menu can really help allow the game to be played in a more efficient, quick way. Do you just want to decorate an entire world and your farm without playing? You can do that too with a mod that allows you to just get any item (kind of like creative mode in Minecraft).

However, it would be a shame to miss all the intriguing things that happen or are said in this game. If you like any game of this genre, you will love Stardew Valley. It is loved and consistently being updated. It truly is one of the best of this kind of game.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is a 2004 action-adventure game developed by Rockstar North and published by Rockstar Games. It is the fifth main entry in the Grand Theft Auto series, following 2002's Grand Theft Auto: Vice City, and the seventh installment overall. It was released in October 2004 for the PlayStation 2, in June 2005 for Microsoft Windows and Xbox, and in November 2010 for Mac OS X. The game is set within an open world environment that players can explore and interact with at their leisure. The story follows former gangster Carl "CJ" Johnson, who returns home following his mother's murder and is drawn back into his former gang and a life of crime while clashing with corrupt authorities and powerful criminals. Carl's journey takes him across the fictional U.S. state of San Andreas, which is heavily based on California and Nevada and encompasses three major cities: Los Santos (inspired by Los Angeles), San Fierro (San Francisco) and Las Venturas (Las Vegas).

While I can kind of understand why people dig this game so much, my experience with it has been very unsatisfying and frustrating.

The game looks good, the sound is nice as well for the most part (some soundtracks are hardcore annoying though and there is a weird "ghost" moan that neither me not my friend understands).
The general idea of the game is nice as well, talk to people, farm, take care of animals etc. In reality, my farm looks exactly the same as it did when we started, slightly more crops maybe, but no coops, other buildings or anything else that could be of use. Because the thing is that everything in this game takes a lot of energy, ressources, time and money and you really have to grind in order to proceed. Nothing makes the game easier. Watering crops takes half of your energy, sprinklers are useless (they water 4 spots, wow!) and way too expensive to make sense, eating crops to have more energy is stupid because you need to make money. Doing quests is no fun either because in the rare case that you actually have what people are asking for you spend 1 or 2 complete days looking for them because you have to deliver things personally and can't just leave them/ or ship them to them. More time wasted, yay.

Befriending people is a chore as well, talking to them everyday does not seem to do anything, doing quests for them...see above. Of course you can just give them gifts but you need the money for backpack and tool upgrades and cannot waste so much on the townpeople.

After 15 hours I don't feel like I have achieved anything, my farm is still the same, people don't like me any more than they did in the beginning.

And the combat... in theory the mine might be one of the more interesting things in the game. But you are spammed with enemies sometimes and combat is just plain shit. For one enemy it might work but after lv 50 (it goes down to 100) you are just lost. For the combat to be this bad there is definitely too much of it in the game.

And don't even get me started on the absolute ABOMINATION of a fishing mini-game. There has never been anything I have hated more in any other game.

I am sure there are better farming games out there, maybe Stardew is just not for me - who knows. But I have never been able to experience the "calming" game Stardew Valley wants to be.
This game is everything I've need, and never knew I desired. The peace and tranquility of exploiting my farm, befriending the villagers. I highly recommend it, to anyone, of any playstyle.

Where the AAA gaming space often lets us down, Small teams and in this case a single dev and their Indie projects show just how much creativity and passion their still is in the industry.

Super cozy game that's always a fun and relaxing time logging on to play, so much content and variety with regular free updates added throughout the years. It can take some time to get into the swing of things, the game does start quite slowly but that's not necessarily a bad thing. You'll soon have plenty to do once you have your farm up and running.

You have a bunch of plants to sow depending on the season, animals to care for, decorating your home, trees to cut, fishing, townsfolk to interact with the list goes on. customizing and slowly building up to my dream farm was just a really fun time highly recommend this game if you want to chill with something casual, and i say this as a competitive gamer.

The game oozes quality, care and passion, and for such a low price you really can't go wrong.

Stardew is an amazing little Indie game that's both peaceful, at at the same time mentally challenging. You need to be smart by how you plant your crops, how you make your relationships and spend your time if your goal is to make certain milestones by certain points. Otherwise you can just enjoy the ride; make your dream farm or focus on mining and fishing as a source of income. The most annoying thing to me is the holidays, especially when I need to leave my farm for something and I accidentally go to the screen where it's being held and I'm forced to socialize.

Here is my big review that covers some of the story (no spoilers) and some of the aspects of the game. This is really long because I have a need to write about something.
Stardew Valley is a single or multiplayer RPG, indie, and adventure game. It's about the story of a young farmer who inherited the land of their grandfather in a small place called Pelican Town. At the beginning of the game you can customize your character with many different shirts, hairs, and pants with customizable colors, and you can choose any name, favorite thing, and preferred pet. Yes, you can adopt a dog or a cat. In the game you can grow crops and raise farm animals on your new land, and build it however you like. Pelican Town has a ton of townies (NPCs) in it. Each townie has their own storyline and lore along with them along with many quests and rewards. Throughout the seasons, there are different events that mimick the ones of real life. Like an easter egg hunt for example. The game also has fishing, mining, fighting, and a lot of resource gathering. You will need to end up doing all of these things to finish the big goal of the game which is the community center. In the town there is a run down community center that the mayor will want to fix. You will need to donate some crops, foraged items, resources, fish, animal products, and cooked items to finish this quest. Once the community center is complete, the world is completely free to explore and roam, and you can find all the different pieces of story and collect every exotic item in the game. Stardew Valley is very calming and stress free -until you go to the mines- and any and all stress is avoidable. It has a great soundtrack that sets the mood and great characters you will (literally) fall in love with. This is a great game :D

I was never into the pixelart and "jarpg" style games, but I love gardening and nature so I decided to try this out. It seemed overrated at first, like, what's so special about this little farming game?

I have to say, this is now my happy place besides skyrim and minecraft. It's so relaxing, fun, and the characters and their development will make you cry. I didn't expect to get emotional over a game but I teared up over a scene because it was just so beautiful and peaceful.

The gameplay itself is addicting. It feels so satisfying to do so much hard work farming, digging, chopping, feeding animals, etc, and getting rewarded for it by selling or using what you've created. Reminds me of how it feels to have your hard work paid off irl after breaking your back tilling soil and raising plants.

The music is one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard. The visuals are really nice. The only problem I have is that while in the mines, having to mine every single rock or blow them up to find the ladder to the next level is SUPER annoying. But that's literally the only flaw I can find with it.

I hope you give it a try, you won't regret it.

If I could only play one game for the rest of my life, I'd pick this one. There are so many different ways you can play this game. You can push yourself to earn a lot of money, or to finnish a challenge or quest as fast as possible. Or you marry different NPCs to find out what their 14 heart event cut scene is. Or you decorate your farm and pet your cows. It's as challenging or relaxing how you want it. And as a plus, the Reddit Community is super welcoming if you have questions.

~ DIFFICULTY ~

☑️ Easy (Fishing is hard in the beginning, but gets easier. Food buffs help, e.g. from fish tacos. Same with fighting in the mines. Otherwise there aren't many possibilities to fail)
🔲 Normal 
🔲 Hard
☑️ You Will Rage! - when you play Journey of the Prairie King

~ GRAPHICS ~

🔲 MS Paint
🔲 Bad
🔲 Meh
🔲 Graphics don't matter in this game
🔲 Good 
☑️ Beautiful
🔲 Masterpiece

~ MUSIC ~

🔲 Bad
☑️ Not special (After a while I put it on mute and play my own music)
🔲 Good
🔲 Beautiful

~ STORY ~

🔲 This game has no story
🔲 Forget the story, just play for vibes
☑️ It's there for the people who want it (There are beautiful cut scenes to discover with the different NPCs if you build a relationship with them. You can focus entirely on the farming part of the game or mining or whatever you like. But in my opinion, the story is as much fun as the rest of the game)
🔲 Well written
🔲 Epic story

~ PRICE ~

🔲 Free
☑️ Under priced (I don't know the price range for games of this kind, but you can play it for an endless amount of time, so I think the price is a bit low)
🔲 Perfect Price
🔲 Could be cheaper
🔲 Wait for sale
🔲 Complete waste of money

~ LENGTH ~

🔲 Very Short (0 - 3 hours)
🔲 Short (3 - 15 hours)
🔲 Average (15-50 hours)

If you thought Harvest Moon was unreasonably difficult and complex, this is the farming sim for you! The base game alone has hours and hours of content that you can play at any pace and in a multitude of ways (I've played the base game for longer on my Switch than I have on my modded PC game), which can vastly alter your playtime. 

Mods can give you an entirely re-imagined experience, extend the existing gameplay, add extra features, or simply patch existing ones for accessibility. It's extremely versatile and allows you to create a unique experience for yourself, almost as if the postgame of your first playthrough is a sandbox.

This game will hold up forever. Get it! You won't regret it, unless you're a big boy macho gamer bro who doesn't like to have fun.

This game is really fun as you have to plant all your crops, give them fertilizer and water, and plan for the seasons! After a bit, you can collect sprinklers to water crops for you and the greenhouse to be able to plant crops in any season. Many of the crops are season-dependent which I think is a really nice aspect of the game as it makes you really plan things out! There are many enjoyable things to do such as events, friendships, farming, mining, fishing, collecting, and so much more which just gives this game so much to do!

The game is very cute! It catches your attention with the well-done pixel art, and holds you with the story. There might not be a "main" questline, but the many small quests that help you understand the world of Stardew are (if you read the text..) wholesome and intriguing. As you progress, so does the valley. The different areas in the game keep it interesting and spice it up when you get to the more end-game content, where you're just farming every day. The game not only has soft and calming gameplay, it also has puzzles. There are some pretty confusing ones I've yet to figure out. But I'm excited to! Overall, this game is really enjoyable, and very worth the small amount of money you pay for it.

This game is like a home away from home. I've always been a big fan of Animal Crossing, and though AC and SDV are so alike, you'll find they have many differences. Both games are primarily non-combat oriented. Stardew Valley does have mines which involve combat, but they aren't central to the gameplay. In most cases, you'll be collecting goods, and interacting with the townspeople. In both games, you customize your own home. In SV, you plant crops and use various tools. In AC, you customize your home with furniture and room dressings. You can also customize your town with various public works projects. 

In both games you can easily imagine leaving a stressful life behind for a more serene and simple one outside the country. Usually, I primarily play competitive shooters, but this game is a great way for me to relax afterwards. You can tell the developers put a lot of love and care into this game. I highly recommend it.

I grew up playing the Harvest Moon series and a number of spin offs. I love Stardew Valley so much that I own it on multiple platforms. I have no issues dropping $15 here and there to just be able to playing wherever and on whatever device.

Stardew Valley offers a lot of content to keep you busy just like the Harvest Moon games and arguably gives a little more freedom in your life choices throughout the game.

My only complaint is the lack of calendar events in game and the lack of NPC character engagement in the end game. This game never really ends, but it would be nice to have a number of dialogues or activities you could engage in with characters instead of exhausting every character dialogue to be left with just maintaining your farm for the rest of eternity.

i now own stardew valley on 3 different platforms. pc, android and ios.. (long story) but i love being able to just plop on the couch with it and just relax. 

now having played this game exclusively on tablets and such it is quite frankly baffling me why the click-to-move-and-pick-the-right-tool-to-do-action isn't available for the pc version of the game. i thought i could just lean back in my chair and one-hand my way through this game like on the tablet, but alas, i have to use either a controller (preferred as it supports the more lounge-able positions) or wasd and mouse to move about. 

this presents some problems, 1 aiming where i place my swings, plots and plants and 2 when you get attacked in the mines you have to actually aim.
i know that is mostly player preference and how i got used to playing it on a tablet but this game so lends itself to just being pointy clicky.
another thing that gets my gears grinding is the terrible fishing ui. it's designed so it gets easier to catch fish if you have a higher fishing level but it is near screen-punchingly frustrating to fish at low levels.

you can play by just being a hermit and mope around your farm with minimal connection with the people in the town or just go nuts and have kids. 
there is no YOU HAVE WON or YOU LOOSE mentality in this game. do what you like seems to be the option.
complete the bundels, or not. the game is okay with it.

just don't stay out after 2 am or you will get robbed by the locals.

I absolutely LOVE this game. I'm almost 1300 hours in and I'm still finding new things to do and discovering things I've never seen before. 
If you're looking for something chill and therapeutic, with lots of things to explore and figure out this game is definitely for you. Regular updates have also added a ton of content to this game, making it fun to re-start and explore anew. 
As it gets a bit sandboxy towards the end, it's also a great game to play if you enjoy setting up challenges for yourself, or starting over with specific goals in mind as you play. Very enjoyable to play with friends as well.

Someone once asked me why this game had gotten me so hooked I keep returning to it, and I think it's because it's just so calming and welcoming, it's like getting a big warm hug when you feel down. It just goes so well with my Sunday morning coffee.

10/10 - I will HIGHLY recommend this to anyone who enjoys this genre.

Pros: 
-Characters each with a different unique personality, that you can date/marry/become platonic roommates with.
-Unique non-dateable characters with great plot lines and personalities.
-So. Much. Exploration.
- Great Achievement system to work towards, and to keep playing for.
-So many different ways to play, farming, fishing, animal keeping, mining, decorating, and combat.
-A lot of replayablity

Cons:
-Definitely gets grindy
-Once you get to end game, it does get stale, and you will have to get creative to make it fun, or just start over.
-Difficulty spike towards an mid/endgame combat/mining area, It seems too difficult to traverse at first.

Overall I've beyond enjoyed this game, and I still haven't beaten it. I definitely recommend at least giving it a try, especially if you are into a farming sim/rpg style game. However, it will get grindy in a lot of spots, and you will have to be creative during those times. Overall though, a really well rounded game with lots of things to work towards and discover.

I was between Stardew Valley and Animal Farm. I opted for Stardew Valley, it's an okay game but the genre is not really my thing. No violence, no nudity. I think those are essential in a game. But it was fun growing a farm and there is the combat aspect if you go to the caves, which the game soon or later forces you to go. Overall good experience, but not worth my time.

The basic gameplay has pretty much everything I'm looking for in a farming sim: crop planning, resource management, processing for value-add, a nice hand-drawn feel to the animation, and a cozy feel to the storyline. The courting and marriage options are wide open, which is nice, although you have to use a mod to have a polycule. The modding process is relatively painless. I find I only want a couple of mods, one to get rid of the twitch-gamer fishing minigame that I can't do, I'm old, and one to expand the cellar to the size of the house. The farm maps offer enough variation in strategy to keep me entertained for a while. 451 hours and I'm only on my third farm map, that's good replay value.

Stardew Valley has everything I could ever want in a relaxing, sandbox game. It perfectly captures the peaceful, calming atmosphere surrounding the area with a delightfully charming cast who fill the stunning backdrop. You will spend hours completely lost in the world forgetting your sorrows, purely focused on how you can make the people of the village happy, why does no one want this cave carrot (more for me?)! Who knew planting, harvesting and of course, who could forget, fishing would be so fun; not only fun but genuinely rewarding and purpose serving. The game is a must play for anyone looking to relax in the gentle breeze of this stunning artistic masterpiece. I cannot recommend this game enough!
The best game you'll ever buy.

Игра для тех кому нравится каждый день поливать по 10+ часов огород, осознавая что за день вы ничего не сделали, а потом когда дождались дождя, не знаете что делать, ведь огород не надо поливать.
Могу дать советы по тому что делать:
1- Постройте курятник. ~ Заведите курочку по имени "Анатолий".
2- Идите гриндить шахты до 23:00, а потом летите домой. 
3- Ловите рыбу, ночью вам может выпасть розовое ди*до, под названием "чудо-огурец", лучше сохраните его. ведь какой-то девушке он может понадобиться, и они будут этому рады. 
4- Полейте огород, не спрашивайте зачем. Просто полейте огород пока идёт дождь.
5- Очистите свою территорию.
7- Купите новых семян (молитесь чтобы была не среда, ведь Пьерр тогда не работает).
8- Позовите друга поиграть с собой, но учтите что если у вас будет ошибка, вам двоим придётся перезагружать комп, ведь ошибка не фиксится так просто.
9- Идите дарите подарки энписишникам.
10- копайтесь в мусорках (Осуждается энписишниками, не рекомендуется делать на их глазах).
11- Идти собирать ресурсы для клуба.
12- Идти делать задания.
13. Идти на ивенты, которые заберут у вас время, и отпустят вас поздно домой, что многие навряд-ли успеют полить огород.
14- Скипайте кат-сцены торговцев, или персонажей которые вам нужны срочно(как минимум если играете по сети, не знаю что в одиночной), ведь персонаж может уже уйти пока кат-сцена идёт, и вы не продадите свою тыковку ему. Кат-сцены просто потом глядите на ютубе. 
15- Хз что написать, удачи, и следите за временем, ведь воришки всякие воруют у вас деньги (10% с общей суммы(максимум 1.000)).
16- Чем позднее вы ложитесь, тем меньше энергии восстановите.

Stardew Valley seemed like a game I wouldn't like at first: Busywork on a daily basis with all not only being on a timer daily but also seasonally. If you wanna be a in secure situation to keep progressing, you gotta keep buying and growing crops or earn money otherwise. Then take care of those crops, Clear your farm for space, water crops, later on you have to check on your animals and on top of all that you have a relationship mechanic with every villager in town, some of which you can even marry and have kids with. And I'm not gonna lie, it seemed simultaneously too slow and overwhelming at first.
This, however, was only a cursory glance. Once you have a foothold in the game or know roughly what you wanna do each season, the game becomes that much more enjoyable. You grow and ship or donate specific crops to complete certain goals or quests. You start building specific buildings for specific purposes. Outfitting them to automate processes so you spend less time and energy each day. You even unlock a whole new area with its own quests, called Ginger Island. This makes it easy to sink over a hundred hours into a save and play the year over and over again, putting new priorities into each season, without it feeling the same.
I'm told there's a whole aesthethic element to it, too. And I can certainly see how you can acquire certain decorative items and place them almost all over town. That part isn't so much for me, but you could easily be lost in it.
I recommend trying this if you wanna deccelerate even if it doesn't feel like a game you'd enjoy. I also recommend playing at least a year by yourself before felving into a multiplayer experience (which is supported aswell).

An overall amazing and complete game - a friend offered it to me, and I originally thought that it was definitely not my type of game. I decided to try it out for them and out of curiosity, and oh boy i do not regret it.
I'm a pretty chill player, and spent my first 70hrs or so in the game just discovering all of its possibilities, enjoying the music and universe, getting to know all the NPCs, taking care of my farm and everything, and i did not see them go by. There is a lot to discover in there, and the community is super helpful and wholesome. The music is perfect, even the wood chopping sounds are relaxing its incredible!
You will definitely find something you like in Stardew, no matter what's your usual gameplay style. I mostly play MOBA and rogue lites, but there is this little special place for Stardew in my heart that the developer managed to carve. You can play to finally chill, you can go for a perfection run, you can play to explore the mines and fight monsters, you can play to date NPCs, you can play for the fishing mini game, you can play for the aesthetics and the joy of decorating your farm, you can play to screw Joja, you can play to screw Pierre, you can play for the money and start a wine empire, but once you get this game, I guarantee you you'll play.
If comfort was a game, it definitely would be this one - playing Stardew feels like staying home in a cozy blanket on a rainy day, and I highly recommend the experience.

This game is Life. So addicting, and very wholesome :) It is also quite relaxing, and just overall an AMAZING game. Highly Recommend! It has so much depth to it, esp considering it was made by a single person, and was basically his passion project. I'm so glad I came across this game, because after a long and potentially stressful day, this game is perfect for getting rid of all that and an awesome way to unwind. I can't seem to be able to tear myself away for hours once i sit down and start playing. And that is a GOOD thing! You've got farming crops, raising animals, making artisan goods like mayo and cheese, pale ale, beer, etc. You've got a relationship/friendship building system, fishing, mining, combat, exploration, and so much more! Your seriously doing yourself a major disservice by sleeping on this game!
Also: The artisan perk at farming level 10 is freaking CRACKED XD
This game is so therapeutic.

Stardew Valley is an amazing game where you talk and interact with NPCs or friends.You can also fish, mine, fight and farm.A main objective of most players is to fix up the broken up community centre.Tons of people love it and you can also get a girlfriend/boyfriend and husband/wife and babies.Festivals...Festivals are another part of the game.There are the Egg Festival, Flower Dance, Luau, The Night Of The Moonlight Jellies, The Stardew Valley Fair, Spirit's Eve, Festival Of Ice, Night Market and The Feast Of The Winter Star.You also get quests.And for those people who want to be bad there is a bad route.The Joja Mart.Along with all these good and bad stuff and drama.You can get a free pet and a not so free Chicken, Duck, Rabbit, Dinosaur, Cow, Goat, Sheep, Pig, Ostrich and Horse.Everything is so fun and amazing.Well that about wraps it up.

I grew up playing Harvest Moon- and had been dying for a new Harvest Moon. Stardew Valley scratched that itch for me in the best of ways. This game has brought me (including my play time on the Switch) well over 1,000 hours of entertainment. With the addition of multiplayer, my boyfriend and I have made it a frequest routine for us to work on our farm together. With the multiple play style options- he can do the dungeon delving, fishing that he loves- and I can do the crop management and farm design that I enjoy the most.This game resonated deep within my psyche and awoke ancestral memories from uncountable past generations of farmers time immemorial.

The feeling was so strong that I completely altered my life plans, bought a small farm in the middle of diddle-do nowhere, and am more or less living the game irl. However I am so busy learning how to farm that I don't have time to play Stardew Valley anymore.

Thank you ConcernedApe, your little pixel game literally changed my life and now I won't starve while Western civilization collapses.
It's a good all-rounder and it gives more than what one would expect :3

Although I have only played for 38 hours at the time of this review I can say this is the best game I have ever played. Whenever I play this I am always calmed by the farmwork (harvesting crops,feeding animals) exploring the environment (Pelican town, the beach and especialy the cindersnap forest) the foraging, townfolk oh and the music! I love the music it is so fit for the mood of the game and so calming (I am in fact listening to the full soundtrack at the time of this review) then there is all the work that has gone in to this game. It can be seen after about a season (game days) playing with all the NPC's, the game artwork (witch is also very calming) all the progress, story, items, pets, events, the food, the different seasons, how the feeling of acomplishment when finishing something feels real (or just very good) after achieving something and the work gone into the happy vibe of the game. And not forgetting how the developers actualy made this game not for the money but for the expirience the gameplay. In total Stardew Valley is the best game I have ever played with amazing art, gameplay story, realaxing vibe and heart. 10 out of 10   Five stars out of five.

Old review:
great game with fun activities and has large replayability

New Review:
I wanted to add this to really give insight into how much more I enjoy this game now. At first It was a fun standard game. I was not really into the whole aspect of farming games. But the more I played stardew especially with a friend changed my entire mindset on this game. I started to take it more seriously and looked into the story telling aspects. I started to dig deeper into understanding the story, lore and characters. I read more about to understand the fundamentals of the game. Ultimately this is something that I would highly recommend to someone even if you may think this is not the game for you. I would suggest getting it with someone to play with (especially someone who has played it before you) for your first time. Then after you understand the basics you can branch out and play the basegame by yourself or go for some great expansive mods.

Over all, this game made me feel immensely good inside. 
The graphics, and just the wonderful soft little music playing in the background. Oh my, it just has this.. Settle little cozy vibe in it, and just move at your own pace. 
This game doesn't make you feel competitive, or rushed; it's just a slow, work and enjoy game. I think that I've spent multiple hours during the summer on here, just because I was bored and something so satisfying about making thousands over night from selling vegetables. Like c'mon. Is that not even slightly satisfying to you? 

If you don't like all the working in it and the time you have to put into this game, then I'd advise you to still play; just install a cheat or something. Even though that isn't truly playing the game to the fullest experience. I do believe that literally anyone can enjoy this game. 
So long story short, just download something like SMAPI. After doing so you'll have the ability to add the mod through that and have your cheats. 
(Disclaimer, I do think this doesn't actually show you the beauty of the game, you can't actually understand everything like those who played it raw. Or in other words, using no cheats.) 

I think a few of my favorite parts where all the little hidden messages. Finding those was like a treasure hunt, because in some cases it was! 

Summary: 
10/10 Totally recommend for anyone who just needs something to hang out and play, the game has a feature where you can play with friends! I find that very fun. This game is flexible and just lets everything take it's toll on the player. Do yourself a favor and just play the dang game already!

This game is amazing I played it since it came out on the ps4 and then decided to get it on steam to do mods,  The only down side I ever face with this game is getting a little bit bored in late game but you can go grind the mines in the desert or skull cavern. I love this game. It's simple on the outside, but once you step in, there's so much to explore. Game mechanics are challenging enough that it's incredibly rewarding when you accomplish a task or unlock new things and you won't feel too bad if you mess up. I've gone through a few save files but it never gets old. NPC dialogue can get repetitive in the beginning, but as you progress, their stories get deeper and some of it hits hard! Designing and building your farm and the community is incredibly challenging and rewarding. It's so addictive and you can see how much fans love it just by seeing all the content they share online, and it's all so positive (as far as I've seen). I cannot stress enough how much I adore this game. The story and creativity of each character is fantastic, and I love/love to hate all of them. However, it is nearly impossible without the wiki telling you what time or day and what time of year to do something or where exactly to dig or things like that. It gets a little repetitive occasionally, but the gratification of making progress makes it worth it. It’s a combination of animal crossing, Minecraft, and terraria. Definitely recommend it, as I’m on my 3rd year of the game and not even close to finishing it. The level of content is very impressive.

The game is great, very homey and very easy to sit down and play an in-game day or two per session or spend an entire day playing, going for "just one more day" for 7 hours.

I couldn't exactly call it relaxing per se, as days are very short and if you miss a fish, crop, etc then you've missed your opportunity to get it until the next year. So you'll be spending a lot of time hopped up on caffeine and crab cakes, sprinting around town just trying to get things done before you collapse at 2am. 

I'm not a big fan of how many requests from npcs involve a ton of luck to catch a specific fish or find a specific item, but you're (mostly) well compensated for your time. And the fact that you have to randomly stumble into a villager's affinity cutscenes to further your relationship means that you might have to look things up to avoid spending 3 years following them around at all hours of the day which is a bit on the annoying side. (Even just some hints would help.)

The game is an extremely slow burn similarly to animal crossing, but unlike animal crossing once you've completed your ultimate goal, you'll have 3 more dumped on you. The game is BURSTING at the seams with content, and has plenty of QOL that other games of the genre simply don't have like being able to check what you need to complete the community centre from your inventory or being able to see if you have any good gifts for a neighbour in your pockets from the relationship menu.

All in all, Stardew valley is the farming sim genre done probably the best it's ever been done, and for the price you get hundreds of hours of gameplay that you can come back to whenever to plant some crops do some mining, and seduce your crush with weeds and mayonaise.

i love this game and i havent even scratched the surface of what i assume you could do in it. but despite me recommending it and loving it there are some flaws to the game

1) the energy system. im sorry but its too unforgiving at least at the beginning, it makes you feel like your character truly is someone who never did any physical activity in their life and yes i get it, she was working in an office before but theres no way she cuts some trees or whatever and is immediately depleted of all her energy. also its just not fun it limits you and what you can do in the game thats all it does, LIMITS YOU in a game thats advertised by soo many as relaxing and fun and peaceful its more anxiety enducing cause you have to think about energy depletion and how the heck to work around it. it gets better over time but its always gonna be there permanently annoying the heck out of you

2) time. the in game time is ridiculous it goes by wayyyyyy tooo quickly like i have never counted the time in the game but it feels like one day is only ten minutes or something how the heck am i suppose to get anything done at all no wonder the in game progress is so slow for me at least also if you dont get back to bed by 12 you lose money. like hello?????

3) the save system imsure for many players this is not as issue but for me it is. having a reallllyyyyy old school save system wherein you can only save progress when you get back to bed and sleep is realllllyyyyy annoying. first of i already have to manage energy depletion, manage time, manage where i am going, manage what i am doing, allll to fit so that i know i will be in bed by 12. JUST LIKE IN REAL LIFE??? this is a video game i wanna have fun not feel like i have to manage things so harshly i get it its a farming sim any sim game involves management one might aruge that without management and strategy sim games are nothing, but its just tiring and not fun

4) the npcs are incredibly boring unlikable and dont feel real at all. the dailouge for each character feels incredibly generic. oh look its an old man, hmm i wonder what personality he has? oh hes grumpy as heck of course, oh look a handsome guy i wonder if his convos will be filrtatious, ah yes they are, hmm little girls i wonder if they will all just be annoying and hate on my character for no reason. hmmmmm i wonder what else anyone in this town has to say about stardew valley aside from how hecking peaceful it is and how much they hecking LOVE living "the simple life" hmm,,,,,, the business manager for a big conglomerate gee i wonder if he will be typecast as the evil business person here to destroy this valley's purity oh yeah first cutscene of him is him giving out coupons and corrupting everyone. see what i mean? everyone feels like a caricuture.

ok thats it. despite all the ranting i still genuinely think this is an amazing game, albeit sometimes frustrating to get through.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Ok, this has been driving me crazy for seven movies now, and I know you're going to roll your eyes, but hear me out: Harry Potter should have carried a 1911.

Here's why:

Think about how quickly the entire WWWIII (Wizarding-World War III) would have ended if all of the good guys had simply armed up with good ol' American hot lead.

Basilisk? Let's see how tough it is when you shoot it with a .470 Nitro Express. Worried about its Medusa-gaze? Wear night vision goggles. The image is light-amplified and re-transmitted to your eyes. You aren't looking at it--you're looking at a picture of it.

Imagine how epic the first movie would be if Harry had put a breeching charge on the bathroom wall, flash-banged the hole, and then went in wearing NVGs and a Kevlar-weave stab-vest, carrying a SPAS-12.

And have you noticed that only Europe seems to a problem with Deatheaters? Maybe it's because Americans have spent the last 200 years shooting deer, playing GTA: Vice City, and keeping an eye out for black helicopters over their compounds. Meanwhile, Brits have been cutting their steaks with spoons. Remember: gun-control means that Voldemort wins. God made wizards and God made muggles, but Samuel Colt made them equal.

Now I know what you're going to say: "But a wizard could just disarm someone with a gun!" Yeah, well they can also disarm someone with a wand (as they do many times throughout the books/movies). But which is faster: saying a spell or pulling a trigger?

Avada Kedavra, meet Avtomat Kalashnikova.

Imagine Harry out in the woods, wearing his invisibility cloak, carrying a .50bmg Barrett, turning Deatheaters into pink mist, scratching a lightning bolt into his rifle stock for each kill. I don't think Madam Pomfrey has any spells that can scrape your brains off of the trees and put you back together after something like that. Voldemort's wand may be 13.5 inches with a Phoenix-feather core, but Harry's would be 0.50 inches with a tungsten core. Let's see Voldy wave his at 3,000 feet per second. Better hope you have some Essence of Dittany for that sucking chest wound.

I can see it now...Voldemort roaring with evil laughter and boasting to Harry that he can't be killed, since he is protected by seven Horcruxes, only to have Harry give a crooked grin, flick his cigarette butt away, and deliver what would easily be the best one-liner in the entire series:

"Well then I guess it's a good thing my 1911 holds 7+1."

And that is why Harry Potter should have carried a 1911.

Perhaps the most relaxing and charming game I've played. At first I was not at all interested due to the graphics or the cute-nature, but I'm a sucker for world building. I love building and customizing my character's area in any game that offers it to me. From styling my farms, to determining what i'll specialize in growing/making to sell.. I just love it to bits. Oh, and Fish tanks that animate with any fishies I catch! I love my Squid tank and Eel tank so much. Oh and Sea Urchins with little hats on them that randomly move around the tank.. okay okay too much random here- let me refocus. This is such a simple and yet charming game that it being a labor of love really shows. I'd call this game a very Lite-experience for the few genres it occupies. 

Farming and Customizing your home/farm is the top attraction to the game. Where as if you want indepth control over how things look, you'll find Minecraft more appealing.. but if you want something to just settle down on, do a little busy work, watch cute plants grow.. and be able to do it on potato-y computers without a problem- then this game is really perfect. You'll have 4 seasons each with their own unique crops, grow fruit trees, grow coffee or tea saplings, make all kinds of foods out of everything you grow. You can even tend to basic farm animals like chicken, cows.. even rabbits and ducks! If you're really lucky, maybe even a lil dinosaur too! 

Combat is simple and to the point; slash the weapon when a monster is near. Move around to get out of attacks or attempt to block. Just slash slash til it dies. Plenty of healing items and food as well as buffs you can make for this later- some areas do actually get very hard later. But if you want hard-hitting combat or really smooth controls.. uhh no. Stardew is not that. 

Socializing with the many NPCs in the game grants you access to their homes or rooms, gives you gifts through your mail and even unlocks recipes you otherwise couldn't get. You'll get quests in the form of a questing board that is simple fetch or kill quests that improves your friendship with them. There is a bulletin board that opens up later that is intended for week or even monthly (ingame time) long quests which reward much more gold as well as unique recipes or equipment. You are not nagged to do these things and can approach them at any time you wish. There are also town events/season holiday events too where the towns people all gather and depending on that theme of the vent- you socialize, buy exclusive goodies for that event, play minigames.. just a lot of little things! Though eventually you may not really need to go to them anymore, and sometimes it is annoying that you may run out of seeds on a day an event happens and you cannot go to town cause 'we're preparing for the event!' which makes me a grumbley grumbler. 

Story wise there is a little theme and all the NPCs have their own personalities and stories.. from the tragic to the spoiled to the set-in-their-ways types. You can even take on a boyfriend/girlfriend and they'll come live with you at your farm and have their own little place.. sometimes they'll help out too! But eh... I wouldn't rely on this being useful in a mechanical sense, but for RPers out there you'll have a variety of people to choose from. I won't say its all ground breaking story telling, but it has heart and enough character that it isn't boring- its just normal. Normal everyday life, with a few odd exceptions here and there. I also want to point out that the game isn't too alienating either- you can have same-gender relationships too. Albeit there isn't anything that really is standout LGBTQ+ but it also wasn't limited out of your partner potentials either. Just putting that there for the curious ones out there. :)

There are a lot of challenges you can do, various different farm layouts you can try, a museum of items to collect, a handful of dungeon crawlers to do, lots of little unlockables... for such a tiny package the game really does offer a lot to do. I HIGHLY recommend the game for anyone who enjoys/needs a chill-out mode every now and then.. heck, Its even fine to play on the regular and just go nuts with farming! Much love and appreciation to ConcernedApe for just being an all around awesome dude with a genuine talent for charming games.

Favorite thing to farm? Blueberries, Cranberries and Coffee beans.. I love making ballpits of deliciousness! Its weirdly satisfying running through 100 blueberry bushes getting all the berries going WHEE! .. iz.. iz dis just me? Oh noes.. Also, Coffee.. ALL the coffee.. Must go fast!

Wholesome farming simulator. But you get to talk to people in the town, build relationships, go to festivals, and build your home and farm. I didn't grow up with harvest moon so I can't tell you it's "Just like harvest moon!" but as someone who came into this genre with this being my first game, it's a very peaceful and enjoyable game. 

The only cons I could give this game is the fact it does get repetitive over time, but I haven't played new updates of the game so it may be better now. It's enjoyable when you've had a break but playing this often is... it starts to feel like a chore to water the plants daily and take care of the farm. Don't get me wrong- this game is great but it does get to be much so if you are into casual gaming and not long sessions, this would be your friend. Otherwise, you may be more like me who binges a few days and then won't touch it for months. 

Still is definitely an enjoyable game though. Is it worth the price? Yep. Do it.

My playtime for Stardew is closer to two hundred hours, across multiple platforms. 

A lot of farming sims have slowly become more and more forgiving and easy, and Stardew is a nice break from it. It won't slam you into the ground if you mess up, but it stops the hand holding after spring which is lovely. The game itself has tons of content, and if you really want to do and see everything even past perfection it'll be a plenty long game. The characters are great and one of the best parts of this - I actually want to know more about them, and don't skip the heart events most of the time. The mechanics are slow at first, but speed up as soon as you get sprinklers and it can really be fully automated if you want. One of the best farming sims I've ever played, and it's still getting updated to this day. Absolutely worth the 15 dollars.

This game resonated deep within my psyche and awoke ancestral memories from uncountable past generations of farmers time immemorial. 

The feeling was so strong that I completely altered my life plans, bought a small farm in the middle of diddle-do nowhere, and am more or less living the game irl. However I am so busy learning how to farm that I don't have time to play Stardew Valley anymore.

Thank you ConcernedApe, your little pixel game literally changed my life and now I won't starve while Western civilization collapses.

This game is amazingly wholesome with a lot to do that it was actually stressful from time to time especially when you are focusing on completing many tasks or objectives within time limits but the outcome was always worth it. I now have 100% the game(in terms of achievements but haven't gotten "perfectionist") and can finally take a break from the game. I have many good memories(and a few bad/bitter sweet ones) that directly connect with certain experiences in my life but I can now finally put this game to rest for awhile and move on with a smile on my face. Thank you so much ConcernedApe for making such a genuine game that many people should try out and I'm looking forward to your next project, Haunted Chocolatier!

Not for me.

A daily time and energy limit makes this game stressful to play and severely limits what you can do in a day. It's especially annoying when you want to explore the mines, as you can't go too far without running out of energy. When you run out of energy, you pass out, lose money (someone robs you) and then you wake up in your house the next day.

This limiting factor seeps into the entire gameplay where you will always nervously watch the time and energy meter, making sure that you're back in your house before it gets too late, and this ruins the freedom to explore and fun factor for me.

There's also a FOMO factor in that if you miss f.ex. an event or someone's birthday, you lost some potential progress and/or rewards.

The controls are a bit too clunky and inaccurate for my taste.

On the plus side, there's a lot of choice in the game, there are many varied activities, the pixel art is great and the music is allright.

If you're a completionist or perfectionist, I don't recommend this game. You have to pick and choose what activities to focus on, and you will always miss out on some things. Graveyard Keeper was a lot more fun and involved and had a clear goal.

Stardew Valley is a lot more open, with more activities but no clear goal.
great game

I don't play many games like this, but ever since I have it has been almost impossible for me to try other games similar to this. I just play it on here with mods or on my Switch (mostly the Switch). Amazing depth and the amount of options for the player to choose from make this game very satisfying. You can choose to farm crops or brew beers and wine, or be a bee farmer and sell honey in massive quantities, or make fruit jellies and pickled vegetables, or go fishing, or mining, or mega harvest certain crops during certain seasons and do other things during the rest of the seasons. Truly excellent, and it is always getting little fixes and has multiplayer where you can build another home on the ranch for your friend(s), up to 3 other players can join you, making these farming and other options free to divide up the labor and maximize efficiency. Player choice is definitely this game's strongest feature and it is both relaxing and engaging. Definitely recommend for solo and or coop play.

around 2 years after buying this game, I think I have a good and honest review for it. I bought it contemplating if I really should as I don't enjoy games such as this where you farm and do quests and such. However when I bought it, I got hooked on the game. The music is a 5/5 and the atmosphere is amazing. It's a fun game to play whether you are streaming or just relaxing. Fun for all ages too! If you were to buy this game, know what you are getting yourself into. This game isn't a hop on for a few hours and you're done with the game type of thing, its a play for about 50 hours plus and you're done. However you can never really be done with a game like this. There are so many different ways to play and you cant choose just one! Whether you want to spawn in a lush forest, or the sandy shores of the beach. You are going to want to play this game so many times its hard to count. As you may have noticed, I've only played for 24 hours. However its not cause I don't find the game very enjoying, I just don't have as much time as I would want to play this. I give this game a solid 10/10 IMO. I'm sure you'll love it too.

This game has shown so much and I believe that more can be done to make it better but for me, I love the game and everything that they put in it. I have this game on Xbox, Switch, and PC. But i just started on computer a year or Two ago. I suggest this game to all players who love RPG and Farming games. Thank you.

This game has been a favorite that I've bought across almost every platform of mine.
A few days ago I decided to test this with the deck.
First and foremost I have loved this game on desktop, and it has always controlled well. Even when I paired an Xbox Controller. Once I booted it on the deck I was greeted with the same config as switch. It works and plays wonderfully on the deck which made me quite happy. 

Now about just the game and not just how well it has run for me:
If you're seeking a good simulator game that allows you to choose what you do freely, this is for you. You can not hone in specialty crafts, but you can choose to mine, farm, forage, fish, and more sorts of things. With so many secrets in the game and hidden story-lines, you can learn so much about all the characters around town.

Great game, sank way too many hours into it.

A few mods make it even better. You can use SMAPI (cross-platform, docs at https://smapi.io) to load lots of different mods, all of which can be found at https://www.nexusmods.com/stardewvalley.

Here's a list of the mods I used, which I'm posting mostly for myself in case I want to revisit this game again some day (95% achievements, 500+ hours, was... enough).

AutoGate
BillboardAnywhere
ContentPatcher
FastAnimations
GenericModConfigMenu
HorseFluteAnywhere
HorseOverhaul
Kats High Vis Fertilizer
LookupAnything
NPCMapLocations
SkipFishingMinigame
SimpleCropLabel
SkullCavernElevator

The wiki at https://stardewvalleywiki.com is also invaluable.

~Pros~

+ Great looking pixel art, that evokes nostalgia

+ The soundtrack is nice

~Cons~

- You'd think this game would be relaxing, but no, it's actually very anxiety inducing, so stay away if you have trouble with anxiety. There's tons of stuff that you need to do, and time limits everywhere, and very little time in the day for you to do that stuff before the game knocks you out. The game is filled with lots of running back and forth to stores, water crops, fetch items, give gifts to NPCs.

- Related to the above, the short days, combined with the busy schedule, results in a lack of time to yourself, so exploring is de-incentivized.

- The gameplay is boring. I don't feel like I'm doing anything, accomplishing anything, or experiencing anything, It just feels like a bunch of pointless busy work and fetch quests.

- The combat is sh*t.

- The animation is very simplistic.

- The character portraits are kinda bad to be honest.

- Nearly all of the NPCs are unlikable.

- NPCs having their own schedule is realistic, but in practice is frustrating. Marnie and Pierre will stand there staring and dumb sh*t THE ENTIRE DAY, and not help you or sell you anything. And this can go on for weeks.

Single-handedly my most played and purchased game ever. I have bought it on every platform that exists on besides Xbox. I love this game. I praise this game for the direction it took into making just a simple game that is complex if you want it to be or the most chilled out game you've ever played. The music helps add this air about the game too. Plus, it isn't just a farming simulator, it is more of a life simulator. As you play as the character you created, you can fish, farm, mine, fight, and forage as all main actions. Plus on top that, you get to recreate this whole town and make friends with tons of people. Being friends with people is also a whole system in itself, plus this can lead to you becoming married and maybe even getting kids on the farm. I recommend this game to everyone and at most ages too. I feel as if both ends of the spectrum can enjoy this game.

Harkonnen

The garish, surreal, and grotesque all hyper-normalize at a certain point until it's just noise. All carried beautifully by a distortion-heavy noise rock chugging that matches with the steady waving rise and fall of the level geometry to form a hypnotic state. Most of the time, the 3-2-1 countdown of the run dying doesn't reach the 2. The momentary flashes of relief from the end of level screen start to feel less like peace and more like the hangover periods sitting at a bus terminal early in the morning. Bleary-eyed, aching, miserable. The last slice of meat in the package, awake at your own protest. Hit the button, spin it again. You know you want to.
