What a fantastic game! It's simple enough for new players to get the hang of, while keeping more advanced players entertained. There's always something to do. 
The day time progression and requirement for energy give the game a pleasant difficulty. Energy lows can be easily remedied by eating food. Time can be easily paused by bringing up your inventory when you need to walk away for a bit.
 The fishing and arcade games can be difficult to master, but well worth the time to learn. Fishing is a great way to make money in the early stages of the game.
The seasonal festivities give a charming feeling like you would expect in a small, rural community. They are also a great place to buy seasonal recipes, decor  and seeds. The festivities also offer an easy way to speak to everyone in town, even if some of the residents are a little cantankerous.
The charming pixel art is well thought out and amazingly detailed. Character customization is remarkably thorough without being overwhelming. 
For those who enjoy modding their games, there are thousands of mods out there. For those who prefer tutorials and walk throughs available all over the internet. 
This game really does have something for everyone!
My only regret with purchasing this game is that I didn't know about it sooner.

For this I was diagnosed as a [b] wasting disease [/b]. So, decaying in my bed of red and green fluids, I grew green and red vegetables on the farm of little troubles. Some days the lethargy bled into my simulation and I let my crops wither as the seasons marched on unsympathetic, never letting me catch up and make good. I hid from the folk of the town who shunned me, tho the children were even more cruel, flinging stones at my shack and teasing me with callously crafted insults like stinging whips of dehumanisation. I dreamed of better, slowly atrophying in my narrow hospital bed and knowing this game was making everything so much more worse. Yet, I play on. Exalted are the pains and pennant labours of starvation on the farm of little troubles. This which must be done every morning without fail, until sweet nothing usurps mortal suffering. I can no longer sustain the weight of my laptop on my legs without pain untold like a stinging nettle vice grip clenching my entire nervous system. Yet despairingly I can no longer lift my arms to play on the dolly tray. My Den Mother Donnah has power of attorney and refuses to let the doctor unplug the game, as she takes the screen captures of my near 24 hour game play and fakes her own lets plays using a computer generated Korean girl, called Hyun-Joo. One time my petrol uncle Richard snuck in and unplugged the game, which I then only pretended to play. I started to recover immediately, but of course Den Mother Donnah eventually came with a thirsty lust for new farm times. The consequences I suffered were swift and efficient. Like in times past, she engulfed me with her frumpus and denied my body sweet life preserving oxygen. All the while she gripped my hair and twisted while leaning back and pinching my stomach, her immense weight seizing my frail frame in place, as I feebly thrashed my legs suffocating in her frumpus musk. This went on until I lost consciousness. When I came to, the laptop was on my lap, with the little trouble farm game running and my aching arms all ready engaging the motions to play before I was even present in the waking world. There was no escaping my farm. Thank you game for giving my life a point.

10/10

Stardew is a fun farming simulator where you can create your own farm, find a romantic partner, fight monsters in caves, and more! This game is a God send for casual players, I'll tell ya. It's hard to be mad at this game when you're the one overreaching because you want to keep going but your character needs to sleep or you know you have no HP and shouldn't go down another level, but you do anyway cause you're trying to get to the next checkpoint. 

This game embodies chill. You can even marry the character of your dreams and have children with them. All the characters have their own story, and you can really vibe with them. The characters in the game are good, in the sense that they hit that "realism" where you can connect with the characters and maybe even think of a couple of people in their life that are just like them. They all have their own schedules as well. 

There are seasons in the game and you can upgrade your farm with husbandry, coops, etc. You can go into a dungeon and just adventure. 

It even vibes well as a multiplayer game. One time a group of us were playing and I wanted to be a fisherman so I only fished, another friend was a dungeon crawler, and the third friend was the farmer. We all turn our stuff in to sell/collect at the end of the in-game day, and whenever we're all ready we just progress. It's all chill and wholesome af. 

Literally anyone can play this game. This is also a great way to get the older generation into video games if they never played games before.

Did I mention this was made by one person? Because it was. 

This game released in 02/26/2016. It's 03/26/2022 and Steam is saying this game is "Currently Popular".

This game is $15, with a $45-$60 value. 

Need I say more?
It's chill and rewarding, definitely worth trying :)

Review seems surplus to requirements at this point because the game has been out so long and its clearly a fave with most people, but you know what? It damn well deserves one.

I bought this on a bit of a whim, expecting a easy, throwaway title that would keep me entertained for a handful of hours, doing a little bit of growing, crafting and easy combat.

Stardew Valley has absolutely captured my heart and has had me gripped for over a hundred hours. Far from being simplistic and quick, what I found was a cracking little RPG-lite, with one of the most in depth and, at times, enjoyably complex titles ive played in a long, long time.

I got such a feeling of "just one more day" that I found myself up until 2am some nights playing this, wondering where the time had gone and being ok with the fact my 40 year old body was going to hate me in the morning. 

This game will suit anyone looking for an RPG type experience, wanting a huge timesink, with multiple objectives, a sense of growth within the game, and quite a bit of time to dedicate into it. Completioinists will love this one. Yes I reccomend it.

I will never forget when I discovered the Stardew Valley forum on Chucklefish's website. I was always checking in on the Starbound dev blog when one day I came across this game's forum. I checked that forum every week from when I discovered in 2014 (I think) to when the game was released on Steam in 2016. I bought the game day one, spending the entire weekend playing Stardew Valley. At the time, there were no wikis, no guides, no walkthroughs. There was no maximally efficient system to play the game with... there was just the game. My original playthrough is like nothing I can possibly describe - the extreme stress of making it back to bed before 2:00AM or getting through watering all my crops without running out of energy contrasted with the absolute ease of fishing or just walking around and listening to one of the greatest video game soundtracks of all time is just awe inspiring. Stardew Valley really has the highest highs and the lowest lows that the medium can offer. All that and the game was coded, graphically designed, and soundtracked by ONE PERSON. The gameplay is bar none the greatest of all time. The combat is solid, the farming is better than I ever could have  asked for, the economy of the game is well balanced while leaving multiple avenues to success and not just one optimized solution. The progression system is rewarding, the lore of the game is exciting to find and uncover, and the villagers make for interesting background pieces in a game focused on being a simple farmer. Every little detail in the game seems to be crafted perfectly, as if ConcernedApe left absolutely no stone unturned in the creation of this timeless classic. And yet the game is STILL getting free content updates and was later updated to include seamless multiplayer. When I say that this game is GOATED I mean that this game is absolutely GOATED. If you haven't played the game and enjoy video games in any sense of the word, pick this game up. If you hate video games and think that having fun is a sin, still pick up this game so that ConcernedApe's next title is just as much of a masterpiece.
It's just a masterpiece.

If for no other reason than this, stardew valley is well worth its price tag. bonus memes: relaxing gameplay, quality soundtrack, and noticeable rpg-style progression.

I highly recommend stardew valley extended which can be found on vortex. IT adds more NPCs to romance and interact with as well as add some quality of life mods. This game is so addictive it borders on illegal! It's not my typical game at all, I tend to like more action in what I play, but there is something so calming, so basic, so pure, and so intangible about Stardew Valley that it somehow makes typically tedious chores enjoyable. I can find no good way of describing the gameplay itself - I've tried several times and it always sounds boring, derivative, and full of contradictions. On the one hand, it is mindless fun, but on the other you need to plan every waking minute and consider the future. On the one hand it is very repetitive, but on the other every day is unique. On the one hand, it's so simple you can start playing immediately, but on the other I have the wiki page open constantly. It really is something you need to experience to understand. 
The game's strongest point is also its most frustrating: it objectively has the best paced gameplay loop in any game ever, period, full stop. It is perfectly designed so that you start a day, check on one or two things, and then you realize half the day is gone, and you might as well finish the day, rinse, repeat. It's immensely enjoyable, but immensely difficult to stop playing.
I'd highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a break from the stress of traditional games.

Not your average farming simulator. This game feels like a complex world of it's own, full of life and personality and story, yet also managing to be a great technical experience as a farming sim. I love interacting with all of the townspeople as well as retreating back to my private farm. This truly is an open-ended world, as you can build your farm as a total hermitage for maximum profits or live a simple village life, socializing with everyone in town and building intimate relationships. There are mysteries to discover and so many different parts of this deceptively small world to explore, you will not be bored by this game. I recommend this game to anyone who is even remotely considering playing it. It will be worth the time you will inevitably dedicate to it.

As a longtime player of the Harvest Moon (or technically Story of Seasons) franchise, this definitely exceeded my expectations. Although this game does pay homage to the HM games, I feel that some of the features that they got from the HM games should have been removed or improved, as it makes the game feel more archaic than it should be. Still, this game is great compared to the other recent games in the genre--which is bittersweet considering the genre's current state.

Stardew valley is a really nice game that teaches you about communicating, and farming. This sandbox game is entertaining but as you progress through the game things don't really change that much, making it less entertaining as it would be. It does a wonderful job portraying real world events such as marriage, farming, and buying things with money. As an addition to the shopping concept, players can sell items to earn more, This helps them become more hardworking in real life. Overall, I think this game is a really nice game for people new to sandbox games because of it's wide variety of characters with different personalities and traits. It has many interesting twists and fantasy based aspects. This game does have a big price tag though so I would rate it 4.7/5 stars.
Still one of the most chill and pleasant gaming experiences available. Years of content patches and now mod support have only served to make this even more of an endless source of fun.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This game gives you an immersive look at the farming life while sprinkling in a bit weirdness, by giving the choices of who to form a friendship with and what to prioritize, whether it'd be growing crops and performing the duties of a farmer, or choosing to fish or mine the dangerous, enemy-filled caves. with this comes other hard like to worry about the NPCs and their thoughts of you, or to worry about your farm and perform your job to the best you can. With that in mind the game lets you complete quests, get married, and even learn everyone's true thoughts and who they truly are. On specific days, festival events will take place allowing you to buy seasonal items and decor for your house. You should definitely get the game for your self if you are looking for a game depicting these characteristics, if you do get the game, more surprises are awaiting, Have Fun.

this game is amazing, and i'm sure it's great for many other people but i do geniunely dislike it. There's too much to do and nothing that says what you're supposed to do. You have to balance quests, skills, social relations, farming, animals, fighting, fishing, mining, and your gold count all in a limited amount of time, especially considering a day lasts like 5 minutes and people Still say "yea this game is easy to pick up". Even if you did spend months learning everything there is in this game that just sucks out all the enjoyment and turns the game into a tedious simulator where you just wait around and don't feel accomplished at all. I get this game is well-liked, and My God did the developer spend so much time on this game that even though i can't derive any enjoyment out of it, I still feel really bad giving a negative review

Alright folks, here it is. 

If you're thinking of buying this game: do it. do it now. 

If you think this game is boring: you weren't ready for the VAST majority of things to do in this game... plus, you were in too much of a rush.

And finally... if you think this game is a "grind": why? there's no required amount of time needed to do anything in this game. It's a beautiful walk in the park, it's not meant to be 'easy' to start up right off the bat, but trust me... it'll come to you pretty gosh darn fast.

I don't play this game to spendrun, I don't play this game to stress myself with challenges... I play this game because it's got a little bit of everything, and I'm STILL learning how to play, even 210 hours in. 

The beauty of Stardew Valley is how many different play styles you can explore and test. Farming may be the main source of income, but there are many others ways to bring in the dough! 

I've had this game in my library since 2017, but it wasn't until this year that I was really able to dive in and appreciate it. What Eric (ConcernedApe) has made here is a one in a million kind of gaming experience, don't pass up a chance to live through this game.

Additionally, I suggest playing your first save WITHOUT any modding whatsoever. Get a feel for the game as it was created, without the help/changes from mods first. It was MUCH easier to take the game in during my first run without any mods, and now it's much easier to pick mods/use mods because I know the game. 

There is also a TON of Stardew Valley content on YouTube meant for beginners of the game, because it's such an extensive game even right from the start. So if you need a hand or your feeling frustrated, go to YouTube before giving the game up. It's worthwhile.

Stardew Valley has been a comfort game to me for a while, I've always seen myself turn to this game when I was in a bad spot or maybe just bored. It's so simple, and the aesthetic of the game in general is just fun to look at. Maybe it's the fact that I fell in love with indie farming games, or maybe that this game is just one of those things you easily get attached to but I'm addicted. The first day I got this during quarantine times, I played it for 18 hours straight. Not the best look on me, but let that leave an impression. I'm so glad I bought this game, and I'm looking forward to the future of ConcernedApe and his games!

This is probably one of the most addicting games I’ve ever played. As simple as it seems you wouldn’t believe how engaging it is. The format is easy and quick to learn. Once you get the swing of things the time rolls by hour after hour with no end in sight. It’s the perfect game to sit back and relax. Playing with friends is also a good time when everyone can contribute to the farm. Choosing between farming, ranching, fishing, and mining make this game the most exciting. You can stick to one or two or do a little of all. The social aspects of this game are also a gem. The characters are all funny and likable in their own way. Building friendships with characters is fun between the constant days of work to be done. All in all you’re getting a highly addictive and fun to play farm management game with much more than meets the eye. Best $15 I’ve ever spent. Check it out!

If you've not played this game yet, then I don't know where you've been.  Cozy and relaxing atmosphere and building your farm is only the tip of the iceberg.  Help a wizard with his marital problems, help a mayor with his secret love affair, make friends with a salty old fisherman and get married to a demon guy who lives in the sewers.  All this while making your grandfather proud...or not, it's your choice.

Stardew Valley is everything that an indie farming sim is supposed to be, plus more! I love the seeing the individual character stories, participating in town events, discovering new areas, and (of course) designing a farm. Very cute, very fun, will always be a favorite of mine.
Also, huge fan of the co-op feature. There are some ways it could be improved, but for the most part, works very well. Stardew is great to play with friends, or even with strangers (making friends!)

Adddicting

as a redditor and avid poster on r/memes and r/anime (amassing over 500,000 karma in my career) i have never been outside, touched grass or interacted with another person within the past decade. i was seriously considering having to go outside at one point due to  wanting to fill the crippling void within myself but luckily, Stardew Valley has replaced all need to ever interact with the outside world as in this game i am able touch grass without going outside, interact with women and exist under the sun for more than three minutes without increasing my risk of melanoma due to my deficiency of melanin in my skin from a lack of being outdoors. returning to the topic of interacting women, i have to commend on stardew valley's depth within friendship and romance mechanics as gifting suffices as a foundation for friendship for the game which is a skill that i have developed to a high proficiency before my retraction from society. although i was well developed in the art of gifting in the real world (even visiting people multiple times everyday according to their schedules) they all called me a 'stalker' and told me to 'never speak to me again.' frankly i don't know what's wrong with them, i'd have to assume that they're glitched and only show the dialogue for hated gifts. in fact i got so attached to Stardew Valley that my own wife left me after i quit my job to spend as much time as possible on Stardew with Abigail and my child (who i named Grubbie) but my wife told me that i 'needed to stop playing that game' and to 'get a job so you can support your daughter.' i don't know what she's talking about, i had to explain that i make 40,000 g per day on ancient fruit alone so we can live just fine and that was the last time i ever saw her or my daughter again. i should probably ask mayor Lewis if he knows where they went. anyways, i am writing this review so that i can share my experience before i lose my house as i have been sent threatening letters in my mail box regarding my 'unpaid rent and bills' but as far as i know, Stardew never required you to pay rent and Stardew is completely true to life! i'll try and see if robin can make me a new house before they cut off my power as without my computer i can't play Stardew and i don't know what i would do without Stardew Valley.

TL'DR: This game has been a fun journey for me. I can honestly say if you're looking for a game that you can enjoy both solo or with friends, (even doing both runs simultaneously) this is definitely one of those games. So you wanna go fight? Go gettem! You wanna relax and fish? By alllllll means. You wanna actually be a farmer? Who'd have thought, use that green thumb! Lumberjack fantasies? Plenty of trees for ya. Or maybe you like dwarfssss? ROCK AND STONE! cough you get the idea, as it is a sandbox game. It's got a little bit of everything in just the right amounts. It is not JUST another farming sim though, this game is that and more, -as fighting, exploration, and interacting with the locals is a big part of progression and the experience. If you're still on the fence however, keep reading and I give a little more depth to help you along.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
To start, after 230 hours I have yet to complete everything this game has to offer, though I can say I have already reached the end game, and am pretty deep into the content that came out with the last major update. That said, I will avoid any unnecessary spoilers in this review. 

Solo Run: Year 3, spring 27 (135 hours)
Group run total (aprox 100 hours) longest group run: year 2 winter 24

This is mostly to show I've split my time pretty evenly. (I actually probably spent more time on my solo due to pausing, afk, and wiki reading lol).
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

MY OVERVIEW:
Starting with the basics, your days start at 6am, and end between 12am-2am.
Each in game hour is a minute, so a day is about 18 min, to max 20 min long.
That means you can easily go through an entire season in two 5 hour sessions, OR if there's a day you and your buds have off each week where that's your gaming day, you can definitely squeeze in one season in one sit.

Starting out, you're pretty limited in what you can do as taking actions like hoeing, watering, fishing, or cutting trees costs energy, and when you run out of energy, you cant do much else. Each season offers different crops, different events, and different fish. What's nice is that you can check all your progress in game. It keeps a tally of all the money you've earned overall, and what items you've sold off (when placed in your shipping bin). Your skill list is up to date as you gain XP, so you'll know if you're about to rank up. Every skill has craftable items you gain by leveling up in each category. You can choose to focus on one skill or do multiple at a time. You can check everything you've turned in, and your relationship status with the people in town, all from your menu. The progression curve feels pretty smooth, and getting better tools or gear ALMOST ALWAYS feels like a pretty big turning point, or achievement.

It may come as no surprise that your main source (and best source) of income is farming, although you can still make your money mining or fishing and selling things you get. You can also level all these as skills, and acquire perks to help you along. It's certainly not as grindy as other sandbox games though, and while overwhelming at first due to timed days, it isn't too hard to get the hang of the learning curve.

STORY: 8.5/10
The story (which you'll get immediately in the intro) is that you leave your soul sucking job to live out in the country and enjoy life. (I think some of us wish we could do that haha). It's a simple premise, though you do get to choose either settling back into that life, or fighting against it once you get there with these two routes; Help the community, or give back into the soul sucking company you left. Most of the characters are pretty charming and seem stereotypical up front until you learn their tragic anime back story (It really does feel that dramatic at times. Like "whatta you mean you kille-") oh sorry. It's okay, you'll never see it coming, (if you even find the quest line.  <_<  ) ....But anyway some characters feel incomplete, or undynamic, and with so much of that dynamicism in other characters and areas in the game, it does leave a tiny more to be desired. Otherwise the lore of stardew, and the characters, and the whole place definitely feels pretty magical.

GAMEPLAY: 9/10
Gameplay is pretty simple and easy to get the hang of. You can roll your hotbar with your mouse, swing with a click, move with your wasd keys, and Useful tip: can turn on (show hit square) so you can see where you're aiming when you're farming (mostly for farming). Sometimes I feel like combat is a little clunky but its not by any means bad in terms of hit boxes or even enemy scaling. Food serves as both energy and health items so you can use it for both when in the mines as you fight enemies and swing your pickaxe.

GRAPHICS: 8.5/10
Graphic wise the game is polished, and charming, but as a top down, it's not super detailed. There is a lot of detail in everything, graphics included, but obviously there are limits to pixelated sprite work. As far as pixel art goes, it's definitely pretty top notch and expressive. I never feel like it ever looks ugly or off putting. I can easily be immersed in the world and my gaming session and have yet to run into anything I would say puts me off about any of the sprites, texture work, or overall graphics.

SOUND/MUSIC: 9/10
The sounds for everything is pleasant. I haven't come across any jarring sounds, and the collecting items and pulling up crops is satisfying to the ears. The music is great. It always feels like I can never get enough of them sometimes though. For example, you only get some music some places, and that means if I wanna hear that really cool cave song, I have to be mining in the cave, and then be lucky enough to hear it. Some of the seasons songs are really lovely though, namely some of the tunes in fall and winter have to be some of my favorite. Every song might not be a banger, but it has enough bangers throughout the entire ost that it makes up for that. Plus, maybe a different song does it more for you, but if I had to pick my favorite 3 songs, they would be Mines (A Visitor To The Unkown), Fall (The Smell Of Mushrooms) WInter (The Wind Can Be Still). There are more I really like, but i'll leave it at those.

REPLAYABILITY: 8.5/10
So far, can honestly say after how many times I/we have restarted runs and play throughs, it has only gotten more fun and enjoyable as I have a better idea of how much I can do with my time, and how to efficiently schedule my days. If I can edit my review, I may update this to a higher score later. I already feel like it will be a mainstay in my collection of games to play even if it's more like Minecraft where I drop it for a while, and then come back and binge it again, like rewatching a movie you love but haven't watched in a while.

All in all, pretty damn amazing it was made by one guy. Hope this helped you decide whether or not Stardew is right up your Valley. Cheers.

best game ever

I've played a lot of harvest moon type games, but this one REALLY stands out because of how all-encompasing it is. Want a dungeon crawl? Stardew Valley has one. Mining game? There's some of that to be done for sure. Talk to people and form virtual bonds? This is the right game. Events (random chance or triggered), crazy funky animals, automation, farming, a heartwarming story, a "bad end" (Screw joja), a villain (Screw joja again), hidden characters (Check the sewers if you haven't already!), over a dozen easily available characters with interesting stories and genuine flaws that serve to make them better instead of grating.. Stardew Valley somehow has ALL of this at once, and oh BOY if you're an easter egg hunter I don't think you'll ever run out of little things to notice. This whole game has been crafted with such amazing love and genuine passion and it shows that in every inch of it. If you think this is just a farming game, you're wrong. I think you can actually progress to the end of basically everything except the farm evaluation thing (vague for spoilers) WITHOUT planting a single crop. You could befriend the entire town, fish for a living, mine for a living, do requests for a living, forage random things from the wild for a living... This game isn't a farming sim, it's a game of it's own class.

[h1]♥ This Game[/h1]

This game is a relaxing little thing you can play as a stress reliever, & the type of game you can easily play even when tired. Children to elders can enjoy this game since the controls are easy & has different activites for different interests

I haven't played solo yet, since I've had friends to play with & I can't imagine enjoying solo more than with friends, but I'm sure it's still enjoyable. Each of my farms are different & earn game currency differently & I like the flexibility of that. Grinding for upgrades on the farm takes a little while, but it isn't stressful or irritating. Farming with a friend makes it easier & quicker, I think

I love pixel art styles, & the usage of it in this game is beautiful & easy on the eyes, the animals are so cute! 

The only things I think bother me, are; 

★ [b]The colour options[/b] (especially for the hair) when you make a character, it's not easy to have light or pastel colours (light blonde or pink for example) for the hair without it looking greyish or dull. I think that could be fixed if we got to colour pick for the highlighting & shading for the hair as well, & not just 1 shade for the whole hair. 

★ [b]Have more things to do with the pet.[/b] We can only pet it & give it water. It would be nice if it did things for us, like hunt & bring back things. Also if we could give it food & treats that maybe boost the activities it can do. Getting pet furniture would also be nice

If you ever wanted to be a farmer, or you never knew you wanted to be one, well let me reassure you that this is the game for you. This will have you living on your dream farm outside of the city life. Living alongside various townsfolk, with very interesting personalities to say the least, and Linus the trash eating sweetheart. Take part in many Festive activities throughout the seasons, go mining, ride horses? oh BABY! As you can see there are many things to do in Stardew Valley, BUT WAIT! I'm not done yet... Save the community center from the evil antagonist, Joja. Yes this game has a villain, which gives you anime enthusiasts more the reason to be the hero of this peaceful, somewhat wacky, RPG. Complete tasks... "AMOGUS?" "Shut up cringelord" This is Stardew Valley. As i was saying complete tasks, and save your local community center and become the "Ultimate Farmer" of 2016's smash hit Stardew Valley Today. #AD (not really). P.S 69 hours EX-DEE

I love almost everything about this game. The gameplay loop is satisfying, the visuals are beautiful, and there's endless things to do. I could go on and on about everything perfect about this game, so I'll just say my one negative.

Interaction with the villagers is really dull. After talking to people a few times, you'll begin to realise how lifeless they feel. Repeating the same lines every day, even after knowing them for years. The cutscenes you get with them all are charming, but to reach them, you just give them gifts every single week, over and over. Really though, its not a deal breaker in the slightest. I went into the game normally loving the social aspects of games, and now I love exploring and grinding to make the best farm I can! The fact that a single person made this game is astounding to me. Stop looking for a reason not to buy it, and get it.

Now this is a fun relaxing game that you can play for hours on end without getting bored. The core gameplay loop is really fun and it has so much content that it's extremely replayable. I've gone through I believe 5 or six different farms and played them to completion and I can say each experience felt different. The developer really cares about this game and is constantly adding bug fixes and thinking of new exciting content. I highly recommend this game to people who enjoy the slower more chilled out games.

What can I say about Stardew that hasn't already been said? I love that it is the work of one man's dream. I love that it is a game where you can be whatever you want to be. Yes, there are quests/objectives, but you don't have to complete them. If you want to mine, mine. If you want to farm, farm. If you want to fish, fish. If you want to decorate your farm, go for it. If you want to only push objectives, go for it. The whole premise of moving to a small town after leaving your corporate job is super relaxing for some reason, despite you still having to choose what you do day-to-day. I also love that the dialogue with the NPCs are relatable, and that you can set this game down for months at a time, but it's really easy to pick up where you left off....or just start over. Music is amazing, graphics are fun!

I tried playing this game years ago, and stopped because I didn't want to put in the work to learn it. (Ignorant, I know). 

But about 3-4 days ago on a whim, I decided to reinstall it and give it an honest shot. ~50 Hours later, clearly, I have been non-stop playing since then. I truly don't know where the time goes because I'm so invested in the story and the gameplay. 
This is honestly one of the best games I have played in such a long time, I feel so refreshed, I only wish that I had picked it up sooner. It's super addicting, and so fun to play. 
I love the stories that were put into the characters around town, and their dialogue whenever you talk with them. I love that there isn't any rush to get tasks done, and you can go as slow, or as fast as you want to to complete objectives. (Besides tasks on the bulletin board, but you don't get punished for not completing those either).
The passion behind the player base of this game also convinced me, when I was being hard headed to try this again. Friends that I've known for years are still playing this game to this day.
Overall, I feel a lot of regret for not picking it up sooner. If you are a fan of Terraria, this is another must-try.

This review will surely get lost in the sea of the literal hundreds of thousands of reviews for this game, but this game is so amazing it deserves a few moments of my time to write something about it. I got this game as soon as it came out my senior year in college and was instantly addicted. 5 years later I'm still playing, and I don't think that'll change anytime soon.

This is the best farming game ever made by a huge margin. If this game is a 10/10 (which it is) the next best possible farming game can, at BEST, score an 8/10. But I'll take it a step further: this is one of the best video games ever made. This game is transcendental. This is the sort of game people tell all their friends about, the kind of game parents can't wait for their kids to get old enough so they can boot it up for them for a co-op run to get them into video games. People will be playing this game for a long, long, LONG time. 

This is a game I'm going to come back to every year or two for the rest of my life.

Stardew Valley is something really special. I have been playing this game on different platforms since 2016, dozens of save files all with unique farms, I've grown attached to the NPCs, not once disappointed with anything in the game. The developer is quick to fix bugs and new content is added frequently. The community for this game is amazing. There are hundreds of fan-made mods that improve, redesign, and extend the game (and some even have their *own* sub-communities.) I have met years-long friends in co-op games. There are plot objectives but really no wrong way to play; you can choose to spend all your time fishing, or fighting monsters in the mines, or romancing bachelors, and still enjoy the full game.

I downloaded Steam just so I could play this game. 

It's been three years and I have absolutely no regrets. I love the world and all of the quests. I love that there's no sense of urgency to complete things; you play at your own pace and enjoy it however you want. I don't love farming, so on my second play I did the bare minimum I needed to do on the farm, and instead, I did a lot of mining and fishing and my game didn't suffer at all because there are so many different ways to grow your farm and your character.

If you want a casual game that you can play a million different ways and always find something new, then this is the game for you!

Stardew Valley has become one of my all time favorite games. Both single player and co-op offer such different but enjoyable play styles, and the variety of starts and options right out the gate and focuses are top notch!
 It's definitely slower paced than some games of this type and genre, but to me that is to its benefit! I enjoy games that allow me to learn slowly if need be, rather than constantly throwing me in the deep end because of accidentally missing an early line or clue. The game also offers ways to explore it in full even if you didn't at first pick a route that seems like it would let you. It doesn't punish you for the paths you've chosen, and can later on down the line offer ways to get items you otherwise might have been blocked from.

 This is barely touching on the co-op, which in many games can be a hassle, this game does wonderfully with the options of how you and your friends want to go about playing. Joint money making or not, where you live on the farm, and opening up areas of the game either through having one person focus on one job or task, or going around in groups to complete the quests or challenges!

 All in all, Stardew Valley is a game I can pick up any time, and it's incredibly enjoyable to grow a farm and whatever it is you want to do with said farm! Become a monster slayer? Sure. Exclusively farm fruit trees and tappers? You can do that (albeit it's a challenge for some areas XD). Have animals and eventually do nothing but care for them? Stardew Valley lets you do that.
 I recommend you give it a try, it certainly isn't for everyone with the pacing it has, but even so I'd say give it a try. See how your first year goes, there's always something new to find and explore in the game!

Stardew Valley
---------------
This Game is a MASTERPIECE, without a doubt, its perfect for what it goes for, simple in almost every way, but doesn't lack story or Gameplay. there is always going to be something to do and that's a great thing!

This Game may not be for everyone and i get that, its a farming game for goodness sake, but for what they do, they nail it as if they hit 10 bullseyes right in top of each other. 

This game has quite a lot to offer, from farming and making money, to marrying and co-op online. it covers almost everything to be a "good" game in general and that's amazing despite on how it started so small. the game has seen many improvements and is still being worked on by the same man until this very say in 2022.

CUSTOMIZATION
------------------
This game has quite a few Customization options.
Not quite as much as the dark souls or the new Elden Rings which im hoping on picking up soon here, but besides that, this game has enough customization options to let you have your own way of how you want your character to look!
it goes from:
Skin: 24
Hair: 73
Shirts: 112
Pants: 4
Gender: 2 (duh)
Accessories: 20
Color (Eyes, Hair, And Pants): all sections have a color bar that goes up to 99, showing the full spectrum of colors.
 You can also count about 6 pets in the mix if you really want to. Now as you can tell thats a lot of customization. but if you really wanna be crazy then go for the random button at the top left of the character customization screen.

Graphics?
-------------
Now lets take this for consideration. graphics in general should be the last of Your concern, and that also goes for Me, but I do have to say the graphics for this aren't the best for sure, but they sure do go well for the style, it stays to the art style and it looks good, like any other Pixelated Games.
 And that's also what i like about Pixelated Games, the Creators focus on fun more than anything else graphics wise and that's good. but keep in mind its always a warm welcome to have improved graphics come in (except for the gosh darn 3) but besides that, its all good.

Now Stardew takes place in a somewhat Third-Person camera view, while the game represents  you in 2nd view (word wise ofc), that's off topic though.
The world is 8-bit and so is everything else. good to know it stays like that LOL.

now the pixel art is most definetily well done and i give them props for that, it took me an hour to replicate one of those slimes, but its probably because i suck at pixel art :p.

Bugs and problems?
----------------------
Any game will have a few bugs, just because its good wouldnt prevent bugs.  But we will see what stardew has to offer when it has to do with bugs.
Some Bugs and Glitches may cause interesting things to happen, some good, and some others mildly annoying, may even be confusing to the player.

Anyways, regarding those, the animations and objects may and will clip into each other but its not game breaking since its a simple Game so it doesn't do much to your Game, now yes Trees don't have collision with the Hills it falls on, not allowing you to get the resources that fall on the Hills, which is mildly annoying.

Now Glitches like speeding up Slime spawning would be useful for farming Slime's in the slime hutch. and the High Quality Fertilizer glitch, which exploits Pierre's Fertilizers, in the 15th of spring.

There's many glitches but I don't want to have to cover them all, all you need to know is that this Game has Glitches too which should be obvious to You by now.

Gameplay
-----------------
Gameplay is pretty solid, and so is the story, but I will not be discussing the story to not spoil the interesting details about it.
Gameplay is simple but has a lot to do. Here's a List to see all the options.

Things to do:
Quests/Special Orders
Helping Jojo mart
Getting back the Community Center
Build Relationships
Farm
Fish
Mine
Scavenging/Foraging
Lumberjacking
Make a barn
Fight monsters
Sell things as well as buy
Adventurers Guild
Upgrade your house and play with Friends
Marry and have a family
Go on Festivals and Events
Discover and adventure
And more that i may not be aware of.

As you can tell there is a LOT to do, not as much as a game like Minecraft. but still has a plethora of options to go for. There are multiple areas you can discover or set as your farm land, like the four corners map, just meant for a group.

CONCLUSION
-------------------
overall this Game rocks for what it is and I would give it a 10/10 for its worth, price, fun, long lasting Gameplay and story, and everything else. It amazes me how well thought out Games can be by just one dude. The Gameplay is perfect for the Genre of Game it belongs in and it stands out well in the crowd. possibly on the very top of the Iceberg.
If you have the time and money to play this game i 100% recommend it to anyone who loves the relaxation and fun with friends and family.

This was my review, thank you for reading, if you decide to get the game, have fun!

Genuinely one of the best games I've ever played. Reminiscent of the old farming sim titles I played growing up in the best ways, while bringing something new and improving on the genre as well. Very relaxing and flexible enough that you can approach it super methodically or more lax depending on your play style and preference. Incredibly charming game and world created here with an immense amount of things to do and pursue, inhabited by fairly nuanced characters, with writing that manages to not shy away from negative aspects of human experience while still retaining an overall sense of hope and joy. I've never felt better about a game purchase with regards to both my play experience as well as the type of creator behind the game. The free updates that improved the game immensely and the consistent communication about bug fixes and patches really earned my confidence in ConcernedApe. I would absolutely buy this game again if I could; it has frequently been a safe haven of harmless fun and joy in my life.

[h1]===GAMEPLAY===[/h1]
The combat system is based on spamming left click to kill the monsters found in very specific locations, a very simple but relaxing system that is surrounded by a relaxing gameplay where you decide how fast you want to progress throughout the game.

The game is so relaxed it is impossible for the player to lose: the crops don't die if not watered for days, you can spend an entire year in your house without losing anything, you can't die (you will instead pass out if your health or energy reaches 0).

[h1]===BUGS/MISSED OPPORTUNITIES===[/h1]
The game missed a lot of opportunities, some examples are:
- The clothing system is rather limited (one example is that you can only change the colour of some clothes),
- The colour sliders present when creating a character or painting a building are very limiting (I have found it very hard to make a character with light-blonde hair),
- You can't change your hairstyle at any time and the section of those is very limited (would have loved to be able to pixel-art my own hairstyle),
- The villagers won't change their clothes around the seasons and festivals (it's a bit of a shame to see characters wearing summer clothes in winter!),
- The player doesn't have a birthday.

Bug-wise the game is well polished: There is no bug that will stop you from playing or crash the game. However it is possible for the player to reach areas they are not supposed to reach by using a chair or spamming their swords in specific places.

[h1]===GRAPHICS===[/h1]
The graphics is okay: I find it very simple and clear but a bit oversaturated.

[h1]===REPLAYABILITY===[/h1]
The game can be replayed with different settings (such as farm types, rewards and bundles) and strategies. However the core content (such as the villagers) will remain the same.

[h1]===FINAL VERDICT===[/h1]
Playing the game is a very nice and smooth experience despite the many missed opportunities that can be (at least partially) improved with mods.

If you enjoy Harvest Moon games and farming simulators, this is the game for you. If you're looking for a relaxing, calming, gem of a casual game, this is also the game for [i] you. [/i] If you're a hoarder (like me), and are looking for a game to satisfy that collectioner's itch - this is [i] also [/i] the game for [b] you! [/b]
Very broad with surprising depth, Stardew Valley distills the HM experience into a game that could be considered the culmination of decades of pixel-based farming game experience - made by one man.

If you've (somehow) exhausted all the Valley has to offer, SV also has an incredibly active modding community, with hundreds of hours worth of extra content only a few mods away - some even add entirely new areas and storylines, to create the most expansive Harvest-Moon-like game ever!

I could not recommend it more.

You can farm, make friends, mine, craft, fight, and YOU CAN EAT BUGS. This game is a guilty pleasure for me because I love action games like Garfield Kart and Conan The Mighty Pig but they lack in the whole bug eating aspect. My fascination with this game began when I was a little tot, I used to help my family with the crops that we grew in the fields. We didn't earn much but it was an honest living, growing up in a household of 9. Since I could walk I was helping with the farm. I had to fight worms for potato skins and my 7 siblings for corn and bread. When I was 6 my grampa died in the hospital and he told me his final wish. He told me that in 7 years the best animated snail movie (Turbo) would be released. I couldn't believe it. It was a curse upon my family as soon as it released, the misfortune began. My dad died from a big tapeworm, my mom was struck down by a derelict satellite, and my seven sisters stepped on a landmine. My crops soon died and I was back to fighting the worms

A game all about making the most out of each day and "striving for excellence in everything you do." You could just do one task, go to sleep, start a next task, and so on. But the game flows best when you're juggling multiple different things. You'll want to be working on several things at once to be efficient, since it takes time to walk to places. And that's where the game really shines. Occasionally you'll have an off day and go to sleep at like 4pm, but if you think, you'll often be able to come up with a new task that serves your overall purpose. The game manages to impress the importance of filling your day with important things.

The system that is the game as a whole is mechanically and thematically intertwined with itself in many ways. It's a crafting game, and you'll need different resources to make things. Each of the villagers has their likes and dislikes. As said, it takes time to walk places. It's from this complexity that causes the player to need to juggle tasks.

And I haven't even gotten to the psychological benefits of this game. Many people consider this game to be a sort of salve for depression. It takes place in a beautiful, natural valley, it's all about down-to-earth farming of vegetables, fruits, and animals, and you can give gifts to the neighbors and make all sorts of friends.

It's through this context, combined with the mechanics, that this game imparts its one great lesson. It's amazing that this was coded, written, drawn, and musicianed by one person. I think this is Eric's way of passing on his apparent mentality of “Never stop striving to achieve perfection. Settle for nothing less than excellence in everything you do.”

After spending a whole day marathoning the game and reaching 100% perfection, I just got up and randomly did a bunch of chores around the house; I guess it inspired me? Or maybe the chores had been piled up since I hadn't done anything else but play the game for 48 hours? Either way, positive review from me.

I heard a lot of things about this game before I bought it. A simple farming sim with lots of fun things to do. I figured that at minimum I'd play for a bit. I made it through my first year, and while I was still learning the game, I found it at least interesting and a way to pass the time. not to mention, with my PC being basically a Nokia with a potato for a processor, it was and is about the only thing I can run smoothly. I played through a few more years, and while I'm nowhere near great at the game, I enjoy it immensely. I've put in almost 150 hours, now, and even bought a few copies for friends to play. I've only played Stardew Valley for 50 hours at the time of this review but it is one of the best games I've ever played. I was sceptical about buying this game as I had purchased it in the past and refunded it, but I finally decided to give it a second chance and I never looked back. It is not like any game I've played in the past, there is so much to do and that's what I love about this game. From farming crops to marrying one of the 12 available marriage candidates, there is something for everyone to enjoy. Stardew Valley is a beautiful game with so much things to discover and I highly recommend this game to anyone wanting to try it out.
great game

I did not think I would be torn with this game. Stardew Valley, from what anyone and everyone who praised it told me, was supposed to be a type of game I enjoy. Farming, collecting, fishing; whatever you want to do, you do at your own leisure. I like management games, I like expanding and collecting and socialising with NPCs. When I started playing this game, I thus thought that its appeal would be a non-issue for me. Maybe it was that expectation that lead me wrong.

I think that Stardew Valley is a good game. It looks good, has plenty of different things to do, it has good mechanics and a variety that never disappoints. NPCs have individual cut scenes linked to your social progression with them, giving glimpses into characters that have their own interests and problems and, crucially for such an idyllic setting, aren't always well adjusted members of the community. For the first 20, 30, maybe even 50 hours this game really holds up as the small town experience it seeks to emulate.

So why am I so somber? Well, while Stardew Valley has a lot of choice, I never felt free while playing it. The game has a shockingly rapid pace, with in-game days that go by fast enough that I always found myself running from one location to the other, sometimes opening the menu just to take a bit of a break. I often found myself desperately trying to squeeze in tasks before the dreaded "zZz"-symbol formed over my head, signalling the ticking clock to get back to your bed before collapsing. Before getting automation options, half a day often goes by before you're even done with your chores, leaving precious little time to do anything else.

On top of this, there is almost nothing in the game that you can straight-up avoid. It is part of the design of the game; to get materials for upgrades for yourself and the community, you have to interact actively with pretty much all that the game has to offer, from fishing to mining to fighting enemies. There are constant, strong incentives to pursue new things in the game. That sounds fine, even great, until you realise that your least favorite task is going to be pretty much mandatory for the rest of the game.

Quests further works to pull you in one direction or the other, with side quests having tight deadlines to chase resources and item drops that might not even show up after two in-game days of grinding because of the random drop chance. To pursue them means even more focus has to be put on maximising your time and effectivising your process. For long periods in this game, I wasn't doing what I wanted to do, instead chasing upgrades and quest objectives. There is something darkly capitalistic about it all, which to me clashes with the positive, anti-corporate values that the game seemingly wants to convey.

Despite this, there is a real addictive element to the game; partially because the core gameplay loop is quite good, but also because you simply [i]want[/i] to do everything you can to serve the community of the game. That's the truly toxic thing, that quests are linked to friendship progression with the characters, charging often mindless tasks with the value of social acceptance, however simulated. Ironically, you end up spending less time with the characters in service of becoming friends with them faster.

I liked Stardew Valley, at least mostly. It might sound strange after everything I've written here, but I do think that this is a game that is worth playing. However, I would offer a word of advice: Don't listen to what the game is telling you. Don't do side quests that don't serve your own enjoyment. Don't chase resources endlessly. Only do what you want to do in the moment, and exclude everything else. Let things take time. If you can do that, then I think that you'll have a much better experience with this game than I had.

When I first heard about this game I thought it would be overrated, I did not expect to love a farming sim game. It is very relaxing, very addicting and very fun. I love the characters and the hidden secrets the game has. Each character has something different to offer making it difficult to choose just one bachelor. I like the daily routines I do on the game, such as greeting the towns folk, taking care and collecting from my animals, decorating, mining, cooking, fishing and so much more! The achievements are fun to collect. The game can get pretty challenging after a certain point, but never dull. Playing with friends also adds a whole new feels to the game! I love both single player and multiplayer! Stardew Valley has truly become my favorite game, theres mods you can use if you ever get tired of the amazing art, theres expansion mods adding a whole new other layer to the game and there are quality of life mods making some things easier than others. The wiki for this game helped me out so much when I first started the game and the community is just so wholesome and amazing. I love Stardew Valley and I thank concernedApe for creating such an amazing game. My overall rating is 10/10. ♡

[h1] Simple and brief review [/h1]
Farming game with lots of events and stuff to do. 10/10

[h1]Pros: [/h1]
-Very fun
-Lots of content
-Supports multiplayer
-Easily can be played for years
-Lots of mods for quality of life upgrades or just some spice to the game
-Community is warm and friendly

[h1] Cons [/h1]
-The endgame is kinda hellishly grindy and RNG based (not really a con but its kinda annoying)
-Lots of stuff to keep track/memorise/google for crafting and farming (some people might not find it interesting to remember many stuff or keep on needing to google)

[h1] Overall [/h1]
This game doesn't really have cons, just pros. 10/10 recommended for people who like to play farm games with friends at a cheap and affordable price with loads of content.

I can't possibly cover everything I want to say here, but I've posted my thoughts on Stardew Valley on my blog. You can check it out here: https://mrdavepizza.com/stardew-valley-a-praiseworthy-staple-game-about-farming-fishing-sleeping-and-living/

Just a drop in the pond here, I'm sure, but naturally, this is one of my favorite games I have ever played. I've played it on Switch, Steam, and Android, and it works well with each system. It's kind of confusing to see an indie game that's so immensely popular and wonder if it is really indie with its often genre-specific usual quirkiness. It's really an independent work of art though, and it made me feel so good as I sat down to really see what it's about. Farming, yes, gathering, yes, but it's an open world that's ready to be imprinted by your creativity.

Here's some gameplay for you, yes you, you someone out there reading this. Just some demonstration of the game in action though from my original review:

Stardew Valley is a wonderful 2D experience with beautiful scenery, loving community with their own twisted plotlines, and many attributes that make it a great, time-consuming game for those wanting to get lost in the wilderness, start anew and build your way up! Find love within Pelican Town or victory down in the mines from fearsome battles and live the humbling life of a farmer. 

Overall Stardew Valley is a great game, one worth the purchese, however it can be boring at times. The characters themselves are all quite entertaining and hold their own heavy truths but I wish there were more random dialogue! Perhaps while either Shane or Sam are off to go to Jojo Market and you approach to talk, they could say, "Sorry, I'm in a hurry!" or, "Sorry, (insert player name)! I'm almost late to my shift!" and continue on.

The bachelors and  bachelorettes by themselves can hold some pretty heavy topic and truly make you feel some sympathy for them, but that can, of course, take time with some being portrayed as arrogant, like bachelor Alex, or a simple drunk, like bachelor Shane. I've done my own bit of researching with these twelve town folk and some of the marriage aspects are a little disappointing and I wouldn't mind some changes, but overall their personalities and lifestyle can truly catch the eye of the player and I'm sure some players have a relatable backstory with these twelve characters.

The townspeople have their own share of drama that can be shown through dialogue or through heart cut scenes which, in my opinion, really bring this game's community to life! It really shows how much the developers of Stardew Valley have inputted the detail needed to really make everything pop out! The monthly events are amazing and far more enjoyable with those the player is close with (I highly suggest getting those hearts up for the Spring Dance! I already faced enough rejection in Year 1...). 


I'd happily give Stardew Valley an 8/10, I wish there were some more details within the characters or just something simple put together to really bring out how the townspeople are on their day-to-day lives with dialogue to match what they're doing. While I'm highly enjoying the game and loving every bit of it, my only complaints are minor things to due with the people of Pelican Town, but other than that the game is extraordinary and very enjoyable to play when you have free time or need something to pass it.

Stardew Valley is a pretty good game for what it is, though it's a bit outside of my usual preferences. It's pleasant, relaxing, and has just enough challenge to be engaging without being stressful (unless you want to hyper-optimize everything, in which case I suspect it could give Factorio a run for its money). However, I've definitely got a lot of gripes, which are mostly things that bother me because they're the only things keeping me from getting really immersed and most of them feel like they could have been fixed with moderate to zero effort. Keep in mind that all of these are things that I found the core gameplay good enough to forgive, but these things annoy me enough I still want to complain about them.
- controls are a bit janky. I don't know how many times I've gifted a villager an item they hate or that I desperately needed for something else because I forgot what my menu was set to, or set off a bomb on my farm that broke a bunch of expensive equipment because I wasn't close enough to interact with the thing I meant to, but it was way too many. Two thirds of my controls woes would be solved if they just mapped separate buttons for "interact" and "use item". I suspect this might be the fault of console compatibility.
- The combat mechanics feel both token and out of place. They could honestly have ditched mining entirely and made metals a thing you just buy from the blacksmith without hurting the gameplay much, but even if they insisted on keeping mining and smelting in the game the combat isn't very good and they should have found a better way to spice up the process of mining than filling the mines with monsters to fight. It's also a major tonal clash since outright violence feels so out of place in the world of the rest of the game. Heck, even filling the mines with monsters you can't fight and have to avoid would have been both more fitting and more interesting than the half-assed combat the game actually has.
- I feel like the difficulty of the random quests (especially the large ones) wasn't playtested at all. Some of them you can knock out with a dedicated game-day of work or spare time before the deadline while others feel grindy to finish before the deadline. A few of them are even worse because they include a random element or require harvesting a resource that might or might not even spawn in sufficient quantity to meet the quota before the deadline.
- The difficulty curve of befriending villagers is completely upside down. At first it's a daunting task because you need to figure out what they like and gifts are expensive in the early game, then you start finding hints about the right gifts and you start having enough money that gifts aren't hard to provide, and eventually you've maxed out their affection and they give you free gifts while you have no need to invest further time or thought into befriending them.
- The menus are missing a lot of much-needed quality of life features. Basic things like a "number to buy/sell/transfer" selector so you don't need to manually click a bunch of times, or a quick eat button so you don't need to sit through the eating animation seven times if you're eating small things that don't restore much stamina.

When your real life is out of control, Stardew is here to have your back. Well-structured farming system, mining for components and collectibles while also having a mild RPG feel while fighting off monsters in the caves. Deep character development with an overall cohesive and intriguing main story line with lots of side paths to take that divert you onto more details about Pelican Town, the Junimos and other creatures, and even the Joja Mart. Rare side events and rare obtainable items, and hard to achieve romances make the game very addicting and the stability and structure feels pleasant and calming to how I can plan out my day to either farm, fish, mine, or partake in other events. Challenging yearly events for each season also really keep you on your toes. The game is a masterpiece among farming simulators and I would also consider it much more of a farming simulator considering the romance and detailed dialogue for each towns person also makes this game a light dating sim and also very light RPG mechanics with other fun mini games like the fishing as well. The fun and amount of things to do never ends.

Listen, if you've got someone in your life telling you to get this game, but you don't think you will, trust me when I say this. I'm not a "cute-gamer", I don't enjoy farming sims, dating sims, or slice-of-life, and I've put well over 300 hours on my PS4 version of this game, and 20+ hours on this one. Just give in, I promise it will be worth it.

After playing this game for nearly 15 hours, even if I am nowhere near knowledgeable about it, I must recommend it. If, like me, you dream of having your own farm but are not sure if that dream will ever come true, and are looking for a nice, peaceful game to escape from life for a couple of hours, Stardew Valley is for you. You can do a lot in this game (no, it's not just farming), from mining to exploring to socializing to fighting slime. All of these aspects of the game have their own mechanics which you will learn over time, and your dedication to them will pay off big time in the long run. However, the heart of the game is what truly won me over, and that is how idyllic and quaint it is. A simple but fulfilling life, where you actually feel productive and where relationships truly matter. Isn't that the dream? If you want a surprising but relaxing experience, buy this game.

As someone with over 1,000 hours in this game all I can say to you is just buy the game and play it. You don't need to have a specific goal in mind. You don't even need to finish the game or get far into it. The game itself without getting into all the lore and perfection runs and all of that is just so relaxing and its really fun to play and explore the mechanics of the game. Personally I really love the fact that you are able to romance people and start a family along with being able to romance people of the same gender. As someone who identifies with the LGBTQ+ community having the ability in a game to marry and have a relationship with someone of the same gender and of your choice and then being able to have children with your spouse is really nice. Having that sort of representation in something as interactive as a video game is really amazing. For me I don't see a lot of representation, I mean obviously I know there is some, but for someone who doesn't watch a lot of shows and movies it's nice to have some representation in something I do take part in and have it as interactive as it is. This only scratches the surface on how well the characters are written and how many of the characters have relatable and representative stories. Each character has their own story to tell and each one faces issues and a lot of them are things that we don't really see much in anything. For example me personally I've never seen a character in anything with as much dialog as Linus does who is homeless. I mean that for me is one of the bigger ones that stuck out where I was like oh that's really cool actually. Along with all of the amazing writing and gameplay, I think how the game works is very well. It is pretty simple and it is really easy to learn. For some people who play more mellow games like this the fighting aspect can be very hard for them. However I really don't think that even the fighting in this game is that hard. It is pretty simple and it makes it very easy to learn. I think the hardest thing for me to learn was how to fish. For me it took a while to figure that. But in general all I can say is just play it. Even if you don't get far in the game it is still a fun time to experience the game itself.

My first gaming experience, and it is awesome! I started on the tablet (Android), which is slightly scaled down and very modified for Stardew Valley, borderline enabling (HA!).  The tablet is great for people who have limited mobility.  I just switched to the computer so I could play the full version.  

I use an XBox Gaming controller in my left hand for the joy stick.   I had to relearn combat once I switched to the computer as the tablet assists you quite a bit.  Once I figured it out, my skills began to improve.  On both the tablet and the computer version fishing is hard, no sure if it is because I use a controller and not a mouse.  I took at least 2 seasons off from farming to learn how to fish.  It was really hard on the controller!  The fish moves up and down on the bar, but the controller can only go up.  You can attach a lead tackle to keep it from bouncing so much, eat the soup Willy sells and go on a good luck day.  I have caught one legend fish on one of my 3 played games, in the sewers.  I have caught and purchased the sturgeon.  I have caught all the fish for the community center except the catfish because I've been enabled by Linus, and the Puffer Fish (sold on the traveling cart).  

I've added a few mods once I switched to the computer.  One helps by showing if the animals have been petted, it also shows who is having a birthday that day and if it will be good luck or bad. My son had to help with this, and I was impressed by his file management skills.  I'm off to find the tractor mod.  May you all have a good luck day!

This game is a masterpiece created by one single person, Eric Barone (ConcernedApe). All gameplay elements (farming, fishing, foraging, mining, and combat) are well balanced and you get to choose how you want to play the game by selecting specific buffs. It provides an open-world like experience in a limited area. You have the freedom to plan your days, choose how you interact with certain NPC's and trigger lots of events. There is much to discover in the valley! The thing that I like the most is there are very few "points of no return" in the game. Many "choices" are reversible by various interactions in the game (wedding, forgetting divorce, buff selection etc.)
I think Stardew Valley is the most wholesome game of all time. I just sit there and smile..

6 years ago, when I was a kid who really like a simulator game such as Harvest Moon, Pokémon, and I used to play Minecraft with my friends. I also remember buying this game on my pc. My computer was old and slow at the time, and I couldn't play many games because of it, but there was one game that I could enjoy without worrying about my frame rate. This game called Stardew Valley. It is a farming simulation game that can run on any pc. I have a lot of fun playing it from time to time. Harvest Moon inspired Stardew Valley, which is why several of the mechanics are similar. What’s make Stardew Valley unique is the story of this game, each of the game's Npcs has their own backstory. You can also flirt with Npcs whose names have a single next to them. In this game, you have a lot of options. There are 4 seasons on this game, each season have different seeds to plant and when the game changes the season the previous season seeds won’t be able to survive and died. So, you must manage your see growth time to not make it grow before the game changes the season. Also, you can explore the town and you can choose the way how the story goes. The Npc in this town has their own like and don’t like, it may be a food or things depends on that person. I know some of you guys might feel bored from playing alone. They updated the game that you can play with your friends now. So, you won’t feel bored playing by yourself now. This is a game that I recommend you play. I’m sure you will not be disappointed. Hope you can decide it after read my review. Thank you for reading my review.

Stardew Valley is a throw back to my teenage years of 8 bits games, but with a modern twist.  A modern-day love story to games of old, you can tell that the designer has poured themselves into the game.  I like that their are lots of things to do, and that's it is not just an endless farming game.  I've been enjoying it so far, and my favorite part is of course my farm cat, Brownie.  You'd understand if you knew... felines are my one weakness.  I'm still learning how to play, and haven't quite caught onto how to fish.  I do wish there was a bit more of a walk-through and guidance on how to play the game, but I am hoping to catch on without resorting to looking up answers online.

How I got here...
I saw Claire Siobhan play this game on her channel.  I've never really watched a gaming You Tuber before, but I enjoy her upbeat and quirky humor.  I have been going back to see some of her other games she's played through other than Sims.  She likes supporting indie designers, and this is now the second game I've bought from Steam that she played and recommended.

A game with the soul of Harvest Moon, containing the heart (and spleen) of a creator that pulls you into a world you [b]want[/b] to know more about as you play. The comfort of repetition aside, with so much to work through (with handy checklists) you never feel it's a grind. Unless you work for Joja, you filthy capitalist.

That my 336 hours of entertainment have come from a SINGLE individual (lewd) is impressive. Adding to that, the community also pitches in for quality of life tweaks via mods; many of them being incorporated by the creator in later versions (he listens! he watches!). Be careful with your modding, though, or you'll lose that kind balance between a good gaming experience and "press X to receive win scenario", which takes all the fun out of getting there.

That being said, I will 100% this game. The last achievement will be siding with Joja Corporation. On a separate save. Which will be deleted after completion. Brrr...

Stardew Valley offers a lot of diverse options for incredibly chill gameplay experiences.  From growing, harvesting, and processing your own produce to hacking-and-slashing baddies in the mines, from fishing and foraging to immersing yourself in the stories of the townsfolk and wooing some of them along the way, Stardew Valley has it all.  While this game can be played with a posture toward minimizing resources (time, money, space) and maximizing profit, I think Stardew excels in allowing users to customize their games such that players can temper that posturing to whichever degree a user prefers with diversified options and sheer aesthetics.  If you're looking for a game to distract you from the suffocating day-to-day within your life, then the Valley is calling out for you.

Stardew Valley has created some of my favorite video game memories, ever. I can't praise enough the feeling you get from playing this game with a friend or friends late at night in the summertime. Such an incredibly charming game with such a relaxing atmosphere. Far more than just a farming sim, absolutely everything in Stardew is beyond addicting: fishing, mining, decorating, gifting, exploring, cooking, it's all so calming and satisfying. The OST and visuals breathe life into every moment of gameplay, interacting with the NPCs is a delight, and pretty much every Stardew Valley devotee will admit to how much time they've spent on the wiki, desperate to research exactly what they can accomplish before the season ends. Even if you have no interest in farming games, I highly recommend trying out Stardew with a friend, it's a challenge not to get hooked.

This is a very charming game with fun farming and ranching mechanics, and a nice bit of crafting, dungeon-delving and friendship/exploration to go with it. It took me 2 tries or so to get into it, though I did have other games to distract me then, but now I'm really enjoying myself. I'm only just getting to the end of my first winter, but I can easily see sinking another couple dozen hours into this game. Plus, knowing that there's technically no end, and thus no deadline (other than getting money to get through winter and buy crops each season) makes it easy for me to do what I want and not feel pressured!

I am the type of person who likes a little bit of everything in my games. If i want to adventure, I can. If i want to start a family, I can. If i want to stay at home and farm to my hearts content, I can. The only thing i dislike about this game is that there isnt a version with better pixilation/graphics or fpv. Thats it. I know there are other games out there to scratch that itch, but this game is practically flawless. Especially with how easy it is to mod the  game to how you like it. I can make the game exactly how i want it at any given moment, or reverse it if it isnt behaving how i want it to. Thank you ConcernedApe for this blessing of a game. You are truly a pioneer for games like this.
