I have over 800 hours in this game across several platforms. ConcernedApe's open-minded stances and love for the project are so visible in everything about Stardew. It's an amazing game that pleases to most gamers with flooding amounts of charm, and always the one game me, my partner and my friends find ourselves coming back to whenever we want a stress-free quality time. Stardew Valley isn't just a timeless classic. it's also the best example of iyashikei ever made by someone who's not japanese.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Stardew Valley…, for 6 years after the game was released I finally picked this up and now it is the time for review.

First off, I am not a fan of this genre at all, all I’ve ever played was FPS, MMORPG, Tower Defense and some others but not this kind. Ever. So it came as a surprise to me ever since the game was out, is this game good? Short answer, heck yeah! I don’t know why but I’ll try my best to explain to you why you may like this game.

[h1]Story[/h1]
So, what exactly is Stardew Valley? You are recently unemployed because you disliked your company and left. You found a letter left for you by grandpa who gave his old farm to you and wants you to revive the place back. An unemployed man has no choice and guess what? He decided to go and see the farm. Ha! Simple as that! Getting down from the bus you meet a run-down farm, it is now yours to revive and start a new life in the country.

[h1]Experience[/h1]
Now.. you have a lot to do, and I mean A LOT. Clearing out your farm because it is overrun with weed, start farming and make some money, getting to know villagers because it is good to have friends. And probably along the way find yourself a pretty wife and form a little happy family, sounds great! But if you try to do all that you will get exhausted for sure. Try to take it slow, relax and immerse yourself in daily farmer life. Learn what people do each day, find out what they like, catch some fish, try digging down the mine or take a day off and just walk around in town and talk to people.

The thing is, Stardew Valley is a game about exploration. Try walking that way and look around, you already discover new things. Wait until night and you see creatures running around. Finding out these unexpected secrets is what makes the game beautiful, and each time, makes it even more addicting.

[h1]Playing & Progress[/h1]
I have played this game for ~140 hrs and now at the end of year 3, I still have events I didn’t encounter, things I want to do in the game and I’m definitely willing to continue playing it. I can see now why people pour thousands of hours into this game. All the time you will find yourself listening to soothing music as you do your daily routine. People you talk to will eventually become closer friends and by doing that you might also solve some of their problems. It makes you attached to those people and feel a connection between you and them. The game will be fun to play and will always be.

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]
Multiplayer is what I didn’t touch on the most in this game, but from what I heard, you can play with your friends with shared assets and separate houses which sounds fun. If you have people to play with, Stardew Valley is good!

[h1]Remarks[/h1]
Stardew Valley earns a special place in my heart. Its relaxing and laid back nature separates itself from other games in the market. It is a game you can always come back and enjoy anytime. Even if you are not into this genre the same as me, maybe you will find yourself mesmerized after you try.

I resisted this game for years.  Knew how I was with Harvest Moon, could absolutely lose myself in farming sims. 

Stardew is 100000x better. This game is my happy place.  If you like mods, there are hundreds; every game can be different.  You can play with friends, or solo; you can be the hero, make everyone hate you, fish, never fish, do nothing but farming or everything but farming.  I cannot simply express in words how much this game has improved my quality of life just by existing.

So thanks, ConcernedApe.  You made my life better with pixels.

I quite liked this game. I haven't finished it yet, simply because it's tedious and frankly a bit boring sometimes. It's a fun game, though, and I recommend buying it.

The music and art are gorgeous, and the NPCs, although repetitive in terms of dialogue, are nice enough and you really care about them after a few cutscenes. 

It also has some downsides, though. Most notably, as many have said, the social mechanic is crap, it's tedious and boring, and the lack of things that can go wrong is irritating. The latter is manageable for me, though, because I'm not playing it to beat it, or be a gamer, you know? I'm playing to be a farmer, raise some goats, and live my life surrounded by numerous friends!

Despite the downsides, it's a pretty good game, really relaxing. I totally think you should buy it, and if you're reading reviews instead of forking over your fourteen dollars, cut it out, buy the game, and get some goats for me.

If you're looking for a review on this game, you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe, you've come to the right place. 😏

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This is a game that I truly enjoyed. In about 3 months I acquired about 140 hours of play time. I truly loved the different farms a player could have as well as all the different buildings, animals, and plants you could have. The little chicks are so cute! 
I also loved how much you could explore around the Valley. There are a lot of challenges and a lot of quest, and for a very long time, it does not get boring. 
However once you are finished with the Community Centre and the first set of mines, it starts becoming boring as well as expensive to do a lot do the other challenges and quests. 
On top of this the years become very repetitive with barely any change. Right now I am on my fifth year and I am stuck on the island trying to find golden walnuts. 
I just finished my fourth winter which was quite boring as there are no plants to plant really, I’ve caught most of the fish, and my farm is finished. I don’t want to spend 1000 gold to go to the island or desert everyday, especially if I die in the mines I lose more gold as well as my stuff. 
The romance and friends in the game are very cute though, but once you are married and have children there isn’t much to do with the spouse or children. Life kind of becomes a standstill. 
One thing that has really bothered me is how hard it is to marry my real life partner in this game. The items I need are incredibly rare and very dangerous to get. It almost doesn’t make it worth it, nor do I understand why it is this difficult. 
I do plan on starting a new farm soon, but I am not sure I want to restart everything. I tried coming back to the game a few months of no play, but I find it kind of boring now. 
I wish there was more to do and there weren’t so many risks as well as expenses.

Stardew Valley is a fun little farm game with plenty of interesting plots woven into each of the characters. The controls are relatively easy to figure out (except for fishing. It's a game designed to play with friends, and the recent updates make it all the more enjoyable for co-op play. 9/10 game and definitely worth the money you pay for it.

Amazing game, music reminds me of Minecraft, relaxing and good pace. Love playing this after I finish studying or when I come home from the gym, or a long day at work. A gentle change of pace and keeps me engaged with it's relatively simple mechanics. Fishing is difficult at the start but they have a solution for that, the training rod, which makes fishing more enjoyable and prevents you from getting as frustrated.

Overall amazing game. Stardew Valley is on par if not better than Minecraft and Terraria for games I want to spend hours playing.

The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy

His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.

The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.

A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.

The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.

However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.

Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.

It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.

Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.

When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings.

Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building.

Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox.

If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique.

For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed.

For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa.

They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider’s landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower.

The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push.

A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distracted

A very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower.

This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower.

The Hog Rider should be placed behind the Valkyrie to give it a boost so that it stays in front of the Hog Rider, protecting it.

A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage. However, a Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower.

Fun game, very remenicent of the Harvest Moon/Story Of Seasons series but it manages to stay different enough to keep your interest.

The characters are loveable and I find myself growing attached to all of them very quickly every time I play.

The controls could be a little easier - I find how finicky it is to ensure you're looking the right direction while using a tool, or are in the exact right position for the spot you want to do something tends to be a bit annoying. 
It would also be awesome if you didn't need to install mods to simply see where your neighbours are at any given time.

Overall, I would rate Stardew Valley a 4/5. 
It's a great game and I'm happy to have bought it (I mainly play it on my Nintendo Switch).
Def not for everyone, but anyone who enjoys classic farming/life sims like Harvest Moon or enjoys classic RPG style but doesn't want to be a 'hero' in every single game should buy this - it's a good, cozy classic to have in your collection.

Stardew is the sort of game, where you start playing it at 11pm and then you first stop at 4 in the morning. It is a very calming game with quite the expansive story and many small easter-eggs. Concerned Ape (the creator) has made something amazing with his "one man crew". The mixture of a fun entertaining storyline, mindless grinding, simping for the villagers, and an amazing soundtrack combines to the game, which can be played anywhere. 
All in all a lot of fun, and you can always create a farm with a friend.

BUG. Watering can vanishing.

Did not pass out or be knocked out in mine.
Not in ANY chests. Checked ALL of them day after day. 
Let weeks pass to see if game could register watering can as missing. It doesn't.
Never shows up in Lost and Found box.
I guess it's too early to try the Adventurer's Guild, since there's no option for the item's retrieval. (Because of that possibility no way to prove or disprove if it works or not.)

So, it's just gone. Guess the game THINKS it still exists, but it doesn't.

The community was great trolling me for the spelling of one word. Added one too many o's which could happen by rushing or a simple oversight since I was stressed out. 
So, y'know. Great community. Don't try to help anyone, but comment anyway. 'Cause I want that attention.

Someone gave me a good possible idea of use "cheats" to get it back. Wish they emphasized on that because I have no idea what they meant. And trying to search and search on it left me fruitless. 
One possibility was to have a tool "item code", great, but apparently those don't exist, so I can't find them anywhere. 
You can have weeds, miscellaneous items that I don't wanna list, and weeds. Lots of different codes for weeds.

So, you can edit a save file and add a watering can? And how? Because I don't know. I know how to do money, if you want to cheat yourself rich. I don't.
I don't know how to add a watering can to my inventory, which is all I want.
I don't know if I need a non-existent item code.
It's great to search and to stress about how to fix a bug that can just happen randomly to wipe one of your tools away, with no way to be able to get a replacement tool just in case. That there's no way to fix it and no one to help. Because they may also not know what to do.

This was a bit of a rant.. sorry. But sometimes you need an outlet. Still recommended, it's a good game. But to have something like this, something completely avoidable. It's ridiculous and unnecessary and completely preventable by just being able to purchase a lost tool.
Worst thing is have two tools. And that's not bad at all.
